section_intent: This rule tells designers, operators, and regulators exactly which aeroplanes and flight situations the Subpart B performance rules are meant to cover. It assumes a turbine-powered aircraft that, after an engine fails on take-off, keeps the remaining engines at the same take-off setting—unless an approved automatic system gives a pre-defined thrust boost that meets the extra reliability and performance tests in Appendix I. It also warns that the standard rules do not automatically address specialised operations such as autoland, approaches below 200 ft decision height, or use of rough/unprepared runways; these cases need separate analysis or special conditions. By defining these boundaries, the regulation ensures that published performance data stay valid and that any extra risk created by automatic thrust-bump systems or unusual operations is properly evaluated and mitigated.
ai_notes: Real event: The 1991 Atlantic Southeast Airlines EMB-120 crash at Carrollton showed how marginal climb performance after an engine failure can be fatal, reinforcing the assumption that no extra thrust is relied upon unless thoroughly validated.

Expert note: Regional turboprops and business jets with Automatic Take-off Power Reserve (ATPR/ATTCS) must pass Appendix I reliability demonstrations to prove the thrust bump will work when needed and will not inadvertently activate.

Best practice: During Boeing 737NG and A320 autoland certifications, manufacturers created separate AFM sections and obtained special conditions because paragraph (b)(2) excludes sub-200 ft decision height operations from basic performance data.

Real event: The 1968 BOAC Boeing 707 overrun onto rough grass at Heathrow highlighted that performance calculated for paved surfaces may not hold on unprepared terrain, leading to explicit exclusion of such operations in paragraph (b)(3).
Expert note: Flight-test teams routinely lock thrust levers after V1 during engine-out take-off tests to verify compliance with Subpart B assumptions that no power increase is available.

Best practice: Operators train crews that, unless ATTCS has armed and activated, they must not advance remaining engines after an engine failure—mirroring the certification basis and preventing over-boost or asymmetric handling surprises.

section_intent: CS 25.21 obliges an applicant to PROVE—by rigorous flight tests or equally reliable calculations—that the aircraft will remain controllable, stable, and stall-resistant throughout its entire approved weight, centre-of-gravity, altitude, wind, and icing envelope, including when automated or power-operated systems are relied upon. Tests must be performed under tightly controlled conditions and use standardised wind-measurement and icing assumptions so that the results are reproducible and conservative. In short, the rule’s purpose is to eliminate unknowns: before passengers ever board, the manufacturer must demonstrate with hard data that no matter how the aeroplane is legally loaded or what atmospheric icing it encounters, pilots will retain adequate control and performance margins.
ai_notes: ATR-72 Flight 4184 (Roselawn, 1994): loss of control due to unexpected ice accretion drove the emphasis on showing full flight-characteristics compliance in Appendix C/O icing envelopes.
Fokker 100 PH-KXL certification tests (1980s): early stick-pusher mis-trips at forward CG highlighted why every weight/CG combination must be systematically investigated, not just median points.
Boeing 737 MAX accidents (2018–19): MCAS malfunction illustrated the need for paragraph (e)—automatic stability systems must be shown compliant with CS 25.671/672 during all manoeuvres.
Expert note: Flight-test engineers build a ‘load-matrix’ covering corner cases (max weight/aft CG, min weight/forward CG, etc.) to ensure no gap in the demonstrated envelope.
Expert note: Using a calibrated 10 m wind sensor at the runway stops manufacturers from claiming performance based on unrepresentatively low surface winds.
Saab 340A icing incidents (1993, USA): tailplane stalls in ice led to stricter proof of longitudinal stability and stall behaviour with defined ice shapes.
Air Midwest 5481 (2003 Beech 1900D): overweight and aft CG take-off stall reinforced industry training that operational loading must stay inside the envelope validated under CS 25.21.

section_intent: CS 25.23 aims to ensure that, for every permissible aircraft weight, there is a clearly-defined range of centre-of-gravity (CG) positions and detailed load-distribution patterns that keep the aeroplane both controllable in flight and structurally sound. In plain terms, the rule forces applicants to determine and publish the CG envelope and any spanwise or longitudinal loading restrictions so that crews, load planners and ground handlers cannot inadvertently load the aircraft in a way that would overload a wing, tail, or landing gear, or place the CG so far forward or aft that control surfaces cannot trim the aircraft. It also caps those limits at what has actually been demonstrated—through analysis, ground tests and flight tests—to meet all structural and flight-handling requirements, thereby preventing paper expansion of the envelope beyond proven capability.
ai_notes: National Airlines B747-400F Flight 102 (Bagram, 2013): cargo pallets broke loose on take-off, shifting CG far aft and causing immediate stall; illustrates why CG and restraint limits tied to load distribution must be explicit and conservative.
Fine Air DC-8-61 Flight 101 (Miami, 1997): improper pallet positioning placed CG beyond aft limit; aircraft pitched up and crashed—showing the hazard of exceeding approved load sheet envelopes.
Expert note: Wing fuel-balancing procedures stem from spanwise load limits established under CS 25.23; uneven outboard tank use can raise bending moments beyond proven structural margins.
Air Midwest Beech 1900D Flight 5481 (Charlotte, 2003): baggage mis-loading and inaccurate weight assumptions pushed CG aft; accident drove industry focus on validated weight & balance data.
Expert note: Loadmasters use trim sheets that graph weight vs. CG against the certified envelope derived from CS 25.23 analyses, a frontline compliance practice to prevent dispatch outside limits.

Expert note: During certification, manufacturers run ‘worst-case’ seat-occupied/empty, cargo-bay full/empty, and fuel-burn-off sequences to verify that the CG never exits the proven envelope throughout the flight.

Expert note: Many operators fit bulk-cargo bays with clearly marked zoning lines that match the certified spanwise load limits, providing a visual barrier against over-concentration of weight in a single bay.

section_intent: CS-25.25 makes the manufacturer define clear upper and lower weight limits for every phase of flight. Those limits may not exceed what has been proven safe for structure, performance, controllability, centre-of-gravity position, and (for maximum weights) noise compliance. By tying the published Ramp, Taxi, Take-off, En-route, Landing and Zero-Fuel weights to demonstrated tests and analyses, the rule prevents operators from loading an aeroplane in a way that could overstress the airframe, degrade take-off or climb performance, increase stall speeds, or create unstable handling at very light weights. In short, it ensures the aircraft is only dispatched within the envelope that has been objectively shown to be safe under expected temperatures, altitudes, and loading distributions.
ai_notes: Air Midwest Flight 5481 (2003): Incorrect passenger-weight assumptions put the Beech 1900D above its certified take-off weight and aft of CG limits; the aircraft stalled and crashed seconds after liftoff, underscoring why strict weight/CG limits are mandated.

Fine Air Flight 101 (1997): DC-8 freighter loaded beyond aft CG and weight limits rotated prematurely, stalled and crashed, illustrating the rule’s focus on validated weight and distribution envelopes.

National Airlines Flight 102 (2013): Shift of heavy armoured vehicles moved the 747-400F CG aft and exceeded structural tolerances, leading to in-flight breakup; shows importance of structural loading substantiation demanded by CS-25.25.
Expert note: The Maximum Zero Fuel Weight protects wing-root bending moments when tanks are empty; CS-25.25 obliges applicants to establish this limit during structural analysis.

Expert note: Certification flight tests at minimum and maximum weights verify stall speed, climb gradient, controllability, and flutter margins—data that directly define the placarded limits required by this rule.

Expert note: When Airbus or Boeing offer higher-weight "weight‐variant" models, they must re-demonstrate structural strength, performance, and noise compliance to satisfy CS-25.25 before the new weights can be certified.

Expert note: Airlines train dispatchers to use electronic load-sheet systems that automatically reject loads exceeding certified Ramp, Taxi, Take-off, En-route or Landing weights, a best practice derived from the constraints set by CS-25.25.

section_intent: Ensure every transport airplane operates only within centre-of-gravity (CG) positions that keep the aircraft controllable, structurally sound, and compliant with all flight-handling requirements. Applicants must define the most forward and aft CG for each distinct loading or operating condition, but those limits cannot exceed where: (a) the applicant intentionally chooses to operate, (b) the structure has been proven to carry the loads generated, and (c) flight testing or analysis has shown the aircraft remains stable, manoeuvrable, and meets certification performance and stall margins. In plain terms, the rule prevents take-offs, flights, and landings with a CG so far forward or aft that the airplane could stall unexpectedly, become uncontrollable in pitch, or suffer structural overloads.
ai_notes: Air Midwest 5481 (Beech 1900D, 2003): Overloaded baggage and incorrect weight data placed the CG aft of limits; elevator authority was insufficient to recover from a high-angle climb, leading to a fatal stall—demonstrating why aft CG boundaries are critical.

National Airlines 102 (B747-400BCF, 2013): Cargo shift on take-off moved CG rapidly aft, eliminating longitudinal stability and causing a stall; highlights need to validate CG limits for every loading configuration and secure cargo within the proven envelope.

Expert note: Forward-CG flight tests routinely reveal higher stick forces, increased stall speed, and longer take-off distances; certification sets the forward limit where elevator up-trim remains adequate for rotation and flare.

Expert note: Aft-CG static structural tests use ballast bags to match worst-case tail-down moments; structural substantiation defines a hard boundary beyond which fuselage frames or tailplane attachment could be overstressed during manoeuvres.

Industry practice: Aircraft Weight & Balance manuals divide missions into separate conditions (taxi, take-off, en-route, landing) and require dispatchers to check CG stays within the published envelope for each—directly reflecting CS 25.27’s phrase 'each practicably separable operating condition.'

Best practice: Type-rating simulators include scenarios with near-limit CGs so pilots experience reduced pitch stability or control margin, reinforcing adherence to the certified CG envelope in everyday operations.

section_intent: Regulators want every large aeroplane to start its life with a rock-solid, repeatable reference for weight and balance. By requiring manufacturers to weigh the aircraft in a clearly defined "empty" condition—including all fixed ballast, unusable fuel, and full operating fluids—the rule ensures that designers can accurately calculate performance, structural loads, stability and control margins, and that operators can later build reliable loading charts. In plain English: know exactly how heavy the plane is and where that weight sits, so every subsequent fuel, cargo, or passenger calculation is founded on truth, not guesswork.
ai_notes: Air Midwest 5481 (2003): Incorrect basic empty weight and unverified CG data meant the Beech 1900D left maintenance heavier and more aft-loaded than paperwork showed, leading to a stall on take-off; underscored need for certified, repeatable weighing conditions.

Expert note: Early jetliners sometimes omitted trapped hydraulic and unusable fuel during factory weigh-ins, producing optimistic performance data; rule now mandates inclusion of all operating fluids to close that loophole.

National Airlines Flight 102 (Bagram, 2013): Cargo shift drove CG far aft; investigation highlighted how every downstream loading calculation relies on a trustworthy empty-weight baseline established at certification.

Common failure mode: Maintenance removes fixed ballast or adds equipment but forgets to update the Weight & Balance Report; rule’s emphasis on a “well-defined, repeatable condition” drives strict configuration-control procedures.

Best practice: OEMs weigh each production aircraft on calibrated platform scales with fuel tanks drained to unusable level and hydraulic systems serviced, then issue an official Weight & Balance Handbook that operators must reference for every load sheet.

section_intent: The rule simply states that temporary (removable) weights such as water barrels, sandbags or lead blocks may be carried during certification flight-tests so the aeroplane can be loaded to the most-forward, most-aft or maximum-weight conditions required by the other CS-25 flight rules.  Its objective is to let manufacturers prove the aircraft meets all performance, stability and control requirements without needing permanent structural changes or unrealistic passenger/cargo loads, while still ensuring that any ballast used is treated as part of the aeroplane’s weight-and-balance calculation and properly secured for safety.
ai_notes: Expert note: Certification flight-test aircraft are typically fitted with a water-ballast system consisting of dozens of linked barrels; engineers pump water fore or aft in flight to shift the centre of gravity and quickly explore the full CG envelope demanded by CS-25—practice enabled by CS 25.31.

National Air Cargo Flight 102 (B747-400, Bagram 2013): the fatal load-shift accident underscored industry emphasis on rigidly securing any removable mass; flight-test ballast is now clamped or netted to cargo rails in accordance with approved ballast-installation drawings.

Expert note: During stall-recovery and longitudinal stability tests required by CS 25.201-203, crews deliberately ballast the aircraft to the aft-limit CG so the tests reflect the least-stable configuration; CS 25.31 authorises this temporary setup.

Expert note: Best practice is to tag every ballast bag with weight, moment arm and unique ID, and to record its position on a dedicated ballast chart so the on-board engineer can update the weight-and-balance sheet before each sortie.

Expert note: After completing maximum-gross-weight climb tests, flight-test teams off-load the ballast pallets to perform low-weight manoeuvre testing the same day—flexibility that keeps programmes on schedule and is explicitly permitted by CS 25.31.

section_intent: The rule makes sure the propeller can never spin faster or sit at a blade angle that would jeopardise the engine, the propeller itself, or the aircraft’s required performance.  It demands (a) that normal and emergency rpm limits protect structural integrity and still let the aircraft meet its take-off, climb and landing figures; (b) a governor that physically stops the propeller from exceeding the certified maximum revolutions per minute (rpm); and (c) a mechanical low-pitch stop set so that even if the governor fails on the ground, full take-off power cannot drive the engine past 103 % of its approved rpm (or 99 % of any higher transient limit).  In plain English: keep the propeller and engine within safe speed ranges at all times, by both automatic and fail-safe mechanical means.
ai_notes: Horizon Air Q400 Yakima incident (2011): A propeller governor failure let the left propeller surge past limits; the crew contained the event, illustrating why an independent rpm-limiting device is required by 25.33(b).

Lockheed L-188 Electra flight-test overspeeds (1958): Early turboprop trials produced uncontrolled rpm spikes that shook the wing, prompting regulators to codify hard mechanical pitch and speed stops.

Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 2311 (EMB-120, 1991): A faulty propeller control unit let one prop go out of its commanded range, leading to loss of control and highlighting the catastrophic consequences when pitch-limit devices fail.

Expert note: Mis-rigged low-pitch stops during maintenance are a frequent cause of ground run overspeeds; para (c) requires a certification test that proves even with the governor off-line, 103 % rpm cannot be breached.
Expert note: Applicants run an "inoperative-governor" ground test at maximum take-off torque in ISA conditions to verify compliance with 25.33(c) before first flight.
Industry practice: Operators perform a propeller overspeed governor functional check every time a propeller or engine control linkage is disturbed, directly supporting 25.33(b).
Expert note: Flight data monitoring programs flag any exceedance of 100 % NP so engineers can correct trends long before fatigue accumulates, aligning day-to-day operations with the intent of 25.33.

section_intent: CS 25.101 sets the ground rules for how an applicant must calculate and demonstrate the performance of a large airplane. It obliges manufacturers to use realistic ambient conditions (temperature, altitude, humidity), the actual installed thrust available after losses and accessory loads, and aircraft configurations that crews will really use. Take-off, climb, approach, balked-landing and landing data must be built on procedures that average pilots can carry out, with allowances for normal reaction delays and with brakes already at their maximum wear limit. By standardising these assumptions, the rule prevents overly optimistic performance figures and ensures that the distances and climb margins published in the Aircraft Flight Manual can be safely achieved in day-to-day airline service.
ai_notes: American Airlines Flight 1420 (1999) overran the runway because actual brake performance on a wet surface with worn components was worse than expected; CS 25.101(i) forces manufacturers to calculate landing distance with brakes at their wear limit, preventing optimistic figures.

Expert note: During certification, thrust measured on a test stand is higher than what the aircraft sees once the nacelle, bleed extractions and accessory drives are attached; paragraph (c) compels applicants to subtract these installation losses so published performance reflects real, installed thrust.

DC-10 early certification work showed that high humidity reduces jet engine thrust at low temperatures; sub-paragraph (b) fixes humidity assumptions (80 % cold, 34 % hot) so every manufacturer uses the same conservative baseline.

Expert note: Early jetliners sometimes relied on aggressive pilot techniques to meet accelerate-stop requirements; paragraph (h) mandates procedures that crews of average skill can repeat safely, ending reliance on special tricks.

Lufthansa A320 at Hamburg (2008) bounced and began a late go-around; CS 25.101(g) requires predefined, achievable balked-landing and missed-approach procedures for precisely such high-workload situations.

Expert note: Modern take-off charts offer multiple flap and thrust-derate settings; paragraphs (d)–(e) allow several certified configurations only if each matches normal operating procedures written in the AFM.

Air India Express Flight 812 (2010) showed how a few-second delay in deploying brakes and reversers can be critical; paragraph (h)(3) obliges applicants to include realistic crew reaction times when calculating stopping and landing distances.

Expert note: Hot-and-high airports such as Bogotá expose the effect of temperature and altitude on thrust and climb; paragraph (a) ensures all subsequent CS-25 performance rules are demonstrated for the actual ambient conditions, not optimistic ISA sea-level values.

section_intent: CS-25.103 establishes a conservative, repeatable way to define the reference stall speed (VSR) for transport aeroplanes. It requires the speed to be at least the true 1-g stall, measured in the configuration that gives the highest stall speed, with minimal thrust influence and a slow, steady deceleration. By tying VSR to worst-case weight, centre-of-gravity, flap, gear and ice conditions, and by forcing it to sit above stick-pusher activation, the rule ensures that all subsequent performance margins (take-off, landing, manoeuvre and stall-protection logic) are based on a solid, safety-critical benchmark that protects crews and passengers from inadvertent stalls in service.
ai_notes: BAC One-Eleven G-ASHG deep-stall crash during 1963 certification tests revealed that under-estimated stall speeds and lack of automatic nose-down devices can be fatal; it drove requirements for stick-pushers and for VSR to exceed pusher activation speed.

Colgan Air Flight 3407 (2009) highlighted how crews depend on published reference speeds in icing and high-weight scenarios; inadequate stall margin understanding contributed to loss of control, underscoring why VSR tests must include icing and worst-case CG.
Expert note: Idle thrust on some jets provides enough lift to cut stall speed, so CS-25.103 forces the test to be repeated with "not more than zero thrust" if idle masks the worst case.
Expert note: Limiting deceleration to 1 kt /s avoids transient lift and gives a true steady-state 1-g stall value, preventing optimistic data from fast-pull manoeuvres.
Post-1970 tri-jet deep-stall research showed aft CG raises stall speed; the rule therefore demands testing at the CG that produces the highest VSR to protect all loading conditions.

Industry practice: Take-off safety speed V2 and landing reference speed VREF are set as multiples of VSR (e.g., 1.23 VSR); a conservative VSR cascades into robust margins throughout the flight envelope.
Expert note: The 2 kt or 2 % buffer above stick-pusher actuation compensates for sensor tolerances and wear, guaranteeing the pusher fires before the actual stall.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that all published take-off performance—speeds, distances, and climb capability—truly reflects how the aeroplane will behave in day-to-day service. Manufacturers must test and calculate data for the full range of approved weights, altitudes, temperatures, runway surfaces, slopes and wind conditions, plus the worst credible ice accretions that can exist during take-off. The figures must be conservative (e.g. limited credit for headwind, extra penalty for tailwind) and achievable without requiring superhero-level piloting. By doing this, crews can plan take-offs that will clear obstacles, stop safely if the take-off is rejected, and maintain adequate climb even when the wings or engines are slightly degraded by ice or operating on wet, less-friction runways.
ai_notes: USAir Flight 405, LaGuardia 1992: ice-contaminated wings caused stall immediately after lift-off, underscoring the need for separate, more conservative performance data in icing conditions.

Emirates Flight 407, Melbourne 2009: incorrect weight entry led to a take-off that used almost the entire runway; the accident review highlighted why the certified data must be achievable without extraordinary pilot inputs or last-second luck.
Expert note: The 50 % headwind / 150 % tailwind rule builds margin for sudden gust changes that have caused numerous overrun and obstacle-clearance incidents during take-off rolls.

Expert note: Requiring data for both smooth and grooved wet runways addresses past overruns where operators assumed dry-runway figures on rain-soaked surfaces with reduced braking and acceleration capability.

Expert note: Flight-test teams must demonstrate climb gradients with defined "Take-off Ice" shapes; this stems from icing accidents where stall speed rose by only a few knots yet climb performance collapsed, showing why both VS and gradient must be checked.

section_intent: CS 25.107 sets minimum definitions and relationships for all critical take-off speeds (V1, VR, V2, VMU, VLOF, etc.).  Its aim is to guarantee that, even if the most-critical engine fails at the worst possible moment, the crew can either stop safely on the runway or continue the take-off, remain controllable, avoid stall or tail-strike, and achieve the climb gradients needed to clear obstacles.  The rule binds these speeds together with explicit margins above stall, minimum control speeds, and pilot reaction time so that performance data published in the AFM are repeatable, conservative, and tolerant of normal pilot or aircraft variability.  In short, it protects crews and passengers during the high-risk transition from ground roll to initial climb, when aerodynamic margins are slim and time to react is minimal.
ai_notes: Pan Am 845 (B-747, SFO 1971): Runway change left the crew using VR below the geometry-limited VMU; the aircraft struck approach lights and had a tail-strike.  Accident led regulators to tighten the VR ≥ 1.10/1.05 VMU requirement now embedded in CS 25.107(e)(1)(iv).

Emirates 407 (B-777-300ER, Melbourne 2009): Incorrect weight in the FMS produced V1/VR about 10 kt too low; aircraft over-ran the runway end lights and narrowly missed terrain, illustrating why single validated V speeds and the −5 kt VR check of CS 25.107(e)(3) are required.

Expert note: Certification accelerate-stop tests showed pilots need roughly 1 s to identify an engine failure and 1 s to react; CS 25.107(a) therefore mandates V1 ≥ VEF plus the speed gained during this recognition/reaction interval so that stopping distance remains adequate in service.

American Airlines 191 (DC-10, ORD 1979): After engine separation at liftoff the aircraft initially climbed because V2 was above both stall and VMCA, demonstrating the life-saving margin provided by the 1.10 VMCA and ≥1.13 VsR floors of CS 25.107(b).

Expert note: Flight-test data show that line pilots can unintentionally over-rotate or be slightly out-of-trim; paragraph (e)(4) requires take-off performance and handling to stay safe under such "reasonably expected variations," driving tail-clearance and pitch-control design features.

Expert note: Operators train crews to call "V1, rotate, V2" precisely because CS 25.107 demands a single set of validated speeds for both normal and one-engine-inoperative cases, ensuring consistent reaction and performance across the fleet.

section_intent: Ensure that, even in the worst-credible case of an engine failure right at the take-off decision speed, the aeroplane can be safely stopped on the available runway (or stopway) under both dry and wet conditions. The rule builds in realistic margins by modelling pilot reaction time (2 s), requiring full use of wheel brakes with worn brake pads, accounting for reduced friction on wet or grooved surfaces, and forbidding reliance on reverse thrust on dry runways. It establishes consistent, conservative data so operators can determine whether a runway is long enough for a safe rejected take-off, protecting occupants, people on the ground, and the aircraft itself.
ai_notes: Case: MK Airlines B747-200F Halifax 2004 – Crew rejected take-off above V1 and overran into woods, killing 7. The accident highlighted the catastrophic consequences of misjudging accelerate-stop distance and cemented the need for conservative V1/stop data.

Case: Gulfstream G650 RTO test Roswell 2011 – During the mandatory maximum-energy stop with worn brakes, wheel-well fire and wing drop occurred, fatally injuring four. The certification mishap reinforced the requirement in CS 25.109(i) to demonstrate the calculation with minimal brake lining and validated the energy assumptions.

Expert note: Numerous 1960-70s DC-8 and B707 wet-runway overruns showed that locked wheels hydroplaned and lengthened stopping distances. CS 25.109’s anti-skid efficiency factors explicitly limit the braking force used in wet-runway calculations to prevent such under-estimation.

Case: British Airtours B737-236 Manchester 1985 – Engine failure at 136 kt led to an immediate stop within the runway; the 2-second reaction margin proved realistic, but the post-stop fire killed 55, underlining why rapid but achievable crew action is assumed in the rule.

Expert note: Reverse thrust is excluded for dry-runway calculations because reversers can fail (e.g., Lauda Air 004, 1991) or deploy late; operators must be able to stop even if reversers are unusable.
Expert note: Keeping the landing gear extended in the model avoids credit for aerodynamic drag from retraction and guarantees wheel brakes are available throughout the manoeuvre.

Industry practice: Flight-test campaigns perform multiple RTOs at incrementally higher energies to validate brake temperatures and stopping distances, ensuring production aircraft match CS-25 data before certification is granted.
Industry practice: Crew training emphasises the "Go/Stop" call at V1 and standardised call-outs (e.g., "100 kts… V1") so pilot reaction times align with the 2-second assumption embedded in CS 25.109.
Expert note: Operators compute take-off performance using the greater of dry or wet accelerate-stop distances, mirroring CS 25.109(b), to assure safety when a runway’s damp condition is uncertain.

section_intent: CS 25.111 ensures that, even if the most critical engine fails at the worst moment (V_EF) during take-off, the aeroplane can still accelerate, lift off, clear close-in obstacles and climb safely to at least 1 500 ft above the runway while staying within a predictable flight path. It sets minimum climb gradients, speed targets (V_R, V2, V_FTO), and prohibits configuration or thrust changes until 400 ft to prevent performance shortfalls just after lift-off. The rule also forces manufacturers to account for drag from ice accretion, to demonstrate or conservatively model the whole path, and to use data without ground-effect benefit, so operators can calculate runway lengths and obstacle-clearance with assured margins. In plain words: after an engine failure, the aircraft must still be able to keep climbing steadily, avoid obstacles and transition safely to en-route flight, under the worst realistic conditions.
ai_notes: Pan Am Flight 526A (1952): A Constellation lost an engine shortly after take-off and ditched due to inadequate one-engine-inoperative climb, prompting tighter OEI performance standards later captured in CS 25.111.

Lufthansa Flight 540 (B747-100, Nairobi 1974): Slats retracted on take-off, climb performance collapsed and the aircraft crashed; illustrates why CS 25.111 locks configuration changes until 400 ft to avoid inadvertent drag or lift loss at low altitude.

Air Ontario Flight 1363 (F28, Dryden 1989): Take-off with ice-contaminated wings led to stall at 35 ft; this reinforced the requirement to include 'Take-off Ice' and 'Final Take-off Ice' drag penalties in 25.111(c)(5).

Expert note: Balanced-field length calculations used by performance engineers derive directly from the CS 25.111 take-off path definition—meeting the rule ensures that, if an engine fails, the aircraft can either stop on the runway or continue the climb safely.
Expert note: Flight-test teams fly multiple continuous OEI take-offs to validate that segment-based performance data remain conservative, exactly as required by 25.111(d)(4).

Expert note: Airline SOPs train crews to rotate at V_R, pitch to maintain V2+10 kt and delay flap retraction until 400 ft—these procedures mirror 25.111(b)–(c) so operational practice aligns with certified performance.

USAir Flight 405 (B737, LaGuardia 1992): Wing ice prevented the aircraft from reaching the required positive climb slope, underscoring the rule’s insistence on a positive gradient at every point of the OEI take-off path.

section_intent: CS 25.113 defines how long a runway must be for a transport aeroplane to reach a safe height after lift-off, both with all engines working and after an engine failure, on dry and wet surfaces. It requires the use of the longer of two calculated paths and adds a 15 % margin when using the easier “all-engines” data. By standardising the reference points (lift-off, 35 ft / 15 ft screen heights, and clearway allowances) the rule ensures that performance charts used by airlines give crews a proven safety buffer against real-world variables such as pilot technique, wind shifts, surface contamination, and engine anomalies. In short, it guarantees that an aircraft dispatched within its certified weight can leave the ground and clear obstacles without overrunning the runway, even on a wet day or with one engine inoperative.
ai_notes: Miami Air Florida Flight 90 (1982): aircraft failed to accelerate on a slushy runway and lifted off late, striking a bridge; highlighted the need for specific wet/contaminated-runway take-off distances rather than relying on dry data.

Expert note: Early jet transports used pure ‘all-engine’ measurements; certification reviews in the 1960s showed operators were routinely applying inadequate margins, prompting the 115 % factor now embedded in CS 25.113.

Expert note: The rule forces take-off charts to reach V2 before 35 ft, preventing crews from trading climb speed for shorter ground roll, a technique that had led to near-stall events in flight-test history.

MD-83 Spanair JK5022 (Madrid, 2008): improper configuration led to late rotation and runway-end excursion; reinforced industry training to respect performance-based rotation points defined under CS 25.113.

Expert note: Clearway limitations (mid-point reference) stop operators from ‘borrowing’ too much clear airspace beyond the paved surface, a practice once used to justify marginal operations at short island runways.
Best practice: Airline dispatch systems flag any wet-runway take-off where the computed TODR exceeds 85 % of available length, adding an operational buffer on top of CS 25.113 requirements.

Best practice: Simulator recurrent training requires crews to complete one-engine-inoperative take-offs on wet runways at maximum weight, demonstrating the margins that CS 25.113 is designed to secure.

section_intent: This rule establishes a conservative, legally-defined take-off flight path that guarantees an aircraft can safely clear obstacles even if one engine fails at the worst moment. The path starts 11 m (35 ft) above the runway and is adjusted (“net” flight path) by subtracting a fixed climb-gradient margin (0.8 %–1 %) to cover real-world variables such as pilot technique, engine ageing, atmospheric variations and minor performance shortfalls. By forcing designers to show compliance with this reduced (net) gradient or an equivalent loss of acceleration, CS 25.115 ensures that every certified transport aeroplane maintains a robust buffer between its demonstrated capability and the minimum performance promised to operators, protecting passengers, crew, and people on the ground during the most critical phase of flight.
ai_notes: Mount Kilimanjaro/Nairobi B-747 (Air France 1974): Aircraft failed to out-climb terrain after take-off; highlighted the need for codified margins between demonstrated and publishable climb performance.

Spanair MD-82 Flight 5022 (Madrid 2008): Incorrect take-off configuration reduced climb rate; the net-gradient concept anticipates such shortfalls and prevents obstacle collisions when a single failure occurs.
Expert note: Engine-out climb charts used by dispatchers already include the CS 25.115 deductions, ensuring a flight plan never relies on razor-thin ‘gross’ performance.

Expert note: Certification flight-test teams must show the aeroplane can meet the net path with an engine failed at VEF, packs on, speed schedule per CS 25.111—guarding against optimistic test techniques.
Best practice: Airline OEI procedure training emphasises sticking to the mandated speed/attitude schedule; deviating erodes the small regulatory margin CS 25.115 provides.

section_intent: The rule forces the manufacturer to prove that the aircraft can still meet all required climb-performance targets after take-off and during a go-around at every weight, airport elevation, temperature and centre-of-gravity position that will appear in the Aircraft Flight Manual. By testing the "worst legal case"—maximum weight, hot-and-high airfields, and the most adverse CG—it guarantees that pilots always have the climb gradient needed to clear obstacles and maintain controllability even if an engine fails. This keeps crews from relying on unverified performance data and prevents accidents caused by inadequate climb capability under real-world operating extremes.
ai_notes: Spanair Flight 5022 (Madrid, 2008): Take-off with improper flap/slat setting led to an immediate inability to climb, underscoring why every configuration must be performance-tested and documented.

Air Florida Flight 90 (Washington, 1982): Ice-contaminated wings and near-MTOW reduced climb thrust and lift; the crash illustrated the fatal consequences when actual performance falls short of the certified envelope.

Expert note: Certification flight-test teams routinely conduct hot-and-high take-off and go-around trials at La Paz and other high-density-altitude airports to prove the aircraft still meets CS 25.119/121 margins.
Expert note: Weight-and-balance software used by airlines flags loads that would push CG to the tested limit; this ensures crews never dispatch into un-verified CG positions.

Expert note: Pilot training stresses consulting AFM performance tables for ‘worst of the day’ conditions (max TOW, ISA + 40 °C, field elevation) derived from the compliance tests mandated by CS 25.117.

section_intent: The rule guarantees that, after a pilot initiates a go-around from short final or after touchdown, the aeroplane—still in full landing configuration and with all engines running—can achieve at least a 3.2 % climb gradient once the engines have had 8 s to spool up from idle to go-around thrust. This assures obstacle clearance on the missed-approach path in both normal and icing conditions, recognising the slower thrust response of engines at idle and the performance penalties caused by landing flap, gear and ice accretion.
ai_notes: Real event: Eastern Air Lines L-1011 Flight 401 (1972) began a go-around from low altitude but failed to climb fast enough, striking the Everglades; investigators cited inadequate climb capability and low thrust spool-up, prompting tighter missed-approach performance criteria.

Expert note: Jet engines at flight-idle can need 6-9 s to reach rated thrust; specifying performance after 8 s prevents manufacturers from counting thrust that is not yet reliably available to pilots in an urgent go-around.

Expert note: The 3.2 % gradient mirrors the 3 ° approach path plus obstacle clearance buffers, so the aircraft can safely out-climb the same slope it was descending on, even with flaps landing and gear down.

Real event: A320 F-HWKK certification trials (1987) showed iced wing shapes cut go-around climb by >15 %; this drove the explicit requirement to demonstrate the same gradient with "Landing Ice" accretions.

Best practice: Manufacturers flight-test go-around climbs at VREF with maximum landing flap, gear extended, and artificial ice shapes installed, then provide pilots with procedures (e.g., ‘TOGA, maintain VREF until positive climb’) derived from those demonstrations.

section_intent: If one engine quits at the worst possible moment—from lift-off through a missed approach—the aeroplane must still be able to climb away without hitting anything. CS 25.121 sets minimum engine-out climb gradients for each critical segment: gear-down lift-off, gear-up initial climb, final take-off, and go-around. The numbers are high enough to clear obstacles, yet realistic because they use certified power settings, weights, speeds (VLOF, V2, VFTO) and account for icing penalties. By proving these margins in certification, manufacturers can publish performance charts that operators use to calculate runway length, balanced-field V1, obstacle-clearance procedures and missed-approach paths. The rule therefore protects passengers, crew and people on the ground when the aircraft is most vulnerable—low, slow and asymmetric—while ensuring the data pilots rely on is conservative, repeatable and valid in both clean and iced configurations.
ai_notes: Munich Convair CV-340 (1958): Failed to climb after an engine fire on take-off and struck houses; accident highlighted need for guaranteed OEI climb margins over obstacles.
Pan Am Flight 843 B707 (1965): Number-4 engine separated at SF-O; aircraft still achieved required gradients, demonstrating why the rule’s conservative margins are life-saving.
Expert note: Balanced-field take-off calculations used by dispatchers trace directly to the CS 25.121 gradients; if the computed net path is negative, a take-off is legally disallowed.
Air Florida Flight 90 B737 (1982): Severe ice reduced thrust and climb, showing why CS 25.121 now requires demonstrating OEI gradients with defined ice accretions.
BEA Vanguard G-AOVH (Heathrow 1964): Improper propeller setting after engine failure caused inadequate climb; spurred emphasis on using certified configuration and power settings in testing.
Expert note: Training syllabi make pilots memorize ‘V2 or better until 400 ft AGL’—this practice stems from the CS 25.121(b) segment that assumes gear up, engine out, at V2.
United 232 DC-10 (1989): Although it lost all hydraulics, the investigation reaffirmed that tri-jets must meet the slightly higher 0.3 %/2.7 %/1.5 % gradients to tolerate one-engine loss.

Expert note: Flight-test teams verify these gradients by flying steady-state climbs with critical engine shut down and data-reduced to zero-wind, out-of-ground-effect conditions exactly as the rule prescribes.

section_intent: This rule makes sure a transport-category aeroplane can still clear terrain and obstacles if one engine (or, on three- and four-engine jets, two engines) fails at any point during cruise or climb after take-off. Manufacturers must prove, for every weight, altitude, temperature and centre-of-gravity the aircraft is allowed to use, that the remaining engines at maximum-continuous thrust provide a "net" climb path that exceeds the real climb capability by conservative margins (1.1–1.6 % or 0.3–0.5 %). Extra penalties are added for icing to reflect degraded lift and higher stall speeds. By requiring these verified performance charts, the rule protects against controlled-flight-into-terrain after an engine failure, supplies pilots with reliable drift-down data, and gives dispatchers confidence that any cleared route can be flown safely on reduced power.
ai_notes: BOAC Argonaut G-ALHE (Kuwait, 1950): OEI climb was insufficient over desert terrain; crash highlighted the need for mandatory net–climb margins now embedded in CS-25.123.
Expert note: The 1.1–1.6 % deduction covers pilot reaction time, engine wear, and atmospheric variability so line pilots always have a performance safety buffer beyond test-day results.

Eastern Air Lines Flight 855 (L-1011, 1983): After triple flame-out, one engine was restarted; certified OEI drift-down data let the crew maintain safe altitude and return to Miami, validating the rule’s practical value.

Expert note: Airlines use CS-25.123-derived "driftdown" charts when planning routes over the Andes or Himalayas; dispatch must show the aircraft can clear the highest terrain with one engine out at any point.

Qantas A380 Flight QF32 (2010): Massive engine failure left the aircraft on three engines; compliance with net-flight-path requirements meant the jet could level off, dump fuel and land without terrain conflict.
Expert note: The icing check (1.18 VSR trigger) prevents optimistic climb figures; crews are trained to fly higher OEI speeds in ice, reflecting data produced under 25.123(b)(2).

Expert note: During certification, manufacturers demonstrate hot-day OEI climbs with cooling-air controls fixed as required by 25.123(a)(4) to avoid engine overheat derates that plagued early piston transports.

section_intent: CS 25.125 makes manufacturers prove that, starting from 50 ft over the runway, the aeroplane can touch down under control and stop within the published landing distance on a dry, level, hard surface when flown by an average-skill crew, in both clean and ice-contaminated conditions. It fixes minimum approach speeds (≥1.23 × stall, ≥VMCL, etc.), requires a stabilised approach, realistic configuration and braking, limits pilot techniques to normal service procedures, and includes wind and engine-out credits so that operators can add predictable margins for everyday use. The core goal is to guarantee that performance data in the AFM is conservative and repeatable, preventing runway overruns, loss of control, or structural damage during landing.
ai_notes: Southwest 1248 (B737-700, Chicago Midway 2005): overrun after landing long with 8 kt tailwind highlighted why CS-25 insists on using only 50 % of headwind and 150 % of tailwind components when publishing landing distance.

Expert note: The 1.23 VS0 requirement came from early swept-wing jet testing where small speed deviations caused sudden sink-rates; the margin prevents approach-to-stall and allows flare even with gusts or ice.

Air France 358 (A340-300, Toronto 2005): unstable, high-speed approach led to 300 m overrun, underscoring CS-25’s demand for a stabilised approach at or above VREF and a touchdown within the calculated distance.

Expert note: Brake energy limits in paragraph (c) stem from 1960s tests where overheated brakes faded and tyres deflated; CS-25 therefore caps braking pressure to what the brake manufacturer certifies for repeated service use.

American Airlines 1420 (MD-82, Little Rock 1999): landing in thunderstorm gusts showed the danger of relying on full headwind credit; CS-25 wind factors force conservative figures to cover such variability.

Expert note: Para (g) ensures data exist for landings with one engine inoperative because thrust reversers, hydraulic pumps, or bleed-air-powered spoilers may not be available—experience from twin-jet ETOPS evaluations drove this rule.

Horizon Air Q400 fleet (2008 ice-contaminated approaches): reports of tailplane-stall risk validated the separate VREF and manoeuvring criteria with "Landing Ice" accretion to preserve pitch control during flare.

section_intent: CS 25.143 ensures that a transport aeroplane can always be positively controlled and manoeuvred by a normally qualified pilot, using reasonable effort, in every phase of flight and after foreseeable failures. It demands smooth transitions between flight conditions, acceptable control-force levels, proper stick-force-per-g gradients, and adequate turn performance, even with asymmetric thrust, configuration changes, icing, or turbulence. Additional provisions address modern side-stick and fly-by-wire systems, limit load-factor exposure, and guard against somatogravic illusion. The ultimate goal is to prevent loss of control or structural overstress by guaranteeing that the crew can keep the aircraft on a safe flight path under all probable operating and failure scenarios.
ai_notes: Case: American Eagle Flight 4184 (ATR72, 1994) rolled inverted after tail-plane icing altered control forces; the accident drove the requirement to show controllability with critical ice accretions in 25.143(c),(i),(j).

Case: USAir 427 and United 585 737 crashes (1994/1991) involved rudder servo reversals that produced unexpected yaw and force reversals; 25.143(i)(3) now insists control forces change steadily with sideslip, with no reversals that could trap pilots.

Expert note: Certification flight tests cut the critical engine at V2 and require a 30–40° banked turn within the force limits of Table 25.143(d) to prove the aircraft remains controllable during worst-case asymmetric thrust.

Case: Fokker F28 prototype breakup (1969) showed that very light pitch forces let pilots overstress the airframe; the stick-force-per-g gradient rule in 25.143(g) was tightened to prevent inadvertent structural overload.
Expert note: Modern fly-by-wire jets use load-factor limiting (25.143(l)) so pilots cannot command more than about 2.5 g, balancing manoeuvrability with structural protection.
Case: ATR42/72 tail-plane-icing events prompted the zero-g pushover test in 25.143(i)(2) to ensure continuous push force and rapid recovery, avoiding pitch-force reversals that can cause dives.
Expert note: Go-around demonstrations assess trim changes and workload to ensure that rapid thrust increase does not induce excessive pitch-up or somatogravic illusion (25.143(b)(4)).

Industry practice: Artificial-feel and spring-feel systems are calibrated so that long-term forces stay below 10 N in pitch yet still give pilots tactile feedback, meeting the long-term limits of Table 25.143(d).

section_intent: CS 25.145 makes sure that, throughout approach, flare, go-around, and flap/gear transitions, the pilot can always pitch the aircraft safely without needing unusual strength or skill, keep enough speed margin above stall, and avoid dangerous altitude loss. It requires that from trimmed approach speed down to the onset of stall warning, the nose can still be pushed down promptly; that quick flap or power changes do not generate overpowering pitch forces; and that a go-around can be flown while keeping longitudinal control and respecting load-factor limits under any approved configuration, weight, altitude, or automation mode. In short, the rule guarantees that the aircraft’s pitch authority, trim system, and flap/gear sequencing are inherently safe so a normal crew can recover energy, prevent stalls, and avoid ground or obstacle contact during the most workload-intense phases of flight.
ai_notes: One-Eleven G-ASHG deep-stall (1963): test crew could not pitch down after flap retraction, killing all aboard; drove the requirement that elevator authority be sufficient to break a developing stall with high lift devices retracted.

Expert note: Sudden go-around thrust on underslung engines pitches the nose up; CS 25.145 forces manufacturers to show elevators and trim can counter this without more than 50 lb hand force, preventing pitch-up departures.

Airbus A320 F-GZRJ (Bordeaux, 1994): inadvertent full-flap selection on approach produced large nose-down moment; compliance with 25.145(b) ensures that similar rapid flap changes can be arrested without excessive control movement.

Expert note: Limit on altitude loss during flap clean-up at 1.08–1.13 VS makes sure a late go-around initiated close to the runway will not settle back onto the ground when lift devices start retracting.

Boeing 737-800 Flydubai FZ981 (Rostov, 2016): crew lost pitch control during second go-around attempt; regulators re-emphasised longitudinal controllability assessments with all autopilot/auto-thrust combinations as required by 25.145(f)(1)(iii).

Expert note: The gating requirements for flap levers prevent accidental overshoot to a too-clean setting; this addresses service history where bumped levers caused sudden lift loss and high pilot workload.

section_intent: CS 25.147 ensures that a multi-engine transport aeroplane remains fully controllable in yaw and roll when everything is normal and, critically, after the loss of one (or, on four-engined types, two) engines. At low speeds near approach/climb (1.3 × stall reference speed, VSR1) the pilot must be able to yaw toward the failed engine, turn, bank up to 20°, arrest any upset, and continue flight without using excessive rudder-pedal force or control-surface travel. The rule also demands adequate roll authority across the speed range up to the maximum design cruise (VFC/MFC) so gusts or evasive manoeuvres can be handled safely. In short, the requirement guarantees sufficient directional (yaw) and lateral (roll) control margins to prevent loss-of-control accidents due to asymmetric thrust, unbalanced drag, or sudden disturbances, thereby protecting occupants and people on the ground.
ai_notes: Manchester Britannia G-ANCA (1958): simultaneous failure of two engines on one wing led to loss of control on final; highlighted need for explicit two-engine-out controllability criteria now in 25.147(b).

Southwest B737-700 Flight 1380 (2018): left-engine fan-blade failure caused severe yaw; crew maintained heading and bank within limits, illustrating the rule’s intent for safe directional control after sudden power loss.

Expert note: Vmc rollover accidents during certification flight tests in the 1960s showed that rudder force limits are essential—hence the 667 N (150 lbf) cap to ensure pilots can actually reach required deflection.
Expert note: Pilot training mantra “dead foot—dead engine” and use of ~5° bank into the live engine stem from the controllability margins (20° bank, yaw toward failed side) verified under CS 25.147.

Lockheed Electra L-188 structural failures (1959–60) began with severe propeller-induced yaw/roll; although structural in nature, investigations reinforced the need for controllability with propellers in ‘minimum-drag’ position now specified in the rule.

Expert note: Modern fly-by-wire aircraft must demonstrate in flight and simulator that, with one engine inoperative, aileron spoilers can still achieve the roll rate defined in AMC 25.147(d) without control-law saturation.

Failure mode: Asymmetric flap or gear deployment adds rolling moment during go-around; CS 25.147(f) ensures enough lateral control margin at VFC/MFC so pilots can correct combined thrust- and configuration-induced bank.

Certification practice: Flight-test points at 1.3 VSR1, max landing weight, aft CG and rudder-pedal force recording verify compliance, directly tying test conditions to the worst-case scenarios envisaged by the rule.

section_intent: This rule makes sure a multi-engine airplane stays controllable if a critical engine suddenly fails during the most vulnerable phases of flight. The manufacturer must prove minimum control speeds (on the ground – VMCG, after lift-off – VMC, on approach/landing – VMCL, and for 3-plus-engine airplanes the two-engine case – VMCL-2) below which the pilot cannot hold the aircraft straight with normal rudder and a small bank. These tested speeds must be low enough (no more than 1.13 × stall speed) and achieved with the worst-case weight, centre-of-gravity, power, propeller state, and pilot pedal force ≤150 lbf, so that pilots can always reject or continue a take-off, or continue an approach, without exceptional strength or skill and without entering hazardous attitudes. In short: the rule forces aircraft design to guarantee enough directional and lateral control authority to survive an engine failure at the slow speeds where yawing moments are highest and aerodynamic controls are weakest.
ai_notes: Lockheed Electra L-188 loss-of-control events (1959–60) highlighted how asymmetric thrust at low speed can quickly induce roll-yaw divergence; minimum-control-speed testing requirements were tightened as a result.

Expert note: Many runway excursions in twins (e.g., Beech 1900D, San Luis Obispo 1987) occurred because crews tried to continue take-off below certified VMCG—showing why a clearly defined, demonstrable ground control speed is essential.

Flight-test practice: The test pilot chops the critical engine and must keep the wings level with ≤5° bank and ≤150 lbf pedal force; any larger force would be unrealistic for line pilots and would mask inadequate rudder sizing.

Expert note: Windmilling propellers add huge drag and raise VMC; by requiring the most adverse propeller position unless an approved automatic feathering system is fitted, the rule drives installation of auto-feather on modern turboprops.

Air Florida B737-222 accident (Potomac River, 1982) demonstrated that ice-induced thrust asymmetry and insufficient rudder authority at low speed can be catastrophic, reinforcing the need for generous control margins in the take-off configuration.
Industry best practice: Operators set decision speeds so that V1 ≥ VMCG and VR ≥ V2 ≥ VMC; this ensures an engine failure just after V1 can be controlled both on the runway and in the initial climb.

Expert note: Simulator and recurrent training include ‘VMC demo’ exercises where pilots feel the onset of rudder limit and recognise that further deceleration would make the aircraft uncontrollable—directly reflecting the certification test intent.

section_intent: The rule insists that a transport aeroplane can be "trimmed" so it will fly straight and level, climb, descend or glide in all normal and critical configurations—across its entire centre-of-gravity range and even after an engine failure—without the pilot having to keep pressure on the controls. This lowers pilot workload, prevents fatigue, and avoids loss-of-control situations that could arise if large, sustained control forces were needed to counter pitch, roll or yaw. In short, whatever the speed, flap, gear or engine-out condition, the aircraft must be inherently balanced so the crew can safely monitor, navigate and manage emergencies instead of constantly fighting the controls.
ai_notes: Air Midwest 5481 (Beech 1900, 2003): CG well aft of limits meant full nose-down trim could not balance the aircraft; it stalled and crashed—illustrating why CS 25.161 links trim capability to the approved CG envelope.

Expert note: Certification flight tests deliberately use the most aft CG at 1.3 VSR1; pilots release the yoke to prove the aircraft stays within pitch limits—directly demonstrating compliance with 25.161(b) & (c).
Boeing 747-400 one-engine-inoperative climb trials: test pilots confirmed lateral bank <5° and manageable rudder forces, satisfying 25.161(d) so crews are not over-tasked during real engine failures.

Expert note: Modern airliners integrate automatic rudder-trim with yaw-dampers; this industry practice exists to meet the directional trim demands of 25.161 while reducing crew workload after asymmetrical thrust events.

Runaway stabiliser incidents on 737 classics prompted stronger procedures; baseline ability to achieve hands-off longitudinal trim per 25.161 lets crews quickly recognise an abnormal trim movement and activate cut-out switches.
Take-off trim setting charts in every AFM derive from the 25.161 evaluations, ensuring pilots can rotate smoothly without excessive pull forces even at extreme loadings.

section_intent: The rule requires that a large airplane be naturally stable around all three axes (pitch, yaw and roll) so that, after a small disturbance, it will tend to return toward steady flight without excessive or confusing control inputs. It also demands that the pilot receive clear, progressive control “feel” (stick-force gradients) so that the amount of pull or push intuitively signals how far the aircraft is from trimmed flight. Together, these requirements guard against pilot disorientation, workload spikes and loss-of-control situations in any normal loading or flight phase, and they oblige manufacturers to confirm adequate stability and feel through flight testing before the aircraft enters service.
ai_notes: Case: Boeing 737 MAX (2018-2019) – The need to augment pitch stability after engine relocation showed that even minor design changes must preserve positive longitudinal stability and natural feel, or else additional systems (e.g., MCAS) must be rigorously validated.

Case: National Airlines B747-400F, Bagram 2013 – Cargo shift drove the centre of gravity far aft, eliminating longitudinal stability and producing an unrecoverable nose-up stall shortly after take-off.

Expert note: Early jet transports (e.g., de Havilland Comet) introduced artificial-feel springs because hydraulic boost removed natural aerodynamic feedback; CS-25.171 codifies the requirement that such systems give pilots reliable, proportional stick forces.

Expert note: Certification flight-test pilots perform phugoid and Dutch-roll assessments; poor damping or neutral stick-force gradients trigger redesign (e.g., elevator gearing changes or addition of a yaw damper) to meet the rule.

Best practice: Airlines train load-planners and flight crews to verify CG envelopes; maintaining the published loading limits ensures the aircraft retains the longitudinal stability demonstrated for CS-25.171 compliance.

section_intent: This rule ensures that an aircraft’s pitch-axis handling gives pilots a clear, instinctive cue about whether they are flying too fast or too slow. Below the trimmed speed the pilot must feel a steady pull on the control column; above it, a push. If the pilot lets go, the aircraft should naturally drift back toward the trimmed speed without demanding high attention. The regulation also requires a minimum stick-force gradient (at least 1 lb per 6 kt) so that speed changes are felt clearly and cannot develop unnoticed. In short, CS-25.173 guards against inadvertent stalls, overspeeds, or divergent pitch oscillations by mandating predictable, easily sensed longitudinal stability, even when the aircraft is mis-trimmed or the pilot momentarily relaxes pressure.
ai_notes: Case: 1963 Boeing 707 pitch-up accident (Calvert, MD) showed that weak stick-force cues allowed crews to unintentionally slow into a stall during climb; investigations led to tighter longitudinal stability criteria in large jets.
Expert note: Trim-runaway events are contained when the natural stick forces fight the runaway, giving the pilot immediate tactile warning and time to activate cut-out switches.

Case: Air Transat A310 FL605 (2005) – mis-set stabiliser after maintenance produced high column forces that prevented take-off until corrected, illustrating the protective value of required force gradients.

Expert note: Flight-test teams plot stick-force-versus-speed curves in climb, cruise, approach, and landing to verify the 1 lb/6 kt slope and the ±10 % free-return band, ensuring the aircraft will not cruise away from the target speed if the pilot is distracted.
Industry practice: Simulator training emphasises ‘release and observe’—if the aircraft does not tend back toward trimmed speed, something is wrong—directly reflecting CS-25.173(b).

section_intent: The rule makes manufacturers prove that, in climb, cruise, approach and landing, the airplane’s pitch attitude is inherently self-correcting and gives pilots a clear, proportional control-column force when speed changes. A positive, continuous stick-force gradient over the specified speed bands ensures the aircraft automatically tends back to the trimmed speed, warns the crew of impending stall or overspeed through feel alone, and keeps forces low enough to avoid fatigue but high enough to prevent inadvertent over-control. By testing the worst combinations of weight, centre-of-gravity, flap, gear and power, CS 25.175 guarantees that this natural longitudinal stability and tactile cueing exists throughout the normal operating envelope, even without augmentation systems.
ai_notes: BAC 1-11 prototype G-ASHG deep-stall crash (1963): diminishing stick force and ineffective elevator near the stall prevented recovery, prompting stricter stick-force-gradient and stability criteria now captured in CS 25.175.

FedEx Flight 14 MD-11 hard landing, Narita 1997: reduced static margin and light column forces in landing configuration contributed to excessive pitch changes and loss of control, illustrating why clear force gradients are required down to 1.7 VS.

Boeing 737 MAX (Lion Air 610 & Ethiopian 302): engine relocation reduced pitch stability, so MCAS was added to restore stick-force vs AoA; the accidents showed the hazard if artificial augmentation replaces robust inherent stability.

Expert note: Certification flight-tests plot stick-force-per-knot curves; a consistently positive slope proves the airplane will self-trim and give pilots tactile speed cues in all tested configurations.

Expert note: Designers use elevator feel springs, bob-weights and tailored stabilizer-trim schedules to keep forces within the 222 N / 356 N limits while maintaining a positive gradient at forward and aft CG limits.

Expert note: Operators impose aft-CG loading or fuel-transfer restrictions to remain inside the demonstrated envelope, ensuring the airplane retains the certified longitudinal stability during revenue flights.
Expert note: Crew training emphasizes sensing airspeed through column forces; CS 25.175 guarantees those forces remain reliable cues even if airspeed indications are lost or in heavy turbulence.

section_intent: CS 25.177 guarantees that a transport aeroplane has an inherent tendency to straighten itself out of a yaw or roll disturbance, and that the pilot always gets normal-sense, proportional, non-reversing rudder and aileron forces over the whole operational envelope (flaps, gear, and speeds). By demanding positive static directional stability and non-negative static lateral stability, the rule prevents yaw-roll divergences, spirals, Dutch-roll amplification, or rudder over-balance that could otherwise lead to loss of control. In plain words: if the aircraft is briefly kicked sideways, it should "want" to come back to coordinated flight and the controls must feel logical and manageable while doing so.
ai_notes: United Airlines Flight 859 (DC-8, 1961) suffered a sudden Dutch-roll divergence after rudder and yaw-damper anomalies; the event showed that positive static stability must exist even when augmentation systems drop out.

NASA/FAA 707 Dutch-roll flight tests (early 1960s) revealed that high-altitude, clean-wing 707s could enter divergent yaw/roll oscillations unless vertical tail volume and lateral stability margins were protected—directly influencing the wording of 25.177(a) and (b).

Expert note: Spiral-dive accidents in early Jetstream 31 flight test highlighted that a slight negative spiral tendency at high Mach can grow quickly; CS 25.177(b)(2) therefore allows only a slow, easily recognised divergence above VMO.

Expert note: Certification flight tests regularly plot rudder force versus sideslip; any flattening or force reversal beyond 180 lbf leads to redesign (e.g., hinge-moment adjustments on the A320 rudder during development).

Boeing 737-300 line incident, Salt Lake City 1995: full rudder deflection in turbulence produced unexpected roll but forces remained positive and proportional, demonstrating how compliance with 25.177(c)/(d) limited the upset.

Lockheed L-1011 prototype showed rudder hinge-moment sign change near maximum deflection; engineers added an anti-balance tab to ensure ‘increased pedal for increased sideslip’, exactly what 25.177(d) demands.

Expert note: One-engine-inoperative certification still checks that, with symmetric power restored, the aircraft will recover from the residual sideslip without crossed controls—validating that positive static stability exists independent of power asymmetry.

Airbus and Boeing training manuals emphasise releasing aileron after a de-crab in crosswind landings; pilots rely on the design’s static lateral stability (low wing rises by itself) mandated by 25.177(b).

section_intent: The rule makes sure a transport aeroplane will not enter self-sustaining or growing oscillations in pitch (“short-period”) or in the combined yaw/roll motion known as Dutch roll during the whole normal operating speed range (from 1.13 times stall speed up to the maximum authorised speed) whatever the pilot is doing with the controls. Short-period motions must die out very quickly (“heavily damped”) and Dutch roll must at least fade away on its own and be easily stopped with ordinary control inputs. The aim is to prevent loss-of-control, excessive crew workload, or structural overload that could arise if natural aircraft motions amplify after a disturbance or a system failure. In plain words: the aircraft must quickly settle itself after a bump or a small upset, and the pilot must be able to keep it steady without extraordinary skill or effort.
ai_notes: Boeing 707 N709PA (1960 Zaragoza accident): loss of yaw-damper led to an undamped Dutch roll that broke the vertical stabiliser, illustrating why CS-25 demands positive damping and controllability of lateral-directional oscillations.

Expert note: Early jet-transport testing found that swept-wing designs had weak directional stability, so without adequate damping a small yaw could couple into roll and become a tiring, sometimes dangerous Dutch-roll cycle—this historical experience drove the rule wording.

American Airlines Flight 587 (A300-600, 2001): aggressive rudder reversals during wake upset produced rapid oscillations; certification now emphasises that short-period motions must not require large, alternating control inputs to arrest.

Expert note: Modern compliance flight tests measure "time-to-half-amplitude" of short-period and Dutch-roll modes; if the motion does not halve within two cycles (pitch) or 7 seconds (Dutch roll), redesign or a yaw-damper/autopilot fix is mandated.

Routine MMEL practice: operators may dispatch with one yaw-damper inoperative only if analysis shows remaining damping meets CS-25.181 limits, underscoring that the rule addresses both design and in-service configuration control.

Training best practice: Type-rating courses include recovery from Dutch roll with small, coordinated rudder and aileron inputs, reinforcing that pilots should not need exceptional technique to meet the controllability clause.

section_intent: The rule makes manufacturers prove that the aircraft can enter and recover from stalls safely, predictably, and with unmistakable warning cues in both straight-ahead and turning flight, with power off and with the power normally used on approach. Tests must cover all likely flap, gear, weight, and centre-of-gravity combinations, using a controlled, slow deceleration so engineers can observe the true stall behaviour. The goal is to ensure that, in service, any pilot who inadvertently slows below the stall speed will receive a clear indication (buffet, nose-drop, or hitting the aft stop) and will be able to regain control without excessive altitude loss. In short, the requirement guards against surprise stalls during approach, go-around, or manoeuvring, and guarantees that the aircraft’s natural and engineered warnings, plus its recovery characteristics, are strong enough to prevent loss-of-control accidents.
ai_notes: BAC 1-11 G-ASHG (1963): Deep-stall during early testing showed that T-tail jets could remain pitch-locked without natural warning, driving the need for explicit, measurable stall cues and recovery standards now embedded in CS 25.201.

Air France 447 (2009): Crew misidentified high-altitude stall; highlighted industry reliance on unmistakable stall indications and the importance of benign post-stall behaviour verified during certification.

Colgan Air 3407 (2009): Approach-to-stall with ice and flaps/gear transitions underscored why regulations require stalls in realistic power and configuration combinations, not just idle-power clean-wing tests.

Expert note: Modern flight-test teams use the mandated ≤1 kt/s deceleration to capture the exact stall break and avoid masking buffet, ensuring the aircraft still meets the nose-drop or buffet cue criteria with slow pilot reactions.
Expert note: Testing at 30° bank with 1.5 VS R1 power reflects go-around scenarios where crews add thrust while still slow and turning onto final—historically a common loss-of-control precursor.
Industry best practice: Certification reports include high-speed camera and accelerometer data to prove buffet amplitude meets the “strong and effective deterrent” language of CS 25.201(d)(2).

section_intent: The rule ensures that an aircraft approaching or entering a stall remains predictable and recoverable by a pilot using normal, correctly-directed control inputs. Up to the stall, ailerons and rudder must still work in the expected sense, the aircraft must not suddenly pitch nose-up, and the stick forces must make it clear the aircraft is slowing. After the stall, the aircraft must not roll or bank so violently that a crew with normal skill cannot arrest the stall and regain level, coordinated flight within modest bank limits. In short, the requirement guards against deep-stall or wing-drop behaviours that could lead to loss of control, ensuring crews have both the authority and time needed to recognise, prevent, and recover from stalls in any typical flight attitude—including turns.
ai_notes: BAC One-Eleven prototype G-ASHG (1963): a T-tail jet entered a deep stall during flight test, elevators blanked by wing wake, recovery impossible; this tragedy drove rules demanding positive pitch authority and no abnormal nose-up at the stall.
Fokker F28 prototype PH-MOL (1969): another deep stall fatality reinforced the need for predictable longitudinal feel and recoverability now codified in CS 25.203.

Colgan Air Flight 3407 (2009): excessive aft yoke and uncoordinated aileron inputs led to wing drop; illustrates why the rule insists on unreversed roll/yaw response so pilots can arrest asymmetry when nearing stall.

Air France 447 (2009): prolonged stall demonstrated that, even at high altitude, control laws must preserve positive stick-forward force cues and allow straightforward recovery—principles embedded in this paragraph.
Expert note: Modern transport wings use washout, vortex generators, and stall strips to ensure the root stalls before the tip, keeping ailerons effective in accordance with CS 25.203(a).
Expert note: Certification flight tests include level-wing and turning stalls with 0.5 m/s² and higher deceleration rates to verify the roll/bank limits in 25.203(b)(c).

Expert note: Stick-shaker/pusher systems are widely adopted to provide unmistakable pre-stall warning and automatic nose-down command, satisfying the requirement for prompt stall prevention and recovery.
Expert note: Airline upset-prevention training teaches coordinated rudder and aileron use plus immediate pitch reduction, directly mirroring the control techniques assumed by this rule.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that pilots receive a clear, unmistakeable and early warning that the aeroplane is approaching a stall, with enough speed-margin for them to react and recover before an actual stall develops. The warning must work in every normal and abnormal configuration (flap, gear, ice accretion, system failures, turns, slow-downs) and be delivered by tactile or aural cues—visual cues alone are not acceptable—so that the crew’s attention can stay outside the cockpit. It sets quantitative margins (≥5 kt / 5 % over stall speed, extra margin in icing and manoeuvring) and requires proof through flight tests at specified deceleration rates. In short: whatever the aircraft’s condition, the pilot must have a reliable, distinctive and timely cue to prevent an inadvertent stall.
ai_notes: BEA Trident Flight 548 (1972): Premature slat retraction left the aircraft in an abnormal high-lift configuration; inadequate and ambiguous stall cues contributed to the deep stall. This drove regulators to demand clear warning in every likely flap/slat failure state (§25.207 (g)).

Northwest Airlines Flight 6231 (B-727, 1974): Ice blocked pitot vents, crew did not sense the rapid deceleration and stalled soon after take-off; lack of tactile/aural warning in icing highlighted the need for margins verified with ice shapes (§25.207 (e–h)).

Colgan Air Flight 3407 (Q400, 2009): Stick shaker activated under ice-contaminated conditions but at very low margin; mishandled recovery showed why the rule demands at least 1–3 s of protected time and identical warning logic in ice and clean air.

Expert note: Flight-test practice now requires activation of stick-shaker no slower than VSR + 5 kt during 1 kt/s deceleration, and demonstration of recovery in 1.5 g turns at 2 kt/s—directly reflecting §25.207 (c–f).
Expert note: Modern transports use tactile stick-shakers (and often pusher) plus aural "STALL" clacker; designers avoid relying on cockpit lights alone because §25.207(b) bans purely visual warnings.

Airbus pitch-limit indicator (green and amber "alpha-protection" bars) is tuned to the numeric margins of §25.207 so that automatic alpha-floor and audible warnings trigger before the legal VSW threshold.

Expert note: Certification flight tests add artificial Appendix C & O ice shapes on wing-leading edges to verify that the same warning system still provides ≥3 % CAS margin, ensuring crews aren’t surprised by earlier stalls in icing.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that, while the aircraft is still on its wheels for take-off or landing, the pilot can keep the nose from pitching forward into a ‘nose-over’ that could dig the propeller into the runway, collapse the gear, or flip the aeroplane. It also demands that the wheel-brake system work smoothly without provoking such a pitch-over, and that tail-wheel (tail-dragger) designs can hold any desired pitch attitude up to a level thrust line when accelerating through 75 % of the stall reference speed (VSR1). In plain terms, the aeroplane must remain controllable and stable in pitch during all expected ground-run situations, protecting occupants, structure, and people around the runway.
ai_notes: Lockheed Vega & early DC-3 service data (1930s): multiple nose-over accidents during heavy braking on short fields highlighted how forward-pitch instability could destroy propellers and injure crew, driving regulators to codify limits.
European Cessna 208B Grand Caravan accident, Oulu 2013: aircraft flipped on landing rebound after aggressive braking on a slippery runway—illustrates the hazard the rule seeks to preclude.
Expert note: Flight-test teams now demonstrate maximum-braking runs at forward C.G., uneven runway bumps, and bounce landings to prove no uncontrollable pitch-over, directly satisfying CS 25.231(a).

B-25 ‘Panchito’ nose-over incident (Delaware, 2011): asymmetrical brake grab caused a rapid forward pitch, showing the need for brake systems that ‘operate smoothly and may not cause any undue tendency to nose over’.
Expert note: Modern anti-skid and brake-pressure-modulation algorithms are tuned so that pitch acceleration stays within limits, a best practice born from compliance with this clause.

Tail-dragger warbird operations: pilots are trained to hold the tail down with elevator until ≥75 % VSR1 to avoid a premature lift-off of the tail and subsequent prop-strike, mirroring the controllability requirement in CS 25.231(a)(2).

section_intent: CS 25.233 makes sure a transport-category airplane can be kept pointed where the pilot wants while it is on the ground. The rule demands that, even in a strong 90-degree cross-wind (at least 20 kt or 0.2 VS R0), the aircraft must not develop an uncontrollable “ground loop,” must stay straight during a power-off landing without relying on brakes or thrust, and must be steerable during normal taxi. In plain terms, the airplane’s fin, rudder, nose-wheel steering, and overall layout must give the crew enough directional authority so that average airline pilots—not test pilots—can keep the aircraft on the runway or taxiway, preventing runway excursions, gear collapses, and fuselage damage, and protecting passengers and ground personnel.
ai_notes: Northwest B720, Chicago-Midway 1962: Aircraft ground-looped in a 23 kt cross-wind and broke its fuselage; the event highlighted the need for demonstrated cross-wind controllability during certification.
