This protects against tab deformation, flutter, or detachment that could suddenly change the main control-surface angle, overwhelm pilot authority, or induce catastrophic manoeuvres. In plain terms: the tabs must be strong enough for the worst loads they can see while the airplane is still inside its approved flight envelope, including maximum forces a pilot can apply.
ai_notes: Case: BEA Vickers Viking G-AHPH (1951) lost elevator servo tab in flight; sudden pitch change led to structural breakup—illustrates why tabs must survive full flight loads plus pilot opposition.
Expert note: Early Boeing 727 flight-test program revealed elevator trim-tab flutter at high Mach; redesign of tab stiffness and hinge fittings became industry best practice for CS 25.409(a).
Case: DC-9 series experienced jammed balance tab during certification manoeuvres; required proof that remaining structure withstood full pilot effort without overstress, shaping 25.409(b) guidance.

Expert note: Typical compliance analysis now couples CFD pressure maps with FE models to evaluate worst-case tab loads when pilot applies maximum 75 lb force per CS 25.397, directly meeting 25.409 requirements.

Industry practice: Operators include visual hinge-bolt checks and free-play limits for elevator and aileron tabs during maintenance, addressing fatigue and wear that could reduce load-carrying capacity anticipated by 25.409.

section_intent: CS 25.415 makes sure an aeroplane’s movable surfaces and their control systems can safely withstand a sudden 65-knot wind while the aircraft is on the ground. By prescribing how to calculate hinge moments, adding factors for dynamic-flexibility, and covering both “controls locked” and “unlocked” situations during taxi and parking, the rule aims to prevent bending, jamming or failure of ailerons, elevators and rudders. In plain English: even if a violent gust, jet-blast or thunder-storm hits the aircraft before take-off, the surfaces and linkages must stay intact so the crew can still control the airplane and no hidden damage is carried into the next flight.
ai_notes: Typhoon Mangkhut, Hong Kong 2018: 60-kt winds damaged elevators and ailerons on several parked A320/A330 aircraft, demonstrating the need for structural margins and effective gust locks exactly as CS-25.415 prescribes.

American Airlines MD-82, St. Louis 1993: elevators slammed against stops during a 55-kt thunder-storm because the internal gust lock was not engaged; bent push-rods led to costly repairs and highlighted the unlocked-taxi case in the rule.

Expert note: During certification, many OEMs discover that adding the 1.25 static-load factor forces thicker push-pull tubes or stronger stop brackets; this prevents latent damage that past operators found only after post-storm inspections.

Expert note: Airlines mandate external control-surface lock-pins or hydraulic-pressure hold procedures when parking in high winds—best-practice maintenance steps derived directly from CS-25.415 requirements.

Pilot-training SOP: crews are taught to centre controls and apply yoke into the wind while taxiing in gusty conditions, limiting hinge moments on surfaces and keeping loads within the CS-25.415 design envelope.

section_intent: This rule makes sure the tail of a transport aeroplane (the horizontal stabiliser/elevator and any support structure) can safely carry loads when the left and right halves are not equally loaded. Side-gusts, yawing or rolling manoeuvres, propeller slipstream, wing–tail interference and buffet can put much higher lift and twisting on one side of the tail than the other. CS 25.427 obliges designers to size the structure for those imbalances—typically 100 % of the worst symmetrical load on one side and 80 % on the other, or any sideways gust for high-dihedral or fin-mounted tails—and to include buffet effects. Meeting these cases prevents structural damage or loss of the tail when the aircraft is hit by turbulence, rapid rudder use, or disturbed airflow in everyday service.
ai_notes: BOAC Flight 911 (B-707, 1966): in-flight breakup after mountain-wave turbulence showed that intense lateral gusts can over-stress one side of the tailplane, driving regulators to codify asymmetric gust load limits.

American Airlines Flight 587 (A300-600, 2001): alternating rudder inputs in wake turbulence created extreme, rapidly varying side loads on the empennage; although the vertical fin failed, the accident reaffirmed the need to size for unsymmetrical manoeuvre loads.

Expert note: Turboprop airliners such as the ATR-72 or Dash-8 experience swirling prop-wash that increases down-load on one half of the horizontal tail during take-off; the 100 %/80 % rule ensures attachment fittings are strong enough for that everyday condition.

Expert note: T-tail jets (e.g., CRJ series) with tailplane dihedral >10° are analysed for gusts coming from any side because the tailplane sits on the fin; paragraph (c) drives FEM cases that often govern fin-to-tail joint sizing.

West Air Sweden Flight 294 (CRJ-200, 2016): severe turbulence led to asymmetric elevator positions and overload of the tailplane before structural breakup, illustrating the combined gust-and-manoeuvre scenario the rule anticipates.

Expert note: During full-scale fatigue tests on the Airbus A350, certification teams applied the CS 25.427 100/80 asymmetric load to the stabiliser to demonstrate lug and spar durability under realistic service spectra.

Best practice: Flight-test programmes include deliberate steady-sideslip manoeuvres while measuring strain gauges on each stabiliser half; comparing these data to CS 25.427 predictions verifies compliance and calibrates structural models.

section_intent: CS-25.445 ensures that auxiliary aerodynamic devices such as winglets, dorsal fins or ventral fins do not overload themselves or the surfaces they are attached to when the aircraft is manoeuvring or being struck by gusts. It requires designers to account for the way these add-ons alter the airflow around the parent wing or tail and to check both symmetric and asymmetric cases, especially when fins are located above and below the horizontal tail. By explicitly prescribing a 100 % / 80 % split for the unsymmetrical case, the rule guarantees that the structure can survive the most severe pitch, roll, yaw or gust loads without failure, preventing in-flight loss of fins or damage to the primary surface.
ai_notes: Case: Boeing 747-400 static tests (1988) uncovered higher-than-predicted loads at the winglet root due to wing–winglet interaction; the design was reinforced, illustrating the need for CS-25.445(a) analysis.

Expert note: Early winglet CFD studies showed yaw manoeuvres could shift pressure fields and raise local bending moments on both the fin and the wing tip by >5 %, prompting the current requirement to include coupled pitch/roll/yaw and gusts.

Case: Gulfstream G-IV dorsal fin loss (1993) after severe turbulence highlighted that combined vertical-tail and horizontal-tail interactions can cause unexpected stress concentrations if asymmetric loads are not covered.

Expert note: Repeated ventral-fin cracking on MD-11s during cross-wind landings demonstrated why the rule demands a 100 % load on one side and 80 % on the other to cover tail scrape and yaw scenarios.

Expert note: Compliance teams now build high-fidelity aeroelastic models and corroborate them with flight-test strain gauges to prove that both the auxiliary fin and the supporting surface meet strength and fatigue limits under CS-25.445.

Expert note: Structural training guides tell engineers to apply the 100/80 rule early in sizing to avoid under-estimating torsion in the horizontal tail spar webs, a common oversight before the regulation was formalised.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that the wing-flap panels, the gears, motors, linkages that move them, and the structure that holds everything to the wing can all survive the highest aerodynamic and inertial forces they will meet in service. Those forces arise not only in the steady "flaps-up" or "flaps-down" states but also during the brief but often more severe moments when the pilot is extending or retracting the flaps at the limits of allowed speed. By tying the requirement to the manoeuvre and gust cases of CS-25.345, the rule obliges designers to analyse and test the flaps for high-lift take-off and landing loads, gust encounters, accidental overspeed, and asymmetrical operation so that they will not deform, jam, or detach, safeguarding controllability and structural integrity throughout the flight envelope.
ai_notes: TACA Flight 110 (B737, 1988): flap-retraction in heavy rain and gusts damaged a flap track canoe; investigation highlighted the high transient loads that occur during movement and fed into later design and inspection criteria.

Expert note: Early 747 certification fatigue tests revealed cracking in flap track beams when flaps were cycled near VFE, prompting structural reinforcements and illustrating why transition loads must be covered.

ATR 72 EI-SJU (1991) accident: asymmetrical flap deployment on approach produced unexpected roll moments and high loads on one side, underscoring the need to size mechanisms for off-balance loads during transitions.

Industry practice: Structural substantiation includes a dedicated "flap manoeuvre load case" at VFE + 2 kt with rapid extension/retraction, ensuring positive margins where dynamic pressure and hinge moments peak.

Expert note: Compliance teams routinely stress-test drive shafts and torque tubes for jammed-flap scenarios because history shows that stall-type motor burnouts can leave one panel moving while the other stops, sharply increasing loads on the still-moving side.

section_intent: Ensure that any aerodynamic add-ons—such as slots, slats, spoilers, or similar devices—are structurally sized using measured flight or wind-tunnel data, not just calculations. Because the airflow around these devices is complex and can create large, localized loads, proof from real tests is required so the parts, their hinges, and the supporting wing structure will not fail in service.
ai_notes: Boeing 747 flight-test programme (1969): unexpected buffeting on an outboard slat produced higher hinge moments than predicted; test strain-gauge data were used to reinforce the slat track structure before certification.
Lufthansa Flight 527 (B737-200, 1973) shed a spoiler panel during overspeed descent; investigation showed underestimated aerodynamic suction loads, underscoring the need for validated load data.

Expert note: Current CS-25 compliance typically instruments every high-lift panel with strain gauges during Vmo/Mmo dive tests to capture real hinge-line and panel loads for structural substantiation.

Expert note: High-Reynolds-number wind-tunnel campaigns on full-span Krueger flaps are an accepted industry practice to build load envelopes when flight-test measurement is impractical for early design sizing.

BAC One-Eleven G-ASHG accident (1963): inadvertent leading-edge slat deployment in a stall test led to structural break-up; highlighted the dramatic load increase such devices can impose if not fully characterised.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that when an aircraft is on the ground—during taxi, take-off, landing or a hard touchdown—the landing-gear system and the surrounding structure are strong enough for the very worst loads they could realistically see. Designers must treat the ground reactions as external forces and balance them with the aircraft’s own inertia (its resistance to being accelerated or rotated). They must also test the most extreme fore-aft, vertical and side-to-side centre-of-gravity (CG) positions the operator could legally fly with, because different CG locations shift loads between nose, main and wing-gear legs. Small random lateral CG shifts caused by passengers, cargo or fuel imbalance can be ignored only if kept within 3 % of the critical design load and if the flight manual tells crews how to stay inside that window. In short, CS 25.471 sets the foundation for all later ground-load calculations so that no landing-gear component or attachment point will fail when the aircraft touches down, brakes, turns or hits bumps.
ai_notes: Sioux City DC-10 (1989): After engine failure, hard landing with right-wing low overloaded one main gear leg; investigators highlighted the need for conservative side-load criteria and proper CG modelling now embedded in CS-25 ground-load rules.
Expert note: Early 707 service revealed cracked nose-gear trunnions traced to forward CG taxi loads; modern design practice now runs CG sweeps per CS 25.471 to size nose-gear attachments.

A340-600 manufacturing test accident (2007): Unanticipated inertia build-up during ground-run led to nose-gear collapse—showing why external forces must be placed in equilibrium with angular inertia when modelling ground loads.
Expert note: Weight-and-balance programmes require lateral fuel balancing and seat-map limits so that random passenger or cargo shifts stay inside the ±3 % CG band referenced in 25.471(b)(1)–(2).

Industry practice: Landing-gear drop-tests are executed at both forward and aft CG extremes to capture highest nose-gear and main-gear loads respectively, directly satisfying the ‘critical centres of gravity’ clause.

Expert note: Finite-element models of gear–wing junctions routinely include the Appendix A geometry parameters cited in 25.471(c), ensuring consistent load-path assumptions across manufacturers and certification authorities.

section_intent: This rule sets the baseline ‘hard-landing’ conditions that the structure and landing gear of a large aeroplane must safely absorb. It tells designers: assume the aircraft can hit the runway with up to 10 feet-per-second (3.05 m/s) vertical speed at normal landing weight, or 6 fps (1.83 m/s) if it is still near take-off weight, and in the touchdown attitudes defined elsewhere. Within those conditions the gear, airframe and tyres must be analysed—using dynamic methods that include tyre spin-up, rebound (‘spring-back’), aircraft pitching, and any significant flexing of the structure—and the dynamic model must be proven by drop tests. Designers may credit some residual aerodynamic lift (never more than the weight) and must use realistic tyre–runway friction (capped at 0.8). The objective is to ensure the landing gear system and surrounding structure will not fail, collapse or transmit dangerous loads to occupants during the hardest landings that can reasonably occur in service, while avoiding unrealistically high design loads that would penalise weight or performance.
ai_notes: Southwest Airlines Flight 345 (B737-700, 2013): nose-first touchdown with ≈960 fpm vertical speed exceeded certification assumptions; nose-gear collapsed—illustrates why the rule defines maximum descent rates and correct pitch attitudes.

FedEx Express Flight 80 (MD-11, Narita 2009): heavy-weight landing with high sink rate caused gear failure and breakup; shows that exceeding the 10 fps limit can be catastrophic and validates why gear energy-absorption margins are defined.

Expert note: Drop-test campaigns under CS 25.723 use instrumented gear legs dropped from calibrated heights to match 10 fps impact, confirming spin-up, spring-back and damping models used in CS 25.473 analyses.

Expert note: Multibody simulations (e.g., MSC Adams or SIMPACK) model tyre-runway friction with µ capped at 0.8; higher values would under-predict required sliding distances and overload gear side-braces.

Bombardier Global 7500 certification: designers credited residual lift from locked-out spoilers; compliance analysis had to show that automatic lift-dump deployment after WOW removed the extra lift considered in CS 25.473(b).
Expert note: Pilot training SOPs limit planned sink rate at flare to ≤600 fpm; this practice mirrors the 10 fps structural limit and reduces the probability of load exceedance in daily operations.

Boeing 787 flight-test 2010: intentionally performed ‘drop-in’ landings at 102 % design sink rate to validate structural dynamic response, demonstrating industry practice of correlating analysis with full-aircraft flight test traces.

Expert note: Certification reviews often uncover overly-stiff gear that rebounds (‘spring-back’) and increases peak fuselage loads; CS 25.473(c)(2) ensures designers damp rebound energy to protect passenger floor beams.

section_intent: This rule makes it clear that the ground-load equations and test conditions given in CS 25.479 to CS 25.485 are valid only for aeroplanes that use the two widely-used “conventional” landing-gear layouts—a tricycle arrangement with main and nose gears, or a tail-dragger arrangement with main and tail gears—operated with normal landing techniques. The intent is to guarantee that structural load analyses, drop tests, and flight tests are based on force paths and pitch attitudes that genuinely match those gear geometries, so the gear, supporting structure, and attachment points will survive every expected taxi, take-off, landing and ground-handling event. By defining this scope, the rule also warns designers of aircraft with non-standard gear (tandem, outrigger, skid, etc.) that they must propose alternative analyses or special conditions, ensuring every configuration achieves the same level of ground-load safety.
ai_notes: Southwest Airlines Flt 345 (B737-700, 2013): premature nose-gear touchdown at LaGuardia led to nose-gear collapse, illustrating why tricycle-gear load cases must consider forward pitching moments developed in "normal" but sub-optimal landings.

Buffalo Airways DC-3 tail-wheel collapse (Yellowknife, 2015): damage during routine landing showed the high vertical and side loads a tail-gear must absorb, underpinning the need for dedicated main-/tail-gear criteria.

Expert note: Aircraft with tandem main gears and outriggers (e.g., B-52, Harrier) were certificated under special conditions because CS 25.479-485 did not match their load paths—demonstrating the rule’s scope limitation.

Expert note: Compliance testing routinely includes drop tests of main and nose gear at attitudes defined in 25.479–485; this standard practice stems directly from the assumption of a conventional gear arrangement.

Learjet 60 N999LJ overrun (2008): landing overrun caused main-gear failure and nose-gear detachment; investigation highlighted the importance of sideload and torsion criteria that CS 25.479 ff. prescribe for conventional gear.

section_intent: Ensure that the landing gear and the surrounding structure can safely absorb the combined vertical, drag and side loads that arise when an aeroplane touches down in a level attitude at or above stall speed, in hot-day conditions, with possible down-wind, cross-wind or nose-first contacts. The rule sets specific speed ranges, attitudes for nose-wheel and tail-wheel types, and mandatory load combinations so designers account for higher approach speeds, simultaneous wheel contact, and lateral drift. Its goal is to prevent gear collapse, structural damage and loss of control during normal, down-wind or cross-wind landings across the full operating envelope.
ai_notes: Accident: Southwest Airlines Flight 345 (2013) – Nose-first touchdown exceeded design loads on the nose gear and it collapsed, illustrating why CS 25.479 demands the gear and structure tolerate simultaneous nose- and main-wheel contact.

Accident: Lockheed L-1011 ‘Windshear Demonstrator’ test crash (1984) – Unexpected tail-wind landing increased ground speed, reinforcing the rule’s 1.25 VL2 margin and the need to evaluate down-wind landings beyond 10 kt.
Expert note: Cross-wind operations regularly create drift; certifying to 25 % side load with 40 % drag prevents ground loops or gear folding when wheels touch while side-slipping.

Accident: Boeing 737-800 runway excursion at Yogyakarta (2007) – Touchdown with significant drift and side-load damaged the gear, underscoring the importance of the vertical-drag-side load combination in 25.479(d)(2).
Expert note: Structural compliance tests apply 25 % aft drag with maximum vertical reaction to verify keel-beam, trunnion and wing-root strength, directly reflecting 25.479(d)(1).
Industry practice: Pilot operating manuals limit down-wind landings to 10 kt unless specifically approved, mirroring the regulation’s requirement to study higher ground speeds.
Expert note: Tail-wheel aircraft certification keeps the reference line horizontal during tests to prevent the nose-over tendencies experienced in early DC-3 operations, satisfying 25.479(b).

section_intent: This rule makes sure the landing gear, its attachments, and any structure that might touch the ground can safely absorb the loads that occur when an aeroplane touches down in a "tail-down" attitude—i.e. with a relatively high pitch angle during the flare or for tail-wheel aircraft. Designers must show the aircraft can withstand the combination of vertical impact loads and horizontal drag loads that exist at stall speed (VS0) both in standard and hot-day conditions, with the loads acting through the main-wheel axle and, for tail-wheel types, through the tail-wheel. For nose-wheel aeroplanes it also checks that nothing other than the main wheels will hit the runway at the highest practical landing pitch. In plain words, the rule guards against structural failure or ground contact damage when pilots land a little nose-high.
ai_notes: Douglas DC-3 early-service tail-wheel fractures (1940s) revealed that simultaneous main-gear and tail-gear impact loads were higher than anticipated, prompting regulators to codify explicit tail-down load cases.

Expert note: Many WWII trainers suffered fuselage buckling at the tail-wheel bracket during bounced landings; the failure mode directly matches the 45° up-and-aft tail-wheel load vector now required in CS 25.481(b).

Qantas B747-438 VH-OJH tail-strike (Bangkok 1999) highlighted the need to ensure rear fuselage clearance at high-pitch landings on nose-gear aircraft, mirroring the attitude limits referenced in CS 25.481(c).

Expert note: Certification drop-tests routinely pitch the test article to the maximum stall-attitude to check that main-gear attachment lugs, drag-braces, and keel beams meet the combined vertical/drag load paths defined by this rule.

Airbus practice: A330/A350 structural substantiation includes FEM cases with VS0 at ISA+22.8 °C to capture lower air density, ensuring gear-down-landing loads are still within material allowables per CS 25.481(a)(2).

Training best practice: Airline FCTM procedures limit rotation rate in the flare and call for immediate go-around after a bounce to avoid second impact in a steeper tail-down attitude, directly mitigating the load scenario addressed by the rule.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that an airliner’s structure can safely take the hit if only one main landing-gear leg touches the runway first. In a cross-wind, side-slope, bounced or gear-malfunction landing, the airplane may be level overall yet roll just enough for a single wheel set to absorb the full vertical load while the rest of the aircraft is still airborne. CS 25.483 requires designers to prove the gear, wing root, fuselage and supporting structure can carry that asymmetric load, and that any resulting twisting or side forces are safely balanced by the airplane’s own mass (inertia) without overstressing parts. In plain terms: the aircraft must not break, bend excessively, or cause loss of control if pilots ‘land on one wheel’, even under worst-case vertical loads already defined elsewhere in the rules.
ai_notes: Hamburg A320 cross-wind event (Lufthansa D-AIPQ, 2008): right main gear touched first, sudden gust rolled the aircraft and stressed one gear attachment—illustrates why single-gear strength and torsional wing capacity are vital.

Expert note: Cross-wind training routinely teaches ‘wing-low’ techniques where pilots deliberately touch down on the up-wind gear first; the rule ensures the structure tolerates this normal-operation asymmetry.
Southwest B737-700 drop-test data: certification drop tests include 1-wheel touchdown cases to verify wing-fuselage joint torsion, a direct compliance method for CS 25.483.
MD-82 accident, Little Rock 1999: Right gear hit hard in a storm while left gear was still airborne, contributing to structural damage—underscores real-world loads the rule anticipates.
Expert note: Finite-element models of wing box include out-of-plane bending moments from single-gear reactions; conservative inertia coupling per 25.483(b) avoids under-estimating those loads.

section_intent: This rule makes sure the landing gear and adjoining structure can safely absorb strong sideways forces that occur when an aeroplane lands in a cross-wind or touches down with some yaw. It tells designers to analyse a level-attitude touchdown where only the main wheels are on the runway and to apply specific inward- and outward-acting lateral loads (80 % and 60 % of the vertical wheel force) together with half of the peak vertical load from a normal landing. By requiring the gear, wing attachments, and supporting structure to withstand these side loads—without help from wheel drag or the nose gear—the regulation protects against gear collapse, wing or fuselage damage, and subsequent loss-of-control during demanding landings. (CS = Certification Specification; “vertical reaction” is the downward force at the wheels.)
ai_notes: Hamburg 2008 – Lufthansa A320 D-AIQP struck its wingtip while landing in a 47 kt gust; the main gear stayed intact because it had been certificated for CS-25 side-load values.
FedEx Flight 80 (MD-11F, Narita 2009) broke apart after an over-yawed, bounced touchdown; investigators noted lateral loads far above limits, underscoring why strong side-load criteria are mandated.

Expert note: Cross-wind certification flight tests deliberately land with near-limit crab angles to show that gear loads predicted by CS-25.485 are not exceeded and that steering/shimmy remain controllable.

Expert note: Structural qualification of a main landing gear includes a static test where 0.8 × V and 0.6 × V side forces are applied at the wheel centre while half the vertical limit load is maintained, validating finite-element models.
Expert note: Airline training emphasises ‘de-crab and roll-out into the wind’ technique; this reduces the side force delivered at touchdown to values the gear was designed for under CS-25.485.
Expert note: Operators schedule repetitive NDT of side-brace joints and trunnions because cumulative cross-wind landings generate fatigue driven by the same lateral load paths defined in this rule.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that an aircraft’s landing gear and the structure that holds it can survive the violent ‘bounce-back’ that happens if the wheels leave the runway and the strut shoots to full extension. When the oleo strut tops out, the wheels (the “unsprung” mass) can decelerate extremely fast—up to 20 times the force of gravity (20 g)—and that inertial kick is transmitted into axles, drag braces and wing or fuselage fittings. CS 25.487 therefore demands that designers analyse and test for this 20 g rebound load so gear components, attachment lugs and surrounding primary structure will not crack, detach or jam, preserving controllability for any subsequent touchdown or go-around.
ai_notes: FedEx Flight 80 (MD-11, Narita 2009): first hard touchdown caused a bounce; on the second impact the overstressed main gear fractured and tore into the wing, illustrating why rebound loads must already be covered at the design stage.

Expert note: Drop-test data show that when an oleo reaches full extension the wheel hub can stop in as little as 20 ms, producing ≈20 g; CS 25.487 codifies this worst-case so engineers size axles, trunnions and stop-rings appropriately.

Lufthansa A320 certification: dynamic rig tests at 1.3 × limit drop height verified that gear attachment fittings took the rebound kick without permanent set—demonstrating a standard compliance path for 25.487.
Expert note: Finite-element models used in fatigue substantiation must include the 20 g ‘top-out’ pulse, because ignoring it has led to brace lugs cracking during service landings on regional jets.

Pilot-training best practice: crews are taught to hold a steady pitch attitude after touchdown and avoid aggressive flare corrections that induce a bounce, reducing the frequency of real-world exposure to the 25.487 load case.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that an aircraft’s landing gear, wheel-well structure and surrounding fuselage can safely carry the full weight of the aeroplane while it is on the ground—during towing, taxiing, braking, tight turns, loading or servicing—before any wing lift reduces that weight. By requiring analysis at the ‘design ramp weight’ (the heaviest the aircraft may be while parked) and with shock-absorbers and tyres in their static position, the regulation targets the highest static and manoeuvre loads the gear will ever see. The intent is to prevent structural failure, gear collapse or fuselage cracking that could endanger ground crews, passengers, or the aircraft itself during routine ground operations.
ai_notes: British Airways B747-400 (G-BNLB) Heathrow 2005: Nose-gear trunnion cracked during pushback and collapsed, injuring ground staff—highlighting the need to size gear attachments for towing side-loads at full ramp weight.

Expert note: Tow-bar-less tractors can apply higher longitudinal and steering torques than traditional towbars; CS-25.489 ensures those loads are considered even though the aircraft is stationary or moving slowly.
UPS DC-8 Memphis 2003: Aircraft tipped tail-down while being heavily loaded, damaging aft fuselage frames—showing why the highest ground weight, not landing weight, drives structural checks.

Expert note: Certification test programmes routinely apply static lateral tyre loads to landing-gear rigs with no aerodynamic lift to prove the wing-to-gear joint can handle sharp taxi turns or one-wheel bumps.

Best practice: Operators train pushback crews to respect published maximum steering angles and towing speeds; these limits are derived directly from the structural capability demonstrated under CS-25.489 conditions.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that the aircraft’s structure and landing gear are strong enough to survive the bumps, ruts and uneven surfaces that can realistically be met while taxiing, accelerating for take-off, or decelerating after landing. Designers must assume the harshest ground roughness likely to be encountered at any approved weight and speed, so that no part of the aeroplane will fail, deform excessively, or lose controllability when operating on imperfect runways and taxiways. (AMC = Acceptable Means of Compliance.)
ai_notes: Case: Delta L-1011 nose-gear collapse at Dallas/Fort Worth (1985) occurred after the aircraft struck a raised pavement joint during a rejected take-off; the incident highlighted the need to design for abrupt ground bumps at high speed.

Expert note: Certification taxi-roll tests over 76 mm (3 in) cleats placed on the runway simulate the ‘roughest ground’ condition required by CS 25.491, validating structural models against real shock inputs.

Case: Air France A340-300 overrun Toronto YYZ (2005) traversed rough grass and ravines; although severely stressed, the landing gear stayed intact, demonstrating the benefit of designs sized for rough-ground loads.

Expert note: Fatigue cracking in main-gear side-brace fittings found during routine inspections of early Boeing 737s traced back to repetitive taxi over uneven pavement—exactly the cumulative load CS 25.491 seeks to envelope.

Best practice: OEM structural analyses apply dynamic amplification factors (≈1.5) to wheel loads when modelling taxi on degraded surfaces, ensuring margin against sudden shock from potholes or runway grooves.

Best practice: Pilot-training manuals limit taxi speed on broken pavement and advise centre-line tracking to minimise bump loads, complementing the rule’s assumption of ‘reasonable’ ground speed during rough-surface encounters.

section_intent: This rule makes sure the landing gear and its attachments are strong enough to survive the worst-case stopping manoeuvres on the runway. When the pilot slams on the wheel brakes—during landing, a rejected take-off, or an emergency stop—the gear must carry both the full vertical weight of the aircraft and the big horizontal drag force generated by tyre friction (assumed at a conservative 0.8). Because this drag shifts loads between main and nose (or tail) wheels and can pitch the aeroplane nose-down, the rule sets specific load factors and a dynamic pitching analysis so designers prove that no gear leg, fitting or fuselage structure will buckle or tear out under the peak stresses. In short: your wheels, struts and surrounding structure must not fail when you hit the brakes hardest on a dry, high-friction runway.
ai_notes: Real event: 2008 Learjet 60 accident at Columbia, SC – rejected take-off with maximum braking burst several tyres; collapsed gear and post-crash fire highlighted the need for gear structures that tolerate peak braked-roll loads and associated pitching moments.

Real event: 1973 Boeing 727 nose-gear collapse at Sydney – hard braking after long touchdown overloaded nose gear attachments; investigation fed into industry understanding of nose-down pitching loads during maximum-brake stops.

Expert note: Tests routinely apply 1.2 g vertical plus 0.8 μ drag on main-gear test rigs; many OEMs add 2.0 dynamic factor to nose-gear loads exactly as paragraph (d) prescribes to capture the transient pitch-down spike seen in flight-test data.

Expert note: The rule distinguishes tail-wheel and nose-wheel aircraft because tail-draggers transfer all weight to the mains during braking, while tricycle gear sees a rapid nose-down load shift that can double nose-leg loads if not designed for.

Best practice: Flight-test brake-energy stops (‘maximum brake rejected take-off’ at V1-10 kt) instrument nose-gear load cells to validate that actual vertical increments stay within CS-25.493 predictions, providing data for compliance reports.

Common failure mode addressed: Over-torqued brake application on one side can create asymmetric drag and sudden pitch-down, risking gear side-load and collapse; structural margins mandated here prevent such mishaps escalating into hull loss.

section_intent: This rule defines a specific ground-load case that every large airplane must be able to withstand when it makes a tight, steady taxi turn using nose-wheel steering or differential engine thrust. When the aircraft pivots, its landing gear, supporting structure and wheel attachments experience both the normal vertical weight (1.0 g) and a significant sideways load (0.5 g). CS 25.495 ensures that the gear legs, attachments, fuselage keel, and wheel brakes are strong enough to resist those combined vertical-and-lateral forces without collapsing or overstressing, thereby protecting occupants, preventing costly structural damage, and maintaining directional control during everyday ground operations such as sharp taxi turns, runway turn-offs and engine-run manoeuvres.
ai_notes: Eastern Air Lines L-1011 N310EA (MIA, 1978): main-gear side-brace failed while making a sharp turn on the ramp, illustrating the high lateral loads that CS 25.495 now quantifies.
Expert note: Ground-test campaigns regularly use a ‘0.5-g lateral jack-down test’ on landing-gear rigs to prove compliance with the 1.0 × vertical / 0.5 × lateral load envelope of this paragraph.
ANA Boeing 787 JA804A (KIX, 2013): nose-gear collapse during a 180° turn-back with differential thrust highlighted why both nose and main gear must tolerate combined side and vertical reactions.

Expert note: Differential-power taxi on twins (e.g., 737 or A320 single-engine taxi) can impose higher side loads than tiller steering alone; CS 25.495 guarantees structural margins for this common fuel-saving practice.

Bombardier Q400 training: OEM flight-crew ops manuals stress limiting taxi speed before tight turns specifically because exceeding the 0.5-g lateral design limit can fatigue gear components over time.

Expert note: Finite-element analysis of gear-to-wing fittings always includes the CS 25.495 case alongside landing, take-off and braking load cases, because historical incident data show turning loads to be one of the top contributors to gear side-brace cracking.

section_intent: This rule makes designers prove that a tail-wheel and the structure that anchors it can survive the sharp sideways loads that occur when a tail-dragger aeroplane yaws on the ground—during cross-wind landings, tight turns, or a developing ground-loop. It sets a worst-case test: assume the tail wheel is carrying its full static vertical weight and, at the same time, is hit by an equal horizontal side force. The wheel is analysed both when it is free to caster 90° and when it is locked or damped, ensuring every steering configuration is covered. In plain terms, CS 25.497 exists to stop tail wheels from tearing off, twisting the rear fuselage, or collapsing the spring assembly whenever the aircraft experiences abrupt sideways ground loads.
ai_notes: Douglas DC-3 ground-loop (multiple 1940s incidents): tailwheel yaws 90°, side load ripped the fork and bent rear bulkhead—highlighted need for defined lateral design loads.
Expert note: Tail-draggers often weathervane in cross-winds; the initial skid can generate a side force similar in magnitude to the static tail load, exactly the case codified here.
B-17G taxi accident, RAF Kimbolton 1944: locked tailwheel sheared at contact point during tight turn, prompting stronger attach-fittings in later mods.
Expert note: Compliance practice—static pull test applying simultaneous vertical and lateral load to tail-wheel spring assembly validates CS 25.497 without costly drop tests.
Piper PA-18 training fleet data: cracked tail-post welds traced to repeated shimmy with free-swivel wheel; modern retrofits add shimmy dampers sized per 1:1 vertical/side load rule.
Expert note: Flight manuals now emphasise progressive rudder during rollout to avoid exceeding CS 25.497 design loads, integrating the requirement into pilot training.
Cessna 195 hard cross-wind landing, 1953 NTSB file: tailwheel swivelled sideways, axle snapped but fuselage remained intact—demonstrated structural benefit of meeting CS standard.
Industry practice: Engineers model 90° caster position in FEA because a castering wheel can instantaneously align perpendicular to travel, producing peak side loads envisioned by CS 25.497.

section_intent: CS-25.499 exists to make sure the nose landing gear, the structure that attaches it, and the forward fuselage can safely carry the large side, forward-aft and steering loads that occur on the ground when the aircraft yaws or turns—especially during one-sided braking, tight taxi manoeuvres, cross-wind operations and full steering deflection. By prescribing specific load factors (e.g., side load = 0.8 × vertical load, steering torque with 1.33 × static reaction), the rule forces designers to prove that neither the gear nor the surrounding structure will buckle, shear or detach under the worst realistic combination of braking, steering and aircraft weight. In plain English: the regulation protects against nose-gear collapses or structural damage when the pilot brakes harder on one side or turns sharply, ensuring the aircraft stays controllable and the occupants stay safe.
ai_notes: Southwest B737-700 Flight 345 (LaGuardia, 2013): Nose gear collapsed after excessive vertical and side loads on touchdown; showed why gear and keel-beam strength margins for yawed landings are vital.

Expert note: Differential braking during tight ramp turns can impose a side load very close to 0.8 × vertical reaction; CS-25.499 makes the designer explicitly size for that predictable pilot behaviour.
Air Canada A320 C-FKCO (Montréal, 2019): Steering angle frozen near full left on landing, producing high side load; accident highlighted the need for structures that survive jammed-steering landings.

Expert note: Cross-wind take-offs with main-gear brakes applied intermittently can create the exact unbalanced moments modelled in 25.499(b); certification test pilots intentionally replicate this in ground-load testing.

ERJ-145 taxi incident (Atlanta, 2015): Nose gear fractured during a 180° pivot turn using inside-wheel braking—an operational scenario directly reflected in the rule’s asymmetric-brake equilibrium case.
Expert note: Modern CAD/FEA runs impose the 1.33× static reaction plus full steering torque per 25.499(e) to verify lug fasteners and keel-beam webs do not reach yield after multiple fatigue cycles.
B757 nose-gear tow breakaway (Manchester, 2005): Excessive tow-bar angle induced loads similar to those in 25.499(e); event reinforced including ‘any steerable position’ in the requirement.
Expert note: Airline SOPs limit ground steering angle when single-engine taxiing because combining high torque with asymmetric thrust can approach the 0.8 side-load limit the rule assumes.

Best practice: Certification programmes run full-scale gear sled tests that couple vertical drop with lateral sled motion to validate that structural margins predicted for 25.499 are met before flight test.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that the landing-gear, its attachments, and the surrounding structure are strong enough if the aircraft suddenly pivots around one main-gear leg while the brakes on that side are fully locked. In that situation the whole aeroplane swings around a fixed wheel, generating high side-loads, torsion, and vertical forces. By prescribing a 1 g vertical load and a tyre-runway friction coefficient of 0.8, CS 25.503 sets a realistic “worst-case” ground-maneuver scenario (for example, an unintended brake lock-up during taxi, take-off, landing rollout, or a tight turn). The ultimate objective is to prevent gear collapse, structural damage, or loss of directional control that could end in runway excursions, fires, or injuries. (g = acceleration due to gravity; coefficient of friction is the grip between tyre and pavement).
ai_notes: Pan Am Boeing 707, San Francisco 1965: right-side brake seized on landing rollout; aircraft spun 150°, right gear fractured—illustrated the destructive loads of a pivot and drove emphasis on locked-brake cases in later certification.

Expert note: Early 747 certification tests revealed wheel-well skin wrinkling when one truck was locked during ground turning trials; strengthening was added to meet the CS 25.503 equivalent in FAR 25.
Lockheed L-1011 tight-turn taxi tests (1971): asymmetric braking produced torsional wing-to-body loads close to calculated CS 25.503 limits, validating the requirement’s load factors.

Boeing & Airbus training manuals now warn crews to release brakes before sharp turns; simulators include ‘locked wheel pivot’ scenarios so pilots recognise and mitigate the loads CS 25.503 is designed for.

Expert note: Maintenance programmes require periodic inspection of torque links, side-brace fittings, and brake hydraulic valves because seizure or unequal pressure can create the very pivot event this rule assumes.

section_intent: CS-25.507 ensures the landing-gear system is strong enough when horizontal loads act in the "wrong" direction—that is, forward at the tyre-ground contact while the brakes are applied. Such loads arise during push-back/towing, reverse-thrust manoeuvres, cross-wind recovery, or an aborted rearward roll, and can pitch the aeroplane onto its tail or overload the nose gear. The rule sets a conservative limit load tied to wheel vertical load or brake torque and prescribes how the pitching moment must be balanced so the load path through the structure is realistic for both nose-wheel and tail-wheel designs. Meeting this requirement prevents gear collapse, axle or attachment failures, and loss of directional control on the ground.
ai_notes: Boeing 747-400 Kai Tak 1991: nose-gear collapsed during push-back when towing forces and set brakes overloaded the forward reaction path—illustrates need for forward-acting load case.
Airbus A320 Hamburg 2008: tow-bar shear pin failed; aircraft rolled off tug with brakes applied, imposing sudden forward loads that damaged gear attachments.
Expert note: Reverse-thrust at high power while wheels are still spinning can momentarily drive tyres forward relative to ground, creating the same load direction addressed by CS-25.507.
DC-8 certification tests (1960s): structural cracks found when static brake torque was applied in forward direction; prompted explicit inclusion of reversed-braking load cases in regulations.
Industry best practice: OEM ground-towing manuals limit push speed and mandate brake release unless required, directly managing the load magnitude envisioned by this rule.

Expert note: Compliance often demonstrated by landing-gear FEM analysis plus a static test where 1.2× maximum brake torque is applied with wheels chocked forward, verifying both gear leg and fuselage attachment integrity.

section_intent: To make sure the landing-gear system and dedicated tow-points are strong enough to withstand the highest foreseeable forces that can be imposed during push-back or towing on the ramp. The rule translates those forces into clear design load cases—forward, aft, and side, with the wheels straight or swivelled—scaled to the aircraft’s weight. By proving the structure can take these loads without permanent deformation or failure, the regulation protects against nose- or main-gear collapses, steering linkage damage, or fuselage skin wrinkling that could jeopardise safety before take-off. (WT = design ramp weight; FTOW = prescribed towing force.)
ai_notes: Delta MD-88 ATL 2010: Tow-bar mis-rigged and tractor applied excessive side angle; nose-gear drag brace failed and the gear folded. Incident highlighted need for structural margins defined in CS-25.509.

Lufthansa A320 FRA 2018: Shear pin in tow-bar parted as designed, sparing the nose gear when tractor driver exceeded permissible draw-bar pull—showing industry use of sacrificial pins to stay within FTOW limits.

Expert note: Tow-bar-less tractors can generate high side loads while turning because the nose wheels are lifted; CS-25.509’s 30° and 45° side-load cases ensure gear forks, steering actuators, and fuselage frames survive these manoeuvres.

Air Canada A320 YUL 2020: Push-back on icy ramp led to tractor slide and sudden aft load; nose gear trunnion cracked, grounding the aircraft. Investigation cited inadequate tolerance to aft towing loads that CS-25.509 explicitly quantifies.

Expert note: During certification, OEMs perform static pull tests on nose-gear lugs to 0.75 FTOW forward and aft with wheels swivelled, and correlate results with finite-element models—standard best practice to demonstrate compliance with the rule.

section_intent: This rule ensures that the landing-gear structure of large transport aeroplanes can safely carry uneven (unsymmetrical) loads that arise when multi-wheel bogies encounter real-world variations such as burst tyres, unequal tyre pressures, worn tyres, runway crowns or the see-saw action of truck-type gears. CS-25.511 obliges designers to analyse how these imbalances redistribute vertical, drag and side loads during landing, taxiing, ground handling and towing, and to prove that the gear, its attachments and surrounding structure will not fail even with one or two tyres deflated. By prescribing specific load-reduction factors and worst-case geometry/pressure differences, the rule guarantees structural margins that protect occupants, prevent expensive gear collapses, and allow continued safe ground operation after tyre damage. (CS = Certification Specification; g = acceleration due to gravity).
ai_notes: FedEx MD-11 N526FE (Narita, 2009): touchdown induced a violent see-saw of the 4-wheel bogie; the forward wheels overloaded and the main gear fractured, illustrating why truck-type gears must be checked for transient fore/aft load peaks.

Air France A380 F-HPJE (Los Angeles, 2017): two tyres burst on landing roll yet the gear truck and wing structure remained intact, demonstrating that certification for one-or-two-tyre deflation prevents structural failure and allows safe stop.

Expert note: Operators often dispatch with small pressure differences between paired tyres; the ±5 % inflation margin in the rule captures this everyday variation so certification analyses do not rely on ‘perfect’ maintenance.

Expert note: After hundreds of cycles the inboard tyres of wide-body bogies can wear faster, creating several centimetres of diameter difference; the ⅔-worst-case growth/wear allowance ensures gear beams are sized for this realistic mismatch.

Concorde tyre-burst accident (Paris, 2000): catastrophic consequences showed how a deflated or destroyed tyre can rapidly shift loads; later gear designs use CS-25.511 logic to contain such overloads and keep the gear attached.
Expert note: Many airports have 1.5 % crowned runways; loads on the downhill wheels of a bogie during taxi are calculated with this slope per CS-25.511, guiding placement of stiffeners in gear beams.

British Airways 777 G-VIIO (Johannesburg, 2013): flat tyre discovered after long taxi and towing; maintenance tow at 60 % design towing load caused no damage, validating the rule’s reduced FTOW factors for deflated tyres.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that an aeroplane’s structure and the special fittings provided for maintenance (jack pads) or mooring (tie-down points) are strong enough to carry the loads that occur when the aircraft is lifted on jacks or held on the ground in strong winds. It obliges the designer to define the maximum permissible jack load, to analyse worst-case combinations of aircraft weight and centre of gravity, and to account for both vertical and side loads so the airframe cannot tip, buckle, or be damaged. By requiring specified safety factors (1.33 or 2.0) and wind criteria (65 kt from any direction), CS 25.519 protects ground crews, passengers, and the aircraft itself during routine maintenance, tire changes, and storage in adverse weather.
ai_notes: FedEx MD-11F, Memphis 2006: aircraft fell off wing jacks during gear swing; damage exceeded US$10 M—shows need for structural margins and correct load paths while jacked.
Expert note: Nose-gear jacking can shift CG aft; requirement to analyse most critical CG prevents tail-tip accidents seen on early jet transports during fuel off-load or cabin re-configuration.
Boeing 737-800 EI-EMH, Dublin 2019: incorrect jack positioning led to local skin buckling; illustrates need for clearly defined maximum allowable jack loads and pad locations.

Expert note: Wind-storm tie-down failures after Hurricane Andrew (1992) prompted industry to adopt 65 kt design wind for transport-category tie-downs, preventing aircraft from sliding or overturning on ramp.
Best practice: AMM procedures mandate simultaneous use of three or more tripod jacks and limit wind to <20 kt during jacking—direct consequence of side-load (0.33 × vertical) requirement.

Expert note: Training on ‘red line’ jack pressures and use of load cells addresses common maintenance error of over-pressurising a single jack, a failure mode mitigated by the 2.0 safety factor on pad and local structure.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that, even if an aeroplane ends up in a survivable crash or ditching, the airframe, seats, seat-belts and anything heavy inside stay intact long enough to spare the occupants from fatal decelerations or loose objects and to let them get out quickly. Designers must prove the structure can handle specified crash loads—3 g up, 9 g forward, 3–4 g sideways, 6 g down, 1.5 g aft—with wheels retracted and belts fastened. Heavy items must either be placed where they cannot hurt anyone or be tied down to the same load levels, and nothing may deform in a way that blocks emergency egress. In short: keep people inside the survival space, keep masses from becoming missiles, and keep exits usable after a "minor" crash.
ai_notes: US Airways 1549 ditching (2009): Despite severe water impact, seats and interior fittings remained attached, helping all occupants evacuate—an example of the 9 g/6 g design philosophy at work.
National Air Cargo B747-400 crash, Bagram 2013: Armoured vehicles broke loose, shifted the CG and destroyed control; illustrates why cargo must be restrained to the same inertia loads as seats.
Expert note: Early 1950s Civil Aeronautics Board sled tests showed that typical seat structures failed at 6–8 g forward loads, prompting the 9 g forward requirement now found in CS 25.561.

Continental B737-500 runway excursion, Denver 2008: Cabin furnishings stayed in place and injuries were largely due to fire, highlighting the benefit of proper seat/floor attachment under sideward and downward loads.
United 232 Sioux City 1989: Some seats tore loose and blocked aisles, hampering evacuation; modern designs under CS 25.561/562 require seat rails that do not deform to keep escape paths clear.

Expert note: Certification testing routinely includes dynamic sled tests where seats, galleys, and bulkheads are hit with the specified 9 g forward pulse to verify attachments and prevent secondary impacts.

Industry practice: Galley carts and cabin monuments are fitted with dual-point floor fittings and 1.33× margin of safety because they are removed frequently, aligning with paragraph (c)(2) wear-and-tear provision.

section_intent: CS 25.562 makes sure that every seat, belt and shoulder-harness on a large aeroplane can keep a normally-seated 77 kg occupant alive and able to evacuate after a hard, survivable crash. It forces seats to withstand two short, violent pulses that mimic the vertical and forward impacts seen when an aircraft lands short, overruns or crashes with some yaw. During those pulses the structure must stay attached, belts must stay on the pelvis and shoulders, head and leg loads must stay below scientifically-derived injury limits (HIC≤1000, femur≤2250 lb, spine≤1500 lb), and the seat must not deform so much that it blocks escape. In plain language: even if the fuselage dents and the floor twists, the seat-restraint system must keep the passenger inside a survivable “package”, preventing fatal head, spine and leg injuries and giving them a fighting chance to get out quickly.
ai_notes: Real event: 1983 Air Canada DC-9 Cincinnati overrun—many survivors, but several spinal and head injuries traced to 9 g seats that detached; accident data drove the 16 g seat upgrade later codified as CS 25.562.

Real event: United 232 Sioux City 1989—dynamic yaw and vertical impact showed seats staying attached were key to 184 survivals; sliding off shoulder harnesses and head strikes highlighted need for strap-retention and HIC limits.
Expert note: Misaligned floor-rail requirement reproduces floor tearing and rotation seen when fuselage breaks, ensuring attachment fittings still hold when the real structure is distorted.

Expert note: Modern compliance tests fire a full seat/dummy on a sled at 44 ft/s, 16 g; energy-absorbing seat pans, crushable honeycomb and break-over seat backs are common design solutions to meet lumbar and femur load limits.
Real event: 2005 JetBlue A320 overrun at BUR—aircraft stopped abruptly yet injuries were minor; later investigation credited 16 g seats and intact restraints with preventing serious harm.

Common failure mode: Lap belts riding up onto the abdomen during forward flail caused internal injuries in legacy designs; CS 25.562 demands belt geometry that keeps the belt on the pelvis throughout the pulse.
Best practice: OEM cabin interior layout reviews ensure no hard structure is within head strike zone, or add padded ‘strike faces’, so certification sled tests consistently achieve HIC<1000.
Expert note: Training for cabin crew now includes post-crash rapid-release of stuck buckles or deformed seat tracks, recognizing the rule’s goal that seat damage must not obstruct evacuation.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that any structural features added to help an aeroplane stay afloat during an emergency water landing (ditching)—such as reinforced fuselage skins, cabin floor beams, or special sealing around doors—are themselves strong enough to survive the initial water impact loads without collapsing. In plain English: if you advertise that the aircraft can float and let people evacuate, the parts meant to keep it watertight and upright must not break when the aircraft first hits the water.
ai_notes: US Airways Flight 1549 (A320, 2009): Intact fuselage and floor structure let occupants remain seated and evacuate onto wings and slides/rafts; shows why ditching-strength evaluation of lower fuselage and floor beams matters.
Ethiopian Airlines Flight 961 (B767, 1996): Fuselage fractured at impact causing rapid flooding and fatalities; illustrates what happens when structural loads exceed ditching strength assumptions.

Expert note: Common compliance practice is to run finite-element ditching analyses followed by drop-test or validated hydro-impact pulses on critical frames to prove the floor, seat rails, and skin panels can carry water slap loads defined in AC 25.801-1B.

Expert note: Reinforcing fuselage break-in points (e.g., cargo doors, service doors) and adding local doublers around drain valves are standard industry measures to prevent tear-out and uncontrolled flooding during ditching.

Expert note: Certification reviews also check that emergency rafts and slide/raft attachment points are tied into primary structure strong enough to handle combined water impact and evacuation loads, preventing loss of life-saving equipment.

section_intent: This rule makes designers prove that every critical piece of a large aeroplane can tolerate cracks, corrosion, accidental dings or bird-strikes long enough for the crew to discover and fix the problem, or that it is replaced before failure.  By combining analysis, full-scale fatigue testing, realistic load spectra and mandatory inspection or replacement intervals (recorded in the Airworthiness Limitations Section), the rule guards against sudden, catastrophic break-up during the aircraft’s whole operational life.  If damage-tolerant inspection is impractical, a conservative safe-life (retirement) limit is required.  The requirement also forces definition of a Limit of Validity (LOV) and a corrosion-prevention programme so that ageing or environment never erodes the structure’s residual strength below ultimate load capability.  In short, CS 25.571 turns lessons from fatigue and accidental damage into mandatory design, test and maintenance actions that keep passengers safe throughout decades of service.
ai_notes: Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (1988): Lap-joint fatigue, corrosion and missed inspections led to explosive decompression; highlights need for damage-tolerance analysis, LOV and robust inspection thresholds in pressurised fuselages.

De Havilland Comet break-ups (1954): Early jetliner hull failures from cyclic pressurisation drove the industry to introduce full-scale fatigue tests and crack-growth evaluation encapsulated in this rule.
Southwest Airlines Flight 812 (2011): 737 crown-skin tear from multi-site fatigue underlines the requirement to consider widespread fatigue damage and set mandatory CPCP and repetitive inspections.

Japan Airlines Flight 123 (1985): An improper tail-cone repair left an undetected crack that grew over years; demonstrates why manufacturing defects must be assumed and residual strength shown after crack growth.

Expert note: Certification programmes now include a two-life full-scale fatigue test with interim operational limits so no aeroplane can fly beyond half the demonstrated test life until the test is finished and an LOV approved.

Expert note: Single-load-path elements (e.g. main landing-gear drag-brace) often receive safe-life retirement times when internal cracking cannot be economically inspected, fulfilling sub-paragraph (c).

JetBlue A320 bird-strike to leading edge (2019): Aircraft completed flight after structural hit, illustrating discrete-source damage tolerance—structure must still carry ultimate loads so crew can land safely.

Expert note: Operators must embed Corrosion Prevention and Control Programmes (CPCP) in their maintenance schedules—routine inspections, cleaning and protective coatings combat the environmental deterioration explicitly cited in CS 25.571.

section_intent: The rule makes sure an aeroplane can take a direct lightning strike yet keep everyone safe. All metallic parts must be electrically tied together and to the structure, and non-metallic (composite or plastic) parts must either carry the current safely or have built-in paths that do. The goal is to give the lightning an easy, low-resistance route out of the aircraft so it cannot blow up a fuel tank, melt flight-critical parts, or fry avionics and controls.
ai_notes: Pan Am Flight 214 (1963 B-707): a wing-tank explosion triggered by lightning killed 81; the tragedy led directly to today’s bonding and fuel-tank protection standards captured in CS 25.581.
Expert note: Compliance testing uses 200 kA high-current shots on wing and fuselage panels per SAE ARP 5416 to prove no arcing occurs inside fuel tanks or systems zones.
Boeing 787 example: carbon-fibre skin is overlaid with copper mesh and all joints have bonding straps so strike current exits via wingtips without damaging the composite structure.
Expert note: Maintenance manuals set a <2.5 mΩ limit for hinge-line bonding jumpers; mechanics measure this at heavy checks to guarantee a continuous current path across moving surfaces.
A320 radome events (1990s–2000s): repeated lightning damage led to embedded strike strips and diverter bars, preventing loss of the weather-radar antenna and meeting CS 25.581 intent.
Expert note: Designers create aircraft lightning zones (1A, 1B, 2A, 2B, 3) and verify wiring transient immunity so a strike in Zone 1 cannot induce destructive voltages in critical avionics.

Saab 340 incident 2012: avionics failures traced to a missing bonding braid after repair; the event reinforced that maintenance errors can defeat lightning-protection assumptions and must be rigorously checked.

section_intent: CS 25.601 exists to keep unproven or suspect design features out of large aeroplanes. If past service experience, accident investigations, or engineering data indicate that a particular part, material, geometry, or system has caused hazards or been unreliable, it must not be accepted as-is. The applicant has to demonstrate—usually through targeted ground or flight tests—that any such “questionable” detail is safe and dependable under all expected operating conditions. In plain terms: no novel, exotic, or previously troublesome design element gets a free pass; it must be proven safe before passengers fly.
ai_notes: De Havilland Comet I accidents (1954): Square window corners caused fatigue cracking; the wrecks proved that seemingly minor design details can be lethally hazardous, prompting the rule’s focus on eliminating proven-dangerous features.

Boeing 737 classic rudder PCU anomaly (United 585 & USAir 427): A subtle servo-valve design flaw led to uncommanded rudder deflection; illustrates why designs with unexplained anomalies must undergo additional reliability testing before further certification.

Lockheed Electra wing-flutter break-ups (1960): Unanticipated propeller-engine mount whirl flutter revealed that new engine installation details can be inherently unsafe unless validated by structural and vibration tests.

Expert note: Certification teams routinely demand full-scale component tests for novel composite structures (e.g., window frames, wing spars) because traditional metal fatigue data do not apply, directly reflecting the rule’s requirement to prove questionable details by test.

Airbus A380 early wing-rib foot cracking (2008): In-service findings showed a specific bracket geometry was unreliable; corrective testing and redesign aligned with CS 25.601’s intent to remove features that experience flags as weak.

Learjet 35 windshield heater fires (1996–2003 incidents): Recurrent arcing highlighted an unsafe wiring/terminal design; enforced redesign and qualification testing demonstrate how the rule mitigates known hazards.

Expert note: Industry best practice now mandates bird-strike and hail-impact tests on composite radomes and leading edges because past service showed certain lay-ups delaminated catastrophically; CS 25.601 underpins this test-based clearance.

section_intent: CS 25.603 makes sure that every material used in parts whose failure could hurt people or the aircraft is proven to be strong and long-lasting. The rule demands three things: (1) evidence – through past experience or specific tests – that the material can do its job; (2) conformity – only batches that meet an approved specification may be installed so the designer’s strength figures remain valid; and (3) durability – designers must show the material keeps those properties under all temperatures, humidity levels, chemicals, UV, or other environmental conditions the aeroplane will face in service. In short, it prevents surprises caused by unknown, badly made, or environmentally degraded materials.
ai_notes: Comet I (1954) – cabin-window corner cracking and catastrophic metal-fatigue revealed that aluminum alloys must be fully tested under pressurisation loads before service.
Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (1988) – salt-air corrosion and fatigue in lap-joints highlighted the need to consider long-term humidity and chemical exposure when qualifying materials.
Expert note: Early 707 landing-gear lug failures from stress-corrosion cracking drove tighter heat-treatment specs and toughness tests for high-strength steels.
American Airlines 587 (2001) – loss of A300 composite fin led to industry-wide programmes verifying composite coupons, elements and full-scale articles for strength knock-downs and moisture ageing.
Expert note: Receiving-inspection now requires traceable material certificates and lot-control so only alloy tempers matching the approved specification enter production.
Boeing 777 centre-wing-box composites undergo hot/wet conditioning to prove laminate strength does not fall below design allowables over life, meeting paragraph (c).
United Airlines DC-10 cargo-door blow-out (1974) exposed sensitivity of latch-beam materials to manufacturing variation; conformity checks were tightened.
Expert note: Acrylic cabin windows are craze-tested under UV, solvent wipes and temperature cycling to ensure long-term transparency and strength.
Magnesium cabin seats used in WWII caught fire; modern rules forbid flammable alloys, illustrating suitability and durability requirements.
Expert note: Salt-fog, thermal-shock and fluid-contamination tests per ASTM and MIL standards are routine to demonstrate corrosion and temperature resistance before certification.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that the way every aircraft part is manufactured and assembled consistently gives it the strength, durability, and other properties the design needs. If a process—such as heat-treating, bonding, composite lay-up, welding, or additive manufacturing—only works safely when it is done under very specific conditions, those conditions have to be captured in approved process and material specifications and tightly controlled on the shop floor. Any brand-new or novel fabrication method must first be proven by a test programme that mirrors how the part will really be used in the airplane, so regulators know it will perform safely in service.
ai_notes: Case: United 232 (1989) – A titanium fan-disk with an undetected melt inclusion from inadequate process control fractured in flight; the accident underlined the need for strict material and process specs for critical forgings.

Case: Aloha 243 (1988) – Poorly bonded fuselage lap-joint cold-bond process and inadequate process surveillance contributed to widespread fatigue cracking, illustrating why bonding steps require qualified procedures and coupons.

Case: Southwest 2294 (2009) – Skin panel manufactured with an incorrect chem-mill step led to early cracking; highlights the rule’s intent to control each fabrication stage that affects residual strength.
Expert note: Autoclave curing of carbon-fibre structures is run to approved temperature/pressure profiles with witness coupons from each batch to confirm properties meet design allowables.

Expert note: When airlines request additive-manufactured cabin brackets, OEMs run a material allowables test programme (e.g., ASTM F42 staircase coupons) before the first article is accepted under CS 25.605(b).

Expert note: Friction-stir-welded aluminium–lithium fuselage panels are qualified through a dedicated test matrix (tension, fatigue, corrosion) because the weld microstructure differs from conventional riveting.
Expert note: AS9100/AS9102 First-Article Inspection and frozen-process plans embody the "close control" philosophy demanded by CS 25.605 for critical fabrication steps.

section_intent: The rule ensures that any bolt, screw, nut, pin or other removable fastener whose loss could jeopardise structural integrity or flight-control authority cannot work loose in service. It mandates two independent locking features (e.g., castellated nut with cotter pin, lock-wire plus self-locking nut) so that if one fails the second still holds the part. Locking devices must keep their effectiveness under vibration, temperature extremes, fluids, and loads specific to the installation, and friction-type locknuts alone are not allowed on joints that rotate during operation. In plain terms, it is a belt-and-suspenders requirement to stop a single loose fastener from causing an accident.
ai_notes: Case: Continental Express Flight 2574 (EMB-120, 1991) – 47 screws were not reinstalled on a horizontal-stabiliser panel; it detached in flight and the aircraft broke up. The accident highlighted how missing fasteners on critical surfaces can be fatal and drove stricter locking and inspection rules.

Case: Rex SAAB 340 VH-NRX (Sydney, 2017) – An elevator control-rod bolt lost its nut because the cotter pin was omitted; crew retained limited pitch control and landed. Demonstrated the value of dual retention on flight-control bolts.

Case: American Airlines Flight 191 (DC-10, 1979) – Improper re-installation of engine-pylon attachment bolts led to bolt failure and engine separation on take-off, causing loss of the aircraft. Showed the catastrophic consequences of inadequate locking and inspection of critical bolts.

Expert note: High vibration and thermal cycling can back off plain or single-lock nuts in a few flights; industry therefore pairs castellated nuts with cotter pins or applies safety wire to engine mounts, flap drive hinges and control linkages.

Expert note: Compliance tests immerse bolted joints in Skydrol, fuel and de-icing fluids, then cycle temperatures from –55 °C to +70 °C while vibrating; torque checks afterwards verify that locking devices still meet CS 25.607(b).

Expert note: Designers avoid relying solely on all-metal self-locking nuts on rotating hinge bolts; they add a drilled-head bolt and lock-wire or cotter pin to satisfy CS 25.607(c) and prevent loosening during operation.

Case: Bombardier Q400 landing-gear failures (2007) – Corrosion and loosening of actuator-attachment bolts lacking effective secondary locks caused nose-gear collapse events, underscoring the need for locking systems that tolerate environmental degradation.

section_intent: CS-25.609 requires designers to build in permanent protection so that rain, salt, temperature swings, cargo spills, sand, or rubbing parts cannot secretly eat away at an airliner’s load-bearing structure. In plain terms, every spar, skin panel and fitting must keep the strength assumed in the stress analysis for the whole service life by resisting weathering, corrosion and abrasion, and by letting moisture drain and air circulate so it never becomes a hidden rust trap. The rule therefore shifts the focus from repairing damage after it appears to preventing degradation in the first place, ensuring that structural safety margins remain intact between scheduled inspections.
ai_notes: Aloha Airlines Flt 243 (1988): Multiple undetected corrosion-assisted cracks in lap joints led to a mid-air fuselage rupture, showing why moisture drainage and corrosion-resistant design are critical.
Chalk’s Ocean Airways Flt 101 (2005): Wing separated after long-term corrosion and exfoliation in a salt-water environment, illustrating the need for protective coatings and drainage on seaplanes.

Southwest Airlines Flt 812 (2011): Rapid decompression from fatigue cracks initiated at chemically milled skin step; poor sealant condition allowed moisture ingress, underlining combined abrasion-corrosion threats.
Expert note: Manufacturers now specify bonded primers, chromate-free topcoats, and removable abrasion-resistant tapes on high-traffic wing walks to stop paint loss and bare-metal wear.
Expert note: Drain holes with flapper valves in rudder, elevator and aileron bays prevent water pooling that can freeze, corrode spars, or unbalance control surfaces.

Expert note: Corrosion Prevention and Control Programs (CPCP) mandate periodic inspections, but CS-25.609 drives the upstream design choices—use of titanium fasteners, alclad skins, and isolation washers—to minimise dependence on maintenance alone.

China Airlines Flt 611 (2002): An improperly sealed doubler allowed moisture to creep into the repaired tail skin; progressive corrosion and cracking culminated in in-flight break-up, reinforcing the rule’s emphasis on lasting repair protection.

section_intent: The rule requires designers to build in practical ways for maintenance crews to reach, inspect, adjust, lubricate, and replace aircraft parts—especially primary structure, flight-control systems, and wiring—at the intervals needed to keep the airplane airworthy. If physical access for a direct visual check is impossible, the design must accommodate proven non-destructive inspection (NDI) methods and list the procedures in the maintenance manual. Electrical Wiring Interconnection Systems (EWIS) must also be laid out so that technicians can readily examine and service them in accordance with CS-25.1719. In short, the aircraft must be maintainable as well as flyable, ensuring hidden deterioration is detected before it becomes a hazard.
ai_notes: Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (1988): Fuselage lap-joint fatigue cracks went undetected partly because riveted joints were difficult to examine; the explosive decompression drove home the need for guaranteed inspection access to principal structural elements.

Expert note: Modern wing spars often have removable access panels and built-in borescope ports so technicians can inspect critical fastener holes without extensive disassembly, directly addressing CS 25.611(a).

Southwest Airlines 737 skin-crack AD (2008): Operators had to cut new inspection holes in the crown skin because original design offered insufficient access, illustrating how poor accessibility leads to costly retrofits and safety action.

Expert note: Flight-control cable runs are installed with stringer-mounted pulleys and quick-release fairings so the entire cable can be visually checked for wear within the scheduled maintenance window.

Swissair Flight 111 (1998): In-flight fire traced to wiring bundles behind panels that were hard to see and maintain; subsequent rulemaking stressed CS 25.1719 accessibility for EWIS and better wire-bundle routing.

Expert note: Operators use phased-array ultrasonic probes through fuel-tank service openings to detect hidden wing-skin corrosion, a compliant NDI alternative when direct line-of-sight inspection is impractical.

Eastern Air Lines L-1011 crash, Everglades (1972): Elevator control-cable failure highlighted the necessity for routine, easy cable inspection and lubrication, leading to design changes such as hinged floor panels over cable runs.

section_intent: Ensure that every structural material used in a large aeroplane is supported by statistically proven strength data so designers can confidently predict how strong each part really is, even after accounting for natural variability, temperature, moisture or other environmental effects.  For parts that carry the whole load alone (single-load-path), the rule demands very conservative ‘A-basis’ values (99 % of pieces will be stronger than this with 95 % confidence); for redundant structures a less conservative ‘B-basis’ (90 % / 95 %) is allowed.  The goal is to minimise the chance that an unexpectedly weak piece of metal or composite causes structural failure in service, while still permitting higher values if every individual part is tested (‘premium selection’) or if EASA specifically approves another basis.
ai_notes: Expert note: Industry uses MIL-HDBK-5 / MMPDS tables derived from thousands of coupon tests to generate A-basis and B-basis values that satisfy the 99/95 and 90/95 statistical requirements in CS 25.613.

Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (1988) – Fuselage skin and lap-joint failed after years of corrosion and fatigue exacerbated by Hawaii’s humid, salty environment, illustrating why CS 25.613(c) requires material properties to account for moisture and temperature effects.

Southwest Airlines Flight 1380 (2018) – Fan blade with subsurface manufacturing anomaly fractured; although an engine part, the incident reinforces the need for tight statistical control and individual inspections (‘premium selection’) when critical components cannot tolerate a single failure.

Expert note: Composite wing boxes on modern airliners are qualified using Elevated Temperature/Wet (ETW) coupon testing to establish knock-down factors so that design values remain valid at the highest temperature and humidity the aircraft might see.

de Havilland Comet in-flight break-ups (1954) – Early jet failures traced to metal fatigue and insufficient understanding of material behaviour, prompting industry-wide adoption of rigorous statistical property determination embodied today in CS 25.613.

Expert note: Landing-gear manufacturers often specify ‘premium-clean’ vacuum-melted steels or titanium and perform ultrasonic inspection of every forging; this meets sub-paragraph (e) by proving each individual item achieves or exceeds the design strength.

section_intent: CS 25.619 requires extra margins—or alternative safeguards—whenever the basic design safety factor may not be enough because the real strength of a part is uncertain, prone to in-service degradation, or highly variable due to production or inspection limits. In plain terms, if we cannot be fully sure how strong a component will stay during its life, the rule forces applicants either to add additional "special" factors of safety or to take other proven actions (enhanced tests, tighter process controls, improved inspection) so the structure will still meet all loads throughout service. This ensures hidden weaknesses, ageing effects, or manufacturing scatter cannot compromise the aircraft’s structural integrity.
ai_notes: Aloha Airlines Flt 243 (1988): Multi-site fatigue and corrosion in lap-joint tear led to explosive decompression; shows why extra factors or stringent inspections are mandated where service deterioration is expected.
