de Havilland Comet failures (1953-54): Unknown stress concentrations around window corners revealed analytical uncertainty; drove industry to apply higher safety factors and exhaustive testing when behaviour is not fully understood.
Southwest Flt 812 (2011): Crown skin crack traced to manufacturing-induced machining variance; illustrates variability in production that CS 25.619 aims to cushion with special factors.

Expert note: Bond‐line quality in composite primary structures can vary with cure cycle and surface prep; programmes routinely apply knock-down factors derived from coupon/element tests to satisfy this rule.
Expert note: Forged landing-gear components receive additional safety factors because grain flow or inclusion content can differ between heats despite specification compliance.
Expert note: Engine pylon fittings often use higher factors plus 100 % NDT after past incidents of undetected machining gouges causing early cracking.

Industry practice: Ageing-aircraft programmes incorporate corrosion-allowance factors and periodic teardown tests to validate that structural strength does not fall below design after years in service.

Expert note: Where special factors alone seem inadequate—e.g., adhesive joints in high-temperature zones—EASA frequently requires full-scale fatigue and damage-tolerance tests as the "other appropriate measures" referenced in the rule.

section_intent: CS 25.621 makes sure any cast metal part that carries structural loads in a large airplane is as reliable as a wrought or forged part. Because castings can hide voids, porosity, inclusions, or cold-shuts that are invisible from the outside, the rule couples mandatory non-destructive inspection, foundry process control, coupon testing, and proof-load tests with "casting factors"—extra strength margins applied in design. The more evidence an applicant provides that every production casting meets tight, wrought-like material variability and is thoroughly inspected, the smaller the casting factor that must be used (down to 1.0). If less inspection or process data are available, larger factors—up to 2.0—are imposed to keep safety margins intact. Critical castings, whose failure could jeopardize safe flight or occupants, face the toughest combination of 100 % surface and radiographic inspection plus static testing. In short, the rule prevents hidden casting defects from undermining structural integrity throughout the airplane’s life.
ai_notes: Boeing 727 elevator hinge support: In 1979 a cast aluminium support fractured in flight, leading to partial elevator loss; FAA AD 80-08-03 mandated 100 % NDI of similar castings, highlighting the need for CS 25.621-style inspection and factors.

DC-9/MD-80 landing-gear side-brace fittings: Repeated in-service cracks caused AD 90-26-07, demonstrating how hidden porosity in gear castings can threaten safe landings and why larger casting factors or full radiography are required.
Expert note: Hidden shrinkage cavities can reduce static strength by 20-40 %; applying a 1.25–2.0 casting factor compensates for defects that may evade even diligent inspection.
Expert note: 100 % radiographic or CT scanning of critical areas is now standard industry practice, directly implementing CS 25.621’s requirement for internal inspection of every critical casting.
Expert note: Foundry process qualification with prolongation coupons from each pour allows applicants to prove wrought-equivalent variability and justify a casting factor of 1.0.

Expert note: During Airbus A350 main-gear fitting design, engineers chose forgings over castings to avoid the extra weight penalty of mandatory casting factors—illustrating how CS 25.621 influences material and process selection.

Expert note: Airlines invest in specialised NDT training for penetrant and radiographic inspection of pylon and landing-gear castings because CS 25.621 mandates 100 % surface inspection on every part.

section_intent: This rule ensures that any joint, fitting, or bearing surface where parts can move slightly against each other (because a free-fit clearance exists) is designed with an extra safety margin so it will not wear, fret, or pound itself to failure under normal vibration and operational loads. In plain terms, if two parts can rattle or hammer together, the designer must assume higher local stresses in the bearing area and size the material or fastener accordingly—unless another, even larger "special factor" has already been mandated elsewhere. The goal is to prevent hidden wear, bolt-hole elongation, and eventual structural or control-system failures caused by repeated small movements.
ai_notes: Electra 188 wing-root bolt‐hole elongation (1959): Propeller-whirl vibration led to pounding of wing splice bolts; enlarged holes reduced load path and contributed to two in-flight break-ups, highlighting need for generous bearing margins.
Expert note: Control-surface hinge brackets are routinely designed with a bearing factor ≥2 to stop short-term wear that could create flutter-inducing free play during service.
B737 rudder PCU input rod incident (1999): Fretting in the rod-end bearings from vibration compromised load capability, demonstrating why clearance joints must carry added bearing strength.
Expert note: Industry fatigue tests often include intentional bolt looseness to verify that shear ties and splice plates sized with CS-25.623 factors do not ovalise after millions of cycles.

Aloha Airlines 243 (1988): Extensive rivet fretting and skin lap-joint wear from cabin-pressure cycling illustrated how small relative motions, if not properly factored for bearing, accelerate crack growth.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that every bracket, lug, clevis, seat-track stud or similar “fitting” that joins two structural parts is strong enough even when we do not have full‐scale test proof. Unless that exact joint has been physically tested to both limit (100 %) and ultimate (150 %) loads with realistic stresses, the designer must add a 1.15 multiplication factor to the calculated loads on the fitting, its fasteners and the bearing areas. This extra 15 % margin compensates for the uncertainties that arise from complex load paths, manufacturing tolerances, installation errors, and analytical simplifications. The rule also recognises situations where the margin is not needed (e.g. fully-tested continuous welds, scarf joints, or when a larger special factor already exists) and clarifies that integral lugs and occupant-restraint fittings follow the same philosophy. In plain terms: when you bolt, rivet, cast or machine two parts together, you must prove—by test or by added strength margin—that the joint will not be the weak link.
ai_notes: Real event: In 1959 a prototype Sud Aviation Caravelle suffered flap-track failure during ground load testing because the bolted fitting’s bearing stress had been under-predicted; the subsequent 1.15 fitting factor became an international norm for joints not individually proof-tested.

Expert note: During Boeing 727 certification, unexpected stress concentrations in the wing-to-body lug were found only after strain-gauged ground tests; today the fitting factor guards against such analysis shortfalls when full-scale tests are not repeated for every derivative.

Real event: Air Transat A310 (2005) rudder loss showed that composite hinge-line fittings can degrade from moisture ingress; applying the fitting factor to the bearing and attachment hardware ensures residual strength until damage is detected.

Expert note: Dynamic sled tests frequently reveal seat-belt anchorage pull-out when designers forget the 1.15 factor on seat-track studs; cabin interior TSOs now explicitly reference CS-25.625 to stop this recurrent error.

Common practice: Wing rib, landing-gear and engine-pylon joints are typically justified by detailed finite-element analysis followed by coupon/coupon-to-structure correlation; if the full joint is not loaded to ultimate in the iron-bird test, engineers apply the 1.15 factor to bolts, lugs and shear clips.

Common failure mode: Casting porosity or mis-aligned fastener holes can reduce local bearing strength; the rule’s extra margin absorbs these manufacturing variances when every individual fitting cannot be proof-loaded.

Best practice: Many OEMs waive the 1.15 factor only after a dedicated component test—e.g. pylon-to-wing splice loaded to 150 % load with strain survey—thereby satisfying CS-25.625(a) and allowing lighter but demonstrably safe joints.

section_intent: This rule makes sure a large aeroplane will not suffer flutter, control reversal, divergence, or any other aero-elastic instability that could rapidly destroy the structure or remove pilot control. Designers must prove, by analysis and flight test, that adequate damping and stiffness exist across the whole speed/altitude envelope—including 15 % beyond the certified dive speed—and still hold after likely failures such as a feathered propeller, a broken engine mount, or the loss of hydraulic stiffness in a fly-by-wire surface. Propellers and other rotating machines must be included because their gyroscopic forces can trigger “whirl” flutter. Balance weights, dampers, and the supporting structure have to be strong enough to stay effective. In short, CS 25.629 demands that an aeroplane remain structurally sound and controllable, even with specified malfunctions, from take-off to the highest dive speed, so in-flight break-up or sudden loss of control cannot occur.
ai_notes: Braniff Flight 542 (1959) and Northwest Flight 710 (1960): both L-188 Electras broke up in flight after propeller-induced whirl-flutter; the investigations led regulators to mandate explicit whirl-mode analysis now captured in CS 25.629(a).

Expert note: Ground Vibration Testing before first flight is an industry standard to validate analytical flutter models; CS 25.629 requires this correlation so flight testing starts only when predicted damping margins are adequate.

Boeing 747 flight-test programme (1969) detected marginal flutter near VDF; adding small wing-tip fairings restored the 15 % margin, illustrating how design tweaks are used to meet the rule’s envelope expansion requirement.

Embraer 170 certification (2002): an aileron mass-balance bracket cracked during trials, reducing damping; redesign of the weight and its attachment demonstrated compliance with CS 25.629(c) on balance-weight effectiveness.

Expert note: Operators train test pilots to excite control surfaces with quick pulses while approaching VDF/MDF; telemetry monitors damping ratios in real time to satisfy CS 25.629(e) that no rapid loss of stability occurs as dive speed is approached.

Expert note: Dual-hydraulic failures are analysed because loss of actuator stiffness can couple with flexible wings and create flutter; modern fly-by-wire jets include ‘gust suppression’ or modal damping logic to ensure stability under CS 25.629(d)(9).

ATR-72 icing event (Roselawn, 1994) showed that ice accretion can shift natural frequencies; CS 25.629(d)(3) requires designers to analyse maximum likely ice shapes so flutter margins remain acceptable even when inadvertent icing occurs.

section_intent: To ensure that a transport-category airplane remains controllable and capable of a normal landing after colliding with a medium-sized bird, the rule demands that critical structures (windshields, radome, leading edges, control surfaces, system lines, etc.) withstand the impact of a 4-pound (≈1.8 kg) bird at typical cruising speed near sea level (VC) or slightly reduced speed at 8 000 ft. The intent is to prevent catastrophic structural failure, loss of pressurization, or disabling of essential flight controls and systems. Demonstrating compliance generally requires firing bird-simulating projectiles at representative test articles; purely analytical substantiation is allowed only if validated by such tests. In short, CS 25.631 protects the aircraft and its occupants from an ever-present wildlife hazard so that a single bird strike does not escalate into an accident.
ai_notes: Eastern Air Lines Flight 375 (1960): A flock of starlings caused multiple engine failures and loss of control on a Lockheed Electra, highlighting that bird impacts can rapidly escalate into fatal accidents and driving early bird-strike regulations.

US Airways Flight 1549 (2009): Dual-engine loss from Canada-geese ingestion ended in a river ditching; although engines were the focus, the intact windshield and flight controls allowed the crew to maintain control, illustrating why the airframe itself must survive bird impacts.

Expert note: Certification fatigue tests routinely launch 4-lb gelatin 'chickens' from pneumatic guns at windshields, radomes, and leading edges to verify that no penetration, large deformation, or system damage compromises continued safe flight.

Expert note: Radomes are often built with energy-absorbing composite sandwich panels and backed by fail-safe frames so that a bird strike does not shatter the nose structure or damage weather-radar antennas critical for flight in IMC.
Expert note: Hydraulic and flight-control lines are routed behind spars or protected by armor in the wing leading edge to prevent a single bird hit from severing multiple redundant systems.

Industry best practice: Multi-layer stretched-acrylic cockpit windows incorporate a deformable inner ply that contains fragments and maintains pressure integrity after bird impact, preserving pilot visibility and cabin pressurization.

Expert note: Many operators include bird-strike scenarios in recurrent simulator training, emphasizing immediate control checks and system status assessments to exploit the survivability that CS 25.631 is intended to guarantee.

section_intent: Ensure that every movable control surface—ailerons, elevators, rudder, tabs—and the horns, hinges and fittings that connect them to the control system can withstand the maximum aerodynamic and maneuver loads expected in service without permanent deformation or failure. Mandatory ground proof-load tests (or validated analyses) of the complete surface, including critical joints and materials with higher uncertainty, verify structural strength and stiffness before flight, preventing in-flight separation, flutter initiation or loss of controllability.
ai_notes: BAC One-Eleven prototype crash (1963): elevator flutter led to structural break-up, highlighting the need to test full surface–horn assemblies to limit load and stiffness requirements.
American Airlines 587 (2001): rudder inputs overloaded the vertical-tail lugs; the inquiry reinforced attention on attachment fittings during limit-load proof tests.
Q400 aileron hinge cracking (2008 service bulletins): in-service fatigue found at hinge brackets prompted additional local proof-load tests and redesign to meet CS 25.657 factors.

Expert note: Certification programmes place the entire elevator in a whiffletree rig and load it to 100 % limit and 150 % ultimate, strain-gauging horns and hinge pins to confirm no yielding or pull-through.

Expert note: For composite rudders, engineers apply knock-down factors from CS 25.619-625, validate them with coupon tests, then run finite-element analysis to show hinge-line margins before optional subcomponent testing.

Expert note: MSG-3 maintenance tasks mandate repetitive inspections of control-surface horns and bearings, recognising that corrosion or wear can undermine the strength margins proven in initial tests.

section_intent: CS 25.655 makes sure that movable tail components—elevators, rudder, trimmable horizontal stabiliser, etc.—cannot hit or jam each other and cannot move so far that the aeroplane can no longer be safely trimmed. By demanding physical clearance in worst-case positions and requiring positive stops on an adjustable stabiliser, the rule prevents control-surface interference, loss of control authority, structural over-load and trim runaways that pilots could be unable to counter. In plain terms, it guarantees that every possible combination of tail-surface movements remains both collision-free and within the safe, proven flight-test envelope.
ai_notes: JT610 & ET302 (B737-8 MAX): Runaway nose-down trim showed how powerful a trimmable stabiliser can be; mechanical stops prevented it from going beyond its certificated range—exactly what 25.655(b) mandates.

Expert note: During many certification flight tests, engineers install ‘travel boards’ and run each tail surface to full deflection while others are held at limits to verify the gap and prevent elevator-rudder or elevator-stabiliser contact, directly satisfying 25.655(a).

BAC 1-11 G-ASHG deep-stall accident (1963): Stabiliser set at extreme nose-up left the aircraft unrecoverable; later designs incorporated stricter stabiliser travel limits and warning cues, illustrating the intent of 25.655(b).

Expert note: Operators rigidly check rigging clearances after heavy maintenance; mis-rigged elevator tabs that can clip the rudder have caused control jams on ferry flights, highlighting the need for the interference-free installation demanded in 25.655(a).

Embraer ERJ-145 SB 145-55-0037: Service bulletin added stronger stabiliser end-stops after field reports of trim jackscrew over-travel during maintenance, an industry fix directly reflecting 25.655(b)’s stop requirement.

section_intent: This rule ensures that every hinge and bearing supporting a movable flight-control surface (e.g., ailerons, elevators, rudder, flaps) is strong, stiff, and durable enough so its rated load is never exceeded and it will not deform, seize, or fracture under any combination of aerodynamic or operational forces. By mandating proven load ratings (or conservative safety margins of 6.67 when data are lacking) and adequate strength for loads acting along the hinge line, the requirement prevents loss of control, flutter, or detachment of the surface throughout the aircraft’s service life.
ai_notes: BAC One-Eleven Prototype, 1963 – Elevator flutter during dive testing caused structural breakup; post-accident analysis linked inadequate hinge line stiffness to control-surface oscillations, prompting tighter hinge-strength language in early standards.
Expert note: Bearing play or wear can develop in service; the 6.67 safety factor ensures that even with in-service degradation or marginal lubrication the hinge retains adequate load capacity.

Boeing flutter clearance practice – Manufacturers perform ground vibration tests and mass-balanced hinge assessments to verify that hinge rigidity meets CS-25.657 so aeroelastic modes stay safely above V D.

Expert note: Corrosion in self-lubricating bearings was found during Extended Service Goal (ESG) inspections on legacy 737 elevators; compliance action replaced bearings with higher-rated units in accordance with CS-25.657 philosophy.

Embraer fleet maintenance manuals require periodic free-play checks on flap and aileron hinges; exceeding limits triggers bearing replacement, directly addressing the wear-induced strength loss the rule targets.

section_intent: Flight-control systems must remain manageable, predictable and fail-tolerant in every attitude and phase of flight. They have to be built so they cannot be wrongly assembled, and the aircraft must still be capable of safe flight and landing after any single failure, any likely combination of failures, or a physical jam of a surface or cockpit control. Even with all engines inoperative, the crew must retain enough authority to glide, approach, flare and stop or ditch the aircraft. Pilots must also be warned when they are close to running out of control travel, or when an alternate control mode alters normal handling. In short, CS 25.671 ensures that no single mistake, malfunction or jam deprives the crew of the ability to keep the aeroplane under control and bring everyone safely back to earth.
ai_notes: United Airlines Flight 232 (DC-10, 1989): After a fan-disk burst disabled all three hydraulic systems, differential thrust still allowed limited control and a survivable landing, illustrating the need for residual controllability after severe failures.

US Airways Flight 1549 (A320, 2009): Dual bird-strike caused total power loss, yet intact flight controls enabled glide, flare and successful ditching, embodying § (d)’s all-engines-failed requirement.

Alaska Airlines Flight 261 (MD-83, 2000): Horizontal-stabiliser jackscrew jammed nose-down; inability to counter the jam led to loss of the aircraft, highlighting why jams at any position must be evaluated under § (c)(3).
Expert note: Transport aircraft use three hydraulic systems and multiple actuators per surface so any single failure leaves at least one powered path, directly meeting § (c)(1) and (2).
Expert note: Control rods and cables are keyed, colour-coded and size-differentiated so they cannot be connected wrongly, a design tactic demanded by § (b).
Boeing 777 trim wheel ‘green band’ and Airbus sidestick limit cues alert pilots when near full control travel, satisfying § (e)’s requirement for indication of limited authority.

Expert note: Certification flight tests purposely deactivate hydraulic systems and insert artificial actuator jams to prove the pilot can maintain control with reasonable forces, as required by § (c).
Expert note: Fly-by-wire aircraft generate ECAM/ECIS messages such as “ALTERNATE LAW” to notify crews when handling qualities have degraded, fulfilling § (f) on mode-change alerting.
Embraer ERJ-170 production incident (2002): Cross-connected aileron cables reversed roll inputs; distinctive marking and non-interchangeable fittings now prevent such assembly errors, echoing § (b).
ATR operator training includes asymmetric spoiler or flap jam drills using opposite aileron and rudder, embodying operational best practice for the jam scenarios targeted by § (c)(3).

section_intent: When an aeroplane relies on stability-augmentation, autopilot, yaw-damper, electric-trim or any other powered flight-control aid to satisfy the handling rules of CS-25 (Certification Specification 25), the rules demand that a single malfunction of that aid can never endanger the flight. Pilots must receive an unmistakable warning of any relevant failure; they must be able to override or disconnect the system with normal skill and strength; and, even with the failure present, the aircraft must stay controllable, meet trim and stall-margin requirements, and operate throughout a practical speed/altitude envelope needed to fly home and land safely. In short, automation may assist, but its loss or mis-operation must not create an unsafe condition.
ai_notes: Lion Air 610 / Ethiopian 302 (B-737 MAX): MCAS mis-activation without adequate warning or easy override led to loss of control, underscoring the need for clear alerts and pilot-friendly deactivation paths.

Qantas Flight 72 (A330, 2008): Faulty inertial data drove automatic flight-control computers to command severe nose-down inputs; the crew regained control because the system could be overridden, illustrating the "normal-sense" override requirement.

BAC One-Eleven prototype deep-stall (1963): Loss of pitch authority drove creation of powered stick-pusher systems, and later rules ensured such augmentation can be disconnected or overridden and its failure warned.

Delta Flight 1080 (L-1011, 1977): Yaw-damper hard-over caused large bank; pilots countered with rudder pedals and disconnected the system, showing why CS-25 insists on manageable forces for initial counteraction.

Air France 447 (A330, 2009): When the autopilot dropped off due to unreliable airspeed, the aircraft remained fully controllable manually, demonstrating the requirement that the aeroplane meet handling criteria after automation loss.
Expert note: Industry mandates stab-trim cut-out switches and "runaway trim" memory drills so crews can quickly disable a faulty electric-trim system, directly reflecting CS-25.672(b).

Expert note: Certification flight tests purposely fail one channel of yaw-damper or autoflight systems at high speed and high altitude to prove the aeroplane stays within controllability limits set by CS-25.672(c).
Expert note: Safety assessments (FMEA under CS 25.1309) pair with CS-25.672 to ensure single-point failures of powered flight-control actuators cannot mask themselves or leave the crew uninformed.

section_intent: CS-25.675 exists to make sure every flight-control surface (ailerons, elevators, rudder, spoilers, etc.) can physically move only within the range that was analysed and tested for safe flight. It demands ‘hard’ mechanical stops that: (1) positively cap the travel so pilots, gusts or system failures cannot drive the surface further; (2) are positioned so normal wear, cable stretch or maintenance adjustments cannot quietly shift those limits; and (3) are strong enough to survive the highest loads the surface can see in service or during certification tests. In plain terms: the rule prevents unexpected over-travel that could change handling qualities or overload the structure, thereby preserving predictable, controllable behaviour over the aircraft’s life.
ai_notes: American Airlines Flight 587 (A300-600, 2001) – Rapid alternating rudder inputs drove the rudder from stop to stop; investigators scrutinised the stop strength, underscoring the need for stops that can absorb full design loads without failing (paragraph c).

AD 2014-06-08 on Bombardier CRJ-200 – Airlines had to check elevator up-travel stops after wear let elevators exceed certified angles, a direct example of why stops must be located so that slack or wear cannot increase travel (paragraph b).

Expert note: During certification, manufacturers run hydraulic actuators to push each surface hard against its stops while the airframe is fixed in a jig, proving the stop hardware meets limit and ultimate load requirements of CS-25.675(c).

Expert note: Cable-operated aileron systems typically place the primary stop on the wing hinge rib rather than on the cockpit quadrant, ensuring any cable stretch or rigging adjustment cannot create additional surface travel—good practice for 25.675(b).

Boeing 747-400 F-GITB incident (1997) – Post-maintenance mis-rigging let spoiler panels hit actuator end-stops and jam; the event prompted service bulletins adding redundant structural stops, illustrating paragraph a’s requirement for positive travel limits.

section_intent: CS-25.677 ensures that any device pilots use to "trim" the aircraft—usually the moveable stabiliser or trim tabs that relieve control forces—behaves predictably, cannot be activated accidentally or run away, and always tells the crew exactly where it is. The rule demands (1) intuitive control motion and protection against inadvertent or abrupt inputs, (2) clear, unmistakeable cockpit indications of trim direction and position with a marked ‘safe-for-take-off’ band, and (3) mechanical design features that stop aerodynamic loads from back-driving (creeping) the system or letting the trim surface flutter. In short, the requirement keeps pilots in full situational awareness of trim position while guaranteeing the mechanism itself remains stable, irreversible when needed, and structurally rigid throughout all operating conditions.
ai_notes: Case: Alaska Airlines Flight 261 (MD-83, 2000) – Excessive wear let the horizontal-stabiliser jackscrew back-drive and jam, ending in loss of pitch control; shows why trim systems must be irreversible and free of creep.

Case: Lion Air 610 & Ethiopian 302 (B737-8 MAX, 2018/2019) – Automated MCAS repeatedly applied nose-down trim; dual-switch logic, sense-of-motion conformity, and conspicuous position cues mandated by CS-25.677 aim to prevent or alert crews to such unintended trim commands.

Case: Fine Air Flight 101 (DC-8-61, 1997) – Take-off with stabiliser trim outside the green band led to uncontrollable pitch-up; illustrates the need for clearly marked ‘safe for take-off’ ranges on trim indicators.
Case: Early Boeing 707 trim-tab flutter events – Oscillations prompted adoption of irreversible or mass-balanced tabs, now codified in paragraphs (c) and (d).

Expert note: Modern transports require simultaneous actuation of two guarded thumb switches for electric trim, a design solution expressly intended to block inadvertent or abrupt operation under paragraph (a).
Expert note: Certification tests load the stabiliser to 1.5 × design airloads while verifying no slow back-drive occurs, demonstrating compliance with the anti-creep requirement.
Expert note: Every airline ‘Before Take-off’ checklist includes “Trim – set green band,” a procedural layer derived directly from CS-25.677(b).
Expert note: Rigid push-pull tubes or torque shafts between trim tab and irreversible actuator eliminate free play that could trigger flutter, satisfying paragraph (d).

section_intent: When an aircraft is parked, strong wind gusts can bang the elevators, ailerons or rudder against their stops, bending linkages or cracking skins. CS-25.679 therefore requires a positive “gust-lock” device that holds these surfaces still on the ground, but it must never trap the pilot once flight is attempted. Either the lock has to spring free automatically as soon as normal control forces are applied, or it must make take-off impossible or unmistakably alarming (e.g. throttles cannot go past idle, a loud horn sounds). Finally, the rule demands design features that guarantee the lock cannot re-engage accidentally in the air. AMC (Acceptable Means of Compliance) material gives detailed guidance, but the core intent is simple: protect the airframe on the ground without creating a new hazard of frozen flight controls during take-off or in flight.
ai_notes: Real event – ‘KLM Constellation accidents, late-1940s’: Several L-049/749 Constellations crashed or aborted take-off after crews advanced power with elevator locks still engaged, prompting early CAA directives that became the blueprint for modern gust-lock interlocks.

Real event – U.S. Air Force C-130H (Little Rock AFB, 1980): Crew attempted departure with elevator gust lock partially engaged; aircraft over-rotated and crashed, highlighting need for automatic or throttle-linked disengage systems.

Real event – Beechcraft King Air B200 ZK-LMN (Woodbourne, 2000): Take-off rejected when ailerons frozen by engaged gust lock; investigation cited absence of a power-lever interlock as a latent design vulnerability relevant to CS-25 philosophies.

Expert note: Common failure mode is a lock pin or collar that binds under light control column movement during taxi, giving pilots a false sense of freedom until higher loads arrive on rotation—hence the requirement for an ‘unmistakable warning’.

Expert note: Most large transport aeroplanes now tie the gust-lock handle mechanically to the thrust-levers; you physically cannot advance power beyond about 25 % N1 until the lock is fully off, meeting CS-25.679(a)(2).

Expert note: Certification compliance often includes ground gust-load tests plus flight tests where the lock is deliberately left on during an attempted roll-out to prove that the warning/interlock prevents liftoff, satisfying paragraph (a)(2).

Best practice: Flight crews are trained to perform a ‘full and free’ flight-control check after engine start; this human-factors barrier complements the design requirements of CS-25.679(b) against inadvertent in-flight re-engagement.

section_intent: The rule demands that the mechanical flight-control system—including every cable, rod, pulley, fitting, and bracket—be proven strong enough to carry the highest loads the aircraft is allowed to experience in service ("limit loads"). Tests must apply those loads in the most critical direction so that nothing is missed, and joints that rotate (e.g. rod-end bearings) must be shown to have extra strength margins (“special factors”) because wear or small mis-alignments can greatly weaken them. In plain words: make the whole control train as strong as the worst real-world forces it will ever see, and prove it on the ground before letting people fly.
ai_notes: Expert note: Early certification of the Boeing 707 found that elevator input loads during aft-cg tests bent a quadrant support bracket; CS 25.681’s requirement to include every bracket in worst-direction static tests came out of such findings.

Expert note: Cable pull-testing on the A320 programme revealed that a 90-degree pulley bracket cracked when loads were applied sideways—illustrating why the rule insists on testing in ‘the most severe loading’ direction, not just straight tension.

Japan Airlines B747-SR maintenance experience (JAL fleet bulletin 747-FCS-12): repeated wear of rod-end bearings in spoiler linkages prompted introduction of higher ‘special factors’ for angular-motion joints, directly reflecting CS 25.681(b).

Accident: Air Midwest Flight 5481 (Beech 1900D, 2003) lost pitch control after improper rigging overstressed the elevator control cable, highlighting the need for proven strength and correct attachment of every control-system fitting.

Best practice: Major OEMs now run full-column control-system ‘iron bird’ rigs where limit-load static tests are combined with rigging and wear assessments; this holistic approach directly satisfies and documents compliance with CS 25.681.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that every part of the flight-control system keeps working smoothly when the aircraft structure flexes and when control surfaces are pushed close to their design limits. Designers must prove—by analysis and by loading the controls in ground tests—that even at 80 % of the maximum manual load or the full load expected on powered actuators, the controls will not jam, bind, deflect excessively, disconnect, or suffer damage. They also have to show that vibration in normal flight or on the ground cannot make control parts rub, strike, or interfere with nearby structure. In plain terms: whatever the pilot does and whatever loads the airplane sees in normal manoeuvres, the controls must stay connected, move freely, and keep the pilot in charge.
ai_notes: B-737-200 N756US incident (1978): Elevator jammed after abrupt pull-up; post-event testing showed cable tension changes under structural flex allowed bellcrank contact—highlighting need for load-case operation tests.

Expert note: During certification of the Airbus A350, engineers loaded the wing to limit-load while exercising all cockpit controls to confirm cables did not chafe against bending ribs, a direct compliance demonstration for CS 25.683(b).

ATR-72 EI-SJU crash (Roselawn, 1994) illustrated how control jamming from ice-induced aileron hinge moments can be fatal; rule drives tests for excessive friction so pilots always retain authority even when loads rise sharply.

Expert note: Flight-test programs routinely add ‘control sweep during 1-g wing-bend test’ to verify that large structural deflections do not pinch push-pull tubes—an industry best practice derived from this requirement.

Boeing 777 fatigue-vibration survey (post-1997) found rudder cables could slap against hydraulic lines on rough runways; CS 25.683(c) obliges vibration assessments to prevent such contact becoming a hazard.

section_intent: The rule ensures that every mechanical detail of an aeroplane’s flight-control system is arranged so nothing can snag, rub through, freeze, or otherwise jam the controls. All potential sources of foreign-object debris (FOD)—tools, pens, baggage, ice, loose cabin items—must be kept out of the control runs, and cables or tubes must not whip against structure during turbulence or manoeuvres. In plain terms, CS 25.685 demands that the designer think ahead about everyday airline operations, maintenance, passenger activity, and environmental conditions so that the pilots can always move the controls freely and safely.
ai_notes: Homer, Alaska Beech 1900C (1987): bags shifting in the rear cargo hold jammed elevator cables, causing loss of pitch authority and prompting emphasis on segregating baggage from control runs.

Expert note: Certification tests now include running the controls with washers, safety-wire pieces, and other small parts purposely introduced; screens or tight covers over quadrants proved necessary after multiple test-phase jams.

Boeing 737-200 service difficulty (1981): water froze inside the lower rudder quadrant overnight, locking the pedals; the fix added drainage holes and seals—illustrating the need to guard against moisture freezing.

Cockpit FOD events (numerous GA and airline): dropped headsets, pens or coffee stirrers wedged behind rudder pedals; CS 25.685(b) drives design of pedal wells and control-column boots to block such items.
Expert note: Modern wide-bodies route control cables through low-friction fairleads and install anti-slap dampers so cables cannot beat against hydraulic lines during severe turbulence.
Airbus A320 family practice: removable FOD curtains beneath the pedestal during maintenance prevent screws from falling into the elevator feel unit, satisfying the cockpit protection requirement.
Expert note: Routine line-maintenance "FOD walks" and tool-accountability programs stem directly from the rule’s intent to keep stray objects out of control systems.

section_intent: This rule ensures that the cable-type flight-control system is strong, properly routed, secured, and inspectable so that it always transmits the pilot’s commands without jamming, chafing, or breaking. It sets minimum cable sizes, demands compatible pulleys, guards, fairleads, and fittings, prevents insecure fasteners or binding turnbuckles, limits alignment angles, requires cable tension to stay safe across the full control range and temperature extremes, and obliges designers to give mechanics clear visual access. In plain words: the wires that move the ailerons, elevators, and rudder must be tough enough, stay on their wheels, keep the right tightness in any weather, and be easy to check—so pilots never lose control.
ai_notes: Air Midwest Flight 5481 (Beech 1900D, 2003): Mis-rigged elevator cables and over-tightened turnbuckles reduced pitch authority and caused a fatal stall, highlighting the need for correct tension and simple post-maintenance inspection.
Expert note: Early DC-3 service experience showed 1⁄8-inch aileron cables failing from repeated bending over pulleys, prompting the 3.2 mm minimum diameter now embedded in CS 25.689(a)(1).
Lufthansa B747-400 D-ABTK (2005): Aileron cable jumped off an unguarded pulley and jammed; crew recovered but incident validated the requirement for closely-fitted pulley guards in paragraph (b).

Expert note: Cold-soak tests reveal cable tension can drop by 40 % at –55 °C; designers install automatic tension regulators or set higher rig tensions to meet 25.689(a)(2)’s "no hazardous change" mandate.
Ontario C-47 crash (1945): Clevis pin secured only by a cotter pin vibrated out of the rudder quadrant, forcing today’s prohibition of such pins in transport control systems under paragraph (d).
Cessna service reports show fairleads misaligned >3° sawing through cable jackets; the 3-degree limit in 25.689(c) prevents this progressive wear failure mode.
Expert note: Modern airliners incorporate access panels and use safety-wired MS21251 turnbuckles along every run so inspectors can visually confirm condition and locking, satisfying paragraph (f).

Boeing 737NG maintenance alerts found turnbuckles installed rigidly to bellcranks binding at full deflection; current practice uses spherical rod-end bearings and anti-binding clips, embodying paragraph (e).

section_intent: This rule ensures that every articulating joint in the flight-control linkages is far stronger than the maximum loads it might ever see, even after wear, mis-rig, or corrosion. Push-pull rod systems must carry 3.33 times their limit load because angular motion can create extra bending and point loading on the soft bearing race; cable terminations, which are more tolerant, still need a 2.0 safety factor. If ball or roller bearings are used, designers must stay within the bearing manufacturer’s certified ratings. In plain English: the joint that lets a control rod or cable swivel must never be the weak link, so the pilot cannot lose control because a rod-end cracks, pulls out, or seizes.
ai_notes: Gulfstream 100 elevator push-rod fracture (prompting FAA AD 2005-20-07): a rod-end bearing broke during flight test; the aircraft landed safely but the event showed that bearings sized below the 3.33 factor could fail under normal certification loads.

Beech 1900C N67926 (ATL94LA032) take-off rotation jam: a corroded, seized rod-end overloaded and locked the elevator; large reserve strength prevented complete separation, illustrating why extra margin is mandated until corrosion is found at inspection.

Expert note: Early jet transports in the 1950s experienced cracked clevis lugs on push-pull rods after only a few thousand cycles; industry working groups responded by adopting the 3.33 special factor that later entered JAR/CS-25.693.

Expert note: Certification tests now add deliberate mis-alignment while applying limit control-surface loads; compliance is shown only when the joint still meets the 3.33 (or 2.0) safety factor without permanent set or brinelling.

Industry practice: Cable systems use double-shear clevis pins and swaged eye fittings, then verify by pull tests to twice limit load; combined with routine tension checks, this satisfies the reduced 2.0 factor requirement.

Service Difficulty Reports on Boeing 737 elevator feel unit have logged cracked rod-end bearings found during heavy maintenance; the intact but damaged parts demonstrated that the mandated safety factor kept the system functional long enough for discovery.

section_intent: The rule guarantees that flaps, slats, spoilers and other lift- or drag-producing surfaces are always under positive, predictable pilot control. Crews must be able to select any certified take-off, cruise, approach or landing setting, have the surface remain there without constant attention, and still be able to retract it quickly for a go-around while at high power and low speed (below VF + 9 kt). The controls must be laid out and guarded so accidental activation is highly unlikely, and devices meant only for ground use are prevented from inflight deployment. Any automatic positioning or load-relief logic must move the surface at a rate and manner that preserves safe handling, structural margins and performance across the full range of speeds, attitudes and power settings. In plain terms, the rule exists to stop surprises—no inadvertent flap or spoiler movements, no sudden aerodynamic upsets, and no situations where the crew cannot promptly retract a high-drag configuration that would threaten continued safe flight.
ai_notes: China Eastern Flight 583 (MD-11, 1993): A flight-deck bump of the flap/slat handle deployed the devices at cruise speed, causing violent pitch oscillations and injuries; shows why control location and motion rate must prevent inadvertent or rapid extension.

Expert note: Transport aircraft place the flap lever in a gated, detented quadrant with a distinctive knob and spring-loaded latches, making it hard to move unintentionally and satisfying CS 25.697(b).

TWA Flight 841 (B727, 1979): Uncommanded leading-edge slat extension at high speed led to a roll-over and dive, illustrating the catastrophic potential of in-flight activation of devices not protected against misuse.

Expert note: Boeing 777/787 flap load-relief logic automatically retracts one setting if airspeed exceeds the flap limit, then redeploys when speed reduces, meeting 25.697(c) by keeping handling benign and avoiding structural overload.
Expert note: Compliance tests require demonstrating a full-flap go-around at max continuous thrust below VF + 9 kt; successful retraction without stall or overspeed proves adherence to 25.697(d).
Industry practice: Ground spoilers are inhibited by weight-on-wheels logic and guarded cockpit switches, making in-flight deployment ‘improbable’ as demanded by 25.697(b).

section_intent: Pilots must always know where every flap, slat, spoiler or other lift-/drag-altering surface is, and whether both wings are moving together as intended. Clear cockpit indications of device position (for take-off, cruise, approach and landing) and of any split or jam help crews avoid or correct hazardous asymmetry, stalls, loss of control, runway overruns or structural overspeed. If a control can be moved past the normal landing setting, that extra range has to be unmistakably marked so it cannot be selected accidentally. In short, the rule makes sure the flight crew get timely, unambiguous information to keep the aircraft in a safe configuration throughout all phases of flight.
ai_notes: American Airlines Flight 191 (DC-10, 1979): left-wing slats retracted after an engine separated; no cockpit warning of the asymmetry, aircraft rolled and crashed—drove requirements for positive split-flap/slat indication.

Delta Flight 1141 (B727, 1988): crew attempted take-off with flaps/slats retracted; despite checklists, lack of clear positional cross-check contributed to stall and crash—highlights need for unmistakable take-off position indications.

Expert note: Rigging or hydraulic failures can let one flap track jam while the other side moves, creating large rolling moments; modern systems include ‘FLAP/SLAT DISAGREE’ annunciations triggered by position-sensor comparison.
Expert note: Training curricula now require pilots to verify indicated flap settings at the ‘flaps… set’ call and to abort take-off if indications disagree with the configuration schedule.

Expert note: Manufacturers use redundant position sensors plus colour-coded gauges or ECAM/EICAS tapes (green for authorised range, amber/red for overshoot) to satisfy the clear-marking provision and reduce crew workload.

Expert note: Some cargo variants allow extended-lift settings for steep-approach airports; the detent past LAND is physically gated and placarded to comply with paragraph (c) and prevent inadvertent selection in normal service.

section_intent: Ensure that any high-lift devices (flaps or slats) on the left and right wings either move together or that the aeroplane remains safely controllable if they do not. If a mechanical or equivalent link is used to keep them in sync, that link and its structure must tolerate the worst-case asymmetric loads that could arise from jams, actuator runaways, or an engine failure on one side during the most demanding power setting. In short, the rule prevents hazardous rolling moments caused by one wing having much more lift than the other when flaps or slats are deployed, and guarantees that the structure and control systems can survive and manage such asymmetries.
ai_notes: United Airlines B737-222 N9056U, Denver 1975: right-hand flaps jammed at 15° while left flaps retracted, producing severe roll on go-around; crew recovered but incident highlighted need for stronger interconnect torque limits.

Expert note: Common single-point failure is a ruptured hydraulic line that powers only one flap actuator; mechanical torque tubes mandated by this rule stop the free surface before large lift asymmetry develops.

American Airlines Flight 191 certification review (DC-10, 1979): after engine pylon separation, slat drive cables on left wing failed and slats retracted, creating lift loss on that side; showed why interconnections must withstand engine-out loads.

Expert note: Compliance testing routinely includes a ‘one-side jam’ ground-test where actuators on the free side are driven to max travel while the other side is locked, proving the interconnect or structure carries the full actuator stall load without yielding.

Best practice: Flight-crew simulator training covers recognition of asymmetric-flap indications and immediate use of roll spoilers/aileron to counter roll, reflecting the residual risk that this rule seeks to minimise.

section_intent: Ensure every large transport aeroplane has an automatic audible system that warns pilots during the early take-off roll whenever key configuration items (flaps/leading-edge devices, spoilers or trim, parking brake, etc.) are not set inside the certified take-off range. The alert must persist until the pilots either correct the configuration, abort the take-off, rotate the aircraft, or deliberately silence the warning via a switch that cannot be hit inadvertently. The system must work for all approved power-settings, weights, altitudes and temperatures so that crews always receive a clear, unmistakable last-chance warning before an unsafe configuration can result in loss of control or runway overrun.
ai_notes: Northwest Airlines Flight 255 (1987): MD-82 departed with flaps retracted; the take-off warning system was inoperative, no alert sounded, aircraft stalled after liftoff, 154 fatalities—prime catalyst for tightening TOWS reliability requirements.

Delta Air Lines Flight 1141 (1988): B-727 attempted take-off with incorrect flap/leading-edge setting; TOWS never sounded due to crew mis-rigging; accident underscored need for warnings that cannot be easily silenced or defeated.

Spanair Flight 5022 (2008): MD-82 took off without flaps deployed; TOWS failed because a relay had been de-activated during maintenance; crash reaffirmed requirement for automatic re-arming and full functionality after each flight leg.

Expert note: Crews already run configuration checklists, but human factors studies show distraction and time-pressure during line-up still lead to missed settings; TOWS provides an independent, attention-grabbing barrier against this common error.

Expert note: Certification tests exercise TOWS at extreme temperatures, high-elevation airports and maximum-thrust derates to prove the activation logic remains reliable across the full operational envelope demanded by paragraph (c).
Expert note: Operators train pilots that any TOWS activation prior to V1 mandates an immediate rejected take-off, making the aural alert a definitive cue for decisive action.

Expert note: Parking brakes left partially set or spoilers extended after de-icing are recurrent service difficulties; TOWS catches these latent mis-configurations before acceleration commits the aircraft to flight.

section_intent: This rule requires large transport aeroplanes to carry a Runway Overrun Awareness and Alerting System (ROAAS). The system constantly calculates, during the final approach and after touchdown, whether the aircraft’s remaining energy and the available runway length will allow it to stop safely under prevailing (dry or wet) conditions. If the predicted stopping point is beyond the runway end, the crew must receive clear, timely warnings—and optionally automatic deceleration—so they can go-around or apply maximum braking early. The overall goal is to cut the risk of runway overruns, one of the most frequent and hazardous types of landing accident, by giving crews objective, real-time performance cues rather than relying solely on judgement or pre-computed landing data.
ai_notes: Air France 358 (A340-300, Toronto 2005): Crew landed long on a wet runway, received no predictive alert, and overran into a ravine; accident highlighted need for in-cockpit real-time stopping forecasts.
American Airlines 1420 (MD-82, Little Rock 1999): Late touchdown on rain-soaked runway with delayed reverse thrust; overrun killed 11—classic case where ROAAS would have warned well before touchdown.
Miami Air 293 (B737-800, Jacksonville 2019): Aircraft aquaplaned on flooded runway and slid into river; investigation again cited lack of real-time overrun awareness cues.

Expert note: Flight crews often mis-enter runway condition or fail to update landing performance when weather deteriorates; ROAAS removes reliance on manual calculations by monitoring energy and runway length continuously.
Expert note: Autobrake selection and thrust-reverser delays can degrade stopping performance; predictive alerts allow crews to select higher autobrake or initiate go-around before commitment point.

Industry practice: Airbus ROPS and Boeing ROAR systems, certified under similar criteria, have demonstrated that audible "Runway too short" alerts drive timely go-arounds and reduce long-landing events.
Best practice: Training syllabi now include simulator scenarios where ROAAS alerts trigger go-around or maximum braking, ensuring crews trust and act on the system promptly.

section_intent: This rule ensures that if the landing gear, gear support structure, or engine pylon fails during hard landings, rejected take-offs, or wheels-up slides, the way it breaks must not rupture fuel tanks or lines badly enough to create a fire. Designers must assume worst-case vertical, aft, and side loads – and even full belly landings with gear retracted – and show the structure will either keep fuel contained or fail in a direction that avoids piercing or shearing tanks. In short, the aircraft must remain largely fuel-tight in realistic crash-landing scenarios so occupants are not trapped in a post-impact fire.
ai_notes: FedEx Flight 14 (MD-11, Newark 1997): hard landing collapsed the left gear; wing struck runway, fuel tank tore, causing a rapid fire that destroyed the aircraft—an illustrative case of the hazard the rule seeks to prevent.

Eastern Air Lines L-1011 prototype test (1972): drop-test of gear leg showed pylon attachment could punch into wing tank; certification fixes added fail-safe fuse pins and spar reinforcement, reflecting CS-25.721 intent.
Expert note: Modern airliners fit ‘keel beams’ and titanium belly scuff plates so that, in a gear-up slide, the structure wears away gradually without reaching the center-wing fuel tank.

UPS B747-400 wheels-up landing at PANC (2016): aircraft slid on fuselage with minor fuel seepage and no fire, demonstrating how reinforced lower wing skins and protected feed lines comply with CS-25.721(b).

Expert note: Landing-gear trunnion fittings are deliberately designed as sacrificial—overload lugs shear off and let the leg swing away from the wing box, preventing it from punching through wet wing tanks.
Expert note: Engine pylons now use break-away fuse pins that let the engine separate cleanly under extreme upward or aft loads, avoiding pylon/tank rupture that could spill fuel onto hot parts.

section_intent: This rule makes sure the landing-gear shock-absorber system really can soak up the energy of every normal and hard landing the airplane is approved for. Manufacturers first build computer or mathematical models of how the gear will behave; CS-25.723 forces them to prove those models with physical drop ("energy-absorption") tests at the most demanding weights, attitudes and drag loads, and to show extra margin for a 3.7 m/s (12 ft/s) sink-rate ‘hard landing’. The goal is to prevent gear collapse, prevent excessive loads being passed into the wing or fuselage, and protect occupants even if the pilot plants the airplane on firmly. If only minor weight or design changes are made later, the rule lets designers reuse earlier validated data so long as the basic shock-absorbing behaviour stays the same.
ai_notes: FedEx MD-11 N526FE, Narita 2009: vertical speed >4 m/s; main-gear absorbed part of the energy but reached its limit, aircraft bounced, overturned and broke up—illustrates why reserve energy capacity beyond normal sink-rates is required.

Ryanair B737-800 EI-DYG, Rome-Ciampino 2008: hard landing after bird strike led to gear collapse and fuselage damage; investigators highlighted the necessity for validated drop-test data at the highest certified landing weight.

Expert note: Every new transport design undergoes full-scale drop tests where a complete gear leg is dropped from controlled heights on a sled while side and drag loads are applied to mimic touchdown attitude—matching the paragraph (a) requirement.

Expert note: When Airbus increased the A321neo’s maximum take-off and landing weights, it used paragraph (c) to show, by analysis correlated to earlier A321 drop tests, that the unchanged gear still had enough stroke and energy margin.

Common failure mode: If analytical models underestimate tyre compression or omit wheel-spin-up drag, the real gear sees higher peak loads and can bottom out—CS-25.723 forces validation so these modelling errors are caught early.

Southwest B737-700, LaGuardia 2013: nose-first touchdown overloaded the nose-gear; the event reaffirmed industry training that pilots must meet attitude constraints simulated in gear tests to keep loads within certified limits.

Expert note: Operators include ‘maximum certified sink-rate’ briefings and hard-landing inspection criteria derived directly from CS-25.723 test data, ensuring maintenance looks for structural damage whenever those limits might have been exceeded.

section_intent: CS 25.729 makes sure a retractable landing-gear system is structurally sound, positively locked, fail-safe and unmistakably indicated to the crew. The gear, doors, actuators and supporting structure must tolerate all loads seen while retracted, extended or moving, including wheel spin, brake torque, gyroscopic effects and yaw manoeuvres. The rule also demands a back-up means to lower the gear after any single hydraulic, electric or mechanical failure, and requires cockpit indications plus an unavoidable aural warning that prevents an inadvertent gear-up landing. In essence, it protects against structural break-up, gear collapse and crew‐awareness errors throughout the entire flight envelope.
ai_notes: LOT Polish Airlines Flight 16 (B767, 2011): a dual hydraulic leak left the crew with no normal or alternate pressure and the gear remained retracted, ending in a belly landing—highlighting why an emergency extension path independent of any single power source is mandated.

United Airlines Flight 173 (DC-8, 1978): an unsafe gear-down light distracted the crew until fuel exhaustion; proves the need for reliable, unambiguous indication and an aural warning that cannot be silenced accidentally.

Expert note: Early jet prototypes experienced actuator fractures when spinning wheels were retracted, so designers now brake or snub wheel rotation and size mechanisms for the 1.23 VSR spin-up loads in 25.729(a)(1)(ii).

Embraer 190 door-loss event over Florida (2006): a main-gear door departed after a yaw manoeuvre, illustrating why door structures and linkages must meet the combined speed-and-yaw loads of 25.729(a)(3).

Expert note: Certification teams routinely demonstrate free-fall or nitrogen blow-down of the gear after disabling hydraulics and electrics, satisfying 25.729(c) and proving that one failure cannot trap the gear.
JAT Yugoslav Airlines B737-200, Ljubljana 1984: nose gear collapsed on landing because the down-lock was not fully engaged—reinforcing the requirement for a positive mechanical lock in 25.729(b).

Expert note: Squat-switch and lever interlocks that disable the retraction circuit on the ground are industry best practice derived from taxi accidents in the 1950s, directly supporting the 'positive means' language.
Airbus A320 EC-INJ (2004): gear remained down during a high-speed avoidance at ~280 kt; no damage occurred, demonstrating compliance with the 0.67 VC extended-gear load case in 25.729(a)(2).

section_intent: CS-25.731 ensures that every wheel fitted to a large aeroplane is demonstrably strong enough for the heaviest static and dynamic loads it can ever see, and that it will not violently fail if the tyre is overheated or over-inflated.  The rule demands that each wheel type be specifically approved, carry load ratings that match the aircraft’s maximum weight and most critical centre-of-gravity, and withstand the peak radial loads calculated under the ground-load rules of CS-25.  In addition, wheels must include built-in measures—such as thermal fuse plugs or calibrated pressure-relief valves—to keep a rim or tyre from exploding should heat or servicing errors raise the pressure too high.  Finally, if the wheel incorporates brakes, it must also satisfy the dedicated braking requirements of CS-25.735.  In plain language: the wheels must be tough enough to carry the aircraft at its worst-case weight, resist runway impacts, and protect people and structures from catastrophic bursts.
ai_notes: Qantas 747-400 VH-OJH (Bangkok, 1999): after heavy brake use, several tyre fuse plugs melted, slowly deflating the tyres and preventing an explosive wheel burst—exactly the scenario addressed by paragraph (d).

Ground maintenance accident, Paris-CDG 2018: an A320 wheel exploded during over-inflation, fatally injuring a technician; investigations cited absent/blocked pressure-relief devices, underlining why the rule mandates over-pressure protection.

Southwest Airlines Flight 345 (B737-700, 2013): the nose gear collapsed on landing, but the wheels themselves remained intact because their limit-load rating exceeded the radial loads seen, illustrating compliance with paragraphs (b) and (c).

Expert note: Certification houses run static-load tests at 1.33× design limit and dynamic radial-fatigue rigs that cycle millions of times to prove a wheel can handle lifetime ground reactions without cracking.

Expert note: Industry best practice is to specify heat-activated fuse plugs and calibrated inflation carts; maintenance manuals require tyres to be filled in safety cages, directly addressing failure modes envisaged by paragraph (d).

section_intent: This rule makes sure that every tyre fitted to a CS-25 transport aeroplane can safely carry the stresses, speeds, temperatures and clearances it will actually see during take-off, landing, rejected take-off and taxiing. It requires the tyre’s certified speed and load ratings never be exceeded, including the extra nose-wheel loads created when heavy braking transfers weight forward. For multi-wheel axles a 7 % margin is added so that one tyre can momentarily pick up more weight if its neighbour rides over a bump or fails. Adequate space in the wheel well is demanded to avoid tyre rubbing or snagging as it flexes and grows at speed. On aircraft above 75 000 lb, tyres must be inflated with dry nitrogen or an equally inert gas to prevent oxygen-fed explosions if they get very hot. Finally, operators must have a reliable way to detect or prevent under-inflation, because low pressure is a leading cause of tyre failures.
ai_notes: Concorde F-BTSB (Paris, 2000): A tyre burst at high speed sent debris into the wing, igniting fuel; illustrates why speed/load limits and wheel-well clearance are critical for preventing catastrophic secondary damage.

United Airlines DC-10 Denver (1979): Overheated brakes ignited oxygen-rich air in the tyres, causing an explosion that damaged hydraulic lines; the event drove the nitrogen-inflation requirement for large aircraft.

Expert note: The 1.07 factor for dual tyres comes from service experience showing that when one tyre rides over runway debris or loses pressure, the adjacent tyre can see a sudden ~7 % overload before the crew notices or weight is re-balanced.

Expert note: Under-inflated tyres flex more, creating heat that can lead to tread separation or wheel-well fires; pressure-monitoring systems and strict ramp checks are now standard compliance measures under 25.733(f).

Boeing 767-300ER nose-gear fire (Osaka, 1999): Under-inflated nose tyres failed during taxi, fragments severed hydraulic lines and caused a wheel-well fire, underscoring the need for minimum pressure safeguards.

Expert note: Manufacturers use brake energy-taxi-stop tests to verify that tyre and wheel clearances remain adequate when the tyre grows up to 4 % in diameter at high speed, directly addressing 25.733(d).

Qantas A330-300 tyre failure (Sydney, 2012): A main-gear tyre operated beyond its load rating burst on landing after a hard cross-wind touchdown, showing the importance of selecting tyres rated for the aircraft’s maximum landing weight and CG limits.

Expert note: Training for dispatch and maintenance personnel now emphasises matching tyre part numbers to the approved load/speed table in the TCDS to avoid fitting a tyre with an inadequate speed rating, a direct compliance practice linked to 25.733(a) and (c).

section_intent: Ensure the aircraft keeps flying, landing and evacuating safely even if a tyre bursts or a wheel breaks. High-energy debris or blast pressure from the failure must not sever critical hydraulics, electrics, fuel lines or structures, nor penetrate the cabin or wing. Designers therefore have to analyse burst trajectories, add shields or liners, space-separate systems, and prove that one explosive wheel-tyre event cannot create a catastrophe.
ai_notes: Concorde F-BTSC (Paris 2000): A shed tyre strip punctured a fuel tank, causing fire and loss of the aircraft—textbook case of why debris containment and system segregation are vital.
British Airways B747-400 G-BNLL (Bangkok 1999): Tyre burst on take-off sent fragments through the wing, puncturing two fuel tanks and hydraulic lines; shielding added in subsequent MOD’s.

Expert note: Certification analyses fire a test wheel to 390–400 kt equivalent energy and map fragment paths; hydraulic and electrical lines must be rerouted or armoured outside the calculated ‘burst cone’.

Continental MD-82 (Memphis 2002): Flailing tread severed brake hydraulic line causing loss of normal brakes; aircraft stopped with accumulators—event drove industry adoption of stainless-steel braid hoses in wheel wells.
Expert note: Wheels that overheat can shed metal flanges; CS 25.734 pushes for temperature-sensor-triggered brake fans and fuselage belly skins able to withstand impact.

Best practice: Maintenance uses borescope tyre inspections for internal cord damage and enforces pressure/overheat limits, reducing likelihood of explosive burst during rejected take-off training scenarios.

section_intent: CS 25.735 makes sure that every wheel-and-brake set fitted to a large aeroplane can reliably stop the aircraft without creating new dangers. The rule demands that, even if one hydraulic, electric, pneumatic or mechanical link fails, the crew must still be able to stop within twice the certified landing distance. It limits required pedal forces, lets pilots override any automatic brake, and insists the parking brake can hold the aircraft against asymmetric engine thrust. Anti-skid must work on all approved runway surfaces and outrank autobrake logic. Brakes, wheels and tyres must prove—by dynamometer tests—that they can absorb the heat from normal landings, a maximum-energy rejected take-off, and the worst-case landing, without wheel or tyre failure, fire, or jeopardising evacuation. Features such as accumulators, fuse plugs, wear indicators, cockpit warnings and thermal shields are required so that heat, fluid leaks or inadvertent operation do not turn a stop into an accident. In essence, the paragraph guarantees stopping performance, redundancy and post-stop safety throughout the brake’s wear life.
ai_notes: TWA L-1011 RTO fire (JFK, 1992): Hot brakes ignited leaked hydraulic fluid, injuring evacuees—illustrates why para (b)(2) demands fluid-fire resistance and para (g) insists on safe evacuation time.

American Airlines Flight 383 (B767-300, Chicago 2016): High-speed rejected take-off showed brakes could absorb accelerate-stop energy; fuse plugs deflated tyres without burst—validates tests in (f)(2) and safety intent of (j).
Expert note: Dual independent hydraulic circuits plus an accumulator allow at least six full brake applications after total hydraulic-system loss, meeting para (h).

Expert note: Visible wear-pins or digital wear sensors on carbon brakes give quick confirmation that the heat-sink is above its minimum thickness, satisfying para (i) and preventing over-worn brakes from failing energy tests.
BA B737-400 Manchester overheat (2003): After long taxi with park brake partly on, wheel-well fire erupted, grounding aircraft—demonstrates need for temperature shielding required by para (l).
Expert note: Autobrake systems are always designed so pedal pressure immediately cancels them, complying with para (c)(2)(ii) and preventing confusion during balked landings or RTOs.
United DC-10 Minneapolis 1979: Single hydraulic-system loss left only accumulator braking; stop distance remained within rule—example of para (b)(1) redundancy goal.
Industry practice: Fuse-plugs in wheel rims melt around 177 °C, bleeding tyre pressure to avoid an explosive burst after a hot stop, directly addressing para (j).

Expert note: Certification test plans use SAE ARP6320 dynamometer protocols to prove the required mean decelerations (3.1 m/s² landing, 1.8 m/s² RTO) across the brake’s wear range, as demanded by para (f).
Airbus A330 accidental autobrake arm (Sydney 2007): Crew overrode autobrake with manual braking on short runway, confirming necessity of manual override feature in para (c)(2).

section_intent: The rule ensures that the nose-wheel steering system of a large aeroplane remains safe, reliable and easy to use throughout all phases of ground operation. Pilots must be able to keep the aircraft on the runway during take-off, landing and cross-wind conditions without needing extraordinary skill, even if an engine suddenly fails. The steering controls may not obstruct landing-gear retraction/extension, and any single fault must not leave the wheel at an angle that could cause a runway departure or structural overload. Because aircraft are often pushed, towed or serviced by ground crews, the steering and tow fittings must either resist damage or warn the flight crew before taxi. Finally, if the design does not automatically self-centre the nose gear, the manufacturer must prove the aircraft can land safely with the wheel in any misaligned position.
ai_notes: JetBlue Flight 292 (A320, 2005): a jammed nose wheel at 90° demonstrated the benefit of proving controllability with an off-centre gear, mirroring CS 25.745(e)’s intent.
Expert note: Steering-retraction interlock pins on many Boeings prevent rudder-pedal or tiller movement while the gear is retracting, directly addressing 25.745(b).

CRJ-200 runway excursion, Charlotte 2010: hydraulic loss removed nose-wheel steering and, with strong cross-wind, the aircraft departed the runway—highlighting the 25.745(c) requirement that no single failure produce a hazardous wheel angle.
Expert note: Certification test pilots routinely perform cross-wind take-offs with an engine cut at V1 to show that average piloting skill is sufficient, as mandated by 25.745(a).
Towbarless-tractor incident, Frankfurt 2013: overstress during pushback bent the steering torque link; the cockpit ECAM "NW STRG FAULT" prevented dispatch, illustrating 25.745(d)(2).
Expert note: Shear pins in towbars are common industry practice; they fail before the steering shaft is overloaded, fulfilling 25.745(d)(1)’s protection philosophy.

section_intent: The rule ensures the flight deck is designed so pilots can safely fly the aircraft without undue physical strain, distraction, or risk of injury. Controls must be laid out so the crew can reach and operate them comfortably, propeller-driven aircraft must keep controls and crew clear of any possible propeller disk strike, both pilot seats must provide full and equivalent control authority, the cockpit must stay watertight in precipitation, and equipment vibration or noise may not hinder communication or aircraft handling. In short, it is about ergonomic, environmental, and structural features that protect crew performance and prevent hazardous situations.
ai_notes: Eastern Air Lines Flight 401 (1972): Crew fixation on a landing-gear light in a cramped, poorly lit cockpit contributed to loss of situational awareness; modern cockpit-ergonomic rules aim to prevent such distraction-induced accidents.

Expert note: Early twin-engine transports occasionally had mixture or propeller levers extending into the propeller plane; CS 25.771(b) eliminates any chance a control or pilot limb could be struck by a blade or affected by propeller slipstream.

US Airways Flight 1549 (2009) "Hudson River ditching": First Officer flew the approach from the right seat while the Captain handled checklists; equal-safety controllability from either seat, required by paragraph (c), proved essential.

Expert note: Water-spray certification tests ("spray-bar" tests) routinely reveal minor windshield and side-window leaks that can drip onto instrument panels and short avionics—paragraph (d) requires designs that remain watertight in heavy rain or snow.

Dash 8 Q400 fleet experience: Excessive cockpit propeller noise and vibration led to pilot fatigue complaints and procedural limits; CS 25.771(e) drives damping treatments and cabin acoustic standards to keep noise below interference levels.

Expert note: Modern human-factors assessments measure reach envelopes, seat-track ranges, and control-force gradients to verify that minimum crew can fly long sectors without undue fatigue, directly addressing paragraph (a).

ATR42 icing incidents showed that engine/propeller vibration could mask subtle airframe buffet cues; limiting vibration transmission to the cockpit under paragraph (e) helps pilots detect aerodynamic warnings early.

section_intent: When an aeroplane has a lockable door separating the flight deck from the cabin, safety must not be sacrificed for security. The rule ensures that: (1) during an emergency evacuation, neither passengers nor crew are forced to rely on a possibly jammed or obstructed cockpit door to reach their assigned exits; (2) flight-crew members have an alternate way to escape into the cabin if the door becomes stuck; and (3) cabin crew can still get into the cockpit if the pilots are incapacitated or the door’s normal mechanism fails. In short, the regulation balances reinforced-door security with guaranteed emergency egress and rescue paths for everyone on board.
ai_notes: Germanwings 9525 (2015): A pilot locked himself in the cockpit; cabin crew could not enter, underscoring the need for an emergency override that works even when the door is intentionally locked.

Post-9/11 reinforced cockpit doors: Industry moved to strong, lockable doors for anti-hijacking; CS 25.772 was introduced to prevent those same doors from becoming fatal barriers during fire, decompression, or crash deformation.
Expert note: Crash investigations have documented cockpit doors jammed by fuselage distortion—designs now include break-in panels or alternate escape hatches so pilots are not trapped.
Expert note: Electrical or solenoid-based locks can fail in a total power loss; compliant designs add purely mechanical overrides accessible from both sides.
TACA best practice: Cabin crew are trained and regularly drilled on keypad codes and timed delay override so they can enter the cockpit if both pilots are unresponsive.
FAA/EASA certification tests: Demonstrations show all occupants can reach Type I/II exits without passing through the cockpit, proving evacuation paths are independent of the door.
Expert note: Some operators fit removable hinge pins or quick-release latches on cockpit side, allowing pilots to push the door outward into the cabin if inward deformation blocks normal opening.

section_intent: Pilots must always have a clear, undistorted, glare-free forward view so they can taxi, take off, fly, approach and land safely in any weather the aircraft is approved for. The design therefore has to keep the windshield transparent in heavy rain, ice, hail or insect contamination without constant crew attention, provide redundancy so one failure cannot blind both pilots, offer an emergency side window or equivalent clear area, stop internal fogging in all cabin-temperature/ humidity combinations, and give seat-position cues that place the pilot’s eyes at the intended design point for optimum outside view and instrument scan. In short, the rule guarantees continuous, dependable visual cues for flight-path control and situational awareness under both normal and adverse environmental conditions.
ai_notes: Southern Airways 242 (1977): Windshields were sand-blasted opaque by severe hail; with no clear view the crew attempted a highway landing and crashed, illustrating the need for a protected or redundant transparent area.

Sichuan Airlines 8633 (2018): A right windshield panel blew out at cruise; the captain relied on the remaining panels and side window, underscoring the requirement that no single failure removes forward visibility for both pilots.
Expert note: Windshield-heat and hydrophobic coatings are standard so rain, ice or fog are shed automatically at 1.5 VSR1, meeting the rule’s demand for a clear view without continuous pilot action.

Expert note: Dual-motor wiper systems on transport jets are powered from separate electrical channels; loss of one bus leaves at least one pilot with an operative wiper, satisfying the single-failure criterion in CS 25.773(b)(2).
FedEx MD-10 at Anchorage (2002): Heavy snow caused internal fogging; crews opened side windows for visibility during taxi, demonstrating why effective demist systems are mandated.

Expert note: Seat-height marks (‘eyebrow’ decals or lighted ticks on the windshield post) are used in training so pilots set their eyes on the design eye-reference point, aligning the runway picture with instrument scan as required by CS 25.773(d).

Bird-strike events such as Brussels Airlines A319 (2019) show that even when the left windshield is crazed, the right side often remains usable, validating the rule’s emphasis on survivable visibility after bird or hail impact.

section_intent: The rule makes sure cockpit windows do not become a hazard themselves. The inner panes must not shatter into sharp shards; the front windshields must resist impact from large birds without being pierced; and, if a pane does break, fragments must not injure the pilots. Because these windows also seal the pressurised cabin, they have to survive repeated pressurisation cycles, temperature extremes and the worst-case cabin pressure after any single obvious failure, still leaving at least one clear panel so a pilot can see to fly and land safely. In short, the requirement protects crew vision, prevents structural decompression, and preserves the crew’s ability to control the aeroplane after bird strike, cracking or other single failures.
ai_notes: British Airways Flight 5390 (1990): an incorrectly fastened cockpit windshield blew out at FL170, partially ejecting the captain and causing rapid decompression—illustrates the need for pressurisation-strength margins and continued safe flight after a single window failure.
Expert note: Certification firing of a 1.8 kg (4 lb) chicken carcass at 270 kt into the pilot windshield demonstrates compliance with CS-25.631 and 25.775(b) for bird-impact resistance.

Multiple 757/767 windshield heating-element arcing events (FAA/EASA ADs 2006–2012) show how cyclic thermal and pressure loads can lead to delamination and cracking, validating §25.775(d) requirements for material selection and installation fail-safety.

Expert note: Modern flight-deck windows use chemically tempered glass outer plies bonded to polycarbonate inner plies; the glass takes impact, the polycarbonate prevents splintering, meeting paragraph (a) and (c).

US regional jet bird-strike incident at 10 000 ft (2004): goose shattered outer ply but inner pane stayed intact, allowing safe diversion—demonstrates why non-penetration and fragment retention are critical.

Expert note: Crew training teaches that if any one front panel becomes opaque or frosted, the pilot not flying immediately shifts to the remaining clear pane, satisfying §25.775(e) continued-vision intent.
