China Airlines Flight 120 (2007, B737-800): A slat track repair left a bolt that pierced a wing tank fuel line; fuel sprayed onto hot wheel-well components and ignited after landing, destroying the aircraft. Shows why designers must analyse all potential leak paths and nearby ignition sources.

TWA Flight 800 (1996, B747-131): Electrical wiring fault in the centre wing tank ignited fuel vapours, breaking the aircraft in flight. Illustrates the rule’s call to consider vapour flammability and electrical faults inside tanks and bays.

Expert note: Repeated industry findings show hydraulic fluid atomising onto bleed-air ducts; modern designs route lines away from hot zones or use double-wall hoses with leak detection to remove this ignition pairing.

Expert note: Engine and APU fire handles simultaneously close fuel, hydraulic and bleed-air shut-off valves, cutting the energy source and meeting CS 25.863’s requirement to ‘stop flow of fluids’ as a primary fire-control means.

Expert note: Fireproof titanium or stainless-steel shields are installed between fuel lines and electrical power feeders in wing leading edges, preventing arcing or overheating wires from igniting any leaked fuel.

FedEx MD-10 Memphis incident (2016): Fuel leaked from a fractured engine fuel tube during landing roll; cockpit fire warning prompted crew to shut off the engine and discharge extinguishers, containing damage. Demonstrates the value of quick-acting crew alerts mandated by CS 25.863(c).

section_intent: The rule’s goal is to ensure that any parts needed to keep the aircraft controllable (flight-control linkages, cables, hydraulics), the structures that hold the engines on, and nearby load-bearing parts will still work long enough to land even if an intense fire breaks out in an engine bay or other "designated fire zone." It does this by requiring those parts either to be made of fire-proof materials or to be shielded so they will not fail when exposed to a severe, localized fire. In plain terms: if an engine or APU catches fire, the flames must not be able to burn through the hinges, spars, cables or mounts that keep the wing attached and the aircraft steerable. (Fire-proof means it can withstand a 1 100 °C/2 000 °F flame for 15 min without failure.)
ai_notes: Expert note: Early piston-airliners routed aileron cables through the engine nacelle; several post-WWII fires severed those cables, prompting regulators to demand fire-proof routing and the precursor to CS 25.865.

Vickers Vanguard G-AOVF (1966) suffered an in-flight engine fire that burned through elevator push-pull rods, leading to loss of control; the accident is often cited in historical justification for robust fire shielding.

Swissair Flight 111 (1998) showed how heat and flames can rapidly compromise nearby structure; modern designs keep primary control runs out of fire zones or enclose them in stainless-steel conduits as a direct compliance strategy.

Industry best practice: titanium or Inconel shields are fitted around wing-root hydraulic lines where they pass behind the engine pylon, preventing flame impingement in the event of an engine-mount fire.

FedEx MD-11F N386FE (Memphis, 2012) experienced an engine-bay fire on rollout; fire-proof cladding kept the spoiler cables intact, allowing the crew to taxi clear—an operational validation of CS 25.865 requirements.

Expert note: During certification, manufacturers perform 15-minute flame tests on representative control components and must show—by analysis or test—that the flight deck can still command pitch, roll, and yaw after the worst-case fire.

section_intent: Make sure any aircraft structure that sits directly behind an engine (within about one nacelle-diameter of the engine centre-line) is built from material that will not readily burn, melt, or lose strength if exposed to the flames, hot gases, or sparks produced by an engine fire. In plain words, if an engine catches fire the heat must not rapidly destroy the wing or tail surfaces sitting in the fire path, because that could lead to loss of control before the crew can shut the engine down or the extinguishing system works. The rule sets aluminium alloy as the minimum fire-resistance benchmark, unless the part is so far away or shielded that the fire could not realistically reach it.
ai_notes: British Airtours B737-236, Manchester 1985: Engine fire on take-off scorched flaps and aft wing skin; aluminium structure resisted long enough for evacuation, illustrating why materials aft of the nacelle must tolerate flame exposure.
Expert note: Early jetliners used magnesium alloy flap skins that ignited during engine torching events; the requirement was tightened to ban low-melting-point, easily burning metals in these areas.

Qantas A380-842 (QF32) 2010: Uncontained engine failure sent burning debris over the wing; fire-resistant spoilers and trailing-edge panels maintained integrity, showing best practice compliance with CS 25.867.

Expert note: Manufacturers routinely add titanium or stainless-steel heat shields on flap track fairings and use fire-retardant sealant around control-surface hinges to demonstrate that structures aft of engines meet the aluminium-equivalent fire resistance mandated by this rule.

section_intent: This rule ensures that systems that can ignite or feed a fire—electrical components, vacuum-air lines, and oxygen equipment—are designed and installed so they cannot start a fire, will keep working long enough during an emergency, and will not worsen a blaze. In plain terms, wiring in fire-prone areas must resist flame and smoke, vacuum lines carrying flammable vapours must meet the same protections as fuel lines, and oxygen bottles, valves, and pipes must be kept away from hot engine or APU zones and routed so leaking oxygen cannot ignite lubricants or fluids. The goal is to stop fires from starting, stop them from spreading if they do start, and prevent lifesaving systems from becoming new fire hazards.
ai_notes: Swissair 111 (1998): A cockpit fire traced to arcing wiring and flammable insulation underscored the need for fire-resistant electrical components inside areas where smoke can rapidly reach the flight deck—directly influencing tougher CS-25 wiring requirements.

ValuJet 592 (1996): Chemical oxygen generators carried in a cargo hold ignited and fed an uncontrollable fire, illustrating why oxygen sources must be isolated from designated fire zones and prevented from discharging toward flammable materials.

Expert note: Compliance teams route flight-deck oxygen lines through cool cabin zones and shield them with fire blankets where they must cross hot bleed-air ducts, satisfying 25.869(c)(2) heat-protection intent.

Historic vacuum-pump exhaust fires on piston twins showed that gyro vacuum lines carrying oil mist can ignite if they rupture in engine compartments; 25.869(b) now demands these lines meet the same standards as fuel lines in fire zones.

Expert note: Manufacturers qualify wire harnesses in nacelles using the 15-minute flame test of CS 25.863, proving ‘fire resistant’ performance for equipment needed during engine-out or fire-fighting procedures.

Industry practice: Critical electrical relays that must remain powered during an engine fire are mounted on the side of the firewall away from potential flame, giving crews time to run shutdown and extinguishing checklists without losing systems.

section_intent: The rule makes sure every transport airplane has an easy, accurate way to show when it is perfectly level on the ground (no tilt fore-aft or side-to-side). This fixed reference attitude is needed for safe weighing, centre-of-gravity (CG) calculations, control-surface rigging, fuel or hydraulic quantity checks, and calibration of instruments such as altimeters or inertial reference systems (IRS). A dependable levelling aid stops maintenance or loading errors that could shift the CG outside limits, mis-adjust flight controls, or give crews faulty instrument data, any of which can threaten flight safety.
ai_notes: Real event: Air Midwest Flight 5481 (Beech 1900D, 2003) – Elevator cables were rigged with the aircraft on an uneven hangar floor; without proper levelling references, travel was reduced and the aircraft crashed on take-off.

Expert note: During certified weighing, a 0.5° nose-down error can move the calculated CG several percent of mean aerodynamic chord, so manufacturers provide fuselage pins or brackets for a calibrated bubble level before any weight-and-balance work.

Expert note: IRS alignment logic on large jets assumes the airframe is within tight pitch/roll limits; ramp personnel use external levelling marks to verify attitude on sloping stands, preventing nuisance ‘NAV IRS ALIGNMENT FAULT’ messages.

Real event: Multiple Airbus A320 operators traced recurring fuel-imbalance warnings to refuelling on ramps with a 3–4° slope; clearer fuselage levelling marks now let ground crews confirm the aircraft is level before gauging tanks.

Expert note: Flight-control rigging (aileron droop, elevator neutral) is carried out with precision levels placed on cabin reference points specified by the levelling marks, a best practice highlighted in many Part-145 audit findings.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that any structure or window located in the direct line of the propeller tips is strong, stiff and impact-resistant enough to cope with two specific hazards: (1) the continuous vibratory loads produced by the rotating propeller wake, and (2) high-energy chunks of ice that can be flung off the blades during or after flight-into-icing conditions.  By forcing designers to reinforce skins, frames and transparencies in this area, the regulation aims to prevent cracking, loss of structural integrity, or penetration that could lead to rapid decompression or crew-passenger injury.  In short, whatever sits beside a propeller disk must be able to survive the worst vibration and ice-impact the aeroplane can realistically experience.
ai_notes: SAS Flight 1209 (2007, Dash-8 Q400): A separated propeller blade penetrated the cabin wall, highlighting the need for reinforced fuselage structure and windows near the propeller arc.
KLM Cityhopper Fokker 50 (1999): Ice shed from the right-hand propeller cracked a cockpit side window; certification tests were later updated to include higher-energy ice slugs.
Expert note: Cyclic propeller wake induces ‘breathing’ of adjacent fuselage skins; without added doublers and stringers, fatigue cracks can initiate within a few thousand cycles.
Expert note: Turboprop de-ice boot cycling allows ice to build and then shed in large plates; the rule ensures the shed ice cannot pierce windows or thin skins.

Industry best practice: Manufacturers fire artificial ice (frozen glycol/water slugs) at full-scale cabin windows and fuselage panels to prove they survive the ‘most severe ice impact likely to occur’.
Industry best practice: Vibration surveys using strain gauges are run during flight tests to ensure measured stress near the propeller tip plane stays within the reinforced structure’s allowables.

section_intent: The rule requires every part of the airplane to be electrically connected or otherwise treated so that static electricity cannot build up to levels that could harm people, ignite fuel-air mixtures, or disturb on-board electronics. In simple terms, any charge produced by airflow, lightning, refuelling, or system operation must quickly and safely flow to the airframe and dissipate into the atmosphere, keeping the aircraft, its occupants, and its avionics safe.
ai_notes: Pan Am Flight 214 (1963): Lightning ignited fuel vapour in a wing tank after charge built up and bridged a poorly bonded panel, underscoring the need for reliable bonding paths.
United Airlines DC-10 O’Hare ramp fire (1980): A spark from an unbonded refuelling hose ignited fuel, demonstrating why bonding straps are mandatory during ground refuelling operations.
Expert note: Hinges, latches and control-surface interfaces all receive flexible bond jumpers so moving parts stay electrically continuous with the main structure during flight.
Expert note: Composite structures do not conduct well; designers embed metallic mesh or foils and provide bonding terminations so static and lightning currents do not arc through resin or burn holes.

Expert note: Static wicks fitted to trailing edges bleed off charge caused by airflow friction, preventing radio interference and reducing probability of high-energy discharges elsewhere on the airframe.
Expert note: Fuel tank access panels are tested for less than 2.5 mΩ bonding resistance to ensure any lightning-induced or static current does not spark across joints inside flammable vapour spaces.

Expert note: Certification flight tests often include VHF and HF radio checks in dry, dusty air to verify that static charging is low enough to avoid receiver noise, confirming proper dissipation paths.
Expert note: Maintenance training stresses cleaning and re-torquing bonding jumpers—loose or corroded connections are a known in-service cause of spurious avionics faults and refuelling sparks.

section_intent: The rule makes sure every part of the propulsion system—engines, controls, fuel, wiring and mounts—is installed so it can operate safely for the whole interval between scheduled maintenance. Designers must follow the engine maker’s approved installation instructions, keep parts reachable for inspection, assure adequate strength, cooling and fire-protection, and provide proper electrical bonding to avoid sparks or lightning damage. A complete system-safety assessment (per CS 25.1309) is required for all foreseeable failures, except the very rare uncontained engine or propeller break-ups that are handled by separate rules. In short: install the powerplant so it stays safe, inspectable and controllable throughout normal service.
ai_notes: United 232, Sioux City (1989) – DC-10 fan-disk burst severed hydraulics; drove industry to segregate critical lines and comply with CS 25.1309 so no single power-plant failure removes flight controls.
Southwest 1380 (2018) – CFM56 fan blade-out showed why designers must analyse debris paths and bond cowl structures to keep panels attached and minimise cabin penetration.
Expert note: Routine lightning-strike damage to nacelles led to mandatory bonding straps between engine, pylon and wing so current bypasses fuel tanks without arcing.
Expert note: Engine bleed ducts are routed clear of wiring and fuel lines, following CS-E 20 instructions, to stop a simple clamp failure from causing an in-flight fire.
BOAC 911 (1966) – 707 lost horizontal stab skin after engine-pylon vibration; illustrates requirement for continued safe operation and inspection access to detect pylon fatigue.
Expert note: Modern nacelles include large hinged cowl doors and quick-disconnect sensors so mechanics can complete borescope inspections within scheduled line-maintenance windows.
Expert note: Safety assessments routinely model fuel-pump motor seizure, FADEC power loss and thrust-reverser malfunctions to show compliance with CS 25.1309 for each installation.

section_intent: CS 25.903 makes sure that every engine fitted to a large airplane is safe to use and, if it does fail, the airplane can still keep flying. It requires engines to prove resistance to foreign-object damage and ice, or show a good service record; makes designers separate and shield power-plants so one failure cannot cripple the rest; demands a reliable way to shut an engine down and stop it windmilling when that motion could be dangerous; obliges turbine-engine installations to contain rotor bursts and internal fires and to prevent crews from accidentally over-speeding or over-temping the rotors; and insists that any shut-down engine can be restarted within a defined speed-altitude envelope, with independent electrical power available for ignition if all engines quit. In plain terms, the rule assures that engine malfunctions stay an isolated event, do not set the airplane on fire, damage vital systems, or leave the crew without a path to recover flight.
ai_notes: United Airlines Flight 232 (1989, DC-10): A fan-disk burst severed all three hydraulic systems, prompting tighter requirements for system segregation and rotor-burst shielding addressed in 25.903(b) and (d)(1).

Qantas Flight 32 (2010, A380): Uncontained Trent 900 failure punctured wing and systems yet the aircraft survived; the event underscored the need for design precautions against rotor failures and fire burn-through mandated in 25.903(d)(1).

Southwest Flight 3472 (2016, B737): Fan-blade release damaged nacelle but debris was contained from critical systems, illustrating modern compliance with engine isolation and case-strength provisions.

Expert note: Manufacturers route fuel, hydraulic, and electrical lines for the opposite engine outside the predicted debris cone so that a bursting rotor cannot disable the remaining power-plant, directly meeting 25.903(b).

Expert note: Water-spray and hail-ingestion certification tests mirror CS-E 790/800 criteria, ensuring engines mounted close to the runway will not flame out from debris or slush, satisfying 25.903(a)(2).

Air Transat Flight 236 (2001, A330): Both engines flamed out after fuel exhaustion; restart was achieved using the Ram Air Turbine that supplied independent power for ignition, exemplifying 25.903(e)(3).

US Airways Flight 1549 (2009, A320): Crew attempted restarts after bird strike but were outside the certified speed/altitude window, showing why a published restart envelope per 25.903(e)(2) is essential to pilot training and procedures.
Expert note: Fire-resistant feathering lines and firewall-mounted shutoff valves allow propeller aircraft to stop an engine’s rotation without fuel or oil leaks, meeting 25.903(c) requirements.

section_intent: During take-off the aircraft must be able to climb safely even if one engine fails at the most critical moment. An Automatic Takeoff Thrust Control System (ATTCS) instantly commands the remaining engine(s) to a higher, pre-certified power setting without pilot action. CS 25.904 makes this performance credit conditional on the system meeting the detailed design, reliability, annunciation, and inhibition criteria of Appendix I, ensuring it will (1) always activate when needed, (2) never activate or stay active when unsafe, and (3) give the crew clear status information. In plain terms: if the aircraft depends on an automatic “power-up” to meet one-engine-inoperative climb and obstacle-clearance requirements, that automation must be proven fail-safe and transparent to the crew.
ai_notes: Boeing 747-400 certification flights in the late 1980s showed that auto-thrust could reliably command take-off go-around thrust after an engine failure, prompting regulators to codify uniform requirements—now embodied in Appendix I.
1983 Learjet 25D accident at Calgary: delayed manual power increase after an engine failure led to runway overrun; industry cited the event when arguing for mandatory automatic power-reserve systems.
Expert note: Typical failure mode is a single sensor or logic fault that erroneously suppresses ATTCS arming; Appendix I therefore requires dual sensing and self-test before TO for dispatch credit.
Expert note: Many operators include "ATTCS armed—green" call-outs in the take-off briefing and take-off roll cross-checks to satisfy the crew-awareness requirement of Appendix I.

MD-11 flight-test program uncovered nuisance ATTCS activation after minor thrust splits; Appendix I now mandates inhibit logic once airborne to prevent asymmetric power surges that could harm controllability.

section_intent: CS-25.905 ensures that propellers installed on large aeroplanes operate only within the speeds and powers they were proven safe for, that their pitch-control mechanisms are reliable, and that the aircraft structure and systems can withstand—or at least survive—the rare event of a propeller blade or hub failure. In plain terms, the rule aims to prevent propeller overspeed, loss of pitch control, and catastrophic damage from thrown blades so that a single propeller malfunction cannot endanger the whole aircraft, its occupants, or people on the ground.
ai_notes: ASA Flight 529 (EMB-120, 1995): a fatigued blade separated, struck the fuselage, and the resulting imbalance led to loss of control and fire—demonstrating why CS-25.905(d) demands mitigation of blade-release and imbalance hazards.

Propair Flight 420 (HS-748, 1998): a blade failure punctured the wing and fuel tank, feeding a fire; illustrates the need for structural shielding and system segregation around the propeller disc plane.

Expert note: Repeated prop-governor malfunctions on commuter turboprops have caused transient overspeeds; compliance tests require dual governors and automatic fuel limiters so engine power and shaft RPM never exceed the propeller’s certified limits under any normal or single-failure condition (para (b)).

Expert note: CS-P 420 drives use of redundant pitch-control elements (primary governor, overspeed governor, manual feather valve) plus failure-mode analysis to keep blades at a safe angle even after single-point faults (para (c)).

Best practice: Manufacturers add Kevlar or titanium blade-catcher rings on nacelle lips and route hydraulic/electrical lines outside the propeller disc area to contain debris and preserve critical systems, addressing 25.905(d).

Expert note: Flight-test envelopes include intentional rapid engine accelerations and windmilling dives to verify that FADEC or mechanical limiters prevent shaft overspeed, directly satisfying 25.905(b).

section_intent: The rule ensures that the vibration loads experienced by propeller blades in any normal flight condition are measured, understood and kept below fatigue-safe limits. In plain terms, the applicant must either instrument the actual propeller/engine installation or rely on proven, closely-matched data to show that the cyclic stresses created by rpm changes, aerodynamic loading, and engine firing pulses will not cause cracking or separation during the aircraft’s life. This prevents catastrophic blade failure, secondary damage to the airframe or occupants, and loss of thrust. "Safe for continuous operation" means stresses are below the endurance limit or within a validated fatigue life established under CS-P 530/550. Put simply: know the vibration, keep it below what the blade can safely endure, and prove it with data.
ai_notes: Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 529 (EMB-120, 1995): a propeller blade fractured in flight after unseen fatigue cracking; highlighted the need to verify actual vibratory stress levels versus allowable limits.

Expert note: During certification, propellers are strain-gauged and the engine is slowly run through all rpm to identify resonant peaks (1P, 2P, etc.); data are used to create a "vibration envelope" that must stay inside safe stress curves.

Case: 1988 Horizon Air DHC-8 incident where excessive cabin vibration led to precautionary shutdown; investigation traced to out-of-tolerance blade tracking, illustrating how imbalance can raise stress towards critical limits.
Expert note: Manufacturers apply finite-element models validated by flight test to ensure blade root stresses at critical harmonics remain below the Goodman diagram limits set in CS-P 550.
Industry practice: Routine dynamic balancing and tracking checks at maintenance intervals reduce in-service vibration, aligning operational practice with the certification assumptions of CS 25.907.

section_intent: The rule ensures that, under the worst credible loading and attitude conditions, a propeller never hits the ground or the aircraft itself. Adequate ground, radial, and longitudinal clearances protect against “prop-strikes,” which can shatter blades, send debris into the cabin or fuel tanks, cause engine separation, or render the aeroplane uncontrollable. By requiring clearances with maximum weight, most aft/forward centre-of-gravity (CG), extreme blade pitch, deflated tyres, and bottomed-out struts, the rule guards against everyday taxi, take-off, landing, and maintenance scenarios as well as abnormal events (e.g., flat tyres). It also demands extra space to avoid harmful vibration that can propagate through the airframe, preventing fatigue cracks and cabin noise. Overall, CS 25.925 preserves structural integrity, engine thrust, and occupant safety during all ground and low-altitude phases.
ai_notes: SAS Dash-8 Q400 (Vilnius & Aalborg, 2007): main-gear collapse let propellers slice through the fuselage; clearance margins would have prevented penetration if gear had remained upright, demonstrating why propeller/ground margins are vital even with strut compression.

Piper PA-31T taxi incident, Brisbane 2015: a flat nose-wheel tyre caused the aircraft to pitch forward, both propellers struck the pavement, leading to costly engine teardown—illustrates the ‘critical tyre deflated’ test condition.

Expert note: Regional turboprops often install ‘prop cuffs’ to reduce noise; CS 25.925’s 13 mm longitudinal margin ensures these cuffs cannot touch inboard struts or de-ice boots during maximum beta-pitch ground operations.

Beechcraft 1900 fatigue case (1990s): repeated minor prop tip–fuselage contacts during reverse-thrust tests induced tailplane vibration and rivet cracking; the 25 mm radial rule plus extra for vibration addresses this failure mode.

Expert note: Certification flight-test manuals require a “rock-and-roll” push on the horizontal stabiliser while the aircraft sits on deflated tyres to visually confirm prop clearance—an industry best practice deriving directly from CS 25.925.

ATR-72 Florence 1998: runway excursion ended with propellers digging into soil, tearing off blades that penetrated cabin floor; although beyond design envelope, the event reinforces why designers maximise initial clearance to provide extra safety margin.

section_intent: CS 25.929 makes sure that any transport-category aeroplane approved for flight in icing conditions carries a propeller-ice protection system that can stop dangerous ice from building up or quickly remove it before it degrades thrust, causes severe vibration, upsets engine operation, or sheds into the airframe. The rule references the icing envelopes in Appendices C (standard icing) and O (super-cooled large droplets) so the system must work in all legally defined icing environments. If the design uses a combustible fluid (e.g. alcohol spray) the installation must also satisfy the fire-protection rules of CS 25.1181-1189. In plain language: the propeller and its accessories must stay ice-free enough to keep the engine healthy and the aircraft controllable throughout any authorised icing encounter.
ai_notes: Accident: Horizon Air Flight 2412 (DHC-8-103, 1988) suffered heavy propeller icing that caused severe vibration and dual engine flame-outs; the event highlighted how quickly unbalanced blades can jeopardise propulsion and spurred closer scrutiny of de-ice effectiveness.

EASA AD 2006-0285 on ATR 42/72 required redesign of the electrical propeller-de-ice harness after multiple reports of uneven shedding that produced cockpit-level vibrations exceeding limits—direct evidence of the hazard CS 25.929 targets.

Expert note: Certification flight tests place the aircraft in natural or simulated Appendix C & O icing and measure prop-torque, RPM and vibration; if ice causes exceedance of approved limits before the system activates, the design fails CS 25.929 compliance.

Industry practice: Modern turboprops use sequential electric boot heating, cycling each blade every 30–60 s so no blade can accumulate a hazardous ridge—this timing logic is derived directly from data gathered to meet CS 25.929.

Expert note: Maintenance programmes require periodic continuity checks of propeller-de-ice wiring and visual inspection of blade boots; a single inoperative heater strip can allow asymmetric ice build-up leading to imbalance, the classic failure mode the rule aims to prevent.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that any device that puts jet or propeller thrust into reverse is fail-safe. For systems meant only for landing roll-out, it demands proof that an unintended in-flight deployment will not jeopardise the aircraft, or that the probability of such an event is extremely remote and its effects benign (as judged by CS-25.1309). For systems permitted for use in flight, it requires that no single failure or likely combination of failures can create an unsafe condition during any phase of operation. It also obliges manufacturers to limit engine output to idle (or the minimum thrust that still lets the pilot keep directional control if a reverser sticks) when a malfunction occurs. For propeller installations, similar analyses or tests must show that no credible failure can drive the blades into an unwanted reverse pitch. In short, CS-25.933 exists to ensure that thrust-reversing hardware cannot inadvertently generate hazardous forces that would overpower aerodynamic control, damage the structure, or cause loss of control.
ai_notes: Lauda Air Flight 004 (1991): An uncommanded deployment of a Boeing 767’s left-engine thrust reverser in cruise caused an in-flight breakup, illustrating the catastrophic risk the rule aims to prevent.
TAM Flight 402 (Fokker 100, 1996): Reverser unlocked during take-off, producing asymmetrical thrust and runway overrun, highlighting the need for multiple locks and weight-on-wheels interlocks.

Expert note: Early jet transports relied on a single hydraulic lock; certification experience showed that leaks or mis-rigging could spontaneously unlock the buckets, leading to today’s requirement for redundant, independent locks and position indications.

Expert note: Compliance test programmes now include flight-test demonstrations of continued safe flight with one engine at idle and buckets deployed, proving the aircraft remains controllable per 25.143 even in worst-case reverser events.
Expert note: Software FADEC logic is validated so that any disagreement between stow-switches or sleeve-position sensors commands automatic fuel cutback to idle, satisfying 25.933(a)(3).

Propeller overspeed event on Saab 340 (1998): Erroneous blade-angle feedback let blades drive below flight low-pitch, creating high drag; the incident underlines why CS-25.933(b) mandates analysis/testing against unwanted reverse thrust on turboprops.

Best practice: Operators include thrust-reverser lock-out checks on every ‘After Take-off’ and ‘Before Landing’ checklist, and maintenance organisations perform periodic rigging inspections to ensure dual-actuator symmetry, aligning with the intent of preventing latent failures.

section_intent: Ensure that any thrust-reverser fitted to a turbo-jet engine is proven, through the detailed tests and fail-safe criteria of CS-E 890, to operate only when intended, to fail without endangering the aircraft, and to give the crew clear status information. In plain terms, the rule seeks to prevent uncommanded or asymmetric reverser deployment in flight, guarantee adequate stopping power on landing, and verify that any single fault cannot lead to loss of control or structural damage.
ai_notes: Lauda Air Flight 004 (1991): An in-flight, uncommanded deployment of a B767’s thrust reverser caused an uncontrollable roll and crash, illustrating why rigorous anti-deployment locks and tests are mandatory.

Expert note: Typical failure modes—hydraulic leaks, electrical shorts, or FADEC logic errors—are specifically recreated during CS-E 890 tests to show that no single failure can move a sleeve or bucket beyond a safe position.

TAM Flight 402 (1996): A partially deployed Fokker 100 reverser on take-off produced asymmetric thrust and a fatal runway excursion, underscoring the need to verify controllability with one reverser unlocked.

Expert note: Compliance practice includes weight-on-wheels sensors, dual-channel command circuits, and independent mechanical latches; test plans must demonstrate proper operation after rejected take-offs, go-arounds, and engine shut-downs.

Industry best practice: Manufacturers now run endurance cycles and ingestion tests on full-scale rigs before flight-test, ensuring reverser actuation systems meet the reliability targets embedded in CS-E 890.

section_intent: The rule ensures that turboprop aeroplanes have propeller-drag limiting devices (such as auto-feather, pitch-lock, beta-lockout or similar back-up mechanisms) that are fail-safe. If any single component or control channel in those systems fails, the propeller must not move to a blade angle that creates more drag than the airframe and controllability were originally designed to withstand under CS 25.367 flight-load conditions. In plain language, one fault must never let a propeller "windmill" or go into reverse so much that it endangers the structure or makes the aircraft uncontrollable; only combinations of failures so unlikely that they are “extremely remote” may be excluded.
ai_notes: ASA Flight 2311 (EMB-120, 1991): a propeller control-cable failure let one propeller drive to a low blade angle, producing huge drag and loss of control—an event that highlighted the need for single-failure protections.

Expert note: A common failure mode is loss of oil pressure in the propeller governor; compliance designs counterweights and springs that automatically drive the blades toward feather so drag stays within certified limits.

Dash 8 Q400 certification practice: flight-test teams deliberately fail the auto-feather circuit and governor to show that the mechanical pitch-stop still caps drag, demonstrating that one fault cannot exceed CS 25.367 loads.

ATR-72 Lao Airlines Flight 301 (2013): uncommanded propeller pitch change during go-around generated excessive asymmetric drag and contributed to loss of control, reinforcing regulators’ focus on robust drag-limiting architecture.

section_intent: The rule makes sure a turbine-powered aircraft and its engines behave predictably in every corner of the approved flight envelope. During flight tests the applicant must prove that, with any permitted power setting, throttle movement, or manoeuvre, the engines will not stall, surge, flame-out or vibrate in a way that could endanger the aircraft, and that the inlet design does not create harmful airflow distortion. In short: within all certified limits, the engine must keep running smoothly and safely, even in emergency procedures, without destructive vibration or loss of thrust.
ai_notes: National Airlines Flight 27, 1973: A DC-10 experienced a compressor stall and inflight turbine failure after inlet distortion at high Mach—highlighted need to flight-test stall/surge margins across the whole speed range.

British Airways Flight 038, 2008: Dual Rolls-Royce Trent 772 surge during rapid thrust increase on final underscored requirement to show no hazardous surge with normal throttle movements and distorted inlet flow (ice shedding).
Expert note: Certification flight tests include rapid throttle chops, wind-up turns, and sideslips to verify flame-out does not occur during go-arounds or steep descents within published limits.
Expert note: S-duct centre engines on tri-jets (e.g., L-1011) require special inlet distortion surveys; any vibration peaks are corrected with bleed doors or guide vanes per CS 25.939(c).

Industry practice: Engine manufacturers publish ‘surge lines’ and minimum idle relight envelopes derived from CS 25.939 demonstrations; airlines train crews to avoid operating below these margins during abnormal procedures.
Japan Airlines 747-SR Flight test program (1980s): Detected cross-wind induced inlet distortion on take-off; led to nacelle lip redesign, validating rule clause (c) against vibration-induced damage.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that any aircraft whose engines use moving inlets or exhaust nozzles (for example variable-area fan nozzles, translating plug thrust reversers or supersonic intake ramps) continues to fly safely in every conceivable configuration and power setting. The whole system—air intake, engine, thrust-boost devices and exhaust—must keep working as intended, and any failures or transitions must not create sudden pitch, roll or yaw changes that would demand unusual strength or lightning-fast reactions from the pilot. In short, the aircraft must remain controllable within the normal CS-25 pilot-force limits no matter how the inlet or nozzle moves or malfunctions.
ai_notes: Concorde flight-test programme (early 1970s): uncommanded intake ramp oscillations produced violent engine surges; the event drove the requirement to prove that intake control logic cannot jeopardise aircraft controllability.

F-14A mishap USS John F. Kennedy 1976: stuck variable intake ramp caused compressor stalls and strong yaw transients, highlighting how inlet failures can overwhelm a pilot; although military, it underpins civil design guidance on inlet failure effects.

Expert note: Modern biz-jets with variable-area fan nozzles (e.g. Global 7500/GE Passport) must flight-test with the nozzle failed in every position to document pitch-moment changes and verify that CS-25.143 control-force limits are not exceeded.

Expert note: Certification plans routinely include wind-tunnel and CFD studies to predict aerodynamic pitching moments when a translating sleeve thrust reverser or VAFN moves, followed by flight-test validation across the full Mach/altitude envelope.

GE CF34 thrust-reverser ‘bucket’ asymmetry ground test (early CRJ programmes): demonstrated that even partial nozzle deployment at climb thrust does not require more than 75 lbf of pilot force, directly mapping to the §25.143(d) limits referenced in the rule.

Expert note: Compliance teams run simulator sessions where inlet-control computers are failed or frozen at extreme positions; pilots must be able to maintain speed and avoid structural limits without exceeding the stick-force thresholds.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that when an aeroplane experiences negative g-loads (i.e. pushes over so occupants feel light or weightless) anywhere inside the approved manoeuvring envelope, its engines and any powerplant-related systems (fuel, oil, controls, sensors) keep working safely. ‘Hazardous malfunction’ means anything that could lead to engine failure, fire, loss of thrust, or damage serious enough to jeopardise the flight. Designers must prove, for the longest negative-g period the aircraft is allowed to see, that fuel still reaches the engine, lubrication continues, and electronic or mechanical parts are not starved, aerated, or broken. In simple terms: even in the most aggressive but still legal push-over, the engines must keep running and not hurt the aircraft.
ai_notes: Accident: Boeing 727-200 N844AA (1988), sudden push-over during turbulence led to dual engine flame-outs when fuel unported; highlighted need for negative-g fuel pick-up qualification.

Accident: Lockheed L-1011 ‘Caledonian 263’ (near Nairobi, 1972) experienced compressor stalls during steep descent with low or negative g, showing susceptibility of early turbofans to inlet airflow disruption.
Expert note: Oil tanks can unport during −0.5 g causing loss of oil pressure; CS-25.943 drives rig and flight tests where engines are run at −1 g for >10 s to verify continuous lubrication.
Industry practice: Large-jet fuel systems incorporate ‘flapper valves’ and collector sumps that trap fuel near the boost pumps so suction is maintained in zero/negative g push-overs.
Expert note: FADEC logic is also subjected to inverted-rig tests to prove that accelerometer-based limit protections do not issue inappropriate thrust commands when sensing rapid g-vector changes.

Training best practice: Flight-test crews perform pushover manoeuvres at the most critical fuel load (max lateral imbalance, min permissible fuel) to demonstrate compliance with CS 25.943 before certification sign-off.

section_intent: CS-25.945 protects the aircraft, engines, and occupants when a thrust- or power-augmentation fluid (e.g., water, water-methanol, spray intercooler liquid) is carried and injected into the engine. It requires the system to deliver the correct flow and pressure for all approved operating modes, and to remain safe if the fluid can freeze. Tanks and plumbing must tolerate vibration, manoeuvre and pressure loads, have adequate venting and expansion space, and resist leakage or rupture. Where fluid might be jettisoned, drainage must avoid ice accretion and fire risks. Finally, enough fluid must be carried to match the certified operating procedures and ambient conditions so engines are never asked to deliver augmented thrust once the supply is exhausted. In short, the rule prevents structural failure, engine malfunction, asymmetrical thrust, or fire caused by augmentation fluids, ensuring predictable performance throughout the flight envelope.
ai_notes: TWA Boeing 707 (SFO, 1965): Water-injection pump failed during take-off, producing unequal thrust and a heavy rejected take-off; investigators cited inadequate pressure margin—mirrored in paragraph (a)’s flow/pressure requirement.
Expert note: Early JT3C and Spey engines suffered compressor stalls when partially frozen water-methanol clogged nozzles; the rule’s freeze-tolerance and drain provisions target this failure mode.

Boeing 727 water-methanol tank burst while being filled in sub-zero conditions after vent ice blocked pressure relief (1970s maintenance event); 1.5× proof pressure and effective venting in paragraph (b) would have prevented the rupture.

Expert note: Flight-test campaigns revealed crews could exhaust water supply before top-of-climb on very hot days, causing thrust rollback; paragraph (d) forces conservative sizing based on worst-case temperature and consumption rates.

Expert note: Structural-and-vibration bench tests on belly-mounted augmentation tanks now simulate engine-out yaw and landing loads to confirm no leakage of flammable methanol onto hot brakes, aligning with paragraph (b)(1).

Best practice: Business jets with spray-cooling systems incorporate filler neck standpipes and placards so ramp personnel cannot overfill, guaranteeing the mandatory 2 % expansion space required by paragraph (b)(5).

section_intent: CS-25.951 requires turbine-aircraft fuel systems to keep supplying each engine with the right amount of fuel, at the right pressure, in every flight attitude and environmental condition that can reasonably be expected in service. The system must tolerate brief ingestion of air without causing the engines to flame out, and it must keep working even when the fuel contains the levels of dissolved and free water normally found in aviation kerosene that later chills to icing conditions. In plain terms, the rule makes designers prove that their tanks, pumps, lines, vents and heaters will not let an engine quit because of sloshing, negative-g manoeuvres, trapped air, or ice crystals—problems that historically caused loss of power and, sometimes, entire aircraft.
ai_notes: British Airways Flight 38 (B777, 2008): Ice that formed from normal water content during long-haul cruise migrated and blocked the fuel-oil heat exchangers, starving both engines on approach; the accident highlighted exactly why CS-25.951 demands operation with water-laden fuel cooled to worst-case icing temperatures.

Cathay Pacific B777 events (2007–2009): Multiple engine rollback incidents traced to ice restricting fuel flow prompted strengthened compliance guidance on cold-soak and ice-accumulation testing under this rule.

Expert note: Certification tests place the aircraft on tilting rigs and fly qualification manoeuvre profiles (steep climbs, dives, 60° banks) with minimum fuel to prove continuous, bubble-free flow and verify that air ingestion does not cause flameout, directly addressing 25.951(a) and (b).

Expert note: Designers add boost pumps, swirl pots, and flapper-type baffles near tank outlets so that even at low fuel levels or during negative-g bursts the suction line remains immersed, preventing air entry and pressure drop required by 25.951(b).

Expert note: Water-tolerant elements such as fuel heaters, recirculating pumps and ice-tolerant filter media are incorporated because 25.951(c) obliges the system to run with fuel cooled below freezing while still containing entrained water.

section_intent: The rule makes manufacturers prove—through engineering analysis and any tests EASA deems necessary—that the complete fuel system will deliver clean, adequate, and continuous fuel to all engines in every realistic operating scenario (take-off, climb, cruise, descent, abnormal attitudes, temperature extremes, etc.).  It also insists that if a component that uses fuel to heat or cool another fluid (e.g. a fuel-oil heat exchanger) fails, the failure cannot create a fire, engine shutdown, loss of control, or other hazardous condition.  In short, the paragraph exists to prevent fuel starvation, vapour-lock, leakage, fire, or contamination events that have historically brought down aircraft, and to ensure that novel thermal management schemes using fuel as a heat sink remain intrinsically safe.
ai_notes: British Airways Flight 38 (B777-200ER, 2008): ice crystals accumulated in the fuel system and blocked the fuel-oil heat exchanger, causing dual engine rollback on short final; post-accident actions tightened fuel-system icing analysis and FOHE test requirements, illustrating why rigorous analysis/testing is mandated.

Expert note: Fuel-oil heat exchangers are now designed with double walls and leak-before-burst features so that, if a tube ruptures, the system vents fluid externally rather than mixing hot oil with fuel—directly addressing CS 25.952(b).

Expert note: Compliance demonstrations routinely include rig tests that cycle fuel from –40 °C to +60 °C while varying altitude and flow to verify pumps do not cavitate and vapour does not form, preventing flameouts observed on early jet transports in hot-day, high-altitude climbs.

Boeing 747-400 operator incidents (1990s): cross-feed valve wiring faults led to uncommanded closures and fuel imbalance; systematic Failure Mode and Effects Analysis (FMEA) now required under CS 25.952(a) identifies such single-point vulnerabilities before certification.

Expert note: Industry best practice is to run ‘wet-wing’ structural test articles on tilt tables that simulate extreme pitch/roll angles to make sure scavenging, venting, and transfer ejectors still keep boost pumps flooded during go-arounds or extended negative-g manoeuvres.

Airbus A330 Air Transat Flight 236 (2001): an incorrect hydraulic line caused massive fuel loss and dual engine flameout; although not a heat-exchanger issue, the event underlines the need for system-level analysis of all probable failure modes affecting fuel supply, a core intent of CS 25.952.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that no single failure, leak, blockage, fire, or crew action in the fuel system can shut down more than one engine. Each engine must have a dedicated, physically and functionally separate fuel feed—or an alternative arrangement that the authority finds equally safe—so that if one part of the system is lost, the other engines keep receiving fuel and the aircraft retains propulsion, electricity, and hydraulics needed for a safe flight and landing.
ai_notes: Air Transat Flight 236 (A330, 2001): Fuel leak in right engine line plus cross-feed bled the left tank dry, leading to dual flame-out; shows why engines need isolatable, independent feeds.
BOAC 707 G-APFN (Kano, 1969): Wing-root fire damaged a common fuel line and knocked out two engines on one side; spurred routing separation requirements.
Expert note: Compliance demonstrations plug or disable a boost pump, clog a filter, or close a valve to prove only the associated engine is affected.
Expert note: Best-practice architecture assigns each engine its own tank section, pumps, filter, and fire-wall shut-off, with cross-feed valves normally closed and amber-guarded.
Expert note: Crew training drills emphasise temporary cross-feed use and immediate re-isolation after imbalance correction to prevent simultaneous starvation.
Series of 1970s de-icing-fluid contamination flame-outs led to duplicating filters per engine instead of a single shared unit.
Expert note: Design guidance calls for fuel lines for left and right engines to run on opposite sides of the wing box so local battle damage or fire cannot sever both.
Maintenance case studies show that mis-wired breakers tripping both fuel pumps were eliminated by independent electrical feeds per engine pump.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that every part of an aeroplane’s fuel system is designed, installed and maintained so that a lightning strike cannot set fire to fuel vapours. It requires designers to consider the worst-case ("critical") lightning strikes, any possible single failure in protective features, and the natural flammability of each tank. The probability of a lightning-caused explosion must be kept at the "extremely improbable" level (≈ ≤1×10-9 per flight). Designers must also specify Critical Design Configuration Control Limitations (CDCCLs)—instructions, inspection intervals, and life limits that operators must follow—so the lightning-protection features (e.g. bonding jumpers, conductive foils, sealants) stay effective for the whole life of the aircraft. CDCCL information is recorded in the Airworthiness Limitations Section (ALS) of the Instructions for Continued Airworthiness (ICA) required by CS 25.1529.
ai_notes: Pan Am Flight 214 (1963): B707 lightning strike ignited fuel vapour in a wing tank; 81 fatalities. This accident directly drove modern lightning-protection criteria for fuel tanks.
Expert note: Typical failure mode the rule guards against is loss of a bonding strap or fastener, allowing arcing across a joint when lightning current flows through the wing skin adjacent to a tank.
Industry practice: Composite wings (e.g. B787, A350) use embedded copper mesh and conductive fasteners around tank boundaries to create a continuous low-resistance path and avoid internal sparking.

Expert note: Certification analysis uses SAE ARP5414 zoning and waveform criteria; manufacturers must show by test or validated simulation that peak voltages induced on fuel probes, pumps, and wiring stay below ignition thresholds.

Best-practice maintenance: CDCCLs place specific torque values and replacement intervals on fuel tank sealant, vapor barriers, and bonding jumpers so line-maintenance actions cannot inadvertently compromise lightning paths.

Incident—A320 line-maintenance (2005): improper replacement of a rib-foot seal removed conductive frit seals, discovered during inspection; highlighted why detailing protective features in the ALS is mandatory.

section_intent: Ensure each engine always receives enough fuel, at the right pressure, in every flight attitude or manoeuvre, even when a pump fails or a tank runs dry, without the crew having to intervene. This prevents flame-outs caused by pressure loss, un-ported fuel in low-level tanks, or flow-meter restrictions and guarantees that any automatic or manual tank-selection logic will not let an engine starve while usable fuel still remains elsewhere on board.
ai_notes: Case: ‘Gimli Glider’ B-767 (Air Canada 143, 1983) – Both engines quit after fuel exhaustion; the investigation reinforced the certification focus on proving full-rated flow with only the unusable quantity left in tanks.

Expert note: Early jetliners lost thrust when boost pumps failed and suction feed could not meet the engine’s minimum inlet pressure; §25.955 therefore makes flight-tests repeat the worst-case with a standby pump in place of each main pump.

Case: L-1011 N11002 (flight-test, 1971) – A blocked fuel-flowmeter body limited flow and caused an in-flight shutdown; para (a)(4) now requires demonstrating flow through the meter or its bypass when the line is obstructed.

Expert note: Wing-tip tanks on classic 707/DC-8 designs could run dry before in-board tanks, leading to sudden engine flame-out if crews forgot to switch; para (b)(2) now obliges automatic, no-action cross-feed whenever a dedicated tank empties.

Best practice: Modern transports use dual ejector/boost systems and fuel-management software that continuously balance tanks and keep each engine’s feed line pressurised, a standard method of showing compliance during ground and flight tests.

section_intent: When an aircraft can transfer fuel from one tank to another in flight, the receiving tank must never be stressed beyond its limits. CS-25.957 therefore requires vents big enough to let air escape or enter and a transfer system (pumps, valves, sensors, logic) that stops before the tank is over-filled. The aim is to prevent structural deformation, leaks, or rupture that could lead to fuel spillage, fires, or even loss of a wing or fuselage section.
ai_notes: Lockheed Electra certification, 1959: Rapid centre-to-wing transfer bowed the upper wing skin in flight test, prompting redesign of surge vents and providing a case study for this rule.

Expert note: If a cross-feed or ballast transfer pump is left on after refuelling a trim tank, fuel can be forced into an already full outer tank; without adequate venting the incompressible fuel can buckle ribs and crack spar webs—exactly the failure mode CS-25.957 forbids.

Air France A340-300 F-GLZL (2005): A failed auto-shut-off kept the centre-to-outer transfer running; cockpit "FUEL OVFL" alert and vent fuel discharge proved the detection/relief features worked, averting structural damage and illustrating compliant design.

Expert note: Modern big twins use dual-level sensors and software interlocks that stop transfer pumps and open return paths when surge tanks fill, a best practice introduced to show compliance with CS-25.957.

Early 707 development flights recorded tank pressure spikes when wing-tip vents iced up during high-altitude transfer; the data drove industry-wide vent-sizing charts now referenced in certification reports.

section_intent: CS 25.959 makes sure that the fuel quantity an operator calls "usable" is truly available to the engines in every normal flight attitude and manoeuvre. During certification the manufacturer must show, by flight test, the precise fuel level at which the first cough, flame-out or pressure fluctuation appears under the worst foreseeable feed conditions (steep climb, descent, sideslip, low fuel pressure, etc.). Everything below that point is logged as “unusable fuel” and is excluded from performance calculations and dispatch fuel planning. The rule prevents crews from over-estimating range or endurance and eliminates hidden starvation risks without requiring designers to credit improbable component failures. (≈120 words)
ai_notes: Expert note: Tests routinely include long, shallow descents at idle power—where low acceleration forces let fuel run away from tank sumps—to be sure flameout will not occur before the declared unusable quantity.

Expert note: Cross-controlled sideslip trials on wing-tank jets confirm that the outboard tank pickup stays covered when the wing is low in approach or go-around, a condition that previously caused engine hiccups in early 707 flight tests and helped shape today’s wording.

Accident: Beechcraft Duke N350TM (Texas, 1985) crashed after both engines quit with indicated fuel remaining; investigation showed certification had understated unusable fuel during steep-bank flight—highlighting why conservative margins are vital.

Industry practice: AFM fuel tables always list "usable" and "unusable" gallons separately; dispatchers and flight-planning software exclude the latter so endurance predictions remain valid even at reserve levels.

Expert note: Modern swept-wing jets with multiple collector tanks use scavenge pumps and flapper valves; CS 25.959 testing verifies these devices keep at least one pickup flooded during prolonged lateral acceleration on take-off rotation.

Real event: Early Lockheed L-188 Electra prototypes flamed out during -1 g pushover tests, prompting redesign of fuel pickups and reinforcing the need for worst-case manoeuvre assessment now embedded in 25.959.

Best practice: Flight-test pilots progressively drain tanks in flight while performing the required manoeuvre matrix; the exact fuel weight at first pressure drop is measured with calibrated gauges to set the AFM unusable figure.
Expert note: Training syllabi remind crews that "usable fuel" already contains this margin, discouraging risky assumptions such as banking steeply on final with near-empty wing tanks.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that, even on the hottest day at a high-elevation airport, the fuel reaching every engine stays in a liquid state and at a pressure high enough to avoid vapour bubbles, pump cavitation or flow interruption. The applicant must either prove analytically that positive pressure is maintained from each tank outlet to the engine inlet, or demonstrate it through a take-off-to-ceiling climb (or a ground test that realistically mimics that climb) with fuel heated to at least 43 °C. By requiring the worst-case combination of full fuel, maximum power, high temperature and climb to maximum altitude, the regulation guarantees that engines will not lose thrust because of vapour lock, assuring safe take-off, climb and continued flight in “hot-and-high” conditions.
ai_notes: Expert note: During early Boeing 707 desert flight-tests, climb-out at 46 °C caused inlet pressure at the engine fuel pumps to drop below Jet-A vapour pressure, producing transient flame-outs; the solution—boost-pump pressurisation—was later folded into the original FAR 25.961 wording.

Expert note: Certification teams now instrument the entire feed line and run ground ‘hot-soak’ rigs that heat fuel to 50 °C and reduce ambient pressure to 0.4 bar, proving a minimum positive NPSH (net positive suction head) margin at every pump inlet.

Expert note: Operators of high-utilisation narrow-body fleets schedule tank-conditioning flights or recirculate cool centre-tank fuel into the wings before peak-temperature departures from airports such as Dubai or Phoenix to pre-empt vapour lock complaints.

Failure mode: On a hot-and-high day, low wing-tank fuel head combined with climb-induced pressure drop can let dissolved gases come out of Jet-A, forming bubbles that starve the engine LP pump and cause an automatic power rollback—a scenario CS 25.961 forces manufacturers to preclude.

Best practice: Modern designs keep wing tanks slightly pressurised with nitrogen-enriched air and use ejector or electric boost pumps that guarantee at least 6 psi at the engine pump inlet throughout the envelope, directly addressing the intent of 25.961.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that every fuel tank on a large airplane is strong, inspectable, and placed so that, even in severe turbulence, hard landings, gear or engine break-offs, burst tyres or flying debris, the tank will not split open or leak enough fuel to feed a fire inside the cabin or around the engines. It demands that tanks survive vibration, G-loads, pressure surges and crushing with enough margin that occupants could still escape a survivable crash. The rule also requires liners to be suitable, tanks to be accessible for inspection/repair, covers to resist fire, and pressure-relief features to stop a tank from bursting during pressure refuelling or system faults. In short, CS-25.963 aims to keep the fuel where it belongs—inside a damage-tolerant tank—so a controllable event does not turn into a catastrophic post-crash fire.
ai_notes: Concorde AF4590 (2000): A strip of metal on the runway pierced a wing tank; leaking fuel ignited and led to loss of the aircraft. Requirements for debris and tyre-fragment penetration in 25.963(e)(1) directly trace back to this and earlier tyre-burst events.

Continental DC-10 Flight 603 (1978): Multiple tyres burst on take-off, fragments ruptured the wing tank and started a major fire; illustrates why tank and access-cover zones near wheels must resist wheel and tyre debris.

Expert note: Wing-drop tests during certification deliberately grind a fuel-filled wing into a concrete surface to verify that structural crushing and scraping under CS 25.721(b) does not cause significant fuel spillage or ignition.
Expert note: Modern wide-bodies route plumbing and provide fail-safe vents so pressure-refuelling cannot over-pressurise an integral wing tank, complying with 25.963(f).

Qantas A380 VH-OQA (2010) uncontained engine failure: Shrapnel punctured the left wing but localisation of tank bays and anti-spray liners limited fuel release, showing the benefit of internal barriers and design features anticipated by 25.963(d)(3).
Expert note: Operators train maintenance staff to inspect flexible bladder linings for wrinkles, cracking or delamination during scheduled heavy checks, satisfying 25.963(b) and (c).
Expert note: Aluminium or fire-resistant composite access panels are sized and bolt-patterned to stay attached for at least five minutes in 1 100 °C pool-fire tests, meeting 25.963(e)(2).

section_intent: Make sure every fuel tank, exactly as it is installed in the aircraft, stays intact and leak-free throughout all normal and limit operating conditions. The rule forces manufacturers to prove—mainly by physical vibration, pressure-and-sloshing tests—that tank walls, joints and supports can handle: (1) internal pressure surges of at least 24 kPa (3.5 psi); (2) extra air pressure from high-speed ram-air; (3) liquid loads created by maximum g-forces and structural deflection; and (4) the worst combination of banking and fuel quantity. Metallic tanks with large flat panels must also survive long-duration vibration and rocking, while non-metallic or pressurised tanks must meet equivalent demonstrations. In plain terms, CS-25.965 exists to prevent fuel leaks or ruptures that could ignite, starve engines or weaken the airframe, by guaranteeing the tank structure is strong enough under pressure, manoeuvre and vibration stresses.
ai_notes: Real event – Concorde F-BTSCP (2000): Falling tyre debris punctured an over-stressed wing tank, fuel leaked and ignited; the subsequent retrofit added Kevlar liners and stiffer panels, illustrating why tanks must resist deformation and leakage.

Expert note: Early jet transports saw rib-to-skin cracking in wing tanks after prolonged vibration and pressure cycling; CS-25.965’s 25-hour vibration/rocking test was introduced to replicate those service loads before entry into service.

Real event – Boeing 737 AD 2001-08-22: Fatigue cracks in centre-wing tank skin/stringers caused seepage; enforced inspections and stiffener additions echo the rule’s demand that large unstiffened panels be proven against vibration-induced failure.

Expert note: High-speed dives on flight-test routinely generate ram-air pressures above 20 kPa in vent lines; the 125 % ram-pressure criterion ensures margin against such transients and blocked-vent scenarios.

Real event – Learjet 25D accident N546PA (1999): Fuel starvation traced to unanticipated slosh under high-bank manoeuvres; proper CS-25.965 testing forces designers to verify worst-case roll and fuel-load combinations.

Expert note: Many operators fit bladder-type auxiliary tanks; compliance is shown by repeating the CS-25.965(b)(5) rocking test at 43 °C fuel, proving elastomeric material will not creep or chafe and leak in hot cabins.

Industry practice: During ground vibration testing (GVT), manufacturers often co-run CS-25.965 vibration demonstrations, saving time while ensuring the fuel tanks can handle coupled wing/engine frequencies identified as critical.

Best practice: Certification teams review strain-gauge data from structural-qualification flights to validate that in-service dynamic pressures never exceed the test envelope, providing post-test assurance that CS-25.965 margins remain intact.

section_intent: CS-25.967 makes sure fuel tanks are mounted, protected and separated so that they cannot crack, chafe, over-pressurise or leak fumes into the cabin. The rule demands proper structural support, non-absorbent padding and smooth tank compartments so liners or metal walls are not worn through by vibration or fuel weight. Adequate ventilation or drainage keeps vapours from building up, while prohibiting nacelle skin as a tank wall behind hot exhaust avoids heat-weakened structure. Finally, a fuel- and fume-tight barrier must isolate every tank from passenger or crew spaces. In short: support the tank, stop it rubbing, let it breathe, keep it cool and keep any fuel or fumes away from people.
ai_notes: Case: TWA Flight 800 (1996) – Center-wing tank explosion showed how trapped vapours can detonate; ventilation and fume-proof isolation in CS 25.967 target the same hazard.
Case: Airbus A330 VH-QPA (2008) – In-flight fuel leak traced to pipe chafing on tank wall; demonstrates need for pads and smooth tank interiors in 25.967(a)(1)–(4).
Expert note: Static and fatigue ground-load tests confirm ribs and spars carry fuel weight, proving compliance with 25.967(a) by avoiding stress on unsupported skin panels.
Case: Boeing 747-400 nacelle fairing crack SB 57-2313 – Discovery of cracks where nacelle skin formed part of an integral tank prompted design changes, mirroring 25.967(d)’s prohibition.
Expert note: OEMs use cork-rubber anti-chafe strips and fuel-resistant nitrile coatings under bladder tanks to satisfy the non-absorbent padding requirement.
Expert note: Cabin floor and sidewall areas adjacent to wing tanks are lined with sealed aluminium panels and continuous drain paths to meet 25.967(e) fume- and fuel-proof separation.

section_intent: Fuel volume grows when temperature rises or when entrained air is released after loading. If a tank were filled to the very top, this expansion would either push liquid fuel out through the vents, where it could ignite on hot surfaces, or build internal pressure that could deform the tank. CS 25.969 therefore requires every transport-category aeroplane to reserve at least 2 % of each tank’s capacity as empty ‘ullage’ space and to arrange filler necks or pressure-fuelling shut-off so that the crew or ground staff cannot accidentally eliminate that space while the aircraft sits in its normal ground attitude. The rule protects against spills, vent blockage, structural damage and fire during all ground and flight temperature ranges, and it dovetails with CS 25.979(b) which governs automatic shut-off for pressure fuelling.
ai_notes: Nine‐O‐Nine B-17 (2019, Windsor Locks): investigators found that post-refuel venting left pools of fuel under the wing which later ignited after engine start—classic illustration of how overfilling can create fire hazards on the ramp.

Expert note: During long turn-arounds in hot climates, fuel loaded at cool early-morning temperatures regularly expands by more than 1 % by afternoon; without prescribed ullage the resulting vent overflow can reach several litres per wing, endangering ground personnel and APU intakes.

Boeing Service Letter BSL-28-0252: reports multiple 737NG events where pressure fuelling shut-off valves mis-set below the 2 % ullage line caused tanks to pressurise and crack vent surge tanks—industry used these reports to justify strict CS 25.969 interpretation.

MD-11F fire, Memphis 2006: maintenance records showed previous incidents of fuel surge tank rupture during rapid pressure fuelling; FedEx subsequently imposed procedural limits ensuring the 2 % expansion margin is always retained.

Expert note: Training syllabi for ramp staff highlight that the fuelling panel ‘high-level’ lights are calibrated to cut off with roughly 2–3 % free space, directly tracing back to CS 25.969 requirements.
Airbus A320 AMM task 12-11-28: after maintenance defuelling, technicians must refill only to 98 % capacity and perform a drip-check to verify ullage—best-practice compliance step driven by this rule.

section_intent: The rule ensures that any water or debris that inevitably enters an aircraft’s fuel tanks collects in a dedicated low-point (the sump) large enough to hold it until it can be drained on the ground. By mandating minimum sump volume, free flow of contaminants to the sump, and a secure, externally venting drain that can be locked closed, the regulation aims to prevent water from reaching the engines in flight, where it can cause flame-outs, filter icing/blockage, corrosion, or microbial growth. In plain terms, the requirement gives crews and maintenance personnel a reliable place to sample and remove unwanted water before every flight, thereby protecting engine reliability and structural integrity of the fuel system.
ai_notes: Air Canada DC-9, Montréal-Ottawa (1978): Both engines flamed out on climb when slugs of water left over from overnight cold soak entered the fuel control units; post-event analysis highlighted inadequate sump size and drainage access.

Expert note: Routine pre-flight walk-around on transport jets includes taking a clear glass sample from each tank’s sump drain—if any water beads are seen, the tank is re-drained until the sample runs clear, a direct operational use of this rule.

Expert note: Microbial growth ("fuel bugs") thrives at the water–fuel interface; providing a defined sump volume allows biocide treatment and inspection teams to target and flush the lowest point, slowing corrosion and filter clogging.

USAF KC-135 fleet (1960s) experienced multiple dual-engine flame-outs traced to water trapped in outboard bays that could not reach small sumps; design retrofit increased sump volume and added positive-locking drain valves—an action mirrored in modern CS-25 wording.

Best practice: Manufacturers angle internal tank ribs and stringers toward the sump and avoid sealant dams so that, in the normal parking attitude, gravity automatically channels any hazardous water quantity to the drain point as required by CS 25.971(b).

section_intent: This rule makes sure that when an aircraft is fuelled, every drop goes into the tank, any accidental spill is carried safely away, the tank stays sealed in flight, and static electricity cannot ignite fuel vapour. Specifically, it requires filler designs that stop fuel from seeping into wings, cabins or wheel-wells; drains for recessed ports so puddled fuel cannot migrate to hot or sparking equipment; caps that stay leak-tight under pressure changes and vibration; and a bonding point so the aircraft and the fuel truck are at the same electric potential before the nozzle is opened. Together these measures prevent ramp fires, structural corrosion, environmental contamination and in-flight fuel loss or explosion.
ai_notes: ERJ-145 ramp fire, Jacksonville (USA, 2001): A missing bonding clip allowed static discharge to ignite vapour at the wing filler port; the fire was contained but the wing was damaged, showing why dedicated bonding lugs are mandatory.

Expert note: Recessed flush filler ports can trap spilled fuel; without a drain, liquid can run into wheel-wells where hot brakes or generators sit, hence CS-25 demands drains that dump clear of the airframe.

Boeing 737-800 leak, Alicante (2016): Aircraft returned after take-off when fuel streamed from the wing root; investigators found a filler cap not fully latched, underscoring the need for caps that form a positive, leak-proof seal.

Expert note: Certification includes shake-table and wing-flex tests with full tanks to verify caps stay tight and drains work; airlines mirror this by training fuellers to bond first, visually confirm cap lock, and wipe recesses dry so any blockage of the drain is immediately obvious.

section_intent: The rule ensures every fuel tank has a reliable breathing path so that pressure equalises during all phases of flight, ground operations, and refuelling. The vents must stay clear of ice, dirt or trapped water, and be routed so fuel cannot escape or siphon away. They also must be sized so rapid climbs, descents, or high-flow refuelling never overstress tank walls or interfere with fuel delivery. Outlet locations must not discharge fuel near hot surfaces or cabin inlets, and any interconnected tanks must share their airspace so one tank is not pressurised relative to the other. Finally, the system must include flame arresting features that hold back an external fire for at least 2 min 30 s, giving the crew time to shut fuel off or extinguish the fire before flames can flash back into the vapour space and detonate the tank.
ai_notes: Cessna 310R N44742 (Florida, 1983): Mud-dauber nests blocked a wing-tank vent; vacuum stopped fuel flow and both engines quit, proving the need for dirt-proof vent designs.
TWA Flight 800, B747-131 (1996): Centre-wing-tank explosion drove regulators to require flame-blocking features; CS-25.975(a)(7) now mandates 2 min 30 s flame arrest capability.
Expert note: High-altitude icing can freeze moisture in vent lines; manufacturers add heater blankets or locate outlets in warm boundary-layer air to satisfy 25.975(a)(1).
Expert note: Certification descent tests at ≥6 000 ft/min verify vents keep tank differential pressure within structural limits; large diameter lines and surge tanks are common solutions.
Industry practice: Vent outlets are routed aft of the wing, beyond engine exhaust and cabin intakes, so any fuel spray cannot ignite or enter the fuselage (25.975(a)(6)).
Early Boeing 707 service experience showed cruise fuel siphoning when vents faced relative wind; adding anti-siphon loops and check valves became a standard fix referenced by 25.975(a)(2).
Expert note: Interconnecting ullage spaces of saddle tanks prevents pressure imbalance during single-point refuelling, avoiding bladder collapse or wing skin ballooning.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that every fuel tank feeds the engines through a robust, easy-to-inspect screen (strainer) large enough to let the required fuel flow pass while stopping any loose parts, sealant, ice or debris that could block the line or damage pumps, valves and injectors. By mandating a minimum screen area five times bigger than the outlet line and at least the same diameter, the regulation guarantees low pressure loss even if some contamination accumulates. Accessibility for cleaning ensures that maintenance crews can quickly remove trapped debris before it becomes a hazard. In plain words: keep the bad stuff out of the fuel system without starving the engines, and make it easy to check that the screen is doing its job.
ai_notes: TACA Flight 110 (1988): After flying through heavy rain and hail, both 737 engines flamed out; debris and ice partially blocked boost-pump inlet screens but adequate sizing prevented total starvation, illustrating why generous screen area is required.

Expert note: Post-maintenance tank work often leaves sealant flakes or dropped fasteners; outlet finger strainers catch these objects before they reach high-speed fuel pumps where they could shatter impellers and cause immediate engine shutdown.

United Airlines 727 N7037U (1970 incident): A rag left in the center tank migrated to the outlet, reducing flow and forcing an emergency landing—an early case that drove regulators to stress accessibility for inspection and cleaning.

Expert note: Industry best practice is to specify stainless-steel wedge-wire screens with 40-mesh openings, sized ≥5× line area, mounted directly on booster pumps so any obstruction triggers a pressure drop that shows up on cockpit gauges.

ATR 72 Service Bulletin ATA-28-11 (2003): Reports of rubber particles from deteriorated fuel cell bladders found on outlet screens; proper strainer design prevented line blockage and gave operators a clear early-warning to replace the bladders.

Expert note: During cold-soak operations, ice crystals can detach and travel with fuel; a large-diameter, low-velocity strainer reduces the chance that ice bridges across the screen and starves the engine during climb.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that pressure-fuelling and defuelling operations are safe for people, the aircraft and the environment. It requires valves and couplings that will not dump large amounts of fuel if something jams, automatic high-level shut-off devices that can be tested before every fill and that warn the operator if they fail, back-up protection so the fuel tanks or plumbing are not damaged if shut-off malfunctions, and structural strength in the fuelling lines to cope with worst-case pressure surges or suction loads. In short, it prevents fuel spillage, over-filling, structural rupture or fires during fast, high-pressure fuelling by mandating reliable containment, over-fill protection, failure indication and adequate strength.
ai_notes: MyTravel A330 Manchester 2003: High-level shut-off was disabled during pressure fuelling; 4 000 L overflowed from the vents onto the ramp, highlighting the need for an automatic, testable cut-off and clear failure indication.
UPS DC-8 Miami 2006 ramp fire: A fuelling hose disconnected under pressure, spilling fuel that ignited; requirement (a) seeks to prevent large releases if a valve or coupling fails.
Expert note: Early jet transports occasionally split wing ribs when fuelling valves were shut against an active pump, leading to CS-25’s 2× pressure-surge strength margin in paragraph (d).

Detroit MD-80 incident 1987: Surge when a downstream tank valve was closed blew the coupler off the manifold and injured the operator, illustrating why surge loads with any valve position must be considered.

Expert note: Compliance practice is to install dual independent high-level sensors with a ‘pre-check’ switch at the fuelling panel, allowing crews to verify automatic shut-off before every fill as required by (b)(1).
Expert note: Manufacturers provide a "dead-man" trigger on the fuelling nozzle so flow stops if the operator becomes distracted, supporting the intent of rapid spill prevention.
Ground-handling manuals require defuelling pressure limits and calibrated pressure-relief valves to avoid wing skin collapse during suction, addressing paragraph (e)’s load requirement.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that nothing inside an aeroplane’s fuel tanks can ignite the fuel or its vapours during any phase of flight or foreseeable failure. It requires designers to (1) eliminate or isolate every potential ignition source, (2) keep tank temperatures safely below the fuel’s auto-ignition point, (3) minimise how often flammable vapour exists in the tank by limiting heat input or adding inert-gas systems, and (4) lock those protections into the maintenance programme through Critical Design Configuration Control Limitations (CDCCLs) so they are not degraded by ageing, wear, repairs or alterations. In short, the regulation seeks to prevent fuel-tank explosions from design to end-of-life, even after single or multiple failures, ensuring the aircraft can always continue safe flight and landing.
ai_notes: TWA Flight 800 (1996): Centre-wing tank explosion on a Boeing 747 traced to wiring-induced arcing in the tank; this accident directly triggered tighter ignition-source prevention and tank flammability limits now embodied in CS 25.981.

Thai Airways B737-400, Bangkok (2001): Fuel pump motor sparked in a partially empty centre tank during ground ops, reinforcing requirements to show pumps cannot overheat or arc under any operating or failure condition.

Philippine Airlines B737-300, Manila (1990): Lightning strike believed to have ignited vapours via damaged wiring; illustrates the need for bonding, shielding and the cross-reference to CS 25.954 lightning protection.
