Expert note: Air-conditioning packs located under centre tanks can heat fuel; modern designs add insulation and ventilation to keep temperatures below the auto-ignition margin mandated by 25.981(a)(1).

Expert note: Nitrogen inerting systems are now common on transport jets to meet the fleet-average flammability exposure limit of 25.981(b); they actively replace oxygen in the ullage so vapours cannot ignite.
Expert note: Fuel pump and wiring harnesses are listed as CDCCLs; maintenance manuals prohibit substitution of non-qualified parts or changes to routing that could introduce a latent ignition source.

Expert note: Manufacturers use spark-proof fuel quantity indication systems (FQIS) with current-limited intrinsically safe circuits to comply with the single-failure ignition requirements of 25.981(a)(3).

Expert note: Training for mechanics now emphasises restoring bonding straps and conductive sealants around access panels, a best practice born from explosion investigations showing missing bonds can create sparks.

section_intent: To make sure an engine keeps getting fuel even if the pump that normally feeds it suddenly quits or seizes. The rule requires (1) a flow-around path so a jammed positive-displacement pump cannot block fuel, and (2) an immediately available back-up (“emergency”) pump or alternate main pump for every engine. In everyday terms: no single fuel-pump failure—whether from wear, contamination, electrical loss, or mechanical seizure—may shut an engine down or starve it of fuel on a multi-engine transport aeroplane.
ai_notes: FAA AD 2011-13-10 followed several cases where Boeing 737NG boost pumps seized and could have blocked fuel flow; compliant designs already had bypass check-valves so engines kept running, illustrating paragraph (a).

Expert note: Gear-type positive-displacement pumps can lock up when ingesting ice crystals or metallic debris; the mandated bypass prevents the pump from acting like a closed valve and starving the engine.
Eastern Air Lines L-1011 (N310EA, 1983) lost a main tank pump on climb-out; automatic switchover to the standby pump allowed normal flight, demonstrating the redundancy demanded by paragraph (b).
Industry best practice: Two electrically independent boost pumps per wing tank plus a suction-feed check line are standard in ETOPS twinjets to satisfy the ‘immediately after failure’ requirement.
Expert note: Maintenance training stresses verifying that selector logic energises the opposite pump within seconds of a boost-pump failure warning, a direct compliance method for CS-25.991(b).

Certification tests routinely include blocking a pump outlet and cutting its power; the engine must continue to receive rated fuel flow via the bypass or alternate pump, proving both clauses of the rule.

section_intent: CS 25.993 obliges designers to route, support, and select every fuel pipe, hose, and fitting so that it stays leak-free throughout all operating and emergency loads. Lines must resist engine and airframe vibration, fuel pressure pulses, G-loads and thermal extremes; where parts move relative to each other they must incorporate approved flexible hose assemblies that can stretch or bend without cracking. Materials unsuitable for hot zones are forbidden, and pipes that run through the fuselage must tolerate limited distortion in a hard landing or minor crash without spilling fuel. The ultimate aim is to prevent in-flight or post-landing fuel leakage that could cause engine failure, fire, or loss of the aeroplane.
ai_notes: American Airlines Flight 191 (1979) – Engine–pylon separation snapped rigid fuel lines, releasing fuel that fed the post-impact fire; flexible break sections and improved support now stem from this lesson on relative motion.

Expert note: Fatigue cracks have been found in long, unclamped aluminum feed pipes near engine pumps; modern designs add close-pitch clamps and convert critical sections to braided hoses to damp vibration per 25.993(a).
Embraer ERJ-145 ground fire, Tallinn 2010 – A nacelle hose, embrittled by repeated hot-soak, burst during start-up and ignited; paragraph (e) bars temperature-sensitive hose in such locations.
Expert note: Certification pull-and-bend tests demonstrate that fuselage-run lines can stretch several percent without leaking, directly addressing the deformation tolerance demanded by 25.993(f).

Airbus A320 wing-root chafing SB – Fleet inspections found stainless feed lines fretting against structure, an issue mitigated by additional clamps required by the vibration-control intent of 25.993(a).

Expert note: Industry best practice uses double-swaged, fire-resistant conductive hose assemblies wherever axial movement or pressure exists, satisfying 25.993(b)–(c) while preventing electrostatic discharge and leaks.

section_intent: The rule makes designers demonstrate that pipes, valves, filters and other fuel-carrying parts located inside the fuselage or engine nacelles will not crack open and spill a fire-starting amount of fuel when the aircraft has to land and slide on its belly with the landing gear retracted (the CS-25.721(b) “wheels-up” condition).  By keeping fuel contained or instantly self-sealing during the scraping, crushing and vibration that occur in such an emergency, the regulation seeks to prevent post-landing fires, giving occupants time to evacuate and rescue services a survivable scenario.
ai_notes: LOT Polish Airlines Flight 16 (Warsaw, 2011): a Boeing 767 landed gear-up and skidded 2 000 m; intact, shielded nacelle fuel lines prevented leakage and no fire occurred, illustrating the life-saving value of CS-25.994-type design.

Expert note: Several 1950-60s jet belly-landings (e.g., early DC-8 and 707 cases reviewed by the FAA) produced fires when nacelle feed lines tore loose; these investigations drove the original §25.994 wording that EASA later adopted.

Expert note: Designers route fuel tubes above keel beams and install frangible, self-sealing break-away couplings so that if the nacelle skin is ground away the fitting snaps shut instead of pulling the line apart.

Expert note: Compliance testing often uses a sled or drop rig where a pressurised fuel system is subjected to the CS-25.721(b) crush distance; measurable leakage must stay below the ‘no fire hazard’ threshold (typically a few cc/min).

Expert note: Maintenance training stresses correct torque and locking of B-nuts on protected fuel lines—field reports show that mis-torqued couplings defeated the fire-safe design until airlines added focussed task cards under 25.994 obligations.

section_intent: The rule aims to ensure that every fuel valve is mounted on a rigid aircraft structure so that any forces produced when the valve is operated (turned, pushed, pulled) or when the aircraft is subjected to high-g manoeuvres do not get transmitted into the attached fuel lines. Isolating the valve from the plumbing prevents cracking, loosening or fatigue of the pipes and fittings that could lead to fuel leaks, loss of fuel supply to an engine, or an in-flight fire. In plain terms, the valve must carry its own loads; the fuel tubing should only have to carry fuel.
ai_notes: AD 2000-01-02 (Boeing 747): Cracked support brackets on jettison dump valves allowed vibration loads into the fuel pipes, producing seepage that prompted mandatory bracket reinforcement—an illustration of why CS-25.995(b) exists.
EASA AD 2015-0054 (Airbus A330/A340): Reports of leaking fuel jettison valves traced to broken attachment lugs; regulators required new mounts to keep g-loads and torque off the lines.
Expert note: In a 2.5-g pull-up, an unsupported 1 kg valve can impose over 25 N on a soft aluminium line; repeated cycles quickly fatigue a B-nut and can let fuel spray onto hot engine parts.
Expert note: Mechanics sometimes apply high torque to free a sticky shut-off valve; if the valve body is not hard-mounted, that torque twists the tubing, risking cracked flares or stripped threads.

Industry practice: Compliance tests mount the valve to a bracket and loop the connected tubing with flex lines or swivel couplings while subjecting the assembly to vibration and 3-g inertia loads to prove no line loads are transmitted.

section_intent: In plain terms, the rule demands that every fuel line leaving the tank passes through a properly-sized, structurally-mounted and easily-maintainable filter/strainer before the fuel reaches the engine-driven pump or the fuel-metering unit. The aim is to trap dirt, metal shavings, sealant chips, water, ice crystals and other debris so they cannot starve or damage the engine, while still allowing enough clean fuel to flow for all certified power settings. The unit must also have a built-in low point (sediment trap) and drain so contaminants can be removed during servicing, and it has to be mounted on the airframe—not hung from the pipes—so vibration or line loads cannot crack the plumbing. Ultimately, the requirement protects against in-flight power loss, pump seizure and fire risk that could arise from contaminated fuel, and it ensures the crew and maintenance personnel can quickly inspect and clean the filter to keep the system safe throughout the aircraft’s life.
ai_notes: British Airways Flight 38 (B777, 2008): Ice crystals in the fuel migrated downstream and blocked the fuel-oil heat exchanger; the accident underlined that filters must still pass the required flow with worst-case contamination, directly echoing the capacity clause in CS-25.997(d).

Expert note: During initial post-production flights, small flakes of tank sealant and drilling swarf often wash into the system; cartridge filters installed per CS-25.997 routinely capture this debris and prevent scarring or seizure of the engine-driven pump.

Expert note: Remote refuelling from drums can introduce rust or sand; operators therefore specify 100-mesh strainers with quick-drain sediment bowls so ground crews can sample and purge contaminants before the next leg.

NTSB Report SEA00IA037 (B737-400, 2000): A badly mounted filter housing cracked the attached fuel line, causing a leak and airframe fire warning; the incident illustrates why the rule forbids supporting the unit by its plumbing alone.

Industry best practice: Many airlines include filter bowl inspection in every ‘A’-check; recorded sediment quantities are trended to spot tank corrosion early, reflecting the accessibility and removability requirements in paragraph (a).

Certification testing of the CFM56-7B pump (1990s): Deliberate introduction of contaminant loads verified that the filter could deliver rated take-off fuel flow with 125-micron particles, demonstrating compliance with paragraph (d).

Accident: Air Midwest Beech 1900D N233YV (Kirksville, 1998) suffered dual flame-out on climb; investigation traced to filters blocked by improperly drained water that froze, reinforcing the need for sediment traps and low-point drains in 25.997(b).

Expert note: Flight-crew emergency checklists assume fuel filters will not clog completely—‘LOW PRESS’ lights warn but flow continues—because CS-25.997 obliges designers to size the element for continued operation even with significant contamination.

section_intent: The rule makes sure every fuel tank has a properly designed drain that lets crews safely remove water, sediment and small samples of fuel on the ground, yet will not leak in flight or after a crash-landing. Drains must empty well clear of the airframe so spilled fuel cannot run onto hot parts or cabin exits, must lock positively closed so vibration or inattentive maintenance cannot leave them cracked open, must be easy to reach for routine servicing, and must be recessed or shielded so a belly-landing cannot tear them off and cause a major fuel spill. In short, the paragraph addresses both day-to-day engine reliability (clean, contaminant-free fuel) and crash-fire prevention (keeping fuel inside the tanks unless deliberately drained).
ai_notes: Eastern Air Lines B-727 N8147N (JFK, 1984): taxiway fire after fuel streamed from a sump drain left unlocked; highlighted need for positive-locking and overboard-clear discharge.
Expert note: Daily pre-flight water checks on airliners rely on accessible sump drains; if drains were hard to reach, crews tended to skip the task, leading to engine flameouts from water ingestion.

Beechcraft King Air series gear-up landing investigations (multiple NTSB reports, 1970s-80s) showed unprotected belly drains sheared off, releasing fuel that fed post-crash fires—driving the ‘located or protected’ clause.

Boeing fuel-system qualification tests require a simulated gear-up slide with no fuel release; design teams therefore recess drain valves behind keel beams or fit break-away shields to comply with CS 25.999(b)(3)(ii).

Expert note: Industry now uses spring-loaded, flush-mounted drain valves with detent locks, reducing the chance of vibration-induced opening while still letting mechanics sample fuel with one hand and a jar.
CFM56 engine flameouts during heavy rain have been traced to water not drained from wing tanks; regulators cite CS 25.999 to emphasise that drains are part of the contamination-control barrier.

section_intent: CS 25.1001 makes sure large transport aeroplanes can quickly, safely and symmetrically dump enough fuel after take-off so that, if an emergency return or diversion is needed, the aircraft can meet one-engine-inoperative climb requirements and land without exceeding its structural landing weight. The rule also protects against the new hazards created by dumping fuel: it must not create fire, fumes, controllability or asymmetry problems, flight crew must be able to stop the flow at any time, and a minimum reserve must remain. In short, the intent is to give the crew a reliable escape hatch—fast weight reduction—while ensuring the system itself never turns an emergency into something worse.
ai_notes: Pan Am Flight 843 (B-707, 1965): after an uncontained engine failure on climb-out, the crew dumped fuel to reach landing weight and landed safely; industry analysis of the spray pattern and flame behaviour reinforced the need for the ‘fuel clears the aircraft and no fire hazard’ test in CS 25.1001(d).

United Airlines training incident (DC-8, early 1960s): a stuck left dump valve produced a heavy lateral fuel imbalance and severe roll, highlighting why the rule now requires that any single failure must not lead to hazardous asymmetrical jettisoning.

Expert note: Overweight landings on early jet transports cracked wing spars and landing-gear trunnions; mandatory jettison capability lets crews avoid structural overload while still meeting the one-engine-inoperative climb gradient for a go-around.

Expert note: The 15-minute jettison rate was chosen so that, in a typical return-to-departure scenario, the aircraft can complete a standard circuit, dump weight, and be ready to land before fuel imbalance or time-critical emergencies escalate.

Expert note: Certification flight tests routinely show dump spray at 1.3 VSR1, OEI climb and level flight to prove fumes stay out of the cabin—results have driven the common practice of locating dump nozzles near the wing tips and behind the flaps.

Best practice: Operators brief crews to select ‘tail-tank inhibit’ or similar so that take-off/landing tanks cannot be emptied below the reserve specified in CS 25.1001(f), assuring enough fuel for a climb to 10 000 ft and a 45-minute diversion even if the main dump handle is pulled.

Best practice: Placards by the dump handle remind crews not to activate the system with high-lift devices extended, preventing the disturbed airflow from blowing fuel onto the flaps or horizontal stabiliser in contravention of CS 25.1001(h).

section_intent: Every engine must carry its own, self-contained stock of lubricating oil, in an amount and at a temperature that will keep that engine safely lubricated for the whole flight—even in the most demanding phase—so that a leak, over-heating, or high consumption on one engine cannot cripple the others and will not run the engine dry before landing.
ai_notes: B-24 WWII experience: shared oil tanks led to multiple engine failures after a single line rupture, prompting the move to fully independent oil systems.

Lockheed Constellation certification tests (1940s) showed that long-range cruise with higher-than-expected oil burn could empty the sump; modern rules therefore tie oil quantity to worst-case endurance plus margin.

Expert note: ETOPS twin-engine aircraft routinely demonstrate that, with one engine inoperative and the other at maximum diversion thrust, remaining oil quantity and temperature stay within limits for the longest diversion time.

PW4000 in-service events (1990s): blocked scavenge filters caused rapid oil temperature rise and impending seizure; requirement for temperature control and indication helped crews shut down the engine before damage propagated.

Expert note: During certification, manufacturers flight-test oil consumption on hot-day climbs and long-idle descents to prove the system keeps oil temps below red line and maintains positive circulation in all attitudes.

section_intent: This rule makes sure every oil tank in a large airplane is designed and installed so that oil is always available, contained, and safely managed in all normal and emergency conditions. It requires space for oil to expand as it heats, leak-proof filler caps and drains so spilled oil cannot collect on hot parts, vents that work in any flight attitude and cannot ice-up, outlets protected from blockage, shut-off valves to isolate a tank during a fire unless the system is already fire-proof, and materials (including any flexible liners) that are proven safe. Overall, it prevents engine oil starvation, in-flight fires, structural damage from pressure collapse, and environmental contamination, thereby protecting propulsion reliability and fire safety.
ai_notes: United Airlines DC-6A accident (1951): an improperly secured oil filler cap allowed oil to spray over the engine, ignite on the exhaust, and cause an in-flight fire—illustrating why airtight caps and drains are mandatory.

Expert note: Several certification tests have shown that without a 10 % expansion space, rapid oil temperature rise during climb can force oil out the vent, leading to low-oil warnings and possible engine shutdown.

Hawker Beechcraft King Air incident, Wichita (2007): ice blocked the oil tank vent line; the resulting vacuum collapsed the tank liner and starved the engine, highlighting the need for drainage and anti-icing vent geometry.

Expert note: Maintenance findings often reveal rag fragments or safety-wire tails inside filler necks; CS-25.1013(e) obliges designers to fit strainers that stop such debris before it can clog oil scavenge lines.

Lockheed L-188 Electra fleet experience: tanks without shut-off valves fed burning oil into nacelle fires after blade failures; modern CS-25 requires a valve unless the external system is fireproof, limiting fire progression.

Boeing 737NG service difficulty reports (SDR 2013-2015): repeated over-filling of reserve tanks led to oil venting onto wing skins and passenger windows; the rule’s 2 % minimum headspace for reserve tanks addresses this operational tendency.

section_intent: This rule makes sure every oil tank on a large transport aeroplane is strong enough and tight enough to cope with all the loads, pressures, vibration and high-temperature oil it will see in service. By adopting the general fuel-tank proof-test requirements of CS 25.965—but substituting hot oil (up to 121 °C / 250 °F) and a minimum 34 kPa (5 psi) pressure margin—the regulation aims to prevent cracks, ruptures, or leaks that could quickly drain the engine of lubrication or spray flammable oil onto hot parts. In plain terms, it is about guaranteeing that the oil tank will not fail, even in turbulence, hard landings, rapid manoeuvres, or during the worst engine-induced vibrations, thereby preserving engine health and preventing fires.
ai_notes: Qantas A380 VH-OQA (2010): Oil leaked onto turbine discs, ignited, and led to an uncontained engine failure; although the leak originated in a stub pipe, the event illustrates why any pressurised oil reservoir must be proof-tested for pressure and temperature to avoid spray fires.

Expert note: Early jetliner flight tests revealed riveted aluminium oil tanks developing seam cracks under high-frequency engine vibration, prompting the current requirement to test under combined vibration and inertia loads.

Expert note: A common maintenance finding is fretting of oil-tank mounts; CS 25.1015 forces designers to size attachments for multi-directional inertia loads so the tank cannot tear loose in a hard landing or rejected-take-off.

Industry practice: Compliance rigs heat oil to 121 °C and apply 5 psi above maximum operating pressure for several minutes while inspecting for weeps—mirroring paragraph (b)(2) to prove joints and welds remain tight at temperature.

KLM B747 cargo (1999) in-service report: Slow oil tank leak went undetected, starved an engine and forced an ETOPS diversion; underscores the rule’s intent to make leaks ‘fail-safe obvious’ or, ideally, impossible through robust tank integrity.

section_intent: This rule makes sure every pipe that carries engine oil is built, located, and protected so it cannot leak, burst, freeze-up, or turn into a fire source. Oil lines must be just as robust and fire-resistant as fuel lines in hot "fire zones" around the engines, while the crankcase breather line must drain water, stay ice-free, and vent where any sprayed-out oil cannot ignite or blind the pilots, and never be sucked back into the engine. In short, it keeps the lubricant inside the engine, prevents fires outside the engine, and preserves pilot visibility in every phase of flight.
ai_notes: Eastern Air Lines L-1011 (1972, JFK): Ice-blocked breather vent over-pressurised the oil tank, blowing oil onto hot turbine casings and starting a nacelle fire—illustrates why paragraph (b)(1) demands ice-free routing.
Qantas B747-438 VH-OJU (2008): Breather outlet misted oil across the windshield on climb, degrading forward view and prompting design change—directly reflects paragraph (b)(2).
Expert note: Certification fire tests routinely wrap steel-braided hoses with fire-sleeves and install self-sealing fittings inside nacelles to meet CS 25.1183 requirements referenced in 25.1017(a).
Japan Airlines DC-10 (1982) cargo-fire scare: Oil leak from fractured line provided fuel for a small tail-engine fire that self-extinguished but drove regulatory focus on stronger oil plumbing.
Expert note: Cold-weather operators add electrically heated or continuously downward-sloped breather lines to prevent water condensation pockets that could freeze and block the vent.
FAA AD 2016-23-05 on Certain GE90 engines: Required relocation of breather outlet away from core inlet after foaming oil was ingested and caused power loss—mirrors paragraph (b)(3).
Best practice: Design reviews ensure no "traps" or low points in breather routing, and functional testing includes ground-soak at −40 °C followed by rapid climb to verify unobstructed flow.

section_intent: Ensure that turbine-engine oil stays free-flowing and protective even when badly contaminated. The rule requires every engine to have a strainer or filter large enough to trap debris, give a timely cockpit or maintenance warning as it fills, and—if it becomes completely blocked—open a bypass that keeps oil moving without dumping the trapped dirt into critical bearings. This guarantees continuous lubrication, early detection, and controlled bypass so that bearing failures, fires, or in-flight shutdowns are prevented.
ai_notes: Early Boeing 707/JT3C service (1960s) saw several engine seizures when carbon sludge clogged oil strainers; the resulting FAA ADs demanded bypass capability and clog indicators, precursors to CS 25.1019. These events proved that unnoticed filter blockage leads directly to oil starvation and engine loss.

Expert note: Bearing spalls release metallic chips that can load a filter in minutes; CS 25.1019 keeps those chips captured and flagged, and routes any bypass flow away from the debris, preventing them from recirculating and destroying downstream bearings.

Certification best practice: In the CS-E ‘contaminated-oil’ test, manufacturers feed calibrated dust until the filter delta-P light triggers, then run the engine at limit power with the element fully blocked; successful operation demonstrates compliance with 25.1019(a)(1)–(2) and assures authorities that filter blockage alone cannot shut an engine down.

section_intent: Ensure that each engine’s oil system can be drained safely during ground maintenance, while guaranteeing that the drain valve cannot inadvertently open in flight. The rule protects service personnel from burns or environmental spills, and it prevents in-flight oil loss that could cause engine seizure, fire, or shutdown. By mandating accessibility and a positive-locking closed position, EASA seeks both easy inspection/servicing and absolute security against vibration- or maintenance-induced valve movement.
ai_notes: Eastern Air Lines L-1011 Flight 855 (1983): all three engines shut down after take-off due to rapid oil loss following maintenance error—illustrates catastrophic consequences of unsecured oil paths.
Expert note: Vibration has been shown to back-out simple threaded drain plugs; certification now demands lock-wire, detent, or spring-loaded latches that cannot migrate to the open position.

British Airways B747-400 G-BNLO (1998) rejected take-off after engine fire; investigation traced to oil leaking from a drain valve left partially open—underscores need for clear access and positive locking.
Expert note: Line maintenance often performs engine-oil sampling; accessible drains reduce the temptation to use improvised methods that can damage fittings and compromise sealing.

Congo Express ERJ-145 (2011) returned to origin when oil-pressure warnings appeared; root cause was an incorrectly seated drain cap that was hard to reach during night maintenance—accessibility requirement addresses this failure mode.

section_intent: The rule ensures that an aircraft’s oil cooler (oil radiator) will not become a weak link that can trigger engine failure or inflight fire. It demands two things: first, the cooler must be structurally robust against engine vibrations, g-loads, and full oil-system pressure so it cannot crack, detach, or burst and dump oil; second, its air-duct location must be arranged so that, if an engine fire occurs, flames exiting normal nacelle openings cannot strike the cooler directly, preventing the cooler from rupturing, feeding the fire, or losing lubrication. In plain terms, the requirement protects both the lubrication integrity of the engine and the fire safety of the aircraft during all phases of flight.
ai_notes: 1943 B-24 training crash: an oil cooler shook loose under propeller-induced vibration, dumping oil and causing an engine fire; post-accident military directives on cooler mount strength influenced later civil rules now captured in CS 25.1023(a).

1961 Air France B707 test flight: a high-g pull-up burst an oil-cooler tube that could not handle combined pressure and inertia loads, forcing an emergency landing and highlighting the need for combined-load proof testing demanded today.

Expert note: Modern turbofan nacelles place oil coolers behind firewalls or shield them with stainless baffles so flame paths from starter-torches or combustor failures cannot impinge on the cooler, directly addressing paragraph (b).

Expert note: Compliance vibration testing sweeps oil coolers through engine-mount resonance ranges for minutes at maximum oil pressure; this practice arose after early JT8D service reports of cooler fin cracking and is now an industry standard method of meeting 25.1023(a).

section_intent: The rule guarantees that the crew can shut off an engine’s oil supply quickly and reliably to limit fire or leakage, without losing the vital ability to feather a propeller after an engine failure. Valves must satisfy the same rigorous fire-safety standards as fuel shut-off devices, have clear ON/OFF detents or markings to prevent mis-selection, and be mounted so that operating forces or flight loads do not crack or distort the connected oil lines. The overall aim is to make oil-isolation actions both effective and free of secondary hazards.
ai_notes: Propair Flight 420 (1998, Beech King Air 100): an oil leak fed an uncontrolled engine fire; investigators noted difficulty confirming valve closure, underscoring the need for positive-stop shut-off hardware.

Expert note: Early turboprops experienced vibration-induced cracking where unsupported oil shut-off valves transferred loads into rigid lines; para (c) now demands independent support to prevent this failure mode.

FAA AD 2003-17-01 on PW120-series engines required inspection of oil shut-off lever indexing because mis-rigging could both block full closure and hinder propeller feathering—directly addressed by sub-paras (b) and (c).

Expert note: Emergency fire-handle drills in airline simulators confirm that pulling the handle closes fuel and oil cocks yet still allows automatic or manual propeller feathering, reflecting the compliance logic of CS 25.1025(b).

1956 BOAC Canadair Argonaut incident: a crew inadvertently closed an un-indexed oil valve, leading to engine overspeed and shutdown; industry moved to color-coded handles with positive detents, mirrored in sub-para (c).

section_intent: When a turboprop engine fails it is vital that the propeller blades can be turned edge-on to the airflow (feathered) so the aeroplane is not pulled sideways or slowed by massive drag. Many feathering systems use the engine’s own lubricating oil as the working fluid, so a leak that drains the oil could make feathering impossible just when it is needed most. CS 25.1027 therefore requires designers to (1) trap a dedicated quantity of oil that cannot leak away with the rest of the system, (2) show by test that this trapped oil will always let the propeller feather, and (3) keep the dedicated path free of sludge or debris. In plain terms: even if the engine loses all its oil, a clean, isolated supply must still be there to move the blades to feather and keep the aircraft controllable.
ai_notes: Lockheed L-188 Electra flight-test programme (1957): Engineers discovered that a total oil loss prevented feathering until a standpipe was added to trap oil, directly leading to the trapped-oil requirement now in CS 25.1027.

Air Wisconsin Flight 965 (Swearingen Metro, 1980): Oil line failure emptied the sump; the crew could not fully feather the propeller, suffered severe yaw, and made an emergency landing—an accident frequently cited in regulatory discussions of trapped-oil design.

Expert note: Typical compliance testing plugs the tank’s standpipe and feeds engine bearings from an external cart while the crew shuts the engine down in flight to prove the trapped quantity will feather within the certified time.

Expert note: Designers commonly use a raised standpipe or check-valve in the oil tank so normal circulation draws from below the standpipe level, leaving the upper portion reserved exclusively for the feather pump.

Expert note: CS 25.1027(d) drives the industry practice of installing fine mesh screens and routing the feathering pick-up line well above the tank bottom to prevent sludge or metal particles from obstructing the system.

section_intent: Make sure that all engines, gearboxes, hydraulics, fuel, oil and any other power-plant parts stay within their certified temperature limits during every phase—long ground idling, hot-day take-off, climb, cruise, descent, and even the "heat-soak" period after the engines are shut down—so that they keep working, do not catch fire, and do not suffer hidden damage that could cause later failures.
ai_notes: Expert note: Early piston transports (e.g. Lockheed Constellation) regularly lost cylinders on hot-day climbs because cowling and baffle design could not keep head temps in limits; CS-25.1041 institutionalised quantitative cooling proofs to prevent such over-temperature failures.

JT8D-powered MD-80 series underwent post-shutdown ‘soak-back’ analysis after several nacelle wire-bundle fires; tests showed that inadequate ventilation let heat radiate into fuel and electrical lines, prompting redesign of insulation and vent scoops—exactly the scenario covered by the rule’s ‘after normal engine shutdown’ clause.

Boeing 777 certification campaigns include high-ambient, high-gross-weight taxi tests at Edwards AFB to show that oil and hydraulic fluid stay below max limits during prolonged ground operations, a direct compliance demonstration for CS-25.1041.

Qantas A380 VH-OQF (2012) experienced in-flight ENG2 oil temperature rise; investigation highlighted that marginal cooling air flow around scavenge lines can let temps creep beyond red-line—industry now emphasises CFD and flight-test correlation of nacelle airflow per 25.1041.

Expert note: Modern geared turbofans incorporate dedicated ‘heat rejection’ exchangers; designers size ram-air ducts using worst-case hot-day, one-engine-inoperative climb data to satisfy 25.1041 and avoid fluid foaming or gearbox seizure.

section_intent: CS 25.1043 requires the manufacturer to prove, by ground and flight tests, that the airplane’s engines, APU and associated fluids or parts stay within their certified temperature limits during the hottest conditions the aircraft can reasonably meet in service (at least 37.8 °C at sea level, decreasing with altitude). Because test days may be cooler, the rule supplies a standard correction so recorded data can be extrapolated to an ISA + 35 °C "hot-day". Any corrected temperature that exceeds a limit shows the cooling design is inadequate. The aim is to avoid power loss, fires, vapour lock, seal failures or structural damage that can result from overheating during long ground holds, max-power climbs, go-arounds, or when winterization kits restrict airflow.
ai_notes: Qantas B747-400 VH-OJS (Dubai, 2013): 42 °C ambient and long taxi produced engine-oil over-temperature ECAM leading to an air-return, illustrating the ground-idle hot-day case CS 25.1043 addresses.
Expert note: Certification flight programmes run maximum-weight climbs at V2+10 in ISA + 30 °C to show oil, hydraulic and generator temperatures remain below limits—a direct application of 25.1043.
WWII B-29 Pacific theatre: frequent engine failures from cylinder-head overheating in tropical climbs highlighted the safety need for defined hot-day cooling margins in later regulations.

Expert note: When winterization baffles or inlet plugs are installed, manufacturers must re-run cooling tests (or analysis) to prove that reduced airflow will not cause overheating on an unexpectedly warm day, per 25.1043(b).

DC-10 Miami ground fire (1972): fuel leak contacted an overheated nacelle section after extended ground operation; adequate cooling and temperature limits help prevent such heat-soak ignition sources.

Expert note: For ETOPS validation, extended-range cruise at ISA + 30 °C must show oil and integrated drive generator (IDG) temperatures stay within limits, satisfying the same principles laid out in CS 25.1043.

section_intent: CS 25.1045 ensures that, during flight-test, the aircraft’s engines and all associated fluids and components (oil, fuel, coolant, hydraulics, intercoolers, etc.) are proven to stay within their certified temperature limits in the most heat-critical configurations for every major phase of flight—take-off, climb, cruise/en-route and landing. By requiring temperatures to be stabilised or carried through realistic entry conditions until limits are reached, the rule guarantees that no latent overheating condition will appear later in the mission, protecting against loss of thrust, fire, fluid degradation, or structural damage. In plain English: the airplane must demonstrate it can keep its powerplants safely cool from idle on the ramp to touchdown on the hottest operational days.
ai_notes: Air France A340 F-GLZQ (1994) suffered an engine oil-temperature exceedance during climb in hot Dakar conditions; post-event analysis highlighted the need for hotter-than-standard climb testing to validate cooling margin.

Expert note: Piston-engine transport aircraft once lost cylinder head integrity when cowl flaps were set for noise rather than cooling in prolonged climb—this historical failure mode drove today’s clause to test worst-case flap/config combinations.

Lockheed Electra early service overheating events (1959) showed nacelle cooling airflow could be insufficient at high power, leading regulators to mandate stabilised-temperature demonstration through the full take-off profile.

Expert note: Modern turbofans use fuel as a heat sink; inadequate cooling verification can cause fuel cavitation or pump seizure—flight tests now include high-ambient, low-altitude holds to prove fuel temperature margins.

Qantas B747-400 VH-OJN (2009) in-flight shutdown traced to oil-cooler blockage; investigation reinforced that cooling tests must run until temperatures stabilise or a limit is hit, uncovering latent trends not obvious in short runs.

Expert note: Certification teams routinely fly back-to-back runway-idle soaks followed by max-take-off thrust to confirm that ground-idle stabilisation does not mask a subsequent rapid temperature rise at brake release.

section_intent: Ensure each engine always receives the right quantity and quality of air so it can generate thrust safely and efficiently. The rule demands that intakes deliver enough airflow for every certified flight condition, remain compatible with fuel-metering devices regardless of valve positions, and be isolated from any source of fire or flammable-fluid leakage inside the cowling. It also requires design features that stop runway water, slush, or foreign objects from being sucked in at take-off, landing, or taxi, and that protect any intake components liable to be damaged by debris. In short, CS-25.1091 is about guaranteeing uninterrupted, uncontaminated, and hazard-free airflow to the engines throughout all phases of operation and preventing intake-related events that could lead to power loss, fire, or structural failure.
ai_notes: Eastern Air Lines L-1011, JFK 1975: deep-puddled runway water was ingested, causing dual-engine flameouts on roll-out; led to renewed emphasis on intake placement and drainage provisions.
Air Florida Flight 90 (B-737, 1982): ice and de-icing slush entered the intakes and disrupted compressor flow, illustrating why the rule insists on preventing hazardous slush ingestion.
Expert note: Modern turbofan nacelles route fuel scupper drains aft of the inlet lip so any leak or over-fill cannot be drawn into the inlet, directly addressing 25.1091(d)(1).

Concorde F-B** accident 2000: shed tyre fragments entered No.2 engine inlet causing surge and fire; example of why designers add inlet deflectors and test per CS-E 790/800 for foreign object tolerance.

Expert note: Certification bird-strike and hail-ingestion tests mandated in CS-E 790/800 verify that inlet guide vanes, acoustic panels, and bleed-valve hardware survive without shedding hazardous debris, meeting 25.1091(e).
GE90 and Rolls-Royce Trent programs employ S-shaped intake ducts on test rigs to confirm uniform airflow and proper fuel-metering across throttle settings, satisfying 25.1091(a)(2).

CF6 engine nacelles have titanium firewalls between accessory gearboxes and inlet plenum, an industry practice mirroring 25.1091(c)’s requirement for a fireproof diaphragm when intakes open inside the cowling.

Expert note: Airport FOD-prevention campaigns (sweeper vehicles, tool-control) are operational measures complementing the design intent of 25.1091 to keep debris out of intakes during taxi and take-off.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that, with all ice-protection systems working, turbine engines can run from ground idle to full power in any certified icing, snow-fall or snow-blowing condition without building up ice that could choke the inlet, shed into the compressor, upset airflow, or damage blades.  It obliges designers to prove (by test or analysis) that no unacceptable power loss, surge, flame-out, temperature exceedance or airframe-engine mismatch will occur—including after at least 30 min of ground idle in snow/ice—so that safe take-off, climb and continued flight are always available.  Appendix C (glaciated clouds), Appendix O (ice crystals) and Appendix P (super-cooled large drops) are all covered, and the rule also drives flight-manual procedures such as periodic run-ups while taxiing in snow.
ai_notes: Boeing 737 Classic fleet – multiple 1990s dual-engine surges on take-off after taxiing in heavy snow led to FAA AD 2000-05-02, requiring idle-run-up procedures; the events showed why 30-minute ground-idle demonstrations and documented run-up intervals are mandatory.

Expert note: CF34-3 and ‑8 engines on regional jets experienced compressor stalls when rime ice shed from the inlet lip at take-off power; compliance testing now verifies inlet lip heating effectiveness across the whole power range.

British Airways 777-200 (2009, LEAX incident) experienced engine rollback in tropical cumulonimbus due to ice-crystal ingestion; Appendix O icing envelopes were added and are explicitly referenced in CS 25.1093 to prevent repeats.

Expert note: Certification findings on Airbus A320 family showed that anti-ice bleed selection at idle is not enough in glaze ice; design changes added lip-skin heaters and FADEC logic to avoid temperature rises that could mask ice build-up.

SAAB 2000 icing trials demonstrated that large super-cooled drops could accumulate aft of the hot lip and be ingested during power changes, causing momentary surges; this drove the requirement that no unacceptable temporary power loss is allowed during the whole flight-power range.

Accident – Fokker F28 ‘NLM Cityhopper PH-CHI’, Eindhoven 1981: dual flame-out on approach in SLD icing when anti-ice off; investigation highlighted need for inlet and engine compatibility assessment now codified in CS 25.1093(b)(1)(i).

Expert note: Modern compliance uses spray-rig ground tests at −10 °C with 25 μm droplets and 0.3 g/m³ LWC to show 30-min idle capability, then an immediate acceleration to take-off thrust without stall or temperature spike, satisfying Table 1 conditions.

section_intent: Make sure that all air-intake and bleed-air ducting on transport airplanes stays intact, does not feed a fire, and does not endanger the aircraft even when the engine surges or moves. The rule requires (1) structure strong enough to handle violent pressure pulses coming back from the compressor, (2) fire-resistant materials where the duct passes through fire zones, (3) flexible joints wherever the engine or pylon can move relative to the fuselage, and (4) design features so that if a hot-bleed-air line bursts anywhere between the engine port and the system it feeds, it will not create smoke, fire, structural damage, or loss of vital systems.
ai_notes: Case: Boeing 737-300 G-BGJL (Malaga, 1998) – a severe compressor surge blew open the inlet cowl; the event highlighted the need for ducts and cowls that can survive surge loads without departing the aircraft.

Expert note: Early turbojet test programs showed that a full-engine surge can create transient pressures exceeding twice normal intake pressure; flimsy sheet-metal ducts collapsed, prompting the strength requirement in 25.1103(b)(1).

Case: L-1011 prototype (1972) – rupture of a bleed-air duct during ground runs caused a cargo-bay fire; investigators pushed for over-temperature detectors and better fire-resistant ducting, now implicit in 25.1103(b)(2) and (d).

Expert note: Hot bleed air (>500 °C) routed through the wing root can melt wiring bundles and hydraulic lines in seconds; designers now add double-wall titanium ducts, overheat sensors, and automatic shut-off valves to remove the hazard demanded by 25.1103(d).

Expert note: Relative motion between engine, pylon, and wing during thrust changes can exceed 25 mm; flexible bellows or swivel joints prevent rigid ducts from cracking, directly addressing 25.1103(c).

Best practice: Certification surge tests use rapid throttle chops and cross-wind ingestion to provoke surging while strain-gauges on the inlet duct verify margins, demonstrating compliance without relying solely on analysis.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that the exhaust system of a large aeroplane disposes of hot gases in a way that never endangers people or the aircraft. It demands that crew and passengers are protected from carbon monoxide (CO), that any part hot enough to ignite leaking fuel or hydraulic fluid is kept shielded or separated, that exhaust does not impinge on fuel vents or drains, that night-time glare from exhaust flames cannot dazzle pilots, and that cooling or ventilation prevents local hot spots. In short, it exists to eliminate fire, toxicity and vision hazards created by engine or APU (auxiliary power unit) exhaust outside the engine compartment.
ai_notes: FedEx MD-11 N602FE (Memphis, 2006): fuel dripping from a drain mast was ignited by the hot APU exhaust, causing an apron fire; redesign moved the mast farther away, illustrating the need for 25.1121(d).

American Airlines MD-80 fumes event (Dallas, 2018): cracked bleed-air duct let engine exhaust and CO enter the cabin, triggering headaches and forcing a diversion—evidence of why paragraph (a) sets strict CO limits and test requirements.

Expert note: During certification tests, CO sensors are placed in every occupied compartment while engines and APU run at multiple power settings to prove levels stay below the 50 ppm health threshold.

British Airtours Flight 28M (B737-236, 1985): a combustor casing failure allowed hot gases to hit fuel and hydraulic lines, starting a fatal cabin fire—this drove the rule that adjacent components be fire-proof or shielded (25.1121(c)).
Expert note: Modern jet tailpipes are double-walled Inconel with forced-air ventilation so the outer skin stays below ~200 °C, meeting paragraphs (f) and (g) on temperature control.
Early Boeing 707 night operations reported pilot glare from under-wing exhaust; angled nozzles and anti-glare shields were adopted, directly addressing 25.1121(e).
Expert note: Fuel vent masts on current transport aircraft are located on wing tips or the vertical tail, well clear of APU exhaust plumes, to satisfy 25.1121(d).
L-1011 TriStar refuelling fire, Rome 1972: fuel spray during ground refuelling contacted a hot center-engine exhaust duct and ignited, underscoring the shielding and layout demands of paragraph (b).

section_intent: The rule ensures that every section of exhaust piping on a transport aeroplane remains intact and leak-free throughout the aircraft’s life. Because exhaust gas is extremely hot, corrosive, and under pulsating pressure, the piping must be made of materials that can survive high temperatures and corrosion, be able to grow and shrink with heat without cracking, and remain firmly supported against engine vibration and manoeuvre/landing loads. Flexible joints or bellows must be provided wherever the engine, mounts, or airframe can move relative to each other so that the exhaust system is not overstressed. Meeting these requirements prevents engine-nacelle or fuselage fires, structural damage, thrust loss, and toxic gas entry into the cabin or flight deck.
ai_notes: PenAir Flight 4166, Saab 340B (Oct 2005): a failed tail-pipe clamp let hot exhaust impinge on nacelle structure, starting an in-flight fire—highlighting the need for secure support and heat-resistant materials.

Expert note: Fatigue cracks in stainless-steel slip joints on early JT8D tailpipes caused exhaust leaks and burned hydraulic lines; flexible, high-alloy bellows now accommodate thermal growth and prevent such leaks.

Industry best practice: Transport-category turbofans use Inconel or Hastelloy exhaust ducts with braided wire supports and vibration isolators, validated by shaker-table testing to meet CS-25.1123(b) vibration load criteria.

section_intent: To ensure that every control the crew uses to manage thrust, fuel, and engine-related valves is positioned, built, and indicated so it cannot be operated accidentally, will survive expected loads, vibration, and fire, will stay where it is set without drifting, and will clearly tell the crew both what they have commanded and whether the system has actually responded. In plain English, the rule demands that throttles, fuel shut-off levers, cowl flap switches, cross-feed knobs and similar items are placed where they are easy for pilots to reach but hard to bump, are strong and rigid enough not to bend or break, use materials and flexible cables that are qualified for their job, include friction or detents so they do not creep during turbulence, remain operable if fire enters the engine bay, and give unmistakable visual or tactile confirmation of valve position. All of this is aimed at preventing inadvertent power loss, asymmetric thrust, uncontrolled fires, or pilot confusion during normal and emergency operations.
ai_notes: TransAsia Flight 235 (ATR-72-600, 2015): The crew accidentally retarded the good engine’s power lever, leading to loss of control; positive detents and unmistakable lever identification address this exact hazard.

British Midland Flight 92 (B737-400, 1989): Identical thrust-lever positions hid that the wrong engine had been shut down; clear indication of valve/lever status and rigidity against vibration-induced creep mitigate such mis-selection.

American Airlines Flight 383 (B767-300, Chicago 2016): Despite a severe engine fire, the crew could still close the fuel and bleed valves using fire-resistant cockpit controls, limiting fire propagation—illustrating 25.1141(e).
Expert note: Modern throttle quadrants include adjustable friction locks and gated idle/shut-off stops to stop lever creep from airframe vibration, satisfying 25.1141(d).
Expert note: Approved flexible push-pull cables for power levers undergo endurance, temperature, and bend-radius testing per AS6270 to show suitability under 25.1141(b).

Expert note: Airbus ENG MASTER switches are guarded and mounted on the overhead panel, well clear of ingress/egress paths, directly meeting the ‘cannot be inadvertently operated’ requirement of 25.1141(a).

Expert note: Fuel cross-feed valve selectors incorporate position-feedback lights that stay amber until the valve reaches its commanded state, fulfilling 25.1141(f)(2) for both selection and confirmation.

section_intent: This rule makes sure the flight crew can positively, quickly and safely control the power of every turbine or piston engine on a large aeroplane. Each engine must have its own throttle so thrust can be balanced or an individual engine can be shut down, yet the levers must also be grouped so all engines can be advanced or retarded together for take-off, go-around or rejected-take-off. The controls have to be responsive and precise, and any auxiliary fluid-injection system (e.g. water-methanol or anti-ice bleed) must be just as well managed. If a throttle also serves as a fuel shut-off, it must have a guarded idle detent and require a deliberate extra action before the fuel is cut, preventing an accidental in-flight engine shutdown under stress or turbulence. Overall, CS 25.1143 guarantees that engine power can be modulated, matched and removed without confusion, delay or inadvertent errors, protecting controllability, structural limits and fire-safety margins.
ai_notes: United Airlines Flight 232 (1989): Crew saved many lives by steering the DC-10 with differential thrust after total hydraulic loss—possible only because each engine had independent, immediately responsive power levers as required by 25.1143(a-c).

Qantas Flight 32 A380 (2010): After an uncontained engine failure, the crew quickly retarded and then shut off fuel to the damaged No.2 engine without disturbing the other three, illustrating the need for a guarded fuel-cutoff feature per 25.1143(e).

American Airlines Flight 383 (Chicago, 2016): Rapid firewall-shutoff of the burning 767 engine used the separate shut-off gate on the affected throttle, preventing symmetrical power loss and giving the crew full thrust on the good engine for evacuation positioning.

Expert note: Modern throttle quadrants use idle detents plus a ‘lift-over’ or ‘pull-back-and-up’ motion to reach fuel cutoff; this distinct action satisfies 25.1143(e)(2) and is checked in every line-oriented flight training session.

Expert note: Coupling/clutch bars ("power levers link") fitted on many four-engine aircraft allow pilots to advance all throttles together for take-off, meeting 25.1143(b)(2) while still allowing quick uncoupling for differential thrust.

Expert note: On older turbo-props with water-methanol boost, separate guarded switches meter injection fluid and are interlocked with power levers so the flow cannot begin or continue unintentionally, complying with 25.1143(d).

section_intent: The rule ensures that flight crews have positive, unmistakable control over each engine’s spark-producing system while also preventing inadvertent loss of ignition. Every engine must have its own ignition circuit that can be selected ON or OFF, and there must be a single-action means (a master switch or grouped switches) to cut all ignition instantly if a fire, propeller over-run, or maintenance hazard arises. At the same time, guards or interlocks are required so that these switches cannot be bumped or mis-selected in flight, except on turbine engines that are designed to run without continuous ignition. In short, the intent is to make shutting ignition off quick and fool-proof when needed, yet impossible to do by accident.
ai_notes: Eastern Air Lines L-1049 (1956): A mechanic was killed when a propeller unexpectedly fired because only one of two magneto switches had been moved; the accident underscored the need for a clear, grouped "all-off" position.

Expert note: Dual magneto systems in piston transport aircraft can run on either magneto; separate switches for each magneto and engine prevent cross-feeds or mis-wiring that could leave an engine "hot" during ground handling.

Expert note: Transport jets use guarded MASTER IGN or ENG START/IGN switches; guards satisfy CS 25.1145(c) by preventing bump-off during turbulence or checklist flow while still allowing rapid access in an emergency.

Garuda Indonesia Flight 421 (B737, 2002): After dual flame-out in heavy rain, the crew selected continuous ignition to aid relight; the dedicated, well-guarded switch ensured ignition remained available without risk of accidental shut-off.

Expert note: During certification testing, crews must demonstrate they can reach and switch the master ignition OFF within one second from either pilot seat, proving compliance with the rapid-shutdown intent of paragraph (b).

section_intent: Propeller-driven transport aeroplanes must give the crew clear, unambiguous and ergonomically-sound means to set each propeller’s RPM and blade pitch. Separate levers for every propeller, grouped so they can be moved individually or together, let the pilot quickly stop an overspeeding unit, balance thrust after an engine failure, or synchronise all props to cut vibration and fatigue. Placing these blue prop-levers below and to the right of the black throttles prevents the crew from grabbing the wrong control in high-workload moments such as take-off, go-around or engine-out flight. In short, the rule guards against asymmetric thrust, structural damage and human-factor errors by dictating how propeller controls are provided and arranged.
ai_notes: Expert note: Early multi-engine transports had throttle and propeller levers side-by-side and the same height; crews occasionally feathered a running engine instead of reducing power, leading to sudden asymmetric thrust and several post-war accidents—driving regulators to prescribe a vertical offset.

QantasLink Dash-8-Q400 VH-QOH (2008): The first officer inadvertently selected DISC on a propeller lever instead of moving the power lever, causing an engine to decouple; investigation highlighted the value of distinct positioning and feel of prop controls mandated by CS 25.1149.

Expert note: Unsynchronised propellers create low-frequency “beat” vibrations that fatigue wing structures and disturb passengers; mandatory synchronisation capability allows crews to fine-tune RPM and eliminate this damaging resonance in flight.

Lockheed C-130 fleet (1960s): Several propeller overspeed incidents were contained because flight crews could instantly pull back just the affected prop-lever, illustrating why independent pitch/speed control must remain available even when engines share a common power lever system.

Best practice: Certification tests routinely include a rapid-action drill where the test pilot must isolate one propeller and then re-synchronise all four without looking down, demonstrating that the control grouping and offset meet the human-factors intent of CS 25.1149.

section_intent: Each propeller-driven engine must have its own clearly identifiable feathering control that cannot be moved accidentally. Feathering turns the blades edge-on to the airflow to stop rotation after an engine failure and minimise drag; doing it on the wrong propeller, or at the wrong time, instantly removes thrust and can create severe asymmetric yaw that the crew may not be able to counter. The rule therefore demands (1) one dedicated control per propeller and (2) positive locks, gates, or guarded switches so normal power-lever movements cannot slip into the feather position unless the crew makes a deliberate, unmistakable action.
ai_notes: American Eagle Flight 3379 (1994): Crew mistakenly feathered the healthy engine’s propeller; the sudden loss of the only remaining thrust led to loss of control and highlighted the need for unmistakable, separate controls.

Expert note: Turboprop power levers now incorporate lift-over gates or push-to-unlock buttons so routine power changes cannot pass the detent that drives the propeller into feather, directly addressing inadvertent movement cited in CS-25.1153(b).

Air Canada Express DHC-8-300 C-GONW (2019): Defective microswitch caused an unexpected feather during climb; although the crew recovered, the event reinforced industry emphasis on redundant interlocks and annunciation to show propeller state.

Expert note: Certification ground tests require a deliberate two-step action (e.g., pull then rotate) to reach feather, and flight tests verify that tactile and visual cues prevent accidental selection even in turbulence or high workload.

ATR72 training best practice: Simulated engine-out drills emphasise touching the correct feather control only after verifying the failed engine with ‘dead leg-dead engine’ checks, mirroring the separation mandated by the rule.

section_intent: The rule’s core goal is to stop an aeroplane from entering reverse-thrust or ground-pitch (‘beta’) modes while it is still flying, unless it is demonstrably safe to do so. Because selecting these modes in the air can abruptly cancel forward thrust, stall compressors or overspeed propellers, the aircraft could lose lift or controllability within seconds. CS-25.1155 therefore demands robust physical/logic barriers that: (1) require a deliberate, two-step action after reaching flight-idle; (2) automatically block the command outside the certified in-flight envelope; (3) warn the crew if the protection or the lever position is compromised; and (4) are so reliable that their failure is only a remote probability. In plain terms, the regulation makes sure you have to really mean it—and be in the right conditions—before the aircraft will let you put the engines or propellers into reverse while still airborne.
ai_notes: Lauda Air Flight 004 (B767, 1991): uncommanded in-flight thrust-reverser deployment led to structural breakup, demonstrating why automatic or inadvertent reverse selection must be physically impossible in normal flight.

Expert note: Early turboprops suffered sudden propeller overspeed and severe yaw when pilots accidentally lifted power levers over the beta gate during descent; modern designs now add finger-lift locks plus weight-on-wheels logic to comply with CS-25.1155.

Incident: FedEx MD-11F (Memphis, 2002) – crew cracked the reverser interlock in flight for training; system logic prevented full deployment and ECAM gave a caution, illustrating the required barrier and alert functions.

Expert note: Certification testing now includes deliberate faulting of squat-switch circuits to prove that a single failure cannot allow ground-only reverse to be commanded in the air, satisfying the ‘remote failure’ clause.

Industry practice: Throttle levers incorporate detents and mechanical baulks that cannot be overridden until the lever is at idle and a lift-and-pull motion is applied, providing the ‘separate and distinct’ action demanded.

Accident precursor: Several C-130 and L-188 Electra mishaps in the 1960s traced to flight-idle beta selection on approach; their lessons drove widespread adoption of beta lock-out gates referenced by this rule.

Best practice: Flight-crew SOPs require verbal confirmation of ‘idle – reverse armed’ only after main-gear touchdown; training emphasises that any in-flight master caution for reverser protection loss calls for a go-around, aligning with CS-25.1155 alert requirements.

section_intent: The rule ensures that the cockpit controls used to dump (jettison) fuel in flight are protected by physical guards and placed well away from any fire-extinguishing or fire-control switches. This prevents crews from accidentally releasing large quantities of fuel—especially during stressful fire-fighting situations—thereby avoiding loss of fuel, sudden centre-of-gravity shifts, environmental hazards, and the dangerous combination of fuel vapour near an active fire. In plain terms: make the fuel-dump switch hard to bump and impossible to confuse with a fire-fighting control.
ai_notes: Expert note: Early jetliners such as the B707 and DC-8 had unguarded dump toggles on crowded overhead panels; certification flight tests recorded inadvertent activation when pilots reached for adjacent fuel-pump or light switches, prompting guard and segregation requirements.

Swissair Flight 111 (MD-11, 1998): Crew initiated fuel jettison while dealing with an onboard fire; the task added workload and illustrated how mixing dump and fire controls on the same panel can complicate emergency response, reinforcing the need for physical and spatial separation.

Expert note: Industry now uses red, lift-latch ‘fuel dump’ handles located on dedicated panels, often requiring two positive actions (lift then rotate/push) to operate, directly satisfying the guard requirement and minimising accidental activation during turbulence.

Expert note: Human-factors assessments show that in smoke-filled cockpits, tactile differentiation (guard shape, handle feel) helps crews find the correct control without visual cues, directly addressing the rule’s intent.

Best practice: Type-rating syllabi include a call-and-confirm challenge—"Fuel Jettison Guard—Up, Switch—ARM"—so crews habitually verify the guard position before activation, preventing inadvertent operation during normal and abnormal checklists.

section_intent: Make sure every accessory bolted to, or driven by, the engine is benign: it must be officially qualified for that engine, attached using the manufacturer’s own pads so loads cannot damage the case, sealed so no chips or fluids migrate into the common oil circuit, positioned so any sparking electrical parts cannot ignite leaking fuel or oil mist, and fitted with a clutch, shear-shaft or other means to stop it turning if it seizes, without shutting the engine down. In short, the rule keeps an accessory failure from propagating into an engine failure, fire or loss of other critical functions.
ai_notes: BOAC Stratocruiser ‘cabin-blower seizure’ events (1950s): jammed engine-driven superchargers oversped, shredded gears and forced in-flight shutdowns—led to mandatory overrunning clutches, the concept codified in 25.1163(c).

Expert note: Generator or IDG pad failures have thrown metal into the shared oil gallery, contaminating oil filters and starving bearings; the sealing and approval requirements in (a)(3) prevent this cross-contamination.

Delta MD-88 ground fire, Atlanta 1998: leaking hydraulic fluid contacted a sparking starter-generator, igniting a fire under the nacelle—(b) now demands segregation of arcing equipment from flammable fluids.
Expert note: Modern practice places brushless IDGs and fuel/oil quick-disconnects on separate planes, and uses fire-resistant sleeving around wiring near fuel lines to comply with (b).
Q400 accessory gearbox shear-shaft design: if the cabin pressurization compressor or fuel pump seizes, the shaft shears, letting the engine keep turning—textbook compliance with 25.1163(c).

Certification testing: OEMs perform drive-pad torque-limit tests and oil contamination checks with approved accessories only, demonstrating paragraphs (a)(1) and (a)(3) before EASA issues the installation approval.

section_intent: CS 25.1165 makes sure that the electrical side of every engine-ignition system remains alive and segregated so the crew can always start, re-start, or keep the engines burning.  In plain terms it demands (1) two independent energy sources (battery plus automatically-cut-in generator); (2) enough capacity so ignition never has to compete with other equipment for power; (3) wiring that will survive a neighbouring engine fire; (4) dedicated, isolated ignition circuits; (5) cockpit warning if the battery is being drained; and (6) recognition that turbine-engine ignition is an essential load that must stay powered after any single failure.  The ultimate goal is to prevent loss of thrust—or inability to relight—after electrical malfunctions, fire damage, or abnormal operating conditions, thereby preserving controllability and safe continued flight and landing.
ai_notes: Air Canada DC-9 (Ottawa, 1988): Dual generator failure left the flight on batteries; continuous ignition was needed for icing penetration but one battery depleted within minutes, illustrating why an automatically-available alternate source and battery-state warning are mandatory.

Expert note: Turbine engines often require continuous ignition in heavy precipitation or volcanic ash; if the ignition bus is tied to non-essential cabin loads, a tripped galley feeder can silently kill spark, so the rule enforces circuit segregation.

Continental Airlines B707 (1969, Madrid): Engine-bay fire destroyed shared ground wiring that passed through the adjacent nacelle, disabling ignition on the other engine; today CS 25.1165(e) demands fire-proof routing or separation.

Expert note: Typical compliance tests include running one generator inoperative and the remaining at idle with all essential loads energised; the engine must still deliver re-light sparks for the time specified in the AFM, proving paragraph (c).

Industry best practice: Designers place ignition exciters on the engine and feed them through shielded, dedicated cables from the Essential or Hot Battery Bus; no entertainment, lighting, or charging circuits are permitted on that feed, meeting paragraph (f).

Boeing 777 ETOPS certification campaigns showed that battery-only starts and in-flight re-lights had to be demonstrated after 30 minutes of essential-load drain, directly reflecting paragraph (b) capacity calculations.

Expert note: Modern EICAS and ECAM systems generate an immediate "BAT DISCH" or "IGNITION ESS BUS ON BAT" message, complying with paragraph (g) so crews know they are on finite battery time and can start APU or shed loads promptly.

section_intent: Make sure any accessory gearbox that is fitted to, but not already certified with, the engine is structurally robust, properly lubricated, and compatible with the engine/airframe so that it will not seize, shed parts, or disable essential accessories (fuel, oil, hydraulics, electrics). By running CS-E endurance and vibration tests and analysing mis-alignment and torsional loads, the rule aims to prevent a gearbox or drive-shaft failure that could lead to loss of thrust, uncontrollable fire, or cascading loss of multiple aircraft systems.
ai_notes: Fokker 50 OO-VLN (2004): a fractured accessory-gearbox quill shaft starved the engine of oil, forcing an in-flight shutdown and illustrating how one small shaft can remove an entire power-plant if not torsion-tested.

ATR 72-212 HB-ACE (1998): oil-pump drive failure inside the accessory gearbox caused rapid propeller overspeed and emergency landing, prompting industry focus on CS-E 80 style endurance proof for remote gearboxes.

Expert note: Multiple operators have reported spline wear where the gearbox couples to the engine pad; flexible couplings and periodic borescope inspections are now standard best practice to address the misalignment scenario highlighted in 25.1167(c).

Airbus A400M TP400-D6 (2016 engine #3 inflight shutdowns): reduction-gearbox vibration uncovered during CS-E 740 endurance testing prevented entry-into-service delays, showing how the mandated tests catch torsional issues before certification.

Expert note: Training syllabi for power-plant engineers now emphasise confirming gearbox lubrication flow after any nacelle or pylon repair, acknowledging that small shifts in mounting can create the misalignment loads referenced in 25.1167.

section_intent: This rule defines every part of a large aeroplane that must be treated as a "designated fire zone." In those zones – the hot core of the engine, its accessory gearbox area, combined nacelles, heaters, compressor/combustor/tailpipe sections that carry flammable fluids – a fire is assumed possible. Once a zone is so designated, the follow-on regulations require fire-resistant structure, drainage, detection and extinguishing so a fire is found quickly, kept inside the nacelle, and prevented from threatening the aircraft or its occupants. In short, CS 25.1181 draws the line around the riskiest powerplant areas so designers cannot overlook them when providing fire protection.
ai_notes: British Airtours Flight 28M, 1985: An accessory-section fire in a B737-200 nacelle burned through the sidewall and spread to the cabin, illustrating why accessory areas must be classed as fire zones with mandatory containment and detection.

Qantas Flight 32, 2010: Uncontained engine failure on an A380 ruptured oil and fuel lines in the turbine/tailpipe region; the fact these areas were already designated fire zones meant sensors and drains limited the subsequent fire risk.

Expert note: Oil-scavenge or fuel lines routed across a hot turbine case are a common leak source; listing compressor, combustor and tailpipe sections ensures any such leak is caught within a protected zone.

Expert note: Bleed-air duct failures inside the nacelle can atomise residual fuel/oil and ignite; treating the entire power section as a fire zone guarantees detectors and extinguishers are present even when no liquid lines are visible.

Piper PA-31 heater incidents (multiple 1990s): Cabin combustion heaters mounted in accessory bays overheated and caused smoke; CS 25.1181 cites such heaters so they receive the same fire-zone safeguards as engines.

Best-practice: Many turbine nacelles include an internal firewall separating power and accessory sections; doing so can allow each sub-compartment to be sized correctly for detection agent volumes while still meeting the rule’s intent.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that the space just aft of an engine firewall—and any part of the pylon/strut that carries fuel, oil, or hydraulic lines—is treated as if it were an engine fire zone: it must be built and vented so a fire cannot start easily, cannot spread to the wing or fuselage, and can be safely drained or contained until the crew can land. While the pylon itself does not have to carry its own fire-detection or extinguishing system, it must satisfy all the other fire-resistance, isolation, drainage, and materials standards that apply inside a nacelle. For aircraft with retractable landing gear that share this space, compliance is shown with the gear stowed, when exposure and system density are greatest.
ai_notes: British Airtours Flight 28M (B-737, 1985): A fire that started in the pylon/wing root area after an engine failure spread rapidly to the cabin, highlighting the need for better fire containment behind the firewall.

Expert note: Turbine-blade bursts or bearing failures often sever oil or hydraulic lines routed through the pylon; requiring firewall-equivalent protection limits ignition sources and gives crews critical minutes.

Boeing 737 Classics Service Bulletins (1990s): Multiple in-service fuel leak reports in the strut fairing led to mandatory drainage and shield upgrades—industry evidence that flammable fluid lines in this area are vulnerable.
Expert note: Modern compliance tests include 2000 °F (≈1093 °C) flame impingement on pylon panels for 15 minutes, mirroring CS-25.1191, to prove materials will not fail before safe landing.

American Airlines Flight 383 (B-767, 2016): Uncontained engine failure ignited fuel in the strut/wing root; fire-hard plumbing and titanium pylon webs kept flames out of the cabin long enough for evacuation.
Expert note: Manufacturers route pylon fluid lines through ‘wet-box’ channels with over-board drains; this best practice meets CS 25.1182 by preventing leaking fuel from pooling near hot surfaces.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that every pipe, hose, tank, valve, and fitting that carries fuel, oil, hydraulic fluid or other flammable liquids inside an engine bay or any other "fire zone" can survive a fire long enough to prevent the fluid from leaking or igniting. Items must either be fire-resistant (keep their contents for at least 5 minutes in a 1 100 °C flame) or fire-proof (keep integrity for 15 minutes) depending on the risk. Parts already certified within the engine itself, or harmless vents and drains, are exempt. In short, the aim is to stop a small engine fire or hot surface from turning into a catastrophic blaze that spreads, disables vital systems, or jeopardises the rest of the aircraft.
ai_notes: British Airtours B-737-236 G-BKKT (Manchester, 1985): uncontained engine failure fractured fuel lines; leaking fuel fed a severe fire that entered the cabin—illustrates why nacelle lines now need fire-resistant construction and shielding.

Expert note: Vibration-induced chafing of stainless-steel hydraulic pipes against structure was a frequent finding in post-flight inspections; modern routing keeps at least 12 mm clearance or uses cushioned clamps to avoid leaks in fire zones.
FAA AD 86-08-01 on 737 Classics required replacement of rubber-lined fuel hoses with fire-sleeved Teflon hoses after multiple ramp fires—industry practice that embodies CS-25.1183’s intent.

Expert note: Certification fire tests expose sample hoses to a 1 100 °C burner for 5 minutes while pressurised; no flame penetration or fluid leakage is permitted before approval for use in fire zones.

Delta MD-88 N906DL (ATL, 2014) ground fire: combustor burn-through ignited oil that pooled under the core; design changes added drip shields so leaked fluid cannot reach hot surfaces, matching the CS-25.1183 shielding requirement.
Expert note: Manufacturers often place boost-pump disconnect couplings outside engine nacelles so that, in case of nacelle fire, fuel supply can be shut off without relying on hoses remaining intact.

section_intent: This rule aims to stop a small leak of fuel, oil, or hydraulic fluid inside an engine, APU, or other "designated fire zone" from turning into an uncontrollable fire. It does so by (1) discouraging designers from putting tanks or reservoirs of flammable fluid in those hot zones unless they are built and protected to the same safety level as if they were outside, (2) ensuring a physical air gap (13 mm/0.5 in) between any such container and the firewall so heat cannot easily conduct through metal-to-metal contact, and (3) preventing insulation, sound-proofing, or other absorbent material from soaking up leaking fluid and providing extra fuel for a fire. In plain terms: keep large quantities of combustible liquid out of the hottest parts of the aircraft, and if you must put them there, isolate, separate, and shield them so a leak cannot feed a sustained blaze.
ai_notes: British Airtours 737-236, Manchester 1985: a fractured fuel line sprayed the nacelle; soaked insulation ignited after engine failure, demonstrating how absorbed fuel can feed a fire—directly influencing the requirement to shield absorbent materials.

Expert note: Chafing of hydraulic return lines on engine mounts is a frequent service difficulty report; locating the reservoir outside the nacelle plus automatic shut-off valves satisfies 25.1185(a) and eliminates the leak source within the fire zone.
MD-11 design change: hydraulic reservoirs originally in the tail APU bay were moved forward and provided with titanium shields and 0.5-inch standoffs to meet the clearance requirement in 25.1185(b).
Expert note: Compliance inspections routinely reject oil tanks hard-mounted to firewalls; adding spacer brackets restores the mandated air gap and avoids heat soak-through during a fire test.

Japan Airlines 123 (1985) post-crash investigation found saturated insulation in the aft pressure bulkhead/empennage that contributed to fire intensity; industry subsequently emphasised treating porous blankets with silicone coating per 25.1185(c).

Line maintenance best practice: after any engine bay wash or leak repair, technicians verify no residual fluid on acoustic blankets and re-seal torn covers, directly addressing 25.1185(c) requirements.

section_intent: The rule ensures that any area of the aircraft where an engine, APU or heater could catch fire is built so leaking fuel, oil or hydraulic fluid can quickly drain away and vapours do not build up. Effective drains prevent puddles that could ignite, and vents keep the air fresh enough to stop explosive mixtures forming—while being positioned so they do not let flames or fuel migrate into other compartments. Ventilation systems must not blow leaked vapours toward hot parts, and the crew must be able to close high-flow ventilation when they discharge fire-extinguishing agent so it is not diluted. In short, CS 25.1187 aims to stop leaks from becoming fires, stop fires from spreading, and let extinguishers work effectively.
ai_notes: Expert note: Engine nacelles incorporate scupper drains and dedicated overboard lines so any fuel or oil line rupture drains outside the cowling, eliminating pooling on hot turbine casings that could ignite.

B737-400 APU Fire (Birmingham, 1991): Hydraulic fluid leaked, pooled in the APU bay and ignited because drainage was insufficient; investigation reports were later cited in guidance for CS 25.1187(a).

Expert note: Certification tests introduce dyed fuel into the nacelle while the aircraft is pitched and yawed; compliance is shown when the fluid exits the drain within seconds and does not contact exhaust ducts.
CV-580 accessory-bay fires in the 1960s revealed that unventilated bays allowed vapour build-up; operators retrofitted screened louver vents, illustrating the intent of paragraph (b).
