Expert note: Modern twin-jets include cockpit-controlled fire-shutoff valves in ventilation ducts so crews can stop airflow before releasing Halon, preventing dilution and meeting paragraph (e).

Regional-jet tail-cone fire test (2005): Flames traveled through an unscreened vent opening from the APU bay into the empennage; redesign moved the vent and added a flame arrestor, satisfying paragraph (c).

section_intent: CS-25.1189 makes sure the crew can quickly stop any flammable liquid from feeding an engine or auxiliary fire. Valves or other shut-off devices must stay operable despite heat, structural damage, or inadvertent activation, must not starve healthy engines, must relieve trapped pressure, and must be reopenable if needed. The rule’s aim is to isolate a fire, keep it from spreading, and buy time for extinguishers and a safe landing, without creating new hazards.
ai_notes: British Airtours B737-236 fire, Manchester 1985: a ruptured fuel pipe kept feeding flames after take-off rejection; the tragedy underscored the need for robust, cockpit-controlled shut-off valves that still work when the nacelle is ablaze.

Qantas A380 Flight 32, 2010: an uncontained engine failure severed wing fuel pipes, but the spar valves closed and prevented a fuel-fed fire, showing effective compliance with the shut-off and fire-proof location requirements.

Expert note: Transport aircraft place the main "spar valve" on the wing rear spar, outside the nacelle, so it remains operable even if the engine detaches, meeting paragraph (g) about structural failure tolerance.

FedEx MD-11F Osaka 1999: a hydraulic leak ignited on landing and burned system components not isolated by shut-off devices, reinforcing the mandate to cut off other flammable fluids, not just fuel, in fire zones.
Expert note: Certification fire tests expose shut-off valves to a 1100 °C flame for 15 minutes; the valve must still actuate afterwards to satisfy paragraph (d) fire-proof integrity.

Industry practice: Engine fire-handles use a guarded pull-rotate action that simultaneously closes fuel, hydraulic, and bleed-air valves while arming extinguishers, directly addressing inadvertent activation and integrated emergency operation in paragraphs (c) and (f).

section_intent: Keep any fire that starts in an engine, APU, or other in-flight combustion device from spreading to the rest of the airplane. Fire-resistant barriers (firewalls, shrouds, or equivalent) must physically separate hot zones, stop flames, gases, or leaking fluids from migrating, and remain intact and corrosion-free for the aircraft’s life. This containment buys the crew time to shut down the source, use extinguishers, and land safely, while protecting critical structure, systems, and occupants.
ai_notes: British Airtours B737-236, Manchester 1985: engine fire breached the nacelle; flames and toxic smoke entered the cabin, highlighting the need for reliable containment and sealed penetrations.
Expert note: Stainless-steel or titanium firewalls with firestop sealant around control cables and wiring are standard to stop flame paths through small openings.
Southwest B737-700 Flight 3472, 2016: uncontained engine failure damaged nacelle, but firewall kept flames out of wing and fuselage, allowing safe landing and illustrating rule effectiveness.
Expert note: Certification fire tests (e.g., 2000 °F flame for 15 min) validate that grommets, fittings, and joints resist burn-through and fluid leakage per CS-25.1191(b)(3).
ATR-72 D-ANIH, Munich 1998: cabin heater bleed-air duct leak ignited insulation outside the heater bay; investigation reinforced need for shrouds around auxiliary combustion equipment.
Expert note: Maintenance practice requires inspecting firewall corrosion and sealant condition because any gap or rust path can let flame or fuel migrate, defeating the barrier.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that the metal and composite panels that cover the engine (cowlings and nacelle skins) are strong enough to stay attached, channel fluids safely, and, above all, prevent an engine-originated fire from endangering other parts of the aeroplane. They must resist flight loads and vibration, drain flammable liquids away, be ventilated, and use fire-proof or fire-resistant materials wherever flames or hot exhaust could hit. If a fire breaks out in an engine fire zone, the cowling must contain it so it cannot burn through into wings, fuselage or landing-gear bays, with stricter “fire-proof” performance required while airborne. Latches, hinges and visual indicators must let the crew and ground staff reliably secure the panels so they do not open or depart in flight, even if one latch is mis-fastened or fails. In short: keep the engine covered, keep fires confined, stop pooled fuel, and stop loose panels becoming hazards, guaranteeing continued safe flight and landing.
ai_notes: British Airways A319 G-EUOE (Heathrow 2013): unlatched fan-cowl doors blew off after take-off, damaging wiring and hydraulics; illustrates why single-latch failure tolerance and positive latch-verification are required.

Expert note: Numerous maintenance events showed small fuel or oil leaks pooling in nacelles; modern designs add dedicated drain paths and ventilation in line with CS 25.1187 to stop liquids feeding a fire.
Continental Airlines DC-10 N130AA (Miami 1993): tail-pipe fire burned through aluminium skin, proving the need for fire-proof material near exhaust impingement areas.
Expert note: Use of titanium or Inconel heat shields around turbine exhaust exits is now standard practice to meet the fire-proof requirement of 25.1193(d).
Embraer E190 PR-YSH (Brasília 2020): inlet cowl detached in climb due to hinge failure; event highlights load-bearing and retention criteria in 25.1193(a) and (f).
Boeing 777 design practice: diaphragm bulkhead isolates accessory gearbox bay from core; accessory-bay cowl panels are tested to 2000 °C flame for 15 min to satisfy 25.1193(c).
Expert note: Pre-flight walk-around training now emphasises checking green/flush latch indicators on A320 family fan cowls—a direct compliance and operational reinforcement of 25.1193(f)(3).
FedEx MD-11F (Memphis 2012) ground fire: nacelle burn-through threatened wing box; showed why ground-operation burn-through protection of critical structure is demanded in 25.1193(e)(3)(ii)(a).

section_intent: This rule makes sure every part of the engine installation or other "designated fire zone" that contains flammable fluids is equipped with a fire-extinguishing system capable of rapidly putting out a fire and preventing it from starting again, even in the high-speed airflow of flight. Adequate agent quantity, proper discharge rate, and proven distribution must be demonstrated, usually by test, and most zones need two independent discharges so the crew has a backup if the first shot fails or if the fire reignites. Nacelles must be protected throughout all their protected sections at the same time, and only portions of the hot turbine section without fuel lines may be exempted when proven safe. In essence, the rule seeks to confine and extinguish engine-related fires before they can damage structure, systems, or endanger occupants.
ai_notes: British Airtours Flight 28M (1985): An engine crack caused a nacelle fire; the single-shot bottle could not prevent re-ignition, the fire spread to the cabin, and 55 lives were lost—driving the later two-shot requirement and emphasis on re-ignition prevention.

American Airlines Flight 383, Chicago 2016: After an uncontained 767 engine failure, the crew used both bottles; adequate agent concentration quickly knocked down the fuel fire and kept it out until evacuation, illustrating the need for sufficient quantity and distribution.

Expert note: Certification testing includes on-wing Halon concentration measurements during high-speed flight profiles to prove the agent stays above the 6 % volume threshold in all corners of the nacelle, directly satisfying 25.1195(b).

Expert note: Designers place burst-disk manifolds near the nacelle hot spot because long, narrow lines were shown to delay agent arrival and fail concentration tests; CS 25.1195 institutionalised this best practice.
1970s JT8D fuel-line leak incidents: Multiple cases of fires that reignited after the first bottle led regulators to mandate two independent discharges for most engine zones.
Expert note: Maintenance training requires verification of both fire-bottle squib continuity and pressure, as CS 25.1195’s performance assumptions are invalidated if one bottle is inoperative.

Expert note: Fuel-burning heaters are allowed a single-shot system under 25.1195(b); operators typically locate the bottle within the heater bay to keep lines short and concentrate the agent where it is needed most.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that any chemical stored onboard as an automatic fire-extinguishing agent will (1) reliably put out fires from fuel, oil, wiring or other combustibles in engines, APU bays and similar compartments, (2) stay chemically and physically stable from the coldest cruise temperatures to the hottest ramp day, and (3) never reach a concentration that could injure or incapacitate people if the bottle leaks or is deliberately discharged. In short, the agent must be both an effective fire-killer and inherently safe for occupants under every foreseeable operating or failure condition.
ai_notes: Expert note: Halon 1301 became the industry standard because it rapidly knocks down fuel fires, remains stable between −65 °C and +55 °C, and is essentially non-toxic below 5 % volume—the performance envelope CS 25.1197 demands.

FedEx Flight 1406 (DC-10, 1996) saw a cargo-hold fire reignite after the initial knock-down because agent concentration dissipated, highlighting why the rule insists on complete extinguishment and adequate charge weight.

Dallas maintenance incident, 2007: accidental APU-bottle CO₂ discharge flooded the cockpit and briefly incapacitated two technicians, underscoring the need for design features that prevent harmful concentrations from reaching occupied areas.

Expert note: Certification testing cold-soaks bottles to −54 °C and then fires them into a nacelle simulator to verify pressure, flow and atomisation, directly addressing the thermal-stability clause.

Air Canada Flight 797 (1983) demonstrated that mixed fires involving plastics, wiring and hydraulic fluid can erupt; the wording ‘fluids or other combustible materials’ ensures agents cope with such combined fire loads.

Operator best practice: Airlines brief crews never to discharge built-in CO₂ systems on the ground with doors open because the gas can back-flow into the cabin, a procedure rooted in the exposure limits mandated by CS 25.1197.

section_intent: The rule ensures that the fire-extinguishing agent bottles installed in transport aeroplanes will reliably deliver the required agent when needed, without creating new hazards. It demands (1) pressure-relief devices so bottles cannot burst, (2) safe routing of any relief discharge so it cannot damage the aircraft and is protected from blockage, (3) clear cockpit/maintenance indication of low pressure or inadvertent discharge so a crew never flies with an empty bottle, (4) control of bottle temperature so pressure stays within the band that guarantees rapid, complete discharge but prevents overheating that could trigger an unwanted release, and (5) protection of pyrotechnic squibs from heat degradation. In short, the objective is to guarantee availability, effectiveness and safe containment of the extinguishing system throughout all operating environments.
ai_notes: ValuJet 592 (1996) – while mainly a cargo-hold oxygen-generator fire, the investigation highlighted the need for reliable extinguishers; FAA reviews found several Halon bottles under-pressurised, reinforcing the requirement for cockpit pressure indication.

Expert note: High ambient ramp temperatures in the Middle East caused CO₂ bottles on early jetliners to over-pressurise and rupture, sending shrapnel through nearby systems—pressure-relief valves and safe discharge plumbing were mandated to eliminate this hazard.

Expert note: Engine-nacelle fire tests revealed that ice particles thrown up from runways could plug relief or discharge outlets; the rule’s ‘located or protected’ clause led to recessed or screened outlets now typical on modern nacelles.

MD-11 freighter (2002) line-check – maintenance found a Halon bottle squib degraded by prolonged exposure to APU heat; CS 25.1199(e) requires bottles be placed where pyrotechnic cartridges stay within certification temperature limits.
Expert note: Pressure gauges with temperature-compensated markings are now standard so mechanics can spot low-charge bottles in cold climates, directly addressing 25.1199(c) and (d).

Airbus A320 family AMM procedures include routine weigh-checks of cargo-hold bottles; this best practice stems from 25.1199’s objective that any silent leaks are detected before the aircraft is dispatched.

section_intent: The rule ensures that the fire-extinguishing system inside an engine or APU compartment will still work, and will not introduce new dangers, at the very moment it is needed. All pipes, bottles, valves, hoses and seals must be made from materials that neither react chemically with the chosen agent (Halon, CO₂, newer clean agents, etc.) nor degrade when exposed to it, so leaks, corrosive by-products or explosions cannot occur. Because those components may sit inside a flame-filled nacelle before the crew even pulls the fire handle, they must stay structurally intact and capable of delivering the agent for long enough to put the fire out. In plain words: the system itself must remain safe, compatible and usable under fire conditions so the crew can rely on it to extinguish the fire without creating additional hazards.
ai_notes: Expert note: Early CO₂ systems that used magnesium-alloy fittings suffered rapid corrosion and clogging from carbonic acid formation, sometimes preventing full discharge; the regulation demands material compatibility to stop this failure mode.

Eastern Air Lines L-1011 nacelle fire (1972): aluminium lines in the engine compartment burned through before Halon could be released, leading to stainless-steel, fireproof tubing requirements reflected in CS-25.1201(b).

Expert note: Maintenance bulletins now prohibit PTFE hoses with bronze over-braid in Halon loops because the agent can leach oils from the liner, causing embrittlement and cracks—illustrating the ‘no chemical reaction’ clause.

FedEx MD-11 fleet practice: extinguisher bottles are mounted outside the nacelle with fire-proof penetrations; where components must remain inside, they are shielded by stainless blankets to meet fireproof criteria.

Expert note: Certification tests include a 2000 °F (≈1090 °C) flame exposure for 15 minutes on sample tubing while pressurised with extinguishant to prove it will not burst or melt before agent discharge.

section_intent: The rule ensures that every engine compartment and other declared fire zones contain fast-acting, reliable sensors that alert the crew the moment a fire or dangerous overheat starts. The system must keep working despite vibration, fluid contamination, wiring damage or electrical faults, and it must be testable in flight. By making the detection network fire-resistant, redundant and immune to nuisance alarms, the regulation gives pilots the precious seconds needed to discharge extinguishers, shut the engine down and land before a nacelle or tailpipe fire can breach its barriers and threaten the whole aircraft.
ai_notes: British Airtours Flight 28M (B737-236, 1985): Engine fire was detected immediately, allowing shutdown, but the rapid external spread showed why quick, unmistakable cockpit warnings are vital to trigger evacuation and fire-fighting actions.

Qantas Flight 32 (A380, 2010): An uncontained engine failure severed one loop of the fire wire; the dual-loop design still reported a valid fire signal, demonstrating the redundancy demanded by 25.1203(b)(2).

China Airlines 120 (B737-800, 2007): Fuel spray and hydraulic fluid ignited during taxi; detectors located in the turbine section gave the crew the first warning, illustrating the need for sensors that are not blinded by fluids per 25.1203(c).

Expert note: Modern transport engines use dual-loop or dual-element detectors with "A AND/OR B" logic, preventing a single short or open circuit from either disabling protection or causing a false fire alarm, meeting 25.1203(b)(3).

Expert note: Cockpit "FIRE TEST" checks performed before the first flight and in-flight BITE (Built-In Test Equipment) satisfy 25.1203(d) by letting crews confirm circuit integrity and annunciator function without external equipment.

Expert note: Compliance data typically shows EWIS routing that avoids running detector wiring through adjacent fire zones; where unavoidable, fire-resistant conduits or common extinguishing coverage are applied, aligning with 25.1203(f) and CS 25.1713/1731.

section_intent: This rule tells applicants how they must prove that the engine, APU and nacelle fire-protection features required in CS 25.1181–1203 really work. Unless another paragraph already spells out a different method, the default is a full-scale fire test that replicates worst-case conditions inside the power-plant bay. If repeating such a costly test is not necessary, the rule permits other evidence—tests on similar configurations or individual components, in-service experience on comparable aircraft, or a thorough technical analysis—so long as it demonstrates an equivalent level of safety. In plain words: don’t just claim that the firewall, tubing, wiring, seals and extinguishing system will hold up in a fire—prove it with hard data, either by burning the real thing or by using rigorously validated substitutes.
ai_notes: British Airtours Flight 28M (1985): A 737 engine fire that breached the nacelle and ignited cabin fumes highlighted the need for verified firewall and seal designs, prompting regulators to insist on full-scale or equivalent fire tests.
Qantas Flight 32 (2010): After an A380 engine burst, previously demonstrated nacelle fire resistance prevented a sustained blaze, illustrating the value of full-scale proof of design performance.

Expert note: OEMs routinely run the 15-minute nacelle oil-spray fire test defined in AC 20-135; CS 25.1207 recognises that such component tests can substitute for repeating an entire airplane burn-through trial.

Expert note: For derivative programmes like the 737-MAX, applicants cite similarity analyses and earlier 737NG nacelle fire test reports under paragraphs (a) and (c) to avoid redundant testing while still satisfying the rule.

DHL A300 Baghdad missile strike (2003): The engine bay caught fire but was contained by certified firewalls and extinguishers—features whose compliance had been shown through component tests plus analysis, exactly as CS 25.1207 allows.

Expert note: Certification teams instrument full-scale fire rigs with thermocouples and heat-flux gauges to prove that firewall materials stay below 400 °C for 15 minutes, generating the data needed for future similarity justifications.

Lockheed Electra nacelle fires (1960s): Magnesium accessory cases burned through walls, leading to requirements for fireproof materials and demonstrating why paper analysis alone is insufficient without physical burn testing.

section_intent: CS-25.1301 ensures that every piece of equipment built into a large aeroplane is (1) suitable for the job it must do, (2) clearly identified so the crew and maintenance personnel know what it is, how to use it and any limits, and (3) installed only within the conditions and limits for which it was approved. In plain terms, nothing may be bolted into the aircraft unless it is the right design, properly marked, and fitted exactly as the approval data say. Paragraph (b) adds that all wiring and connectors feeding that equipment must satisfy the dedicated wiring-safety rules in Subpart H. The overall goal is to prevent accidents that arise from inappropriate, mislabelled, or wrongly installed equipment or wiring faults—whether through flight-crew confusion, maintenance error, or in-service failure—by making suitability, identification and installation discipline a certification obligation.
ai_notes: Swissair 111 (1998): Post-crash investigation showed the in-flight-entertainment system wiring was added outside its approved envelope, igniting a cockpit fire; CS 25.1301(b) now reminds applicants that all wiring must meet Subpart H standards.

Expert note: Many flight-deck switches carry engraved legends and guarded covers (e.g., "FIRE DISCH" with red guard) because 25.1301(a)(2) demands clear function labelling that prevents inadvertent activation during workload peaks.

TUI Boeing 787 ELT recall (2013): Honeywell emergency locator transmitters overheated when installed with improper wiring and bracket torque; regulators cited 25.1301(a)(3) to require re-installation per equipment limits.

Eastern Air Lines L-1011 autopilot mode confusion (1972): Similar-looking but differently-labelled buttons contributed to altitude-capture error; highlighted need for unmistakable identification of each control per 25.1301(a)(2).

Expert note: Environmental qualification (DO-160) testing is routinely cited in compliance reports to show the equipment is 'of a kind and design appropriate' to temperature, vibration and EMI conditions required by 25.1301(a)(1).

Expert note: Certification plans include an ‘Equipment List and Installation Control Document’ linking every part number to its installation drawing and limitations—an industry best practice derived directly from 25.1301 requirements.

section_intent: CS 25.1302 ensures that every control, switch, display or automation used by pilots from their normal seats is human-centred and fail-safe. Equipment must be reachable, easy to understand, and provide information with the clarity, resolution and timeliness the task demands. Its behaviour must be predictable, give the crew immediate awareness of consequences, and allow quick override or disconnect. Designers must anticipate normal human slips, mode confusions or data-entry errors and make sure those errors cannot escalate into unsafe situations. In essence, the rule turns hard-won human-factors lessons into mandatory design criteria so the flight deck helps—not hinders—crews in keeping the aeroplane safe.
ai_notes: Boeing 737-8 MAX Lion Air 610 & Ethiopian 302: MCAS fired without clear cockpit annunciation, leaving crews unaware of repeated trim inputs; the tragedies underline the need for explicit feedback and simple override paths demanded by 25.1302.

Air France 447 (A330, 2009): Loss of pitot data produced conflicting stall warnings and display flags that crews struggled to interpret, showing why information must remain unambiguous and task-appropriate.

Asiana 214 (B777, 2013): Autothrottle logic left thrust at idle while pilots believed speed protection was active, illustrating how ambiguous mode cues can mislead crews and why predictable, well-annunciated behaviour is required.

Expert note: Certification teams now run ‘error-provocative’ simulator trials—wrong data entries, incorrect mode selections—to verify the system prevents or clearly exposes mistakes, demonstrating compliance with 25.1302(d).

Expert note: Frequently used autoflight knobs are clustered and tactilely distinct so pilots can adjust heading, altitude or speed without excessive head-down time, meeting 25.1302(b) accessibility criteria.
Industry practice: Colour-coded Flight Mode Annunciators and standard aural alerts give instant, unmistakable feedback on automation state, directly addressing 25.1302(b)(3) and (c).
Expert note: EASA Human-Factors assessments (HF-A) now include ‘surprise-startle’ reviews to ensure new avionics behave predictably and allow prompt crew intervention, as required by 25.1302(c)(2).

section_intent: Every pilot must always have a clear, independent picture of the aeroplane’s attitude, orientation, speed, altitude, climb rate and heading. CS-25.1303 therefore mandates a minimum set of flight and navigation instruments—plus overspeed warnings and a standby attitude source—that remain readable and powered even after electrical failures. Together they prevent loss of control, structural exceedance or navigation error by giving the crew unambiguous, continuously available data on free-air temperature, time, direction, airspeed (VMO = maximum operating speed, MMO = maximum operating Mach), altitude and attitude throughout all phases of flight.
ai_notes: Birgenair B757-200 Flight 301 (1996): A blocked pitot tube produced wildly conflicting airspeed; without reliable standby references the crew stalled and crashed, illustrating why redundant, clearly visible airspeed indicators and overspeed aural alerts are compulsory.

China Airlines B747SP Flight 006 (1985): After an engine flame-out the aircraft rolled into a spiralling dive; recovery occurred only when the captain refocused on the attitude gyro, highlighting the need for gyroscopically stabilised bank-and-pitch indicators through 360° attitudes.

Northwest Airlines B727 Flight 6231 (1974): Pitot-static icing gave false high Mach, leading to overspeed and structural breakup, underscoring the importance of accurate Mach meters and the CS-mandated VMO/MMO warning horn.

Air France A330 Flight 447 (2009): Temporary air-data loss forced pilots to rely on the battery-backed standby horizon, validating the rule that an independent attitude instrument must work for at least 30 minutes after total generator failure.
Expert note: Certification flight tests deliberately accelerate to VMO + 10 kt and MMO + 0.02 to verify that the overspeed aural warning activates within the CS-25.1303(c)(1) tolerance band.

Expert note: Modern Part-25 cockpits mount the standby attitude indicator on the centreline ‘T-panel’, meeting CS 25.1321 readability criteria and ensuring immediate access if a primary display goes dark.

Expert note: Flight Operational Quality Assurance (FOQA) data show fewer altitude and speed exceedances when crews verbalise the ‘altitude-airspeed-attitude’ scan—exactly the core parameters this rule obliges manufacturers to place at each pilot station.

Early jet upset reports in the 1950s linked un-monitored low outside-air temperature to Mach buffet encounters; the mandated free-air temperature gauge lets crews adjust speed schedules for ISA deviations, preventing similar events.

section_intent: CS 25.1305 ensures that crews of large aeroplanes always have clear, reliable cockpit information and warnings about every system that keeps the engines running: fuel, oil, temperature, vibration, ice-protection, fire, thrust and propeller settings. By specifying which indicators, gauges and alerts must be present—and how independent they must remain after a single failure—the rule aims to prevent loss of thrust, detect malfunctions early, and give pilots time to manage or shut down an engine before it causes a fire, seizure or fuel exhaustion. In short, it makes sure the flight deck never flies blind to power-plant health.
ai_notes: Air Transat 236 (2001): A slow fuel leak went unnoticed until the flight crew received low-fuel quantity and imbalance warnings; the mandated instruments provided the only cues that enabled a safe glide to the Azores.

Qantas QF32 (A380, 2010): After an uncontained engine failure, oil-pressure, EGT (exhaust-gas temperature) and vibration read-outs let the crew identify which of multiple ECAM messages were critical, illustrating why independent parameters are required.
British Airways 38 (B777, 2008): Ice-induced fuel-flow restriction occurred; CS 25.1305(c)(8) requires indicators for fuel-heater function to alert crews before such clogging compromises thrust.

Expert note: Engine vibration sensors mandated by 25.1305(c)(9) are now tied to maintenance trend-monitoring; operators routinely pull high-vibe items for borescope inspection, preventing fan-blade release events.

Expert note: Low-fuel-level alerts set at 30 min cruise burn allow crews to divert before tanks unport in prolonged turns— a lesson from earlier jet transports where sudden flameouts occurred with still-indicated fuel on board (‘trapped fuel’).

UPS Flight 6 (B747-400F, 2010): Early cockpit fire warnings came from 25.1305(a)(7) fire-warning devices; although the origin was cargo, the requirement ensures audible/visual cues reach pilots even with high workload.
Expert note: Starter-operation indicators required by 25.1305(c)(4) prevent crews from exceeding ground-start time limits that historically led to starter-turbine bursts on JT8D and CF6 engines.

Expert note: Propeller low-pitch indication required by 25.1305(e)(2) addresses accidents like Britten-Norman Trislander G-BEDH (1996), where uncommanded beta range caused loss of control; modern turboprops inhibit flight-beta and flag any blade-angle mis-set.

section_intent: Transport aeroplanes must keep essential power, communication, and navigation available even if one component fails or is turned off. CS-25.1307 therefore demands at least two separate electrical power sources, circuit-protection that prevents shorts or fires, and fully redundant two-way radio and navigation sets. All equipment must be wired and located so that a single failure (e.g. generator trip, lightning strike, tripped breaker) cannot silence the flight crew or leave them without accurate positional information. In plain terms, the rule makes sure crews can always talk, navigate, and power critical systems from take-off to landing, including in IMC or remote areas, after any single malfunction.
ai_notes: Swissair 111 (MD-11, 1998): wiring short behind the cockpit ignited flammable insulation when breakers did not open quickly; requirement for proper electrical protective devices addresses this hazard.

American Airlines B777 ETOPS demonstrations: FAA/EASA witnessed intentional shutdown of one engine-driven generator; the independent APU generator seamlessly powered radios and navs, showing the redundancy this rule expects.

Expert note: Separate VHF-1 and VHF-2 radios are powered from different buses and use dissimilar antennas; a lightning strike that detunes one antenna leaves the other system functional, satisfying the 'failure of one shall not preclude operation of the other' clause.

United Airlines Flight 731 (B727, 1978): total loss of VOR receiver 1 due to internal fault; crew used the second, separately powered VOR/DME to continue IFR approach—illustrating why two independent nav systems are mandated.

Expert note: Certification best practice is to route wiring for COM-1 and COM-2 on opposite sides of the fuselage; this segregation minimises the chance that a single fire, fluid leak, or structural break severs both systems simultaneously.

section_intent: CS-25.1309 ensures that every item of equipment or system on a large aeroplane is designed, installed, monitored and maintained so that no single failure can cause a catastrophe, multiple failures are collectively improbable, and the flight crew is given clear, timely information to manage any remaining hazards. By requiring quantified reliability targets, redundancy, segregation, latent-fault detection, crew alerting and scheduled maintenance tasks, the rule turns abstract safety goals into concrete design and operational obligations that keep system-related risk at an acceptably low level throughout the aircraft’s service life.
ai_notes: United Airlines Flight 232 (1989): An uncontained engine disk ruptured all three collocated hydraulic lines, eliminating flight-control power and showing why catastrophic consequences must not stem from a single failure location.
Swissair Flight 111 (1998): Fire that began in optional in-flight entertainment wiring spread rapidly above the cockpit, illustrating that non-essential equipment must not endanger essential systems.

Boeing 737 MAX accidents (2018-19): A lone angle-of-attack sensor drove MCAS trim inputs without adequate crew alerting, reinforcing the prohibition on single-point failures causing hazardous outcomes.
Lauda Air Flight 004 (1991): A latent hydraulic valve defect allowed in-flight thrust-reverser deployment; the crash led to mandatory Certification Maintenance Requirements for such hidden faults.

Expert note: Fly-by-wire transports use three or four independent flight-control computers with dissimilar hardware and separate power sources to achieve the extremely-improbable target for catastrophic failure conditions.

Expert note: Safety assessments employ ARP4761 Fault-Tree and Failure-Modes analyses to show that major, hazardous and catastrophic failure conditions meet the required remote or extremely remote probabilities.

Birgenair Flight 301 (1996): A wasp-blocked pitot probe caused unreliable airspeed with insufficient alerting, underscoring the need for redundant sensing and timely crew information on unsafe system states.
Expert note: Built-in test equipment that flags failed line-replaceable units before dispatch minimizes the time latent failures can remain undetected, as demanded by CS-25.1309.

section_intent: The rule ensures that every system and piece of equipment needed for safe flight, navigation, communication, and landing keeps working even when part of the aircraft’s power-generation chain fails. It requires designers to size and arrange generators, batteries, converters, and wiring so that all "essential loads" stay powered in normal flight, after loss of any one engine or generator, and (for multi-engine aircraft) after the specified worst-case multiple-engine outages. If one power source or distribution path goes down, another independent path must automatically or procedurally take over, with clear crew procedures to shed non-critical loads when needed. In short, the aircraft must always have enough reliable electrical (or other) energy to keep critical systems alive until a safe landing, despite foreseeable single failures or engine loss.
ai_notes: Air Canada 143 "Gimli Glider" (1983): Both engines flamed out from fuel exhaustion; the ram-air turbine supplied essential buses, allowing instruments and flight controls to remain powered and the crew to glide to a safe landing—an exact demonstration of the requirement for alternate power after dual engine loss.

US Airways 1549 (A320, 2009): Bird strike caused dual engine failure; automatic APU start and RAT deployment kept fly-by-wire computers, radios, and flight displays alive during the Hudson River ditching, illustrating mandated backup capacity.

Air Transat 236 (A330, 2001): Fuel leak led to total engine flameout over the Atlantic; essential electrical supply from batteries and RAT sustained navigation and control for a 65-NM glide to Lajes, validating the endurance criteria in CS 25.1310(b).

Expert note: Repeated in-service Integrated Drive Generator (IDG) seizures have shown that loss of a prime mover can cascade; segregated essential buses and automatic load-shedding prevent a single generator failure from darkening flight decks.

Expert note: Modern designs split power into Main, Essential, and Shed buses with physically separate wiring runs. This architecture satisfies the rule’s intent that a distribution fault on one bus cannot remove all critical equipment.

Boeing 787 certification (2013): Lithium-ion battery thermal events forced proof that a single energy-storage failure would not de-energise fly-by-wire or flight-deck displays, reinforcing independent power-source criteria in 25.1310(a)(2) and (4).

Expert note: ETOPS compliance demands that batteries alone can run essential avionics for at least 30 minutes after complete generator loss, directly derived from the endurance assumptions permitted under paragraph (b).

Expert note: Airline training includes "ELEC EMER" or "AC BUS FAIL" checklists that instruct crews to manually shed galley, cabin, and anti-ice loads, mirroring the monitored load-reduction procedure allowed by 25.1310(b) to conserve power for flight-critical systems.

section_intent: The rule requires that no aircraft system or piece of equipment may fail or behave dangerously when the aircraft is subjected to the negative-g manoeuvres already allowed in the flight-loads envelope. Designers must prove, for the full time those manoeuvres could realistically last, that fuel, oil, hydraulic, electrical and avionic systems keep working and do not create new hazards (fire, loss of control, inadvertent deployment, etc.). In plain terms: even when the aircraft briefly "pushes over" and occupants feel weightless or lifted from their seats, everything on board must keep doing its job safely.
ai_notes: China Airlines Flight 006 (B-747SP, 1985): A sudden negative-g tumble unported a fuel pick-up, leading to an engine flame-out and highlighting why fuel systems must keep feeding under −g.
TWA Flight 841 (B-727, 1979): Prolonged inverted descent subjected hydraulics to −g; subsequent system recovery issues fed industry focus on reservoir design and pump inlet location.

Expert note: Oil systems on high-bypass turbofans now incorporate scavenge pickups on multiple faces of the sump so that bearings stay lubricated during the certified −1 g for up to 20 s, satisfying CS 25.1315 tests.
Expert note: Hydraulic reservoirs are baffled and pressurised so that pumps do not cavitate when the fluid shifts upward during pushover manoeuvres.
Expert note: Emergency slide inflation bottles are fitted with dual-orientation firing pins to prevent inadvertent deployment caused by valve movement under negative acceleration.

Certification practice: Flight-test programmes include repeated −1 g pushover runs while monitoring engine parameters, fuel pressure, hydraulic pump output and avionics stability to demonstrate compliance.
Expert note: Modern inertial reference units are qualified to DO-160 section 7 cat B shock-vibration levels so that −g does not trigger false attitude data or automatic disconnects.
Crew training: Airlines brief pilots to avoid sustained pushover in turbulence because, although the aircraft is certified, unnecessary duration beyond the envelope can still unport fuel and oil.

section_intent: Lightning inevitably strikes transport aeroplanes in service. CS-25.1316 requires that any electrical or electronic system whose failure could jeopardise safe flight either keep working during a strike or automatically return to normal operation quickly afterwards. In plain language, the rule makes sure that critical and essential systems (e.g. fly-by-wire flight controls, engine controls, navigation, cockpit displays) are immune to the high currents, voltages and electromagnetic fields produced by lightning so that the crew can always control and land the aircraft. It also ensures the design includes shielding, bonding, surge protection and software recovery logic so momentary upsets do not cascade into a hazardous situation.
ai_notes: Pan Am Flight 214 (1963): Lightning ignited fuel vapour and led to loss of the aircraft; investigation highlighted the need for comprehensive lightning protection of wiring and systems routed near fuel tanks.

Expert note: Early fly-by-wire prototypes showed that a direct lightning attachment could crash flight-control computers; this drove industry adoption of metallic/mesh shielding around LRUs and fibre-optic signal links.

Toulouse A320 test-flight incident (1993): Multiple ECAM messages and flight-control reversion after lightning strike demonstrated how transient upsets can overwhelm pilots if automatic recovery is not assured.
Expert note: DO-160 Section 22/23 surge and waveform testing, plus HIRF/EMI zoning, are now standard certification practices to show compliance with CS-25.1316.

B787 factory tests (2006): Full-scale composite wing lightning tests validated that protected wiring looms and fast-acting current limiters allow flight computers to ride through 200 kA strikes without reboot.
Expert note: Airlines train maintenance staff to verify bonding straps, continuity, and replace worn shielding because degraded bonds are a common in-service finding that can void design assumptions.
Expert note: Redundant power supplies and automatic re-initialisation routines in avionics software are inserted specifically to meet the ‘timely recovery’ clause of CS-25.1316.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that any aeroplane system that the crew needs to keep the aircraft safely under control keeps working when the aircraft is hit by very strong external radio-frequency energy – for example from military radars, broadcast antennas, or satellite uplinks. It obliges designers to prove, by analysis and test, that critical functions are immune to those fields, cannot be latched into a hazardous state, and will automatically return to normal operation within seconds if a temporary upset does occur. The required immunity levels (set out in Appendix R) scale with the consequence of failure, so that even momentary loss or corruption of flight-control, engine or essential display data cannot jeopardise continued safe flight and landing.
ai_notes: Event: 1988 Bell 214ST crash (Abu Dhabi). Investigation showed the flight-control computer latched up after the helicopter flew through a coastal surveillance radar beam, spurring regulators to mandate HIRF protection for fly-by-wire systems.

Expert note: During Boeing 777 certification, primary flight computers rebooted in a 200 V/m chamber test; added shielding, filtered connectors and an auto-restart routine were implemented to comply with CS 25.1317(a)(2).

Event: In the mid-1990s several A320 crews at JFK and CDG reported primary flight displays blanking while taxiing past high-power surface-movement radars; the incidents led to retrofit of better-screened display electronics.

Common failure mode: Long, inadequately bonded wire bundles behave as antennas and inject spurious commands into FADECs or spoilers; CS 25.1317 drives use of double-shielded cables, 360° backshell terminations, and rigorous bonding checks.

Best practice: Airframers now place whole aircraft in reverberation chambers and exercise flight-critical functions up to Appendix R field strengths, then verify that all systems automatically recover within the time limits of paragraph (a)(2).

Event: 1999 FAA flight-inspection Learjet 60 experienced simultaneous GPS resets when overflown by the 15 MW ‘Cobra Dane’ radar in Alaska; data from the occurrence helped establish the envelope for Environment II in Appendix R.

Expert note: Airlines include shield-continuity and bonding-strap inspections in heavy-check task cards because corroded or broken bonds remain the most common in-service cause of HIRF susceptibility findings.

section_intent: This rule ensures that every piece of onboard equipment, system and digital network on a large aeroplane is evaluated for cyber-security. The applicant must identify all possible intentional unauthorised electronic interactions (IUEIs), analyse the safety impact if they succeed, and build in technical, procedural and maintenance measures to stop or limit them. In plain words: prove the airplane cannot be hacked in a way that endangers flight, and keep that protection effective for the life of the aircraft.
ai_notes: Chris Roberts/United 737 (2015): Researcher claimed he accessed thrust-management through the seat-back IFE port; although not verified, the publicity highlighted risks when passenger networks interface with avionics and pushed regulators toward explicit cyber-protection rules.

Boeing 787 Special Conditions (2008): FAA required network segregation after certification testing showed common data buses between cabin and flight-critical domains; this case directly led to CS-25 cyber-security language.
Expert note: Malware-infected navigation database USB sticks have corrupted FMS data during ground updates; CS 25.1319 drives operators to use vetted media, digital signatures and update procedures.
Thales SATCOM penetration test (industry practice): Ethical hackers demonstrated remote entry from ground to cabin router; mitigated by firewalls and one-way gateways now standard under DO-326A.

LOT Polish Airlines flight cancellations (2015): Ground flight-plan system cyber-attack delayed 1,400 passengers; shows how compromised data uplinked to the aircraft can create operational and safety hazards addressed by secure datalink requirements.

Expert note: Certification teams now perform security risk assessments per ED-202A/DO-326A and trace each threat to design, operational or maintenance controls—exactly the process paragraph (a) mandates.
Common practice: Operators add cyber-security items to Continuing Airworthiness Management Expositions and AMM tasks (e.g., verify seals on avionics bay Ethernet ports) to satisfy paragraph (b).
Expert note: Segmentation into Aircraft Control, Airline Information and Passenger Information domains with unidirectional gateways is a canonical mitigation strategy born from CS 25.1319 compliance.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that the instruments a pilot needs to fly, navigate and monitor the engines are placed where they can be seen instantly, without head-turning or guesswork, even in turbulence or poor visibility. It locks in the ‘basic-T’ layout (attitude top-centre, airspeed left, altitude right, heading below) so every transport-category cockpit looks and feels familiar, reducing scan time and training differences. Engine gauges must also be grouped clearly so the pilot instantly knows which reading belongs to which engine. The panel must resist vibration that could blur needles or damage sensors, and any failure flag or warning light has to remain obvious in bright sun, night lighting or instrument-panel dim conditions. In short, the rule prevents spatial disorientation, wrong-engine actions, and missed warnings by guaranteeing clear, consistent, and durable instrument presentation.
ai_notes: Expert note: Military and NACA studies in the 1940s showed accident rates fell sharply when cockpits adopted the standard 'basic-T' layout, prompting civil regulators to codify it in rules like CS-25.1321.

British Midland Flight 92 (1989): Crew shut down the healthy engine after mis-identifying vibration indications; later reports stressed the need for unambiguous, grouped engine instruments matching engine position.

Helios Airways Flight 522 (2005): Pressurisation mode lights were not in the normal scan; the crew missed the warning, underscoring the requirement that vital indicators be plainly visible under all lighting conditions.

Expert note: Certification testing now includes panel vibration surveys; early piston airliners had altimeters and RPM gauges that went out of calibration due to cockpit resonance, causing wrong power settings.
Turboprop training syllabi teach the 'central scan' starting with the top-centre attitude indicator, mirroring CS-25.1321 so pilots transitioning between types do not relearn instrument locations.
NASA human-factors research shows that grouping left-engine gauges on the left and right-engine gauges on the right cuts reaction time by about 30 %, directly addressing sub-para (c)(1).

Expert note: Modern glass cockpits keep the same spatial hierarchy (PFD top-centre, ND below) and place EICAS/ECAM in a dedicated zone to comply with the spirit of CS-25.1321 despite using screens instead of round dials.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that any message telling the pilots something is abnormal is impossible to miss, clearly ranked by urgency, and automatically disappears once the situation is over. "Warnings" (red) demand immediate action; "Cautions" (amber/yellow) need quick attention but not instant action; "Advisories" merely inform. Designers must use more than one human sense (for example, sound plus light) so the cue is recognised even in high workload, yet avoid false or repetitive alerts that would distract or tempt crews to disable them. Colours other than red, amber or yellow are reserved so they do not dilute the meaning. In essence, CS-25.1322 provides a disciplined, prioritised language for cockpit alerts so crews can recognise the right problem at the right time and act safely.
ai_notes: Eastern Air Lines Flight 401 (1972): No master warning drew attention to the unmonitored descent; a conspicuous red-warning hierarchy might have prevented the crash.
United Airlines Flight 173 (1978): Gear-light concern masked fuel-low condition; prioritised caution-then-warning logic would have highlighted the critical fuel state sooner.
Air France Flight 447 (2009): Simultaneous stall, overspeed and altitude alerts overloaded the crew, illustrating why the rule demands intelligible, prioritised messages and suppression of cascades.
Qantas Flight QF72 (2008): Repeated false stall and overspeed warnings forced the crew to silence chimes, showing the need for designs that minimise and let pilots suppress nuisance alerts per §(d).

Lion Air Flight 610 (2018): Continuous stick-shaker from a single AoA failure demonstrates how an un-silenceable single-sense alert can mask further cues and escalate workload, directly addressed by §(c)(3) and §(d).
Expert note: Modern ECAM/EICAS systems display the root cause message first and automatically call up the checklist, embodying §(a)(1) and the mandated alert hierarchy.
Expert note: The classic red MASTER WARNING light plus repetitive horn delivers visual and aural cues, satisfying §(c)(2)’s two-sense requirement.
Expert note: Guarded MASTER WARNING CUT-OUT switches located away from normal controls let crews silence a failed horn without accidental use, meeting §(d)(2)’s suppression provisions.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that the airspeed information a crew sees is consistently accurate, responsive and trustworthy in every phase of flight. It limits calibration and installation error to ±3 %/5 kt, demands predictable needle movement near stall (VS) and overspeed (VMO/VDF), controls system lag during the take-off roll, guards against moisture, dirt and bird strikes, and requires in-flight and ground-run surveys to quantify any residual bias between indicated airspeed (IAS), calibrated airspeed (CAS) and true airspeed (TAS). In plain terms, CS-25.1323 exists so that pilots can set, call and act on critical speeds such as V1, VR, V2, approach, stall-warning and overspeed margins with confidence, avoiding wrong decisions, structural exceedance or loss of control.
ai_notes: Birgenair B757 Flight 301 (1996): Insect-blocked pitot produced falsely high IAS, crew mismanaged thrust and stalled, highlighting why contamination protection and redundant probes (§ h, j) are mandatory.
Air France A330 Flight 447 (2009): Pitot icing created divergent airspeed indications; the accident illustrates the need for correct-sense IAS response across the envelope (§ d, e).
Expert note: Certification teams perform trailing-cone and tower-fly-by tests during take-off, climb and cruise to map IAS-CAS error as required by § b.
Expert note: Short, straight pneumatic lines or digital Air Data Modules are used to minimise dynamic lag and take-off IAS bias, meeting § g.
Qantas B744 VH-OJK (2006): Post-wash water in pitot lines caused unreliable airspeed on rotation, underscoring sealing/drainage demands of § h.
Industry practice: Captain and first-officer pitot masts are mounted on opposite sides of the nose with a third standby probe so one bird strike cannot disable all sources, satisfying § j.
Expert note: Flutter dive testing up to VDF verifies that indicated airspeed never reverses or freezes, preventing overspeed misinterpretation per § e.
FAA rejected-take-off studies show a 5 kt IAS error can flip the GO/STOP decision at V1; the 3 %/5 kt installation limit in § c and lag control in § g directly address this.

section_intent: Keep all externally-mounted flight-instrument probes (pitot, static, angle-of-attack, side-slip, temperature, etc.) free of ice accretion or rain-induced blockage so that airspeed, altitude, attitude-related, and temperature data remain accurate in any weather the aircraft can legally enter. The rule therefore demands reliable anti-ice or anti-rain protection across the full spectrum of icing defined in CS-25 Appendices C, P and O, as well as in heavy rain outlined in Table 1. In plain English: the sensors that feed the cockpit must always ‘see’ the air correctly, even in downpours or super-cooled clouds, so crews never have to fly with misleading or missing flight data.
ai_notes: Air France 447 (A330, 2009) – ice crystals at cruise altitude overwhelmed inadequate pitot heating, producing unreliable airspeed and starting a fatal loss-of-control; illustrates why crystal-icing in Appendix P is specifically referenced.

NASA/FAA heavy-rain tests in the 1970s showed that water slugs entering unheated pitot tubes caused sudden 30–40 kt airspeed errors; results triggered the certification rain-rate table now embedded in CS 25.1324.

Expert note: Certification teams routinely run wind-tunnel SLD (Appendix O) and ice-crystal (Appendix P) tests with heaters de-energised at worst-case electrical loads, then repeat with heaters on to demonstrate no ice impingement or rate-based blockage.

Birgenair 301 (B757, 1996) – blocked pitot tube led to fatal erroneous airspeed indications; while the blockage was insects, the accident cemented industry practice of dual heaters, drainage holes and on-ground covers to prevent any obstruction.

Expert note: Flight-crew training for the ‘Unreliable Airspeed’ QRH drill is considered a complementary mitigation; however, CS 25.1324’s intent is that such procedures are a last resort, not a primary means of safety.

section_intent: The rule ensures that the tubing, ports, and instruments that sense outside air pressure (the static system) provide pilots with accurate, reliable readings of altitude, airspeed, and vertical speed at all times. It demands ports be placed and protected so wind, ice, dirt, or water cannot distort the pressure, the plumbing be leak-free and drainable, and that the whole system be proven airtight through leak tests. It also limits how much altitude error the installation may create across the operating speed range, requires approved and properly calibrated altimeters, and mandates safe bypass or alternate sources if correction devices fail. In short, CS 25.1325 exists so crews always know their true altitude and flight path, preventing disorientation or flight-into-terrain that could result from false pressure data.
ai_notes: Aeroperú 603 (1996): Tape left on both static ports after cleaning blocked the system, feeding the crew wildly wrong altitude and airspeed until the Boeing 757 crashed into the sea. The accident spurred tighter maintenance controls and underscored the need for leak tests and port-protection requirements in CS 25.1325.

Expert note: Routine production and continuing-airworthiness leak tests that evacuate the system by 1 inHg for 1 minute directly derive from paragraph (c)(2); they catch cracked lines or loose fittings that could create dozens of feet of altitude error in cruise.

NASA/Boeing flight-test data in the 1960s showed small shifts in static-port location could change indicated altitude by over 100 ft at high Mach. Today, manufacturers flight-test multiple port positions and use flush, symmetrically-paired ports to meet the ±30 ft per 100 kt accuracy requirement of paragraph (e).

Eastern Air Lines Flight 304 (1964): Ice-covered static ports caused the DC-8’s altimeters to freeze, leading to loss of control in cloud. The event drives the rule’s demand for ice-tolerant port design and, on large jets, electrically heated static ports.

Expert note: Drain traps positioned at the lowest point of static lines are a standard design practice to satisfy paragraph (c)(1); they prevent water pooling that could freeze at altitude and block the system.

Best practice: Flight crew training emphasizes recognising a frozen or blocked static system (e.g., altimeter stuck, VSI zero) and selecting the alternate static source per paragraph (g); this procedural defense complements the hardware requirements.

Expert note: Dual independent static systems with automatic switchover valves are now common on transport aircraft, ensuring one source can be isolated if contaminated while meeting paragraph (g)(2)’s requirement to avoid simultaneously shutting off both sources.

section_intent: This rule ensures pilots are warned any time the heating system for external flight-instrument probes (e.g. pitot, static, angle-of-attack, total-air-temperature sensors) is OFF or has failed. Heated probes prevent ice accretion that would otherwise give false airspeed, altitude or attitude data, which can quickly lead to loss of control. By mandating a CAUTION-level alert that activates automatically whenever probe heat is not available, the rule guarantees the crew can take prompt corrective action (switch it on, follow abnormal check-lists, or change flight path) before unreliable indications endanger the aircraft. In short, it protects the integrity of primary flight instruments by making any loss of probe heat immediately obvious.
ai_notes: Air France 447 (A330, 2009): transient pitot icing caused unreliable airspeed; although the heaters worked, the accident highlighted how quickly probe icing can destabilise a crew, reinforcing the need for unmistakable alerts when protection is absent.

Birgenair 301 (B757, 1996): blocked pitot tube produced false high-speed indications; investigation noted that if probe-heat status had been annunciated the crew might have detected the abnormal condition earlier.

Expert note: Many short-haul jets automatically energise probe heat after engine start, but mechanics sometimes pull the circuit breaker during ground maintenance; this rule requires cockpit indication so a tripped breaker is caught before take-off.

Expert note: Certification tests now include ‘probe-heat fail’ flight-deck annunciation demonstrations—power is disabled to heaters in icing tunnels to show that the CAUTION message appears within seconds, meeting CS-25.1322 timing criteria.

Southwest 727 incident, Denver 2004: crew took off with pitot heat inadvertently off, lost airspeed data in climb; they recovered but the report recommended prominent cockpit alerts, directly feeding into CS-25 amendments.

Best practice: Airlines teach in recurrent training that any “PROBE HEAT” or “PITOT HEAT” caution in flight requires immediate icing assessment, cross-checking standby instruments, and reference to the Unreliable Airspeed QRH checklist, exactly the response path the rule intends to trigger.

section_intent: Ensure that any cockpit instrument that shows the aircraft’s magnetic heading is mounted and compensated so that flight crews always have a dependable reference for direction. The rule limits residual compass error in level flight to ≤10° and demands similar accuracy from any other heading system. By protecting the indicator from vibration and stray magnetic fields, the regulation guards against mis-leading heading information that could cause navigation errors, loss of situational awareness, or controlled flight into terrain, particularly during instrument flight or when all other cues are limited.
ai_notes: Varig Flight 254 (B737-200, 1989): Crew flew 180° off course and ran out of fuel; investigation emphasised the need for an accurate, clearly readable magnetic compass as a last-resort heading check.

Expert note: Compass deviations >15° were discovered during certification tests when wiring bundles carrying high-current loads were routed close to the flux valve; relocating the sensor restored compliance with CS 25.1327(a).

FAA AD 2000-23-10 on B737 classic models: Required inspection of compass systems after field reports of large errors when weather radar or galley power was selected—demonstrating the vibration/EMI concerns addressed by the rule.
Expert note: Airlines perform routine ‘compass swing’ procedures during maintenance to re-compensate for airframe changes, directly satisfying the ≤10° post-compensation limit of paragraph (b).

Common training practice: Pilots cross-check the standby wet compass against the heading display during initial turns after take-off to detect any flux-gate or HSI failure, illustrating operational reliance on the indicator’s mandated accuracy.

section_intent: CS 25.1329 ensures that any automatic flight-guidance feature (autopilot or autothrust) can be instantly and reliably overridden, never startle the crew with large transients, clearly tells the pilots what it is doing, stays within the aircraft’s structural and aerodynamic limits, and reverts safely if something goes wrong. In plain terms, the rule demands that automation must be a helpful assistant that the crew can always disconnect, must not secretly change modes or trim the aircraft into danger, and must give unmistakable alerts when it disengages or is overridden. It guards against confusion, mode-errors, speed excursions, excessive control forces or loads, and makes sure that any single failure or crew action leaves the aircraft in a flyable condition.
ai_notes: Air France 447 (A330, 2009): Unexpected autopilot disconnect in cruise due to iced pitot tubes led to crew confusion; highlights the need for clear, distinctive AP disconnect warnings (para j) and intuitive mode annunciations (para i).

Asiana 214 (B777, 2013): Misunderstood autothrottle status allowed speed to decay on final approach; demonstrates the intent of speed-excursion protection in para h and the importance of mode awareness.
Qantas QF72 (A330, 2008): Faulty ADIRU caused abrupt pitch-down after autopilot disengagement; shows why paras c–e limit transients and require the aircraft to remain controllable.

Expert note: Autopilot runaway-trim tests in certification verify that the pilot’s yoke-mounted red ‘quick-disconnect’ button (para a) reliably removes AP authority within milliseconds, preventing hazardous flight-path deviations (paras g & l).

Expert note: Industry practice places mode annunciations in the primary flight display’s top ‘FMA’ line, grouped by lateral/vertical/auto-thrust logic, meeting para i’s requirement for logical, consistent presentation.

Boeing 737 MAX MCAS accidents (2018-19): Although MCAS is not the autopilot, the events underscored the hazard of automated pitch commands without clear annunciation or easy override, reinforcing regulators’ emphasis on paras g, i and l.

Expert note: Certification flight tests require throttle-lever override forces < 200 N and smooth power response (para m) to ensure crews can reclaim thrust and avoid unsafe trajectories if autothrust misbehaves.
Autopilot disengage chimes differentiated from all other alerts per AC 25.1329-1: prevents nuisance masking and meets para j’s ‘timely and distinct’ warning requirement.

section_intent: The rule ensures that every required flight or navigation instrument that needs electrical or other powered input keeps working – and warns the crew when it can’t. It demands three things: (1) a built-in visual alert on each powered instrument when the incoming voltage/pressure/frequency drops below limits, so pilots instantly know data may be wrong; (2) a fully independent back-up power source so loss of one generator, bus, vacuum pump, etc., will not disable the same instrument on both pilot stations; and (3) if the instrument depends on an external data feed (e.g. air-data, heading, or attitude from remote sensors), it must also tell the crew clearly when that feed is lost and the picture is unreliable. In short, the objective is continuous, reliable display of critical flight information with unmistakable failure cues, preventing spatial disorientation or navigation errors caused by hidden power or data loss.
ai_notes: Case: Delta Air Lines L-1011 N11002 (1972) – a failed AC bus extinguished several attitude indicators without clear flags; crew became disoriented during approach. Investigation led to emphasis on integral loss-of-power annunciations and segregated power sources.

Expert note: Modern EFIS displays have internal comparators that flash "DISPLAY SOURCE" or "SPD/ALT FAIL" when bus voltage or ARINC data drop, satisfying CS 25.1331(a)(1) & (3) and training crews to cross-check quickly.

Case: United Airlines Flight 389 (1965) – dual DC generator failure on a B727 darkened multiple navigation instruments on both sides; the lack of alternate feed contributed to loss of situational awareness and influenced later dual-feed requirements.
Expert note: Transport aircraft now split critical instruments across the Left, Right, Essential and Battery buses; one bus failure cannot blank both pilots’ PFDs, directly addressing 25.1331(a)(2).

Case: ATR-72 vacuum-pump accidents (e.g., Farnair Switzerland HB-AEN, 1992) showed that loss of attitude data without a conspicuous flag can mislead crews; rules now force clear in-instrument warnings when sensor data disappear.

Expert note: Certification test plans include low-voltage ramp tests at each instrument connector to verify that the power-loss flag appears before indications become inaccurate, ensuring the alert is early and unmistakable.

section_intent: CS-25.1333 makes sure that the basic flight instruments every pilot relies on – airspeed, altitude, attitude (pitch/roll) and direction – stay alive after any single credible failure. Each pilot’s displays must be driven by their own independent sensing, processing and power chains, so a fault in one side or in an add-on device cannot wipe out both. If extra equipment is tied into those chains, it must be proven that its failure cannot disturb the required instruments unless the probability is practically impossible. The rule guarantees that, even when something breaks, at least one pilot instantly retains clear, trustworthy flight information and can keep the aeroplane under control.
ai_notes: Aeroperú Flight 603 (1996): Maintenance tape over all static ports removed the crew’s airspeed and altitude references on both sides. The loss of every independent source highlighted the need for physically separate, protected instrument feeds now mandated by CS-25.1333.

Birgenair Flight 301 (1996): A wasp nest blocked the captain’s pitot line, giving wildly high airspeed while the first officer’s side was normal. The tragedy underlined why each pilot must have truly independent air-data and the ability to cross-check sources.

Air France Flight 447 (2009): Ice crystals clogged all pitot probes, causing airspeed flags and autopilot disconnect. The crew still had valid attitude and heading, illustrating CS-25.1333(b)’s requirement that control-critical data remain available after air-data failures.

Expert note: Large jets typically use three separate Air Data & Attitude-Heading Reference Systems feeding isolated displays on different power buses; a short or software freeze in one channel leaves the others and the standby instruments fully usable.

Expert note: Certification testing injects faults—opening a static line, pulling a display power breaker, shorting a data bus—while verifying that at least one pilot keeps continuous speed, altitude, direction and attitude cues without cockpit reconfiguration, meeting 25.1333(b).

Expert note: Supplemental gear such as electronic flight bags is fed through current-limited, opto-isolated interfaces so a shorted tablet cannot blank the primary flight displays, satisfying paragraph (c).

section_intent: Ensure that all engine-related instruments and their piping give the crew reliable, real-time information on fuel, oil, and propeller condition while preventing any flammable-fluid leak or instrument failure from creating a fire or engine-out hazard. In plain terms, the rule demands that fuel and oil quantities be clearly displayed, flow meters and propeller-blade indicators work accurately, and that any tubing carrying hot or flammable fluids is protected, limited by orifices, and routed so that—even if it breaks—nothing ignites or blinds the crew. The ultimate aim is to avoid fuel starvation, engine damage, cockpit fires, and loss of control by guaranteeing trustworthy readings and inherently safe installations.
ai_notes: Varig Flight 797 (Boeing 707, 1984): Cockpit fire traced to pressurised hydraulic fluid line reinforced the need for restrictor fittings and safe routing of flammable lines mandated in 25.1337(a)(2).

Expert note: Many OEMs use calibrated ‘snubber’ orifices right at the engine-driven fuel-pressure pickup, so a broken gauge line cannot spray fuel into the flight deck—direct compliance with paragraph (a).

Air Transat Flight 236 (A330, 2001): Slow fuel leak went unnoticed until quantity indicators showed an imbalance, highlighting why paragraph (b) requires accurate, zero-referenced fuel gauges for each tank.

Gimli Glider – Air Canada 143 (1983): Mis-fueling led to fuel exhaustion; robust fuel-quantity indication allowed crews to see decreasing quantity but conversion errors caused misinterpretation, driving stricter calibration and unit-label requirements in 25.1337(b).

Expert note: Certification testing now forces a flow-meter blockage and requires a bypass path (para c) because earlier turbine installations with single-path transducers caused engine flameouts during icing contamination events.

Beech 1900D blade-angle mis-set incidents (1990s): Erroneous beta-range indications on take-off led to runway overruns; the rule’s 8° responsiveness requirement for turboprop blade-position indicators (para e) ensures pilots see unsafe blade angles early.
Expert note: Stick gauges in oil tanks are painted with contrasting colours and placarded "Read within 10 min of shutdown" to meet paragraph (d) intent for unambiguous oil-quantity confirmation.

section_intent: CS 25.1351 requires that an aeroplane’s entire electrical system—generation, distribution, control and monitoring—be robust enough to power all safety-critical equipment in every foreseeable operating condition, and tolerant of single failures or malfunctions without creating fire, smoke, or loss-of-control hazards. It obliges the applicant to size the generating capacity through a formal electrical-load analysis, provide redundant or alternate high-integrity power sources, maintain acceptable voltage/frequency quality, give the crew the means to isolate a faulty generator quickly, and protect the system from mis-wired external ground power. In short, the rule exists to guarantee that essential flight, navigation, communication, and safety systems always have reliable power—from engine start to landing—even if the normal electrical network is lost or damaged.
ai_notes: Air Transat Flight 236 (A330, 2001): complete dual-engine flameout left the aircraft on its Ram Air Turbine; the event validated the need for an independent "alternate" power source capable of sustaining flight-critical instruments and flight controls until landing.

Swissair Flight 111 (MD-11, 1998): arcing in entertainment-system wiring generated smoke and an in-flight fire, illustrating why CS-25 limits transients and mandates rapid crew isolation of faulty power sources to prevent fire propagation.

Expert note: Electrical Load Analysis documents—now mandatory in certification—itemise every bus and phase-of-flight load so designers can prove that, after one generator fails, remaining sources still cover all essential services with margin.

UPS Flight 6 (B747-400F, 2010): a cargo-hold fire damaged wiring bundles and disabled multiple generators; redundancy in separate busses kept critical displays alive long enough for an attempted return, underscoring separation and independence requirements.

Expert note: Ground-power receptacles are keyed and backed by sensors that block connection if phase sequence, polarity or voltage are wrong, a response to earlier incidents where reversed 28 V DC carts destroyed avionics on the ramp.

Expert note: Modern transport aircraft place generator control switches within easy crew reach; a single action can trip a suspect generator offline, a lesson from 1960s jet accidents where crews could not promptly disconnect shorted generators.

Delta Air Lines B767 lightning strike (N180DN, 2005): simultaneous generator drop-outs were recovered without loss of essential avionics because bus-voltage stability and automatic load-shedding kept critical instruments powered, demonstrating the value of voltage/frequency limits and transient immunity.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that every piece of electrical hardware, its wiring, and the aircraft’s batteries can work side-by-side without creating fire, smoke, toxic gas, interference, loss of essential functions, or structural damage. It demands (1) electromagnetic compatibility so one unit can’t disable another, (2) robust, protected wiring, (3) batteries that will not overheat, vent hazardous gases, leak corrosive fluids, or short-circuit, even in worst-case charging or cooling conditions, and (4) dependable bonding to carry return and fault currents. In plain terms, the objective is to keep electricity from becoming a single-point failure that could compromise flight safety, while ensuring any fault remains contained and annunciated so the crew and aircraft stay safe.
ai_notes: Swissair Flight 111 (1998): wiring arcing in the IFE system ignited insulation above the cockpit, demonstrating how one non-essential electrical system can quickly disable essential ones if EMC, segregation, and thermal protection are lacking.

JAL Boeing 787 battery fire at Boston (2013): thermal runaway in a lithium-ion battery produced smoke and heat, underscoring the need for rigorous battery temperature control, venting, and automatic disconnects set out in CS 25.1353(c).

TWA Flight 800 (1996): a short in aged wiring likely sparked fuel-air vapors in the center wing tank, illustrating why wiring health, shielding, and fault current protection are critical to prevent ignition sources.

Expert note: DO-160G Section 20 radiated & conducted susceptibility tests are routinely applied to prove that new avionics will not jam, or be jammed by, other on-board electronics as required by 25.1353(a).

Expert note: Modern harness design separates essential and non-essential feeders, routes them on opposite sides of the fuselage, and adds arc-fault breakers to ensure a failure in one bundle cannot cripple redundant flight-critical systems.
Expert note: Ni-Cd batteries are installed in ventilated, acid-resistant enclosures with temperature sensors that trip contactors when cells overheat, satisfying 25.1353(c)(3)–(6).

Expert note: Lightning certification includes bonding jumpers across doors, panels, and flight-control surfaces so strike currents return through designed paths rather than wiring looms, meeting 25.1353(e).
UPS Flight 6 (2010): cargo fire fed by lithium batteries highlighted the lethality of battery-generated toxic and explosive gases, reinforcing the rule’s limits on gas accumulation and vent routing.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that any piece of aircraft equipment that is required to have two independent electrical power sources (for certification or by operating rules) will keep working even if one source fails. The electrical "distribution system"—all the busses, cables (feeders) and circuit-breakers that route power—must automatically switch to, or allow the crew to quickly switch to, the other independent source through its own separate wiring. In plain words: no single failure in a generator or its feeder may silently leave essential instruments, flight controls, navigation or communication gear without electricity; an alternate path must be ready and isolated so the airplane can continue to fly safely.
ai_notes: Air Transat Flight 236 (A330, 2001): dual-engine flame-out killed both main generators; automatic transfer to the RAT and essential bus kept flight instruments powered, showing why an alternate source and feeder must come on line without delay.

Expert note: Compliance tests open a feeder circuit-breaker while an autopilot is engaged; regulations require the system to cross-tie to the opposite generator or battery within seconds so the autopilot never drops offline.

Qantas Flight QF72 (A330, 2008): transient AC bus dropout was contained because the flight control computers had independent feeders from the opposite side, preventing total loss of fly-by-wire functionality.

Expert note: Industry designs run VHF radios on dual-wound TRUs connected to separate left/right AC busses; if one side shorts, the other keeps the radio alive, meeting CS 25.1355 intent for continuous ATC communication.

Expert note: Essential lighting and standby attitude indicators are wired so that the crew can manually select battery power if both engine-driven generators fail, ensuring night or IMC flight can be completed safely.

section_intent: Make sure every wire and piece of equipment has the right kind of circuit-breaker or fuse so that, if something shorts, overloads or malfunctions, power is cut off quickly and automatically before it can start a fire, damage other systems, or leave the crew with no way to fix it. Faulty generators must be disconnected fast, circuit-breakers have to trip even if the crew holds the switch in, any breaker that might need to be reset in flight must be easy to reach, and breakers must not be used as on/off switches unless purposely designed for that. In short, the rule forces designers to contain electrical faults, keep essential equipment individually protected, and give the crew a safe, controlled way to deal with electrical problems aloft.
ai_notes: Swissair 111 (1998): IFE-wiring overheated; multiple CBs were not sized/located for quick isolation, leading to an uncontrollable fire—highlighted the need for rapid, automatic disconnection of faulty circuits.
Expert note: Generator Control Units on modern jets are required to open main contactors within milliseconds of detecting over-voltage, a direct compliance measure with 25.1357(b).

B757 ‘coffee-maker’ events: galley power cables chafed and tripped common CBs, temporarily knocking out non-essential busses—airframers now put galley feeders on separate protectors to satisfy 25.1357(e).

UPS Flight 6 (2010): Lithium-battery fire damaged wiring; breakers that could not be reached through smoke underscored why essential CBs must be locatable and labelled for in-flight reset per 25.1357(d).
Expert note: Maintenance practice trains crews never to hold a tripped breaker closed; designs must ensure the breaker will still open under fault per 25.1357(c).
Industry adoption of ‘switchable CBs’ (e.g., Airbus push-pull with integral switch) meets 25.1357(f) by clearly differentiating power-control functions from pure protection.
Expert note: Automatic-reset thermal protectors are allowed inside seat motors or window heaters only when upstream wiring is independently fused, aligning with 25.1357(g).

section_intent: This rule makes designers keep all electrical parts that crew, passengers, ground staff, or maintenance personnel might touch safe from two main hazards: electric shock and skin burns. Live conductors must be insulated, guarded, or otherwise arranged so that normal duties, foreseeable errors, or wet/metal tools cannot put dangerous voltage through a person. Surfaces, knobs, panels, or wiring that must be grasped, switched, or serviced must stay cool enough that a hurried hand-grab will neither injure the person nor cause them to jerk and move a vital control unintentionally.
