The ultimate goal is to prevent rotor failures from injuring occupants or disabling flight-critical systems, thereby preserving continued safe flight and landing.
ai_notes: Event: 1989 DC-10 Sioux City—fan-disk burst sent fragments through systems; although an engine, it illustrated how uncontained rotors can cripple hydraulics and led regulators to tighten containment philosophy for all high-energy rotors.
Event: 2004 Airbus A318 ground run—air-cycle machine rotor burst; shrapnel pierced fuselage skin, prompting industry focus on ACM containment testing per CS 25.1461(c).
Expert note: APU and IDG cases are routinely designed with fragmented-disk energy margins >115% rated speed, then proof-tested to demonstrate full fragment capture as required by sub-para (c).

Expert note: Certification plans include overspeed governor failure analyses and ‘loss-of-oil’ tests to show that automatic protections (per (b)(2)) reliably prevent reaching destructive speeds in service.
Event: Boeing 737-400 9M-MMR (1997)—IDG rotor burst severed hydraulic/electrical lines; aircraft landed safely but incident reinforced installation zoning (d) to avoid single-point cascades.
Expert note: Operators train maintenance crews to borescope rotors for cracks and enforce strict vibration limits, addressing (b) by reducing the likelihood of in-service damage growth.

section_intent: This rule requires that every certified operating limit—speeds, weights, centre-of-gravity bounds, altitude, temperature, system and configuration constraints—be formally set during the design/certification process and then presented to the flight crew in an unambiguous, readily accessible manner (manuals, placards, electronic displays). The goal is to guarantee that crews always know the safe envelope of the airplane and never unknowingly exceed it, thus preserving structural integrity, controllability and system performance throughout all phases of flight.
ai_notes: Air Midwest 5481 (Beech 1900D, 2003) exceeded aft-CG and weight limits; the crash highlighted that crews must have accurate, authoritative loading limits and tables derived from certification data.

Emirates 407 (A340-500, Melbourne 2009) nearly overran because an incorrect take-off weight entry produced low V-speeds; event stressed the need for clearly published weight–speed limits and for crews to cross-check them against FCOM/QRH data.

Qantas QF32 (A380, 2010 engine failure) crew relied on the Quick Reference Handbook to respect reduced flap-limit and speed restrictions after damage, illustrating why limitations must be instantly available in abnormal situations.

Expert note: Certification flight tests define VMO/MMO, VFE, VMCA and other speeds that become mandatory placards on the PFD, standby airspeed indicator and overhead panels so pilots cannot miss them.

Southwest 1248 (B737-700, Midway 2005) overran a short, snow-covered runway after landing above the computed limit weight for conditions; investigation cited ambiguous landing-distance and weight-limit information available to the crew.

Expert note: Many operators embed electronic weight-&-balance calculators in the FMS that lock out dispatch if MTOW/MLW or CG is exceeded, reflecting industry best practice for making certified limits unavoidable.

section_intent: Ensure that every published airspeed limit (e.g., VMO/MMO, flap-extended speeds, manoeuvring speed) remains protective in all conditions that can change structural loads or aerodynamic behaviour. Because the safe maximum speed can rise or fall with aircraft weight, centre-of-gravity position, altitude or compressibility effects (Mach number), the rule forces applicants to analyse every critical combination and give pilots the correct limit for each case. This prevents crews from unwittingly flying faster than the structure, flutter margin, controllability, or performance envelope will tolerate, thereby safeguarding the airframe and occupants.
ai_notes: American Airlines Flight 965 (B757, 1995): Crew descended rapidly at high weight; exceeding manoeuvring speed during turbulence caused structural loads close to design limit—illustrates why Va must be weight-dependent.

Expert note: Transport aircraft flutter analysis shows some flap settings become susceptible to flutter above specific Mach; CS 25.1503 compels separate VFE placards for high-altitude descent with flaps extended.
TWA Flight 841 (B727, 1979): Uncontrolled dive to Mach 0.96 at cruise weight led to structural damage; the event highlighted need for clear MMO values tied to altitude/Mach behaviour.

Expert note: Certification flight tests map out VMO/MMO curves that step down with altitude to keep dynamic pressure and Mach effects within design limits, then these curves are fed into the AFM and FMS speed tapes as required by CS 25.1503.

UPS industry practice: Cargo operators provide quick-reference cards showing flap and gear speed limits for multiple centre-of-gravity ranges, complying with the rule’s requirement to cover critical CG shifts due to container loading.

Expert note: Training syllabi emphasise that Va decreases as fuel burns off; pilots are taught to reference updated weight-based speed tables before turbulence penetration, directly reflecting CS 25.1503 intent.

section_intent: The rule sets a hard upper boundary on the airspeed or Mach number (VMO/MMO) that an aircraft may intentionally fly in normal service. This limit must sit below the design-dive speed (VD/MD or VDF/MDF) by a tested safety margin, guaranteeing that even with gusts, pilot error, or small system malfunctions, the aircraft will almost never reach speeds where structural failure, aeroelastic flutter, or loss-of-control could occur. By prohibiting deliberate exceedance—except under controlled flight-test or training conditions—it ensures crews always have a buffer that protects the airframe, control surfaces, and pressurisation system, and gives time to recover if an inadvertent overspeed occurs.
ai_notes: TWA Flight 841 (B727, 1979): A runaway leading-edge slat and subsequent spiral dive pushed the aircraft far beyond VMO; major structural damage but successful recovery highlighted the need for generous overspeed margins.

China Airlines Flight 006 (B747SP, 1985): Loss of control led to Mach 0.96 and 5 g loads; the airframe survived because operational limits were set well below structural capability, validating the required gap between VMO/MMO and VD/MD.

Expert note: Autopilot or trim runaway events can drive the aircraft into a dive; mandated cockpit overspeed clackers and automatic autothrottle retard lines are direct compliance measures stemming from this rule.

Expert note: Certification flutter testing (CS 25.253) often uncovers altitude/Mach combinations where flutter margins shrink; setting VMO/MMO below these points keeps crews out of unexplored, potentially catastrophic regimes.

Best practice: Airline SOPs drill pilots to simultaneously reduce thrust, deploy speedbrakes, and smoothly pitch up at the first overspeed warning, ensuring the aircraft decelerates before structural limits are threatened.

section_intent: This rule guarantees that the manoeuvring speed (VA) printed in the Airplane Flight Manual is never higher than the speed the structure was actually designed and tested for under CS-25.335(c). VA is the maximum speed at which a pilot can make one full, abrupt control movement (pitch, roll or yaw) without overstressing the airframe. By locking the operational limit to the certified structural limit, the requirement gives crews a reliable reference for turbulence penetration, training manoeuvres and emergency turns, ensuring the aircraft remains within its limit-load envelope at all approved weights and centre-of-gravity positions.
ai_notes: American Airlines Flight 587, A300-600 (2001): rapid alternate rudder inputs slightly above VA produced loads that exceeded the vertical-tail limit and led to in-flight breakup—showing the consequences of exceeding true manoeuvring capability.

BOAC Flight 911, Boeing 707 (1966): aircraft encountered extreme mountain-wave turbulence near the manoeuvring speed and broke up, underscoring the need for crews to have a conservative, structurally valid VA for turbulence penetration.

Expert note: Flight manuals commonly list a weight-dependent table for VA and placard the highest value; crews are trained to reduce VA as weight decreases so that limit-load factor (e.g., 2.5 g) is not exceeded.

Expert note: Recurrent simulator checks emphasise that full or rapid control deflections are permitted only below VA; above it pilots are taught to use smooth, incremental inputs, directly reflecting the intention of CS 25.1507.

Expert note: During certification, ‘stick-pulse’ and rudder-doublet tests are flown at VA to demonstrate that abrupt control inputs generate limit loads without permanent deformation, proving the published speed is structurally sound.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that the maximum speed allowed with flaps extended (V_FE, the number painted on the air-speed indicator) never exceeds the structural design flap speed (V_F) used when sizing and strength-testing the wing and flap system at each flap setting and power condition. In simple terms, it keeps pilots from being permitted to fly faster with flaps out than the airplane was proven to withstand, thereby preventing flap or wing damage, loss of control, and cascading structural failures.
ai_notes: United Airlines B747-400 Honolulu 1997: inadvertent 5 000 ft descent with flaps 10 resulted in 20 kt overspeed, tearing a flap track fairing and prompting FAA review of V_FE markings.

Expert note: Multiple Boeing 737 Service Bulletins (e.g. SB 57-A1057) and AD 98-20-19 cite cracked flap tracks traced to recurrent flap-overspeed events—evidence that repetitive loads above V_F cause fatigue damage.
Austrian Airlines Fokker 100 OE-LVA 2004: flap overspeed jammed the surfaces, forcing a high-speed landing and highlighting need for a clearly limited V_FE for each position.

Expert note: Certification flight-test manuals require demo of 1.1 × V_FE dives to prove structural margin; operators then placard the lower demonstrated value to give crews a buffer against transient exceedances.

Training best practice: many airlines include a ‘clean-up’ call that is only permitted after passing below V_FE on approach or above it in climb, directly reinforcing the regulatory speed limit in routine SOPs.

section_intent: The rule requires that the minimum control speed (VMC)—the lowest airspeed at which the pilot can still keep the aircraft under directional control after a critical engine fails, as determined in CS-25.149—be published as a hard operating limitation. By mandating that VMC appear in the aircraft flight manual and on cockpit instruments, the regulation ensures crews know the exact speed below which asymmetric thrust or other disturbances can overpower the available aerodynamic and control-surface authority, leading to loss of control. The ultimate goal is to prevent take-off, climb, approach, or training scenarios where the aircraft is allowed to decelerate below this critical threshold, safeguarding occupants, people on the ground, and the aircraft itself.
ai_notes: Real event – Beechcraft King Air 90 (N711TM, 2015): During take-off, the aircraft drifted below published VMC after an engine power loss; it rolled sharply and crashed, illustrating why crews must respect the certified limit.

Real event – Cessna 421 training accident (NTSB LAX84FA154): Instructor failed an engine on climb; when speed fell beneath VMC, the aircraft yawed, rolled inverted, and was destroyed, showing the peril of engine-out exercises below the marked red line.

Expert note: VMC is painted as a red radial line on the airspeed indicator and repeated in AFM limitations pages so pilots have an unmistakable visual cue not to let speed fall below it during asymmetric operations.

Real event – Lockheed Electra L-188 test flights (late 1950s): Directional-control difficulties during engine-out trials below calculated VMC led to rollovers, prompting clearer certification criteria and the current operating-limitation requirement.

Expert note: Multi-engine simulator training emphasizes maintaining VMC + 5–10 kt during single-engine go-arounds; this margin stems directly from the regulatory mandate to treat VMC as a non-negotiable limit.

Industry practice: Flight-test engineers verify VMC for each weight, center-of-gravity, and configuration, then codify the worst-case (highest) value as the published limitation, ensuring crews always operate with adequate control authority.

section_intent: This rule makes manufacturers determine and publish the highest airspeeds at which the landing gear can be safely moved (VLO) and left extended (VLE). It ensures that aerodynamic loads will not jam actuators, damage doors or gear legs, or upset the aircraft’s handling when the gear is in transit or locked down. Proving these speeds through CS-25.729 structural analyses and flight tests—and listing different figures for extension and retraction when necessary—gives pilots clear limits that prevent gear overspeed, structural failure, and potential loss of control.
ai_notes: Alaska Airlines Flight 261 (2000) – Crew lowered the MD-83’s gear above the certified limit to slow the aircraft; several gear-door panels detached, illustrating how exceeding VLE/VLO can immediately damage structures.

Expert note: High dynamic pressure can twist trunnions or stall hydraulic motors, leaving gear only partially locked; CS 25.1515 forces VLO to sit below that threshold so an inadvertent overspeed does not result in collapse on landing.

Best practice: During certification, test pilots extend and retract the gear in 5-kt increments while measuring loads and cockpit buffet; the highest speed with no door flutter or handling issues is placarded and reinforced in crew training as the ‘gear speed check’ callout.

section_intent: This rule is a ‑catch-all clause that obliges the applicant to identify and publish every speed limit that is necessary for safe operation but is not already called out elsewhere in the Code (e.g. VMO/MMO, stall speeds, flap speeds). If any system, configuration, structural feature, or operating mode could be endangered above or below a particular airspeed, that limit must be determined by test/analysis, approved, and shown in the Airplane Flight Manual and placards. In plain words: no hidden surprises—anything the crew needs to keep within a safe speed range must be formally established, documented and certified.
ai_notes: American Airlines Flight 587 (A300-600, 2001): Full-scale rudder reversals at ~250 kt exceeded structural limits, snapping the vertical tail. After the accident Airbus added explicit maximum speed/deflection limits for rudder inputs, illustrating why "other" speed restrictions must be spelled out.

United Airlines B-767 ferry flight (1991): Crew deployed the ram-air-turbine at high cruise speed and damaged its mountings. Certification now includes a 250 KIAS ‘RAT-extended’ limit, an example of a special speed cap captured under CS 25.1516.

Expert note: Landing-gear operation and extended speeds (VLO/VLE) are derived from door and leg load surveys; CS 25.1516 ensures these are placarded so crews do not cycle or fly with gear out at damaging speeds.

Expert note: Flutter testing sometimes reveals that with an HF antenna or SATCOM radome installed, aeroelastic margins decrease above a given Mach number; the resulting MMO-reduction is published as an additional speed limitation under this rule.

Windshield-wiper failures on early 707/727s above 250 kt led manufacturers to set a maximum wiper-operating speed; such component-specific limits are mandated by CS 25.1516 and are now standard in AFMs.

section_intent: This rule requires every large aeroplane to publish a "rough-air" or turbulence-penetration speed (VRA) and, where Mach limits apply, a corresponding Mach number (MRA). These targets sit well below the maximum operating speed (VMO/MMO) so that when an aircraft is jolted by up- and downdrafts its inevitable speed swings will not trigger constant overspeed warnings or, worse, exceed structural or buffet limits. By mandating a minimum 35-knot margin (unless a deeper analysis justifies otherwise), EASA ensures a predictable buffer that protects the airframe, avoids distracting cockpit alarms, and gives crews a clear, single number to fly when turbulence is encountered.
ai_notes: BOAC 911 (B-707, Mt. Fuji, 1966): Aircraft in mountain-wave turbulence broke up after briefly exceeding VMO and design gust loads, showing why a lower penetration speed reduces structural stress.

United Airlines 826 (B-747, Pacific, 1997): Crew slowed to the published turbulence speed; despite severe clear-air turbulence, the airframe stayed within limits and only cabin injuries occurred, illustrating the value of VRA guidance.

Expert note: Flight-test teams map low- and high-speed buffet margins; setting VRA ≥ 35 kt below VMO keeps the aircraft inside this safe envelope while preventing constant overspeed clacker activations.
Expert note: Standard operating procedures instruct crews to disengage Mach hold and fly VRA/MRA manually during turbulence, preventing autopilot overshoots that could breach MMO in vertical gusts.
A300-600 AD 2003-14-22: Overspeed alerts during turbulence led to revised warning logic and reaffirmed the need for an appropriate VRA that balances structural margins with nuisance-alarm avoidance.
Expert note: Training simulators regularly include gust-induced speed excursions; pilots learn that targeting VRA gives enough energy to maintain control yet keeps them clear of the redline.
Qantas A380 VH-OQA (2010 monsoon turbulence): Maintaining the published VRA prevented both overspeed warnings and buffet, validating the rule’s practical effectiveness in modern fly-by-wire jets.

section_intent: This rule makes the certified maximum weight, allowable forward and aft centre-of-gravity (CG) limits, and any special load-distribution constraints legally binding operating limits for every flight. It ensures that the aircraft is only dispatched in the same weight-and-balance conditions that were proved safe during certification testing under CS 25.23–25.27, thereby protecting controllability, structural strength, stall margins and performance. In essence, it turns engineering data into day-to-day rules so crews, dispatchers and loaders cannot unknowingly place the aeroplane in an unsafe loading condition.
ai_notes: Air Midwest Flight 5481 (Beech 1900D, 2003): Aircraft departed 600 lb overweight with CG well aft of limits, lost pitch control and crashed; underscored the lethal consequences of ignoring published weight-and-balance limits.

National Airlines Flight 102 (B747-400BCF, Bagram 2013): Armoured vehicle broke restraints, shifting CG aft of the certified envelope; rapid pitch-up and stall showed why load-distribution limits must be treated as hard operating constraints.

Fine Air Flight 101 (DC-8-61F, 1997): Pallet shift at rotation moved CG aft of limit, causing immediate stall and crash; illustrates the need for secure cargo and adherence to weight-distribution charts.

Expert note: Certification testing maps the weight–CG envelope by demonstrating take-off, landing, manoeuvre and stall performance; CS 25.1519 forces operators to respect that proven envelope in service.
Expert note: Airline load/trim sheets require dual sign-off and electronic weight-and-balance systems lock out dispatch if entries exceed the CS-25 envelope, directly implementing this rule.
Expert note: Crew training on fuel-transfer sequencing (e.g., centre-tank first on many wide-bodies) prevents in-flight CG excursions, reflecting the continuous-compliance intent of CS 25.1519.

section_intent: This rule compels the applicant to write into the Aircraft Flight Manual every power-plant "red-line"—thrust, torque, rotational speed, turbine-gas temperature, approved fuel, time-at-rating, icing ground-run-up intervals, and hot-day limits—and to make sure those numbers never exceed what the engine or propeller was separately proven to withstand, nor the values used when the airplane met its climb, cooling, structural-load and performance requirements. In plain words, it puts clear, legal stop-marks on the cockpit gauges so pilots, dispatchers and maintenance staff cannot inadvertently push the engines beyond safe temperature or speed, cannot use an unapproved fuel, and cannot operate in ambient conditions the installation was not tested for. By locking these limits into the certified documentation, CS 25.1521 prevents over-stress, overheating, icing-related stalls and other power losses that could leave the aircraft without the performance or integrity needed for safe flight.
ai_notes: British Airways Flight 38 (2008, B777): Fuel icing blocked flow near Heathrow, showing how marginal fuel properties and cold-soak conditions can rob thrust; the industry responded with tighter fuel-specification and temperature limits now mandated under 25.1521(c)(2)-(3).

Delta MD-88 N979DL rejected take-off Pensacola 2006: EGT exceeded red-line and an engine fire ensued; event illustrates why time-and-temperature limits for take-off thrust must be respected and clearly published to crews.

Expert note: In freezing fog, fan ice can build rapidly; the CS 25.1521 requirement for a certified maximum idle-to-run-up interval ensures operators perform periodic run-ups before ice can shed and cause compressor stalls.

Expert note: AFMs and EICAS/ECAM displays use green, amber and red bands derived directly from 25.1521 limits; recurrent simulator syllabi train pilots to abort a take-off or reduce thrust the moment any parameter enters the red band.

Qantas Flight QF32 (2010, A380): After an uncontained Trent 900 failure, investigators confirmed the aircraft could not be dispatched with thrust ratings higher than the engine’s type certificate allowed, reinforcing 25.1521(a)’s alignment of aircraft and engine limits.

Expert note: Installations with water-injection or other augmentation get separate certified ratings; 25.1521 forces these augmented limits to be listed so crews cannot inadvertently select a setting that over-temps the core during unaugmented operation.

section_intent: This rule forces the applicant to prove, with data and human-factors analysis, how many qualified flight crew members are absolutely needed to fly the aircraft safely in every phase of the intended operation. It ensures that no single pilot or undersized crew is asked to manage a workload, reach controls, or perform procedures that exceed normal human limits, especially during abnormal or emergency situations and for the kinds of routes, weather and operating rules the aircraft will face. The regulation therefore links cockpit design, automation, procedures and operational approval so that the certified “minimum flight crew” is always capable of maintaining safe control, navigation and systems management throughout the flight.
ai_notes: Expert note: In certifying early ETOPS twins like the Boeing 767, simulator workload studies under Appendix D showed two pilots could handle engine-out, diversion and systems failures without a flight engineer, validating a two-pilot minimum.

United Air Lines Flight 232 (Sioux City, 1989) – despite catastrophic hydraulics loss, the presence of a third-rated flight crewmember on the jump-seat aided workload sharing and cockpit resource management, highlighting how crew size can materially affect survivability in extreme events.

Expert note: Manufacturers now run "high-workload worst-case" simulator sessions (e.g., engine fire at V1 followed by complex ATC diversion) to demonstrate that required checklists, radio calls and flight path control remain manageable with the proposed crew size.

FedEx Express Flight 1478 (Tallahassee, 2002) – fatigue and task saturation on final approach contributed to CFIT; the investigation cited improper crew coordination and workload distribution, reinforcing the rule’s focus on individual workload limits.

Industry practice: SOPs for cross-verification of critical actions (gear selection, FMC data entry) assume at least two qualified pilots; the regulation ensures that cockpit layouts and procedures keep essential controls within reach of the intended operator.

Expert note: EASA flight-deck human-factors guidelines require eye-tracking and reach envelopes to confirm that one pilot can operate all emergency switches if the other pilot is incapacitated, directly satisfying CS 25.1523(b).

section_intent: This rule makes sure every transport aeroplane clearly spells out in its Flight Manual what kinds of flight it may undertake—day/night, VFR/IFR, flight in icing, CAT II/III autoland, ETOPS, RVSM, etc. Those permissions must be founded only on (a) the certification category the aircraft was approved to, and (b) the specific equipment that is actually installed and approved on that airframe. By locking the permitted operations to proven capabilities, the rule stops operators from dispatching an aircraft into weather or mission profiles for which it lacks the necessary performance, redundancy or safety systems, thereby avoiding accidents that stem from using an aeroplane outside its certified envelope.
ai_notes: American Eagle Flight 4184 (1994): ATR-72 lost control in super-cooled drizzle; investigation noted the aircraft’s icing certification did not cover that environment, reinforcing that clear, equipment-based ‘icing-approved’ limitations are essential.

Expert note: A newly delivered A320 without autoland or a heads-up display has its AFM marked “CAT III operations — PROHIBITED” until the certified equipment is installed and the limitation amended, exactly as CS-25.1525 intends.

Boeing 777 initial ETOPS approval (1995): regulators allowed over-water routes >180 min only after extra generators, cargo-fire duration and system redundancy were fitted, demonstrating how installed equipment expands the allowable kind of operation.

Expert note: Airworthiness inspectors cross-check the operator’s Minimum Equipment List with the ‘Kinds of Operation’ table; if the weather radar is MEL-deferred, dispatch into known convective IMC is barred in line with CS-25.1525.

JFK Jr. Piper PA-32 crash (1999): although a Part 23 aircraft, the VFR-only operation flown at night over water highlights the broader safety lesson—pilots must know and respect the aircraft’s certified operating kinds, a discipline codified for transport aircraft in CS-25.1525.

section_intent: This rule requires the aircraft manufacturer to define the highest and lowest outside-air temperatures and the maximum altitude at which the aeroplane can safely operate. Those limits must reflect every factor that can be degraded by temperature or altitude—lift and climb performance, structural strength, engine thrust, fuel properties, pressurisation, avionics cooling, etc.—so that crews and operators never fly the aircraft beyond the envelope for which its airworthiness has been proven. In plain terms: tell pilots exactly how hot, how cold, and how high the aircraft can go before safety margins disappear.
ai_notes: Real event – British Airways Flight 38 (B777, 2008): Ice crystals formed in fuel after a long cruise at –65 °C and high altitude, starving both engines on approach; the accident led to revised cold-soak and temperature-altitude limits in aircraft manuals.

Real event – Delta B727 aborted take-off Denver, 2003: Performance calculations failed to account for 35 °C and 5 000 ft field elevation; slow acceleration and brake overheat underscored need for certified hot-and-high limits.

Expert note: Hot-and-high airports such as La Paz, Quito, and Addis Ababa routinely restrict take-off weight; CS 25.1527 forces manufacturers to publish the ceiling where climb gradient, engine output, and pressurisation remain compliant.

Expert note: At temperatures below –54 °C, hydraulic fluid viscosity rises and battery capacity drops; design teams either qualify systems for those extremes or set "minimum temperature" operating limits per this rule.

Real event – Air Transat A330 Flight 236 (2001): Fuel leak went unnoticed during cruise near the certified service ceiling; post-event analysis highlighted how thin margins at maximum altitude can leave no recovery room, reinforcing the need for clearly stated altitude limits.

Expert note: Certification flight testing includes cold-soak overnight parking, hot-day climb-out, and maximum-altitude stalls to demonstrate that handling qualities, structural loads, and engine flame-out margins stay within acceptable levels across the published envelope.

section_intent: This rule makes the aircraft designer produce comprehensive Instructions for Continued Airworthiness (ICA) – the master maintenance manuals, inspection schedules, life-limit lists and repair data defined in Appendix H – before the aeroplane can be certified. The ICA give operators and mechanics the exact tasks, intervals and standards needed to keep the aircraft in the same safe condition in which it was approved, covering structures, systems, wiring, engines and appliances. By locking these instructions into the type-certificate, CS 25.1529 ensures that ageing, corrosion, fatigue or improper maintenance cannot silently erode safety; everyone who flies or fixes the aircraft has authoritative, up-to-date guidance that preserves its original airworthiness for decades.
ai_notes: Aloha Airlines Flight 243 (1988) – Multi-site fuselage fatigue went undetected because early 737 manuals lacked detailed skin-lap inspection criteria; the explosive decompression prompted mandatory structural inspection programs to be built into ICA.

Southwest Airlines Flight 2294 (2009) – A similar fuselage rupture led Boeing to issue new, lower crack-inspection thresholds, illustrating how ICA must be living documents that are revised when service experience reveals hidden risks.

Expert note: The MSG-3 maintenance steering process is applied during certification to analyse failure modes and derive preventive tasks; embedding these MSG-3 tasks in the ICA standardises data-driven upkeep across all operators.

Expert note: Corrosion Prevention and Control Programs in the ICA mandate cleaning, inspection and treatment intervals that combat salt-water and humidity corrosion, a common silent threat to structural integrity.

TWA Flight 800 (1996) – The fuel-tank explosion drove adoption of Enhanced Zonal Analysis Procedure, now included in ICA to ensure periodic inspection of wiring, bonding and fuel-system components vulnerable to arc-induced ignition.

Expert note: Life-limited engine part tables in ICA require retirement of disks, shafts and blades before their certified fatigue life, preventing uncontained failures like the CF6 fan-disk break-up on United 232.

Expert note: Aircraft approved for ETOPS carry supplementary ICA (e.g., APU start-capability tests and rigorous oil-leak checks) that maintain engine and system reliability during long diversion times over remote areas.

section_intent: Ensure every large transport aeroplane has clearly published maximum positive G-loads ("load factors") that a pilot may impose in manoeuvre, and that these operational limits never exceed the structural design limits determined in CS-25.333(b). By tying the flight-manual limitation directly to the certified manoeuvring envelope, the rule prevents crews from unknowingly commanding forces that could deform or break the airframe, protecting occupants, maintaining structural integrity throughout the aircraft’s life, and giving operators a hard number for training, monitoring, and maintenance purposes.
ai_notes: China Airlines Flight 006 (B-747SP, 1985): Recovery from an upset generated ~5.5 g, buckling skin and bending spars—illustrating why crews must know and respect certified G limits.

American Airlines Flight 587 (A300-600, 2001): Repeated rudder reversals produced side and vertical loads above design limits, snapping the fin; highlights need for published, trained manoeuvre limits.
Expert note: Turbulence encounter exceedance reports in FOQA/FDM data routinely show momentary 2.6–3.2 g spikes; clear AFM load-factor limits allow operators to flag exceedances for inspection.
Expert note: Structural fatigue analysis assumes pilots stay within +2.5 g (flaps up) and +2.0 g (flaps down); exceeding these hastens crack growth and reduces airframe life.
Boeing Flight Crew Training Manual practice: Emphasise ‘pitch gently, stay within AFM load-factor table’ during TCAS RA or wind-shear escape to avoid over-stress in high-energy pull-ups.
Expert note: Compliance showing: designers place a red line on cockpit g-meter and list corresponding speeds (VA, VB) in the AFM so pilots connect airspeed and allowable g.
C-checks routinely include ‘over-g inspection’ task cards triggered only when crew/FDMS reports above-limit load; the rule provides the numeric trigger value.

section_intent: This rule makes sure every transport aeroplane carries clear, legally-binding limits that match the conditions under which the aircraft was actually flight-tested. It freezes the maximum weights for take-off and landing, the minimum runway lengths, and the environmental extremes (altitude, temperature, wind, runway slope and surface condition) that were proven during certification. It also forbids crews of partially-iced-certified aircraft from taking off, landing or remaining in super-cooled large-droplet (Appendix O) icing unless the type has been shown safe there. In plain words: the aeroplane may only be dispatched into, and kept in, situations where its performance and handling have been demonstrated to meet CS-25 safety margins; if pilots stray outside those proven envelopes—especially with heavy weights, short or wet runways, high/hot fields, or hazardous ice—the rule demands they do not go, or get out quickly.
ai_notes: Emirates Flight 407, Melbourne 2009 – Incorrect take-off weight entry left an A340 needing almost the entire runway; highlights why certified maximum take-off weight and distance data must be honoured.
American Eagle 4184, Roselawn 1994 – ATR-72 crashed after super-cooled large-droplet icing; drove creation of Appendix O and the prohibition on intentional flight into un-certified icing conditions.
Expert note: AFM performance tables produced under CS 25.1533 give separate dry and wet-grooved runway distances; dispatchers must select the right line to preserve accelerate-stop margins.
Kalitta Air B747-200F Brussels 2008 – Wet runway, heavy weight and marginal field length led to a rejected-take-off overrun, underlining the need for the wet-runway data required by 25.1533(a)(3).

Expert note: Certification flight-test campaigns purposely test high-altitude/high-temperature airports (e.g. La Paz, Dubai summer) to lock down the altitude-temperature extremes that become AFM limitations per 25.1533(b).

Air Florida Flight 90, Washington 1982 – Take-off with wing and sensor icing reduced climb capability; shows why aircraft not cleared for such icing must refrain from take-off or exit those conditions quickly.
Expert note: Pilot recurrent training includes "icing escape manoeuvre" drills to comply with 25.1533(c)(2), ensuring crews promptly leave un-approved Appendix O icing when inadvertently encountered.

section_intent: The rule ensures that any aeroplane intended to fly Extended-range Twin-engine Operations (ETOPS) is demonstrably capable of safely completing the longest planned diversion after a system or engine failure. It obliges designers to show that the whole aircraft (not just the engines) meets all CS-25 airworthiness standards for the increased exposure time, that early-service engines satisfy extra reliability proofs (CS-E 1040), and that cockpit workload, passenger needs, and system capabilities (fire suppression, oxygen, electrical power, etc.) remain adequate throughout the worst-case diversion. In short, it guarantees that an ETOPS-configured twin can protect occupants and manage failures as effectively as a conventional multi-engine aircraft on shorter routes.
ai_notes: Air Transat A330-200 Flight 236 (2001): Fuel leak led to 75-minute engine-out glide to the Azores; highlighted need for proven fuel-system isolation, crew workload evaluation, and passenger physiological considerations during long diversions.

United Airlines B777-200 Flight 1175 (2018): Uncontained fan-blade failure over the Pacific demonstrated importance of CS-E 1040 extreme-cycle engine tests and ETOPS maintenance controls to retain one-engine performance for extended over-water flight.

Expert note: Redundant electrical generators and automatic load-shedding architecture are validated against the maximum diversion time to ensure essential avionics, flight controls, and cabin pressurisation remain powered after a single or dual system failure.

Expert note: Cargo fire-suppression bottle sizing and discharge logic are lengthened and tested so agent concentration is maintained for the full diversion duration, a direct design outcome of CS-25.1535(c) and (d).
Boeing ‘Early ETOPS’ 767 programme (1985): Required additional 1 000 ETOPS demonstration hours and enhanced engine monitoring, setting the template now codified in CS-25.1535(b).
Expert note: Manufacturers run simulated 180–330 min diversion flights in an engineering simulator to verify crew workload, QRH procedures, and passenger oxygen endurance align with paragraph (c).
Delta/Northwest ETOPS maintenance programme: Uses strict oil-consumption trend analysis and pre-departure service checks to uphold the engine reliability metrics demanded for ETOPS design approval.

section_intent: This rule makes sure every aeroplane carries clear, durable and prominently placed markings, placards and instrument limits that tell pilots, cabin crew, ground staff and maintenance personnel exactly how to operate the aircraft safely. If a design has any unusual feature, extra notices must be added. The markings have to stay readable and cannot be allowed to fade, peel, or be covered up, so that critical information—speeds, control positions, fuel type, door-latch status, emergency exits, etc.—is always instantly available and unambiguous, preventing human-factor errors.
ai_notes: Turkish Airlines Flight 981 (1974): Improperly latched DC-10 cargo door, partly attributed to confusing handle markings; crash led to larger, red ‘door not latched’ placards and illustrates why conspicuous, permanent labels are vital.

Helios Airways Flight 522 (2005): Crew left pressurisation switch in manual after maintenance; later crews overlooked its position despite a small caption—demonstrating the need for clear, eye-level markings on atypical controls.

Expert note: Several mis-fuelling events have occurred when faded or missing ‘JET A ONLY’ or ‘AVGAS ONLY’ decals let ground staff load the wrong fuel; industry now uses engraved, colour-coded placards near fillers to comply with 25.1541.

Expert note: Cockpit limit arcs are now silk-screened or laser-etched on instrument faces instead of adhesive tapes that can peel, ensuring Vmo, N1 and temperature redlines remain visible throughout the aircraft life.

Expert note: Certification flight-test teams verify that emergency exit operating instructions can be read in both normal and cabin-smoke conditions, meeting the rule’s ‘conspicuous’ requirement and addressing evacuation-delay incidents.

Expert note: Operator SOPs require periodic cabin walk-arounds to check that seat-belt, life-vest and electronic-device placards have not been obscured by interior refurbishment, directly maintaining ongoing compliance with CS 25.1541.

section_intent: The rule ensures that every coloured arc, numerical limit or pointer reference painted on cockpit instruments remains exactly where the designer put it and can always be read easily by the crew. If the glass cover twists or the paint fades, the crew might think a parameter is inside its safe range when it is actually outside, or fail to see a warning band at all. Therefore the design must physically prevent slippage of the glass and guarantee that markings, in all lighting conditions and seating positions, are unmistakably visible, so flight crews can keep the aircraft within certified limits and react to hazards in time.
ai_notes: Air Wisconsin B-737-200 (1989) ‑ EGT indicator glass rotated during maintenance; crew believed temperatures were normal, leading to engine over-temp and in-flight shutdown—prompted service bulletins stressing anti-rotation devices.
Expert note: After bezel screws are loosened for cleaning, vibration often causes the round glass to creep; CS 25.1543 demands a positive lock or indexing pin to stop this known failure mode.

DC-9-31 Boston overrun (1979) – night glare on faded red-line airspeed marks meant Vref was mis-read; investigation cited poor visibility of markings as a contributory factor and recommended higher-contrast dials.

Expert note: Certification test plans now include cockpit photo-metric surveys from both pilot seats at day, dusk and night to prove every colour band and numeral meets minimum luminance/contrast thresholds.

Best practice: Many operators list "markings legible/undamaged" in daily flight deck pre-flight checks and require shop inspections to verify alignment after any instrument removal, directly reflecting CS 25.1543's intent.

section_intent: The rule ensures that every airspeed limit that safeguards the aircraft’s structure, systems and controllability is displayed in a way the crew can instantly see, recognise and interpret in any cockpit condition. It demands clear, unambiguous presentation of speeds such as VMO/MMO (maximum operating), VA (design manoeuvring), VFE (flap-limit), VLE/VLO (gear-limit) and others listed in CS 25.1583(a), using colour coding, red lines, tapes or placards that cannot be confused or overlooked. By making these limits unmistakable, the requirement helps prevent inadvertent overspeed, component damage or loss of control, especially during high-workload or abnormal situations.
ai_notes: China Airlines Flight 006 (1985): A 747 entered a steep dive and oversped well beyond VMO, suffering major structural damage; investigators cited the need for conspicuous overspeed cues to prompt earlier recovery.

American Airlines Flight 587 (2001): The A300’s fin failed after aggressive rudder inputs above VA, showing how unclear awareness of manoeuvring speed can let crews impose loads the airframe cannot sustain.

Expert note: Glass-cockpit speed tapes that use colour-coded arcs and a moving red/white ‘barber-pole’ for VMO/MMO give pilots instant overspeed awareness and are a common means of compliance with CS 25.1545.
Expert note: Placarding flap and landing-gear limit speeds next to the respective levers is an industry standard that prevents inadvertent extension at damaging airspeeds.
Expert note: Simulator training now includes ‘red-line awareness’ exercises where pilots must react to approaching VMO or VFE, reinforcing the clear-display intent of the rule.

section_intent: Ensure flight crews can reliably convert the magnetic compass reading into a true magnetic heading despite aircraft-specific interference. The rule demands that a clearly visible placard next to the magnetic direction indicator lists the deviation (calibration) values found in level flight with engines running, and specifies whether radios were on or off when those values were taken, because electrical and ferrous sources can change the local magnetic field. By limiting the interval to 45° or less, the placard allows crews to interpolate small errors accurately, preventing navigation mistakes when other heading references fail.
ai_notes: Expert note: Compass-swing tests on early jet transports showed generator currents could shift indications by >15°, prompting regulators to require an onboard ‘compass deviation card’ so crews knew the correction to apply if inertial or radio navigation was lost.

BOAC Comet development flights (1953) recorded VHF transmitter activation causing a 25° compass swing; the event drove the practice of noting ‘RADIOS ON/OFF’ status on deviation placards now embedded in CS-25.1547.

Eastern Air Lines DC-8 polar routes (1960s) experienced large heading errors after in-flight electrical failures; post-incident analysis highlighted the need for an easily accessible deviation table when only the standby compass remained.
Expert note: STC modifications that add wing-tip antennas or cabin IFE wiring must include a new compass swing and updated placard, a standard item on EASA Form 52 compliance checklists.

Best practice: Airline training programmes require crews to check the compass deviation card during the ‘Alt Nav’ drill and use 45° interpolation to correct magnetic headings when IRS or AHRS data are unavailable.

section_intent: The rule ensures that every engine and propeller parameter gauge shows clear, colour-coded limits so flight crews can instantly recognise when a value is normal (green), time-limited or cautionary (yellow), or unsafe (red). By standardising these markings, CS-25 1549 aims to prevent inadvertent exceedance of temperature, pressure or speed limits that can rapidly damage engines, create vibration-induced structural failures, or lead to in-flight shutdowns. In short, it turns complex engineering limits into an intuitive cockpit ‘red-light/green-light’ system, giving pilots real-time cues to protect the powerplant and, by extension, the aircraft and its occupants.
ai_notes: Braniff Flight 542, Lockheed L-188 Electra (1959): Wing separation traced to propeller whirl flutter; subsequent directives introduced red-arc "avoid" RPM bands now required to be plainly marked under CS-25 1549.

Expert note: CFM56-7B engines have a red-line Exhaust Gas Temperature (EGT) around 950 °C; crews are trained that any pointer beyond the red line triggers mandatory maintenance for potential hot-section damage.

Expert note: Modern EICAS/ECAM displays replicate the green-yellow-red scheme electronically, auto-highlighting values that drift toward caution or exceedance, reducing pilot workload and supporting quick corrective action.

Expert note: Transport aircraft tachometers often show a yellow band up to the 5-minute take-off N1 limit; if the autothrottle fails to reduce power after take-off, the lingering yellow reminder prompts the crew to manually bring thrust back into the green.

Expert note: Certification tests require simulated night and glare conditions to verify that the coloured arcs or lines remain visible and unambiguous, ensuring crews can rely on them even in degraded visual environments.

section_intent: The rule ensures that every oil-quantity indicator on a large aeroplane is clearly marked so flight crews and ground personnel can tell, at a glance and with reliable accuracy, how much lubricating oil remains in each engine or system. Adequate oil is essential for cooling, sealing and lubricating moving parts; if it runs low, rapid engine damage, fire or total power loss can follow. By obliging manufacturers to provide an unmistakable, correctly calibrated display—whether a dipstick, sight-glass or digital gauge—CS 25.1551 aims to eliminate guesswork, prevent servicing errors, and give crews timely information to decide whether to continue, reduce power or divert, thereby safeguarding engine integrity and overall flight safety.
ai_notes: Eastern Air Lines Flight 855 (1983): Three-engine shutdown over the Atlantic traced to maintenance-induced oil loss; the accurately marked cockpit gauges showing zero oil alerted the crew and underlined the need for clear quantity indication.

Expert note: Post-maintenance lapses have left engines under-serviced; dipsticks with ambiguous or worn markings allowed dispatch with insufficient oil, leading regulators to stress permanent, legible graduations.

Embraer ERJ-145 N842HK (2012): In-flight shutdown after oil left out during servicing; investigation cited misinterpretation of an uncalibrated electronic display and recommended improved scale markings.
Expert note: Chronic overfilling on some fleets caused seal failures; colour-banded gauges (‘green normal, amber low, red refill’) now help technicians hit the correct target without excess margin.

Industry best practice: Certification ground tests run engines to minimum permissible oil while crews monitor; applicants must prove the indicator’s scale lets pilots detect a low-oil condition before damage occurs.

Expert note: Modern ECAM/EICAS pages replicate dipstick graduations digitally, incorporating litres/quarts read-outs and low-level cautions to meet the “readily and accurately” requirement of CS 25.1551.

section_intent: Ensure flight crews do not mistake residual, non-usable fuel shown on the gauge for usable fuel. By mandating a prominent red arc from zero to the lowest reading attainable in level flight whenever unusable fuel exceeds 3.8 L or 5 %, the rule warns pilots that fuel indicated in this arc cannot reach the engines. This visual cue prevents fuel-starvation events, supports accurate fuel management decisions, and aligns cockpit indications with the actual, certifiable usable fuel supply.
ai_notes: Beech Baron N50FD (1989, USA): Crew believed 25 L remained, but all was below pickup level; aircraft crashed short of runway. Investigators cited lack of clear unusable-fuel marking.
Expert note: Float-type and capacitance probes can read lower than the suction line, leaving litres of trapped fuel; the red arc alerts crews to this design reality.
Cessna 172 N5870G (2015, California): Gauge still above zero yet engine quit on final; post-crash revealed only unusable fuel remained—red-arc requirement would have warned low-time pilot.
Expert note: Many AFMs instruct switching tanks or commencing diversion when pointer first enters the red arc, embedding the marking into standard operating procedures and training syllabi.

FAA/NTSB studies (1970s) showed a spike in general-aviation fuel-starvation accidents where pilots relied on gauges that read beyond calibrated zero, directly prompting stricter marking rules now mirrored in CS-25.1553.

section_intent: This rule makes sure every cockpit control that is not a primary flight stick or yoke is clearly labelled and colour-coded so a pilot immediately knows what it does and which way to move it, even when distracted or under stress. It standardises wording, symbols and colours (e.g. red for emergency shut-offs) and requires fuel selectors, cross-feed valves and gear position indicators to show exactly which tank, engine or gear leg is affected. The goal is to stop wrong-control or wrong-sequence errors—such as shutting down the wrong engine, taking off with locks engaged, or mismanaging fuel—by turning the cockpit into an intuitive, self-explanatory workspace that does not rely solely on pilot memory.
ai_notes: Case: Embraer 190 LV-CEU (2010) – crew inadvertently shut down the healthy engine after a surge; investigators cited identical knobs and unclear fuel shut-off markings, underscoring the need for unambiguous selector labelling.

Case: Helios Airways Flight 522 (B737-300, 2005) – pressurisation rotary switch left in MANUAL due to small, poorly marked control; accident highlighted importance of plain-language function markings for non-obvious systems.

Expert note: Standard colour coding adopted across manufacturers—red for fire handles and fuel-jettison, blue for propeller/pressurisation, yellow for fuel—directly implements CS 25.1555(d)(1) to speed recognition in emergencies.
Expert note: Pre-flight visual checks rely on placards demanded by CS 25.677/699; clear "GUST LOCK ON" tags have prevented numerous rejected take-offs caused by crews forgetting to disengage locks.

Case: LOT Polish Airlines B767 EP-LPC (Warsaw, 2011) – after hydraulic failure, pilots confirmed gear position using clearly marked green/amber wheel indicators required by CS 25.1555(d)(2), enabling a safe gear-up landing plan.

Expert note: Certification test pilots perform "blindfold cockpit familiarisation" during compliance demonstrations; the ability to identify and operate every non-primary control purely by feel and marking is a pass/fail item tied to this rule.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that everyone who loads, fuels, services, or sits in the cabin can instantly see simple, unambiguous labels that prevent three critical human-error threats: (1) putting too much weight in one place, (2) putting the wrong fluid or too much pressure into a system, and (3) blocking or mis-using an emergency escape route. Placards inside baggage, cargo, and ballast areas state allowable weights to keep structural loads and centre-of-gravity within limits. Markings around fuel, oil, and other fluid fillers spell out the correct fluid type and the maximum fuelling/defuelling pressures so ground crews cannot misfuel or over-pressurise tanks. Clear exit and door labels ensure passengers and crew can find and use emergency exits quickly, and that cabin doors which could obstruct evacuation are latched open for take-off and landing. In short, CS-25.1557 turns critical operating limitations into visible, permanent reminders that cut the risk of dangerous, easily-made human mistakes.
ai_notes: Air Midwest Flight 5481 (2003, Beech 1900D): Investigation found the aft baggage bay was loaded beyond its placarded limit, shifting the centre of gravity aft and causing loss of control on take-off. Weight-limit placards demanded by 25.1557 help loaders avoid this error.

Expert note: Multiple piston-engine aircraft have been destroyed after being refuelled with Jet-A because filler caps lacked clear markings; CS-25 now mandates the word "FUEL" plus the correct grade so misfuelling is far less likely.

Gimli Glider – Air Canada 143 (1983): Metric–imperial confusion during refuelling highlighted the need for clear, on-site information; placards listing permissible fuel designations and pressures act as a last-chance check.

Expert note: Over-pressure fuelling events on wide-body jets have ruptured tank vents and sprayed fuel, creating fire hazards. Marking maximum fuelling and defuelling pressures at the filler point is intended to stop such incidents.

Manchester Airport B737-236 fire (1985): Evacuation was slowed when a galley service door was not latched open, partially blocking an aisle. The required placard reminding crews to latch doors open during take-off and landing addresses this risk.

Common airline practice: Every overhead bin and under-seat stowage area carries a placard such as "Max 9 kg/20 lb" so cabin baggage cannot overload structures or upset balance, a direct application of 25.1557(a).

section_intent: The rule makes sure that every piece of emergency or survival equipment carried on a large aeroplane is unmistakably labelled, its storage point clearly identified, and its method of use obvious. In a crisis—fire, ditching, evacuation—seconds count; flight and cabin crew must be able to spot, reach and operate items such as fire-extinguishers, liferafts, life-lines or survival radios without hesitation, even in smoke, darkness, or an unfamiliar cabin layout. Clear markings and placards also guide other rescuers or maintenance staff and prevent the wrong equipment being removed or misplaced. Overall, the requirement minimises delay, prevents misuse, and increases the likelihood that life-saving equipment functions as intended, thereby protecting passengers and crew.
ai_notes: US Airways Flight 1549 (Hudson River, 2009): Cabin crew quickly located rafts and the slide–rafts deployed correctly because the stowage bins and pull handles were boldly placarded, aiding an orderly water evacuation.

Swissair Flight 111 (1998): Dense cockpit smoke forced pilots to rely on tactile memory; clearly marked overhead fire-handle positions were essential to attempt fire suppression, underscoring the need for obvious emergency-control markings.

Expert note: Certification testing often fills the cabin with artificial smoke; evaluators verify that extinguishers, crash axes and medical kits can still be found within 10 seconds solely by placard visibility and touch-readability.

Ethiopian Airlines Flight 961 (1996 ditching): Many passengers could not locate rafts or life-vests; post-accident analysis led operators to upgrade signage and pictograms in overhead bins and seat rows.

Air France industry practice: Bright-yellow ‘LIFERAFT – PULL’ decals with arrow graphics are applied to all ceiling raft panels; maintenance manuals forbid repainting that could obscure these markings.

Expert note: Recurrent cabin-crew training includes blindfold drills to reach fire bottles using only placard shapes and raised lettering, mirroring CS-25.1561’s intent for intuitive access when visibility is lost.

Qantas B747 main-deck fire (Hong Kong, 1990): Prompt crew response was credited to lockers being labelled by both text and internationally recognised fire symbols, highlighting multilingual usability of placards.

FAA/EASA compliance trend: Photoluminescent labels for emergency equipment are now standard so that markings remain legible after power loss, directly answering the ‘conspicuous’ requirement in paragraph (c).

section_intent: To keep pilots constantly aware of the maximum airspeeds (VFE) at which each wing-flap position may be selected, by placing a clearly readable placard in front of every pilot. This reduces the risk of pilots extending flaps at excessive speeds, which can overstress or damage the flap system, degrade controllability, and ultimately compromise the structural integrity and safety of the aircraft during take-off, approach, and landing.
ai_notes: Southwest Airlines B737-300 (N632SW, 2011): Crew exceeded flap-15 limit speed, causing flap track damage and costly post-flight repairs—illustrates why clear VFE reminders are vital during high workload descents.

Expert note: Fleet trend-monitoring shows flap-overspeed write-ups are among the top structural findings on large transport jets; ICAO ASR data attribute many cases to crews not having limit speeds immediately in view.

China Eastern Flight 583 (MD-11, 1993): Uncommanded slat deployment above limit speed led to severe oscillations and injuries, underscoring the catastrophic loads that can arise when high-lift devices deploy too fast.

Expert note: Certification flight-test reports document that just a 15-kt overspeed at flap deployment can raise hinge-moment loads to near ultimate design limits; placards serve as a last-chance cue when digital displays lag or fail.

Airline SOP best practice: Many operators require verbal callouts of "Flap speed verified" while pointing at the placard before moving the lever, embedding the CS-25.1563 intent into crew CRM and checklist discipline.

section_intent: CS 25.1581 makes sure every transport-category airplane is delivered with an officially approved Aeroplane Flight Manual (AFM) that contains all operating limitations, procedures, and performance data needed for safe, legal, and environmentally compliant flight. It obliges the manufacturer to (1) supply the mandatory sections defined in later paragraphs, (2) add any extra instructions peculiar to the design or handling qualities, (3) include any noise–rule restrictions, and (4) clearly separate EASA-approved content from company or advisory material so that crews and regulators can immediately recognise what is authoritative. A table of contents is required when the manual is large, so vital information can be found quickly in normal or emergency situations.
ai_notes: Expert note: The AFM "white pages" are EASA-approved and revision-controlled; airline supplements and quick-reference handbooks are printed on coloured paper to comply with the segregation requirement in 25.1581(b).

United 232 (Sioux City, 1989) – Loss of all hydraulics prompted the manufacturer to add a ‘total hydraulic failure’ checklist to the AFM; the rule ensures such unique design hazards are formally captured and approved.

American 587 (A300, 2001) – Excessive rudder inputs led to structural failure; an immediate AFM revision introduced new pedal-deflection limits, illustrating rapid, approved updates mandated by 25.1581(a)(2).
Expert note: Compliance audits check that every delivered aircraft has the latest AFM revision stamped ‘EASA APPROVED’; missing or mixed-up pages are a common finding and breach 25.1581(b).

Noise-abatement climb procedures printed in the AFM, required under 25.1581(a)(3), allow operators to prove compliance with ICAO Annex 16 Stage 4 limits during certification and routine ramp inspections.

ATR 72 icing accidents (1994 Roselawn, others) – Subsequent AFM supplements added specific ‘severe icing’ limitations and procedures, exemplifying the rule’s requirement to incorporate design-related safety data.

Expert note: Test pilots draft the initial AFM during flight-test; EASA’s cabin of Airworthiness engineers will not sign the Type Certificate until the AFM sections referenced in CS 25.1583-1587 are complete and separated from marketing material.

section_intent: CS 25.1583 makes sure that every transport aeroplane’s Flight Manual spells out the exact operating limits that keep the aircraft within its proven structural strength, controllability and performance envelope. These limits cover speeds (e.g. VMO/MMO – maximum operating speed, VA – manoeuvring speed, VFE – flap limit, VLE – gear-extended limit), power-plant settings, weights and centre-of-gravity, load factors, crew complement, approved kinds of operation, ambient temperature/altitude ranges, and maximum runway-contaminant depth. By mandating that the limits be grouped, explained and, where needed, accompanied by recovery advice, the rule turns complex certification data into clear “red-lines” that pilots, dispatchers and maintenance staff can reference in day-to-day service, preventing overstress, loss of control or performance shortfalls that have historically caused accidents.
ai_notes: Real event: China Airlines Flight 006 (1985) exceeded VMO/MMO in a spiral dive, tearing off parts of the tail; shows why the maximum operating limit speed must be prominently published and never deliberately exceeded.

Real event: American Airlines Flight 587 (2001) lost its vertical stabiliser after rapid alternating rudder inputs below VA, illustrating the CS 25.1583 warning that large alternating control inputs can fail the structure even under manoeuvring speed.

Expert note: Flight-test crews may intentionally fly above VMO with special authorisation; the AFM statement required by 25.1583(a)(1) keeps service pilots from assuming those higher speeds are acceptable in line operations.

Expert note: Exceeding engine EGT or N1 red-lines accelerates turbine damage; the power-plant limits and instrument markings demanded by 25.1583(b) give crews immediate visual cues to avoid such overstress.
Real event: Air Midwest Flight 5481 (2003) crashed after take-off with an aft CG well beyond limits; underscores the importance of the weight & loading instructions that 25.1583(c) requires.
Expert note: Airline electronic load-sheets and FMS weight-checks are built directly on the CG and weight envelopes published under this paragraph, preventing dispatch outside certified limits.
Real event: United Airlines Flight 811 (1989) continued flight with gear extended after a cargo-door failure; compliance with published VLE kept the 747 within safe aerodynamic margins until landing.
Expert note: Upset Prevention and Recovery Training uses compressibility-overspeed recovery techniques that are verbatim from the AFM notes mandated by 25.1583(a)(2).

Real event: Southwest Airlines Flight 1248 (2005) overran a snow-covered runway; investigations led to tighter requirements for listing maximum contaminant depths for take-off as now captured in 25.1583(k).
Expert note: The minimum-flight-crew limitation required by 25.1583(d) prevents operators from reducing cockpit staffing without a formal evaluation of workload and system reliance.

section_intent: CS-25.1585 ensures that every transport aeroplane’s Flight Manual gives pilots the exact, no-nonsense instructions and performance cues they need to operate the aircraft safely in all foreseeable conditions. It mandates clear checklists for normal, abnormal and emergency use, and requires critical supporting data such as when to isolate fuel tanks, how much fuel is truly usable, and the speed/altitude envelopes where buffet (pre-stall vibration) begins. By banning non-airworthiness material, the rule prevents information overload so crews can find and execute life-saving actions quickly, reducing the risk of accidents that stem from confusion, missed steps or misunderstood limits.
ai_notes: Qantas QF32 (A380, 2010): Multiple system failures after an uncontained engine burst were managed using the non-normal checklists that CS-25.1585 requires, illustrating how structured procedures let crews stabilise a crippled aircraft.

Expert note: Certification flight tests time critical checklists (e.g., engine fire) to prove they can be completed within seconds and without extraneous steps, directly reflecting 25.1585(b)’s demand for concise, airworthiness-related content only.

Air Transat 236 (A330, 2001): A fuel leak and subsequent dual-engine flameout highlighted the need for unmistakable instructions on cross-feed and tank isolation—now covered under 25.1585(c) fuel-system-independence procedures.

United Airlines 173 (DC-8, 1978): The crew ran out of fuel while troubleshooting; knowledge that ‘zero’ indicated no usable fuel per 25.1585(e) could have prompted an earlier diversion, showing why clear fuel-quantity limits matter.

Expert note: Test pilots map buffet-onset boundaries during certification so the AFM can warn crews of speeds/weights where vibration starts, fulfilling 25.1585(d) and helping avoid inadvertent stalls in high-altitude cruise.

Boeing 737NG fuel-imbalance incidents: AFM checklists instruct crews to close the cross-feed and use opposite-tank fuel only, an operational embodiment of the fuel-system-independence configuration required by 25.1585(c).
Best practice: Airlines distill the AFM’s CS-25.1585 material into a Quick Reference Handbook that matches checklist order and wording; regulators verify traceability during IOSA and EASA AOC audits.

section_intent: CS 25.1587 makes sure every Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM) contains all the performance data a crew needs to plan and fly the airplane safely under any legitimate operating condition. It demands tables and procedures that translate outside-air-temperature, weight, altitude, wind, runway slope and configuration into take-off, climb and landing capability, plus corrections for instrument error and any abnormal configuration (e.g., flaps stuck). By forcing the manufacturer to publish these numbers, together with clear assumptions, handling techniques and notes on unusual characteristics, the rule ensures pilots, dispatchers and regulators can verify that the aircraft will meet certified performance margins—especially during critical phases like take-off, engine-out climb and landing.
ai_notes: Air Florida Flight 90 (1982): Crew used an incorrect outside-air-temperature, leading to erroneous thrust-setting and climb data; the aircraft stalled after take-off. Accurate temperature conversion tables required by CS 25.1587 would have highlighted the error.

Southwest Flight 1248 Midway overrun (2005): Landing performance calculations did not adequately account for runway contamination and braking action. The rule’s mandate to publish landing-distance data and explanatory runway-length factors addresses this failure mode.

Thomsonfly 757 Bournemouth overrun (2007): Flight crew applied dry-runway figures to a wet surface because the wet-runway tables were hard to access. CS 25.1587 obliges manufacturers to present all pertinent landing-distance data clearly in the AFM.

Expert note: Engine-out escape paths at high-altitude airports such as Innsbruck depend on AFM climb-gradient tables versus weight, altitude and temperature; CS 25.1587 ensures these tables exist so operators can verify obstacle clearance before dispatch.

Expert note: Modern airline performance software is populated directly from AFM datasets. CS 25.1587 guarantees a single, certified source of truth so digital tools—and regulatory auditors—rely on accurate, approved numbers.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that, whenever a manufacturer provides take-off performance figures for slippery wet or contaminated runways, those figures are complete, credible, and published in the Aircraft Flight Manual (AFM). The data must reflect the extra distance, slower acceleration, and poorer directional control that occur when a runway is coated with water, slush, snow, or ice, and it must be clear which contaminant depths and friction levels were assumed. If no data are supplied for a given contaminant, the AFM must explicitly forbid take-off on such surfaces. The aim is to prevent crews from unknowingly using dry-runway numbers on a low-friction surface, thereby avoiding overruns, rejected-take-off accidents, and loss of control at high weight or limited runway length.
ai_notes: Air Ontario Flight 1363 (Dryden, 1989): A Fokker F-28 failed to lift off from a slush-covered runway and crashed; the investigation cited inadequate AFM data and crew underestimation of slush drag, directly prompting tighter contaminated-runway performance requirements.

Expert note: Many AFMs now provide separate "slippery wet" and "RWYCC 2/1" charts that increase accelerate-stop distance by 30–50 % and lower V1; CS-25.1591 obliges manufacturers to supply or explicitly withhold such data so operators cannot unknowingly dispatch without it.

Dryden Commission recommendation: The post-accident report urged regulators to mandate contaminated-runway charts in flight manuals; CS-25.1591 implements that recommendation for new large-aircraft certifications.

Expert note: Runway Condition Assessment Matrix (RCAM) codes 0-6 used by airlines link directly to the AFM tables required under CS-25.1591; if the AFM lacks data for code 0 (ice) or code 1 (wet ice/slush), dispatch is automatically prohibited, satisfying paragraph (a).

Best practice: Airlines winter-ops training requires crews to compute take-off numbers with OEM-supplied contaminated-runway performance software; this training and tooling depend on the validated data package the rule places in the AFM.

FedEx MD-11 directional-control event (Anchorage, 2002): The crew nearly veered off the runway during a contaminated-runway take-off when slush adhesion peaked; the carrier later adopted manufacturer-provided crosswind and distance corrections that CS-25.1591 encourages.

Expert note: Certification flight tests measure slush, standing-water, and snow drag at various depths to calibrate the performance model; CS-25.1591 ensures those test-derived penalties are communicated verbatim to operators rather than left to generic margins.

Industry practice: If an OEM elects not to produce contaminated-runway data (e.g., for deep compacted snow), the AFM must carry a bold limitation "TAKE-OFF PROHIBITED ON RWYCC 0"—a direct outcome of the rule’s paragraph (a) prohibition clause.

section_intent: This rule compels manufacturers to place in the AFM accurate, aircraft-specific landing-distance data that accounts for degraded runway friction—wet, slippery-wet, or contaminated with water, slush, snow or ice—plus wind, slope, weight, configuration and deceleration devices. If the applicant elects not to supply data for a surface, the AFM must prohibit operation on it. By requiring crews and dispatchers to compute the Landing Distance Required at the time of arrival using these data, the rule ensures a quantified safety margin exists between the calculated stopping distance and the runway length available, thereby preventing runway overruns and excursions in adverse conditions.
ai_notes: Air France 358 (A340, Toronto 2005): Overran a wet runway after heavy rain; investigation cited limited operational data for contaminated surfaces, illustrating the need for manufacturer-supplied slippery-runway performance tables now required by CS 25.1592.

Southwest 1248 (B737, Chicago-Midway 2005): Landed on snow-contaminated runway with inadequate stopping margin, leading to fatal overrun; event drove regulators to mandate more precise arrival-landing-distance assessments.
American Airlines 1420 (MD-82, Little Rock 1999): Hydroplaned on a wet runway; crew had relied on dry-runway figures, underscoring why the rule obliges separate wet and slippery-wet data in the AFM.

Expert note: Before this requirement, certification focused on dry-runway tests; operators had to use conservative generic factors. CS 25.1592 closes that gap by obligating aircraft-specific contaminated-runway data or prohibiting such operations.

Expert note: Many airlines now use electronic Landing Performance Assessment Tools (LPAT) that ingest AFM data mandated by CS 25.1592 to compute Landing Distance at Time of Arrival and enforce regulatory safety margins.

Southwest 1455 (B737, Burbank 2000): Overrun after a high-speed touchdown on a short, wet runway; highlighted the interaction of wind, slope and brake/ spoiler effectiveness now captured in the rule’s required inputs.

Expert note: The rule forces inclusion of spoiler, autobrake and thrust-reverser credit in the data set, ensuring crews understand how selecting or failing to deploy these deceleration devices alters the required runway length.

section_intent: Applicants must analyse and document how vulnerable each part of the aeroplane—engines, sensors, windows, bleed-air systems, control surfaces, etc.—is to volcanic ash, gases, and aerosols so that clear operating limits, procedures, and maintenance actions can be published. By understanding susceptibility before certification, crews and operators receive reliable guidance to avoid, detect, or recover from ash encounters and to prevent sudden loss of propulsion, structural abrasion, or system malfunctions that have historically led to in-flight emergencies.
ai_notes: British Airways Flight 9 (Jakarta, 1982): All four 747 engines flamed out after ash ingestion; incident exposed how ash melts, then re-solidifies and plugs turbine cooling, prompting the need for susceptibility studies.

KLM Flight 867 (Anchorage, 1989): Immediate quadruple engine loss and $80 M damage highlighted that unprepared crews had little data on safe power settings or inspection criteria after an ash encounter.

Eyjafjallajökull eruption (Europe, 2010): Week-long airspace shutdown showed regulators lacked type-specific ash tolerance data; rule drives provision of quantitative limits to avoid blanket closures.

Expert note: Pitot-static ports and AoA vanes can be clogged by fine ash, giving unreliable airspeed—susceptibility mapping ensures AFM includes procedures for alternate air data and autopilot disconnect.

Expert note: Windshields and landing-light lenses can sandblast opaque within minutes, so certification reviews include glazing material tests and guidance on using weather radar to detect ash clouds.

Expert note: Compliance often combines engine ingestion tests, materials erosion analysis, and AFM sections titled "Flight in the vicinity of volcanic ash" with power-setting, descent, and post-flight inspection instructions.

section_intent: This rule simply tells everyone exactly what counts as the aircraft’s Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS). By listing every wire, splice, clamp, label and grounding strap that carries or routes electrical power or signals—and by stating what is NOT EWIS (internal wiring of qualified avionics, personal devices, fibre-optic leads)—the regulation draws a clear boundary for all later CS-25 Subpart H requirements on design, protection, inspection and maintenance. The goal is to eliminate ambiguity so that no safety-critical conductor, termination or support hardware is overlooked when assessing fire risk, arcing, electromagnetic interference or system reliability throughout an aeroplane’s life.
ai_notes: Swissair Flight 111 (1998): Fire initiated in supplemental video-system wiring behind cockpit panels; investigators stressed need to treat every clamp, sleeve and splice in that area as part of the regulated wiring system—an idea later embodied in the EWIS definition.

TWA Flight 800 (1996): Chafed fuel-quantity wires inside a bundle were not separated or inspected as a system item; the explosion underscored why the definition had to include in-tank terminations and shields.

Expert note: Early 2000s certification projects showed manufacturers classifying wire bundle clamps and labels as “hardware” outside wiring rules; CS-25.1701 forces inclusion so abrasion or loose identification markers are now covered in safety assessments.

Expert note: Maintenance programmes now create EWIS zone inspection cards using this definition, ensuring tie-wraps, bonding jumpers and pressure seals are periodically checked to prevent shorts or arcing.

Expert note: By excluding internal wiring of DO-160-qualified avionics, CS-25.1701 avoids duplicate testing while still capturing the external connectors; this balances thorough oversight with practical certification scope.

section_intent: This rule ensures that every element of the aircraft’s Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS)—all wires, cables, connectors, splices, clamps, etc.—is properly chosen, routed, and protected so it performs its intended electrical function throughout the aircraft’s life without creating fire, smoke, or system-failure hazards. It demands that wiring be matched to its environment (temperature, vibration, moisture), installed without excessive tension or bending, tolerant of structural flexing, resistant to arc-tracking and moisture intrusion, and that any post-certification changes meet the same rigorous standards. In short, it seeks to prevent wiring-related failures and fires by mandating robust design, installation, and maintenance practices.
ai_notes: Swissair Flight 111 (1998): Arcing in entertainment-system wires ignited flammable insulation blankets; catastrophic fire underscored need for proper wire type, routing, and protection from mechanical strain and moisture.
TWA Flight 800 (1996): Short circuit in aged wire bundle inside center-wing tank sparked fuel-air explosion, highlighting the danger of arc-tracking and inadequate wire selection for harsh zones.

Expert note: Legacy Kapton-insulated wiring on early jets suffered cracking and arc-tracking; modern certification specifies newer insulation types (e.g., XL-ETFE) and stringent bend-radius limits to mitigate those failure modes.

L-1011 fleet service reports (1980s): Main-power feeder cables tore at fuselage frame crossings during pressurization cycles, leading to CS-25.1703(c) requirement for slack and strain relief to absorb fuselage flex.
Industry best practice: Stress-relief service loops, cushioned clamps, and grommets are installed at connectors and structure penetrations to minimise mechanical strain per 25.1703(a)(4).
Expert note: Moisture-prone bilge areas now use environmental-sealed splices and backshells with drip-loops to satisfy 25.1703(d) after corrosion-induced shorts were found during EZAP audits.

Enhanced Zonal Inspection Programs (MSG-3 EZAP): Airlines train technicians to detect chafing, fluid contamination, and improper tie-wrap tension, directly supporting continued compliance with CS 25.1703.
