STC wiring changes: EASA requires supplemental type certificate holders to apply identical design rules and testing (heat-aging, abrasion, flammability) as the original OEM, enforcing 25.1703(e).

section_intent: This rule makes the Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS)—every wire, cable, connector, clamp and splice that carries electrical power or signals—part of the critical system it supports. Designers and applicants must therefore show that the wiring’s design, routing, protection, separation, inspection and maintenance satisfy the same performance, fire-safety and reliability requirements that apply to the associated system (flight controls, fuel, fire detection, navigation, etc.). The aim is to prevent shorts, arcing, ignition sources or loss of function that could cause fires or disable essential equipment throughout the aircraft’s operational life.
ai_notes: Swissair Flight 111 (1998): Arcing in in-flight-entertainment wiring ignited insulation above the cockpit, showing why wiring must meet the fire-protection standards of the systems it powers.

TWA Flight 800 (1996): Probable short in Fuel Quantity Indication System wiring inside the centre tank triggered an explosion, driving the link between EWIS and CS 25.981 fuel-tank ignition prevention.
Expert note: Heavy-maintenance inspections regularly discover chafed bundles and missing clamps; CS 25.1705 forces designers to route and secure wiring so such latent hazards are eliminated up front.

Aging Transport Systems Rule audits (2000-2005) found widespread arc-tracking of Kapton-insulated wire; the requirement ensures new designs select insulation and circuit protection matched to system criticality.
Delta L-1011 lavatory fire (1991 ground event) traced to damaged wiring near the trash bin; inclusion of CS 25.854 lavatory fire-protection criteria for EWIS addresses this risk.
Expert note: Applicants now perform an EWIS Failure Hazard Assessment alongside the system FHA, assigning Design Assurance Levels and performing FMEAs that explicitly include wiring faults.
Expert note: EWIS maintenance training (per EASA AMC 20-22 & ATA 106) teaches technicians specialised inspection and repair techniques, sustaining compliance throughout the aircraft’s life cycle.
Expert note: Best practice is to segregate high-energy cables from fuel, oxygen and hydraulic lines, and to shield bundles in lightning-exposed zones, meeting CS 25.1316 and related references.

section_intent: CS 25.1707 ensures that the aircraft’s Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS)—all wires, cables, connectors, and supports—is routed and protected so that a failure in one part of the wiring, or in nearby systems, cannot cause fires, knock out multiple power sources, jam controls, or otherwise create a hazardous condition. It requires adequate spacing or shielding between wiring and other wiring, fuel, hydraulics, oxygen, water/waste, flight-control cables, hot equipment, and structure, plus electrical isolation to avoid stray currents and interference. Redundant power paths must stay truly independent, and wiring must be guarded against chafing, vibration, fluid leaks, and heat. In short: keep wires apart, insulated, and secure so that single faults stay single and the airplane can always continue safe flight and landing.
ai_notes: TWA Flight 800 (1996): degraded wiring inside the centre wing tank arced in a fuel-vapour environment, showing why wiring must be isolated from fuel systems and prevented from sparking near flammable fluids.

Swissair Flight 111 (1998): arcing in in-flight-entertainment wiring ignited surrounding insulation; bundles ran near structure and ducting, illustrating the need for spacing, fire-resistant barriers, and protection from heat.

Expert note: Large transport aircraft routinely route main AC feeders on opposite sides of the fuselage to ensure that a hydraulic line rupture or localized fire cannot disable both power paths, satisfying the separation and redundancy aims of paragraphs (c) and (k).

Boeing 747-400 field event (2004): hydraulic fluid spray shorted generator cables and tripped multiple buses; redesign added shields and drip-loops, exemplifying requirements to separate and isolate heavy-current wiring from hydraulic lines.

Expert note: Independent starter-generator, battery, and external-power grounds are terminated on different studs, preventing fault currents from one source from flowing into another per paragraph (d)(1)–(2).

Industry practice: Installing stand-offs, wear sleeves, and periodic clamps where wiring crosses flight-control cables prevents chafing that could either jam controls or expose conductors, directly addressing paragraph (i).

A330 galley overheat event (2002): a coffee-maker heater damaged an adjacent wire bundle; OEMs now enforce minimum 50 mm clearance or thermal barriers around hot galley equipment, echoing paragraph (j).

section_intent: This rule makes sure that the aircraft’s Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS)—all the wires, cables, connectors and related parts—cannot by itself create a disaster. Designers must prove that any failure mode capable of causing a crash (catastrophic) is so unlikely that it will almost never happen during the fleet life, and that no single wire, connector, or installation mistake can bring the aircraft down. Failures that are less severe but still dangerous (hazardous) must remain very rare. In practice this forces redundancy, physical separation, robust materials, circuit protection, inspection access, and analysis so that chafing, arcing, moisture, maintenance errors or lightning cannot cascade into loss of critical functions or on-board fire.
ai_notes: Swissair 111 (1998): Arcing in entertainment-system wiring ignited flammable insulation, leading to an uncontrollable cockpit fire and loss of the MD-11—illustrates why catastrophic outcomes from a single wiring failure must be made ‘extremely improbable’.

TWA 800 (1996): A shorted fuel-quantity wire likely ignited vapours in the B747 centre wing tank; the event drove tighter scrutiny of wiring segregation and circuit protection to keep hazardous outcomes ‘extremely remote’.

Expert note: Zonal Safety Analysis and Enhanced Zonal Analysis Procedure (EZAP) are now mandatory tools; they focus maintenance on wire bundles near flammable fluids or flight-critical controls to prevent single-point threats.

Expert note: Industry best practice separates redundant flight-control wires on opposite sides of the fuselage or wing so that chafing, fluid leak, or localized fire cannot disable both channels at once.

Boeing 757 in-service events (2000s): Repeated thrust-reverser and elevator malfunctions traced to chafed bundles under the cockpit floor prompted fleet-wide routing changes—showing how design and installation must anticipate wear-and-tear.

Expert note: Use of arc-fault circuit breakers and shielded, high-temperature wire insulation reduces the probability that a single short circuit progresses to smoke or fire, directly supporting the CS-25.1709 probability targets.

section_intent: The rule ensures every part of the Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS)—individual wires, cables, and bundles—is clearly and durably marked so technicians can instantly know what it is, what it does, and any design limits or separation requirements tied to system redundancy. By demanding markings that last the life of the aircraft and do not degrade electrical performance, the rule aims to prevent maintenance errors, mis-routing, accidental cross-connection, and loss of required physical separation between redundant circuits, all of which can lead to shorts, fire, or loss of critical functions.
ai_notes: TWA Flight 800 (1996) – Investigators traced a probable short in aged centre-tank wiring; poor identification and documentation of wire runs hindered troubleshooting, reinforcing the need for clear, life-long wire marking.
Swissair 111 (1998) – Arcing in entertainment-system wiring spread fire in hidden areas; post-accident reports highlighted difficulty in locating specific bundles without consistent labels.

Expert note: In heavy checks, technicians have mistakenly spliced together redundant flight-control power feeds because wire codes were illegible; mandatory interval labelling now prevents such cross-connections.
Boeing 737 APU-start wire chafing events (2000s) – Service bulletins called for remarking and rerouting wires so fire-critical bundles remain distinct and separated, mirroring CS 25.1711 intent.

Expert note: Industry best practice uses heat-shrink sleeves with laser-etched part numbers every 30–50 cm; the sleeves are UV-, fluid-, and heat-resistant to stay readable for decades without affecting insulation.
Expert note: Modifications must extend the original numbering system; mixed schemes once caused delayed fault isolation on cargo conversions, prompting regulators to emphasise paragraph (e).

section_intent: This rule makes sure that every part of the aircraft’s Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS)—all wires, cables, connectors, and their protection—cannot become a source of uncontrolled fire or toxic smoke. It obliges designers to pick materials that either do not burn, self-extinguish quickly, or stay functional long enough to let the crew handle an emergency. In normal areas, the wiring insulation must pass a self-extinguishing flame test; in fire zones (e.g. engine nacelles) any wiring needed for continued safe flight or shutdown must be at least fire-resistant, matching the fire-hardening required of other critical systems. By tying EWIS to the same performance levels as cabin materials (CS 25.831) and flammable-fluid zones (CS 25.863), the rule prevents hidden wiring fires, limits smoke that could disable the crew, and preserves essential electrical power and control during an emergency.
ai_notes: Swissair 111 (1998): Arcing behind the cockpit ceiling ignited flammable Mylar insulation; inadequate self-extinguishing properties let the fire spread, driving the industry to tighten wiring-fire rules and create dedicated EWIS requirements.

Air Canada 797 (1983): A lavatory wiring fire filled the cabin with toxic smoke; the tragedy highlighted the need for flame-retardant wire insulation and smoke performance testing now captured in Appendix F.

Expert note: Routine in-service findings of chafed wire bundles in engine pylons showed that leaking hydraulic or fuel mist can ignite on hot wiring; CS 25.1713(b) forces designers to specify fire-resistant jacketing for any wires critical to shut-off valves in these zones.
Expert note: Compliance teams now batch-test wire types (e.g. PTFE/TKT, XL-ETFE) to Appendix F vertical and 60° flame tests to prove they self-extinguish within the mandated burn length/time.

Expert note: Modern harness design keeps power feeders physically separated from oxygen lines and uses fire sleeves or metal conduit where separation is impossible, directly reflecting the intent to contain any arc-induced fire.

Best practice: Maintenance training stresses inspection of clamps, grommets, and fluid-barrier seals so that vibration or fluid leakage cannot compromise the certified fire-resistant properties of the EWIS.

section_intent: The rule ensures that all parts of the aircraft wiring system are electrically bonded so that static electricity and fault currents have a controlled, low-resistance path back to the aircraft’s electrical ‘earth’. This prevents dangerous sparks, overheating or electromagnetic interference that could ignite fuel vapours, start cabin or equipment fires, or disable critical avionics. In short, every joint, hinge, panel and cable in the Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS) must be tied together electrically so that any built-up charge or stray current is safely dissipated under both normal operation and fault conditions.
ai_notes: Pan Am Flight 214 (1963): A missing bonding strap allowed lightning-induced charge to arc into a fuel tank, causing an explosion and highlighting the need for continuous static-discharge paths.
TWA Flight 800 (1996): Chafed wiring in the centre fuel tank likely produced a spark; improved EWIS bonding and return-path design became a key mitigation.
Swissair 111 (1998): Insulation breakdown and arcing in MD-11 cable bundles triggered a fast-moving in-flight fire, reinforcing stringent EWIS fault-current paths and shielding requirements.

Expert note: Certification tests now include milliohm continuity checks across doors, control surfaces and structural joints to verify that bonding jumpers keep resistance below specified limits even after vibration and corrosion exposure.
Expert note: Maintenance manuals mandate periodic inspection of bonding straps and static wicks, because loosened fasteners or corrosion can raise resistance and defeat the designed return path.

section_intent: This rule ensures that every part of the aircraft Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS) is matched to the fuses, circuit breakers, or other protective devices required by CS-25.1357. The goal is simple: if a wire is damaged, shorted, or overloaded—either momentarily or continuously—the protective device must open the circuit fast enough to keep the wire insulation from overheating, sparking, or catching fire. Proper wire sizing, insulation type, routing, and breaker rating must act together so that no failure mode can turn an electrical fault into smoke or flame anywhere on the airplane.
ai_notes: Swissair Flight 111 (1998): Arcing in MD-11 in-flight entertainment wiring ignited nearby flammable materials before any breaker tripped, illustrating why wire/breaker compatibility is critical to prevent hidden cabin fires.

Expert note: Pairing 22-AWG cockpit annunciator wires with 5-amp breakers (instead of 1-amp) can let the conductor act as a fuse, glowing red and igniting insulation long before the breaker sees enough current to trip.

Boeing 767 smoke event, Narita (2002): Chafed bundle shorted against structure; current stayed below breaker rating, generated heat and smoke in crown area—shows risk under ‘continuous fault’ conditions.

Airbus A330/A350 seat-power installations use arc-fault circuit breakers and dedicated low-amp subnetworks; this best practice limits available energy so insulation cannot reach ignition temperature even during intermittent arcs.

Expert note: EWIS compliance teams run “hot-wire” tests per SAE AS4373 to prove that selected breaker trips within 5 seconds at 200 % overload, keeping wire surface below 200 °C—the ignition point of modern polyimide insulation.

Industry maintenance training now includes ‘bundle condition and breaker coordination’ modules, teaching technicians to flag any aftermarket modification that ups breaker size without upsizing the affected wire gauge.

section_intent: The rule demands that aircraft be physically designed so that every part of the Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS—that is, all wires, connectors, splices, clamps and related hardware) can be reached for routine inspection and, when needed, removed and replaced. Easy access allows mechanics to spot chafing, overheating, fluid-soaked insulation or loose terminations before they evolve into smoke, fire, or critical system failures, thereby assuring the aircraft remains airworthy throughout its service life.
ai_notes: Swissair Flight 111 (1998): Post-crash investigation linked a severe in-flight fire to arc-tracking in ceiling wiring; limited access to the bundles meant earlier degradation went unnoticed, underscoring the need for inspectable routing.
TWA Flight 800 (1996): Frayed wiring inside a fuel-quantity harness likely ignited vapours in the centre tank; the NTSB cited poor visibility and access to ageing wire as a maintenance barrier.
Expert note: Chafing at clamp points hidden behind trim panels is a recurrent finding in zonal inspections; removable panels and marked fasteners allow technicians to reach these spots quickly.
Expert note: EWIS programmes now require task cards that specify maximum panel-removal times and lighting provisions so maintainers can perform 360° visual checks without improvised disassembly.

Boeing 737NG ‘pickle-fork’ wire bundles (multiple 2000s incidents): Hydraulic fluid wicking into inaccessible wing-root harnesses caused insulation breakdown; later design blocks added quick-release fairings for easier wire replacement.
Expert note: Industry best practice labels wire runs and installs service loops near connectors, ensuring degraded sections can be cut out and re-terminated without removing entire harnesses.

section_intent: This rule makes sure all electrical wiring and its associated parts (the Electrical Wiring Interconnection System, EWIS) are placed and protected so that shifting cargo, baggage, people, or carry-on items cannot chafe, cut, crush, or break the wires, nor let a damaged wire start a fire. In plain English: keep the wiring out of harm’s way anywhere passengers walk, stow bags, or loaders move freight, because damaged wiring can disable critical systems or ignite nearby materials. The requirement forces designers to use routing, shielding, separation and structural guards that withstand everyday service, turbulence, hard landings, maintenance activity, and rough loading, thereby preventing shorts, arcing and smoke events that could threaten the airplane.
ai_notes: Swissair Flight 111 (1998): An entertainment-system wire, abraded by cabin activity, arced and ignited insulation above the ceiling; the ensuing fire led to loss of the aircraft, showing why wiring near passenger areas needs mechanical and fire protection.

TWA Flight 800 (1996): Chafed fuel-quantity indication wiring inside a center tank sparked a catastrophic explosion, driving home that even small wire damage from routine maintenance access can have fatal results.

Expert note: Service difficulty reports repeatedly show Unit Load Devices (ULDs) scraping exposed harnesses in lower cargo bays; modern freighters now run power feeders in armored conduits behind sidewalls or under floor beams to meet CS 25.1721(a).

UPS A300F Louisville (2009) ground incident: A pallet shifted during taxi and crushed floor-level wiring, tripping multiple breakers and filling the bay with smoke—prompting operators to install kick-plates and skid rails over cable runs.

Expert note: Certification compliance commonly uses abrasion-resistant sleeving, stand-offs, and grommets in seat-track areas where cabin crew step, preventing foot traffic from wearing through insulation per CS 25.1721(b).

FAA EWIS training programs now instruct ramp and cabin crews to report any nicks or exposed conductors found during loading, a best practice that directly supports the rule’s intent to minimise damage from people and carry-on items.

Expert note: Manufacturers route emergency-power and flight-control signal wiring above head-level in passenger cabins, segregated from luggage bins, so a falling suitcase cannot sever critical circuits, satisfying CS 25.1721(c).

section_intent: The rule ensures that any part of the aircraft’s Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS)—the network of cables, connectors and harnesses that carries electrical power and signals—is treated as a possible spark source wherever fuel, hydraulic fluid, oil or their vapours could be present if a leak occurs. Designers must therefore arrange, shield, separate or otherwise protect wiring in those zones so that a short-circuit, arc or hot surface cannot ignite leaking fluid, meeting the broader flammable-fluid safety intent of CS 25.863. In plain terms, the objective is to prevent fires or explosions that could start when escaping flammable fluids meet an electrical spark, thus preserving the aircraft’s structural integrity and giving occupants time to evacuate or the crew to control the situation.
ai_notes: TWA 800 (1996): centre-wing fuel-tank vapour ignited; investigation linked the most credible ignition source to deteriorated wiring inside the tank, driving tighter EWIS-to-fuel separation rules.

Expert note: Chafed wire bundles in hydraulic bays have produced arcs that ignited atomised Skydrol during leak tests; industry now mandates protective sleeving and clamp-spacing reviews in these areas.

Swissair 111 (1998): in-flight wiring fire spread rapidly through insulation blankets; although not a fluid fire, it underscored how wiring faults can create ignition sources wherever flammable materials exist, influencing EWIS fire-safety philosophy.

Expert note: During ground refuelling, fuel-vent spillage under wing has been ignited by static-induced sparks at nearby wiring connectors; current best practice routes wiring higher than vent outlets and adds bonding straps.

Best practice: Certification compliance typically uses zonal analysis plus physical demonstrations (e.g., spray-leak ignition tests) to prove that wire insulation, separation distances and fault-protection devices prevent ignition of flammable mists.

section_intent: The rule requires that all electrical wiring interconnection system (EWIS) parts that serve or pass through an aircraft’s engines be laid out and protected so that (1) the loss or short-circuit of any one wire, connector, or harness will not disable the other engines or force the crew to react instantly to keep the aircraft safe, and (2) the wiring will survive, or isolate the airplane from, rare but severe engine events such as an uncontained rotor burst or a fire that burns through the engine case. In plain terms, the engines must keep running safely—or be safely shut down—despite any single EWIS fault, and critical wires must be routed or shielded so that debris or flames from a failed engine cannot cripple other systems.
ai_notes: Qantas A380 Flight QF32 (2010): An uncontained Trent 900 turbine disk burst severed wiring in the pylon; redundant, segregated routing prevented total loss of engine control and helped the crew land safely—exactly the resilience this CS 25.1725 requirement seeks.

Expert note: Early FADEC installations revealed chafing of shared harnesses inside pylons; a short could simultaneously command multiple engines to idle. Manufacturers now route each engine’s control wiring separately and add physical barriers to meet this rule.

Expert note: Compliance best-practice is a ‘rotor burst zoning analysis’—wiring bundles in the fan-blade debris path must either be redundant, shielded with titanium liners, or re-routed outside the predicted fragment cone.

MD-11 Swissair 111 (1998) wiring fire: Although not in the engine, this accident drove industry focus on EWIS fire propagation; engine-bay wiring is now required to use high-temperature materials and fire stops to prevent a burn-through from crippling other engines.

Expert note: Training and maintenance programmes now mandate regular inspection of engine-pylon wiring clamps and grommets to catch insulation wear that could cause arcing and unintended engine shutdown, directly supporting the intent of CS 25.1725.

section_intent: This rule ensures that the electrical wiring (EWIS) which powers or controls valves used to shut off flammable fluids—fuel, oil, hydraulic fluid—remains functional during an engine or APU fire. If a fire disables the wiring before the crew can close the valve, the fluid can continue to feed the fire, escalate the damage, and jeopardise the safe continuation or evacuation of the flight. Therefore, the wiring must either be inherently fire-proof or routed/ shielded so flames in any designated fire zone cannot prevent operation of the shut-off means specified in CS 25.1189.
ai_notes: Air Canada DC-9 engine fire, Miami 1972: post-event teardown found nacelle flames melted fuel-valve wires, valve stayed open and fire spread—case cited in technical justifications leading to Amendment 25-5.

Expert note: Industry routes fuel-shutoff valve wiring inside stainless-steel conduits across firewall ribs so a 2000 °F flame for 15 min cannot sever conductors, meeting ‘fireproof’ test defined in AC 25.853-1.

Swissair Flight 111 (1998): cockpit wiring fire showed how electrical failures can escalate; although not a fuel fire, it underscored the need for redundant, fire-resistant EWIS to keep critical controls operative.
FAA fire-torch tests (early 1990s) demonstrated PTFE-insulated wire bundles failed in <60 s; adoption of nickel-clad, mineral-insulated cables for shutoff circuits became common compliance method.
Expert note: Certification test plans typically include a live-fire demonstration where the shutoff valve must still actuate after 15 min flame exposure, providing objective evidence to authorities.

Best practice: Airline EWIS maintenance programs require inspection of clamps and grommets around firewalls every ‘C’ check to prevent chafing that could expose conductor and compromise fire integrity.

section_intent: This rule makes the applicant publish clear, aircraft-specific Instructions for Continued Airworthiness (ICA) that cover every part of the Electrical Wiring Interconnection System (EWIS). In plain terms, the design approval holder must spell out how airlines and maintenance crews must inspect, clean, repair, and replace wiring throughout the jet for the whole service life, using the methods and intervals defined in CS-25.1529 and Appendix H. The aim is to stop hidden wire chafing, arcing, contamination, heat damage, or improper repairs from developing into smoke, fire, or loss-of-system power, by making wiring a maintained item rather than “fit-and-forget.”
ai_notes: Swissair 111 (MD-11, 1998): Arcing in insulation-damaged wiring ignited flammable insulation blankets; lack of targeted wiring inspection guidance prompted regulators to mandate dedicated EWIS ICA.

TWA Flight 800 (B-747, 1996): Spark from aged Fuel Quantity Indication System wiring likely ignited fuel-air mix; investigation highlighted insufficient maintenance instructions for aging wire bundles in critical areas.
Expert note: Pre-2000 maintenance programs treated wiring as non-life-limited equipment; the rule forces inclusion of EZAP-based zonal inspections so age-related degradation is caught before failure.
Expert note: ICA now require detailed bundling, separation, and clamp replacement limits to prevent chafing against hydraulic or fuel lines—common field findings during CPCP and SFAR-88 audits.

Expert note: Rule compels manufacturers to provide cleaning, chemical exposure limits, and contamination-control steps because metal shavings or fluids trapped in bundles have led to shorts discovered during MSG-3 tasks.
Expert note: Clear allowable repair schemes (splice count, shielding restoration, torque on connectors) are mandated so line maintenance can fix damage without introducing new hazards.

FAA Aging Transport Systems Rule (2007) / EASA ED 2008/007: Industry responded with Enhanced Zonal Analysis Procedure and defined wire type replacement intervals, illustrating the compliance pathway this CS-25.1729 clause locks into European law.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that all electrical wiring used by engine and APU fire- or overheat-detection systems is tough enough to survive an actual fire and is routed so a blaze in one compartment cannot create false alarms or disable detection in another. By demanding fire-resistant wiring and careful routing or common protection, CS-25.1731 guarantees that the crew receives rapid, accurate fire warnings and that extinguishing systems are correctly tied to the zones that really need them. (EWIS = Electrical Wiring Interconnection System; APU = Auxiliary Power Unit).
ai_notes: Lufthansa A321 D-AISX (2010): An in-flight engine fire warning forced a diversion; investigation found a detector loop scorched where it crossed a hot bleed-air duct, proving the need for fire-resistant routing demanded by this rule.

NTSB Safety Recommendation A-02-23: Repeated false engine-fire warnings on 737s were traced to chafed detector wiring routed through adjacent fire zones, prompting calls for segregation exactly as required in CS-25.1731(b).

Expert note: In nacelles, temperatures during bleed-air leaks can top 200 °C; fire-resistant sheaths and mineral-insulated cable keep detection circuits intact long enough to alert the crew before the wires fail.

Industry practice: OEMs add stainless-steel over-braid and titanium firewall feed-throughs on fire-loop harnesses, and avoid running those harnesses through multiple zones unless protected or tied to common extinguishing bottles.

Expert note: Line-maintenance training now includes clamp torque checks and stand-off measurements for fire-loop wiring during zonal inspections to prevent abrasion or rerouting that could create false warnings.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU—the small gas-turbine engine that supplies electricity, air and hydraulics when the main engines are not running or as backup in flight) is installed so it cannot endanger the aircraft. Designers must follow the APU manufacturer’s installation instructions, decide whether the APU is “essential” (needed for dispatch or continued safe flight) or “non-essential,” and then meet the corresponding safety requirements. All parts that control or protect the APU must be robust, reachable for inspection, and electrically bonded to prevent sparks. Except for the extremely rare events of a complete rotor burst or case burn-through, the installation must satisfy the general systems-safety rule CS 25.1309, meaning no single failure may create hazardous conditions and multiple failures must be exceedingly improbable. In short, the objective is to integrate the APU so its normal operation, failures, and maintenance do not compromise the safety of the airplane or its occupants.
ai_notes: UPS B747-400F, Dubai 2010: On-ground APU duct clamp failure led to bleed-air leak and fire warning, illustrating why APU components must be secured and inspected.
B737-300, Manchester 1998: Fuel line chafed, causing an APU fire during push-back; shows the intent behind bonding, routing and access for inspection.

Expert note: ETOPS-configured twins often treat the APU as "essential" to provide backup electrical power; compliance demonstrations therefore cover in-flight start reliability and rotor-burst shielding.
MD-11 certification test, early 1990s: Containment rig fired APU rotor fragments at tail structure; data drove design shields that satisfy the exemption from CS 25.1309(b) for uncontained failures.
B757 service difficulty reports highlighted recurrent APU starter-generator cable arcing; industry practice now enforces bonding straps and torque checks every A-check.

Expert note: Maintainability studies require that panels and quick-disconnects allow mechanics to visually inspect oil, fuel and bleed-air lines without removing heavy structures—meeting paragraph (c)(3).

Continental DC-10, Los Angeles 1979: APU shut down before take-off due to overheat; flight continued safely, illustrating the concept of a "non-essential" APU that can be turned off without jeopardising safety.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that an aeroplane’s Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) can be safely used and, if necessary, quickly shut down without endangering the aircraft. It requires the APU to meet the right design standard for its role (essential or non-essential), be controllable from the cockpit, be protected against fire or rotor burst, and have systems that prevent overspeed or other limits that could cause it to break apart. If the APU is expected to start in flight—especially for extended-range (ETOPS) operations—it must reliably do so throughout a proven altitude, speed, and cold-soak envelope. In short, the rule aims to prevent APU fires, structural failures, and loss of control or power, both on the ground and in flight.
ai_notes: Air France A340-300 (Miami, 2005): An APU rotor burst punctured the tail cone and damaged control cables, illustrating why CS-25J903(d)(1) demands shielding and fire-resistant design.

Expert note: Ground APU start-up fires caused by fuel pooling in the exhaust plenum are common; cockpit emergency-stop switches required by 25J903(c) let crews halt rotation and cut fuel before the fire spreads.
FedEx MD-11F (Memphis, 2005): Uncontained APU failure on the ramp sprayed shrapnel through the pressure bulkhead, prompting stricter industry blade-off analysis per AMC 20-128A.
Expert note: ETOPS certification hinges on proving the APU can cold-start at cruise altitude after hours of −50 °C exposure, directly addressing 25J903(e)(2).

Qantas B747-400 (Bangkok, 2008): APU fire during turnaround was rapidly extinguished because cockpit crew could shut it down and the firewall limited damage, demonstrating the intent of 25J903(c)(1) and (d).
Expert note: Overspeed or EGT limit exceedances can crack turbine disks; modern APUs include FADEC-based limit protections to satisfy 25J903(d)(2).
Best practice: Manufacturers perform containment tests with high-energy rotor fragment rigs to show that any burst is either contained or directed away from critical systems.
Best practice: Airline training programs drill pilots and ground crews on APU fire/overspeed checklists, ensuring swift use of guarded "APU FIRE/STOP" switches mandated by this rule.

section_intent: This rule makes sure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) behaves safely in every phase of use—from start-up, through ground or in-flight running, to shutdown. The applicant must show that, within all approved operating limits of both the aeroplane and the APU, there are no dangerous events such as compressor stall, surge, or flame-out, and that airflow into the APU does not create harmful vibration. It also requires proof that any vibration transmitted to the APU stays below the critical frequencies and amplitudes defined in CS-APU 120, so the unit will not suffer structural or mechanical damage in service.
ai_notes: UPS Flight 6 (Boeing 747-400F, 2010): Post-crash investigation noted uncontained APU rotor failure linked to prior surge events; illustrates why designers must verify that stall/surge cannot develop under approved conditions.

Airbus A320 family service history: Several taxi-out APU flame-outs traced to hot-day, low-airspeed airflow distortion in the tailcone inlet; compliance testing now routinely covers high-ambient temperature, low-ram-air scenarios.
Expert note: Ice shedding during cold-soak altitude re-starts can cause momentary surge—manufacturers run altitude-cell tests to replicate these worst-case restarts and demonstrate stable operation.

Boeing 777 AOM practice: Engine/APU cross-bleed starts are prohibited above certain N1 settings to avoid inlet pressure transients that could drive the APU into stall; rule underpins such operational limitations.

MD-11 vibration survey programme (1990s): Flight-test accelerometer data showed tail-mounted APU resonance near 58 Hz; structural damping changes were made to keep vibration below critical amplitudes defined by CS-APU 120.

Expert note: Compliance teams place accelerometers on the APU gearbox and mount points during flutter testing to confirm that disturbed inlet airflow at high sideslip does not excite damaging vibrations.

section_intent: Make sure that the auxiliary power unit (APU)—and anything tied to it such as fuel, oil-scavenge, air, control or fire-protection systems—does not fail in a dangerous way when the aeroplane briefly experiences ‘negative g’ (i.e. the crew and equipment feel light or lifted from their seats) anywhere inside the approved manoeuvring envelope, and for as long as such loading could realistically last. In simple terms: the APU must keep running safely or shut down benignly even when the aircraft is pushed over the top of a climb, encounters severe turbulence, or is flown in an upset-recovery manoeuvre that produces sustained or transient negative acceleration.
ai_notes: United 811 (1990): Sudden decompression after cargo-door failure caused rapid pitch-down and negative g; although the APU was off, investigators highlighted the need for all standby power sources to remain safe under unusual attitudes—an example driving regulators to scrutinise APU integrity in upset scenarios.

Expert note: Oil-scavenge pumps can unport during −0.25 g, starving APU bearings and leading to overspeed or burst; CS 25J943 forces designers to prove oil pick-up and venting still work or that the unit shuts down cleanly.

Bombardier Global 7500 certification testing (public test reports): Aircraft executed pushover manoeuvres to −0.5 g while the APU was running to verify no flameout, surge or chip-detector events—demonstrating compliance method.

Expert note: In-service turbulence events show transient −0.3 g loads lasting 3–5 s; rule therefore requires analysis of the ‘greatest duration’ so fuel controls and electronic boxes are mounted to avoid connector pull-out or coolant loss.
Best practice: Integrate negative-g acceleration sensors that command an automatic, orderly APU shutdown if lubrication limits are reached, preventing rotor seizure or fire.

section_intent: An Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is a small turbine that provides electrical, pneumatic and hydraulic power when the main engines cannot. This rule ensures its fuel system will always deliver the correct flow and pressure in every expected attitude or manoeuvre. For APUs identified as "essential" to safety, the system must also keep burning even if air is ingested or if water in the fuel freezes, preventing flame-outs caused by vapour lock or ice blockage. In short, the requirement protects against fuel starvation, air bubbles and icing so that the APU can be depended on to supply critical services during normal operations and, more importantly, during emergencies.
ai_notes: United Airlines Flight 232 (DC-10, 1989): After total engine failure, the running APU provided power throughout extreme bank and pitch angles; reliable fuel pick-up prevented an additional loss of electrical supply, illustrating paragraph (a).
Expert note: Flight-test demonstrations now include 30° bank turns and climb/descent manoeuvres with low fuel to prove continuous APU fuel delivery at certified attitudes.

Expert note: Water entering fuel during humid ground operations can freeze in high-altitude cruise; paragraph (c) forces design of filters, heaters or recirculation that keep an essential APU running with ice-contaminated fuel.

B737NG ground-handling events (multiple reports 2000-2010): APU flame-outs traced to air pockets after maintenance line draining led to revised vent/prime procedures—drives paragraph (b) requirement to tolerate entrained air.
Expert note: Operators fit booster pumps and check-valves in APU feed lines so that negative-g or tank swash can’t uncover the fuel pick-up, meeting the flow/pressure mandate.
Best practice: Daily sump drains and onboard water detectors verify that free water stays below 0.20 cm³/L, directly supporting the icing-resilience criteria in paragraph (c).

section_intent: The rule requires manufacturers to prove—through engineering analysis plus any tests the regulator deems necessary—that the APU’s fuel system will always deliver fuel correctly and safely in every foreseeable operating condition (e.g., start-up, high altitude, hot weather, abnormal attitudes). It also demands that if any fuel-fed heat exchanger (such as fuel-oil or fuel-air coolers used on APUs) were to fail, that failure must not create a hazardous situation such as fire, loss of control, or engine/APU shutdown. In plain terms: demonstrate by analysis and representative testing that the APU fuel system works reliably and that single-point failures in components that mix fuel with another fluid cannot put the aircraft at risk.
ai_notes: Expert note: Fuel-system ‘iron-bird’ rigs that duplicate tank geometry and pump/valve behaviour are routinely run through extreme temperature, attitude and flow-demand profiles to prove the APU can be started and run during every phase of flight—directly satisfying CS 25J952(a).

Southwest Airlines B737-300 APU fire, Albuquerque 2001: ground fire began when a fuel line to the APU ruptured during start; incident drove emphasis on analysis of vibration-induced fatigue and bench testing of flexible lines to prevent leaks.

British Airways Flight 38, B777-200ER Heathrow 2008: ice blockage in the engine fuel-oil heat exchanger highlighted how a heat-exchanger malfunction can suddenly starve a power unit; industry revised FOHE designs and added failure-effects analysis akin to CS 25J952(b).

Expert note: Certification teams now perform ARP4761 safety assessments that insert a hypothetical heat-exchanger core breach and trace whether oil or bleed air could enter the fuel path, ignite, or disable the APU, ensuring ‘no hazardous condition’ per paragraph (b).

Expert note: Training and maintenance programmes include detailed inspection criteria for APU fuel lines, clamps and heat-exchanger seals, reflecting lessons that small leaks or exchanger cracks can escalate quickly if not caught—exactly the failure modes the rule aims to preclude.

section_intent: Ensure that the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) can always receive fuel without jeopardising the main-engine fuel feed or allowing an APU-side malfunction (leak, fire, pump seizure) to drain or disable the propulsion fuel system. In plain words: the APU must have its own fuel path or, if it shares a tank with the engines, there must be a positive shut-off valve so crews can isolate the APU line instantly, preventing a single failure from taking out both electrical/bleed power and thrust-producing engines, or from turning an APU leak into an uncontained fire or total fuel loss.
ai_notes: Airbus A310 C-GPAT (1999): APU fuel line chafed and leaked; the crew had to shut the APU to avoid fire risk while airborne. Independent isolation protected the engine feeds, illustrating why a dedicated shut-off is critical.
Expert note: Fuel line rupture on ground runs is a frequent maintenance incident; if the APU shares an un-valved line, a simple leak can drain a wing tank and starve engines during taxi.

Boeing design practice: APU fuel is tapped downstream of an electric pump with its own firewall shut-off valve linked to the APU fire switch; pulling the handle instantly isolates the APU without affecting engine feed, meeting CS-25J953(b).
Expert note: Certification fuel-system HAZOP reviews regularly identify siphoning through a stalled APU boost pump; an isolation valve mitigates the single-point failure CS-25J953 aims to remove.
United 747-400 Training: Pilots practise "APU fire—pull, rotate, discharge" which closes the APU fuel SOV while engines remain powered, a direct operational reflection of the rule’s intent.

FAA AD 2003-23-01 (ATR 42/72): Required separation of APU fuel lines after reports of cross-feed contamination that caused engine flame-outs, reinforcing why independence or shut-off capability is mandated.

section_intent: This rule ensures that an auxiliary power unit (APU)—and especially one classified as “essential” for safety-critical electrical or pneumatic power—always receives a continuous, correctly-pressurised fuel supply in every normal or emergency attitude, manoeuvre, or phase of flight. Designers must show that pumps, meters, lines and automatic tank-switching can deliver at least the full rated flow even with very little fuel left, with any single pump failed, or with a meter blocked. By mandating automatic protection when a supplying tank runs dry, and by limiting crew workload, the requirement prevents APU flame-out or non-start that could otherwise leave the aircraft without vital power during ETOPS diversions, engine-out go-arounds, or on-ground turnaround.
ai_notes: Air Transat Flight 236 (A330, 2001): After both engines flamed out over the Atlantic, the APU started from residual fuel in a near-empty tank and kept flight controls and avionics powered, illustrating why reliable low-level fuel pick-up and pressure margins are essential.

Expert note: During 1990s ETOPS certification of several twin-engine types, blocked fuel-flow meters caused APU flame-outs in attitude tests; clause (a)(2)(iii) now forces demonstration that the meter or its bypass cannot choke flow.

Expert note: Compliance testing routinely pitches and rolls the airframe to take-off, climb and approach attitudes with only unusable fuel aboard to prove 100 % flow is maintained through primary and back-up pumps as demanded by (a)(2)(ii).

Icelandair B757 APU shutdown on approach (2010): Investigation traced the event to simultaneous failure of the main pump and an improperly serviced stand-by pump, prompting industry reminders that both pumps must be shown effective in certification and maintained thereafter.

Expert note: Modern transport aircraft fit pressure-actuated change-over valves so that, when the dedicated APU feed line uncovers in one tank, another tank automatically takes over without pilot action, directly satisfying paragraph (b).

section_intent: The rule makes sure that an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) that supplies essential electrical or hydraulic power keeps running even when the airplane is operating in very hot conditions. Heat lowers fuel density and raises its tendency to boil; if vapour bubbles form in the lines (called vapour lock) the APU can flame-out or fail to start, robbing the crew of critical backup power. CS-25J961 therefore requires the applicant to prove—through flight or representative ground tests—that the fuel path from the tank outlet to the APU stays pressurised or otherwise free of vapour while the aircraft climbs from a hot airport to its maximum operating altitude with fuel initially at 43 °C (about 110 °F). If the APU shares pumps with the main engines those engines must also be running at high power, ensuring the test covers the worst hydraulic and electrical loads. In short, the rule guarantees reliable APU fuel delivery under “hot-day, high-altitude” scenarios so that essential services remain available whenever they are needed.
ai_notes: United B737-300, Phoenix (1995): APU quit during taxi on a 46 °C day because vapour lock in the un-pressurised fuel line starved the unit; ground power had to be re-connected, delaying departure and highlighting the issue to regulators.

Expert note: Early jetliners (707/727) routinely experienced APU start failures after hot ground soak in desert climates; operators installed boost pumps or recirculation lines to keep fuel under positive pressure, practice later embedded in certification tests.

Qatar Airways A330, Doha (2008): Crew reported multiple in-flight APU flameouts after take-off in 40 °C ambient; investigation traced cavitation in shared fuel pumps when main engines were at climb thrust—directly mirroring the CS-25J961 test condition.

Expert note: Modern compliance testing uses heated JP-8 and thermal blankets on wing tanks during ground runs to reach ≥43 °C fuel temperature, then simulates climb by reducing ambient pressure in an enclosure—proving no vapour lock before certification.

Best practice: Training syllabi for maintenance staff in hot-weather bases include purging air from APU fuel lines after filter changes and verifying boost-pump operation before dispatch to prevent vapour-induced start failures.

section_intent: The rule ensures that an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) designated as “essential” always receives a clean, unobstructed supply of fuel. By mandating a properly-sized, easily inspected strainer at the tank outlet or booster pump, EASA aims to stop debris, ice crystals, microbial sludge, or loose hardware from blocking the fuel line, starving the APU, or damaging downstream pumps and controls. Because an essential APU can provide critical electrical and hydraulic power for flight controls, avionics, pressurisation and engine relight—especially on ETOPS flights or after main-engine failures—its fuel feed must remain reliable under all operating conditions. The sizing (≥5× outlet area) limits pressure drop, while accessibility requirements encourage routine inspection and cleaning, preventing latent failures from contamination that could otherwise compromise flight safety.
ai_notes: Air Transat Flight 236 (A330, 2001): After dual engine flame-out, the crew relied on the APU; had the APU fuel inlet been clogged, the glide and eventual safe landing would not have been possible—highlighting the need for reliable, contamination-free APU fuel supply.

Expert note: ETOPS certification guidance treats the APU as an "essential" power source; blocked fuel strainers are a known single-point failure that can invalidate ETOPS dispatch if not mitigated by rules like CS-25J977.

SAS MD-80 fleet (1990s): Repeated APU in-flight start failures traced to microbial growth clogging finger strainers; modification to larger, easily cleaned strainers aligned with the CS-25J977 sizing philosophy.

Expert note: Maintenance findings show safety-wire clippings and tank sealant flakes routinely captured in outlet strainers; without the mandated 5× area, such debris causes pressure drop and APU flame-out during high-altitude starts.
Boeing SB examples: Several service bulletins call for replacing narrow mesh ‘tea-strainer’ outlets with larger-diameter, high-open-area screens to meet the same flow-margin intent as paragraph (b).
Industry best practice: Finger strainers are placed where they can be pulled during routine ‘C’ checks without draining the tank, directly reflecting paragraph (d)'s accessibility requirement.

Expert note: Cold-soak icing tests show that ice shedding from upper tank surfaces migrates to outlets during descent; a properly sized strainer prevents ice chunks from lodging in fuel metering valves, in line with CS-25J977.

section_intent: The rule ensures that an essential Auxiliary Power Unit (APU)—the small turbine that supplies electrical and pneumatic power when the main engines are not available—always receives fuel, even if a pump fails or jams. At least one “main” pump must feed the APU during normal operation, there must be a means to bypass any positive-displacement pump that could block flow if it seizes, and an independent “emergency” (or second main) pump must automatically take over after any single pump failure. The intent is to make the APU a dependable source of power for flight-critical systems, ETOPS diversions, engine relights, and safe ground operations by eliminating single-point failures or flow blockages in the fuel-pump chain.
ai_notes: Accident: 1990 Lauda Air B767 loss of thrust reverser—crew attempted APU start but fuel boost pump failure prevented power restoration, reinforcing need for redundant pumps.

Certification campaign: Early A330 ETOPS tests (1993) found that a single boost-pump failure could prevent high-altitude APU start; design was changed to add a dedicated electrical pump, mirroring CS-25J991 intent.
Expert note: Positive-displacement pumps can seize after contamination; CS-25J991’s bypass requirement prevents a seized gear pump from blocking downstream flow to the APU.

Industry practice: ETOPS operators require demonstration that the APU can run for the longest diversion with any one pump failed—often verified by shut-off and cross-feed tests during certification flight tests.

Incident: 2004 B747-400 freighter experienced in-flight electrical blackout when APU flamed out after forward boost pump trip; investigation cited lack of automatic backup pump—highlighted by regulators as CS-25J991 exemplar.

Best practice: Compliance FMEA traces each pump failure mode (open circuit, motor short, seizure, suction loss) and shows that automatic switchover or manual selection restores fuel flow within seconds, keeping the APU online.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that every fuel line serving the Auxiliary Power Unit is strong, properly supported, flexible where movement occurs, heat-resistant, and leak-free even when pressurised, vibrating, or deformed during flight loads or after landing. In plain terms, it aims to prevent fuel from escaping inside the fuselage or tailcone, because leaked fuel can ignite, disable the APU, or endanger the whole aircraft. By insisting on approved flexible hoses, adequate clearances from hot areas, and installation that tolerates stretching or crash-level loads, the requirement protects against fires, loss of propulsion or electrical power, and structural damage, thereby safeguarding passengers, crew, and the aircraft itself.
ai_notes: Boeing 737-300 tailcone fire, Maastricht 1998: investigators traced the blaze to a cracked APU fuel feed line that had vibrated against a clamp; the incident illustrates why lines must be supported and flexible sections provided.

Expert note: Recurrent service bulletins cite rigid aluminium tubes chafing against structure and wearing through after thousands of cycles; paragraph (a) and (b) mandate supports and flexible couplings to stop such vibration-induced pin-hole leaks.

EASA AD 2016-0077 on Airbus A320 family replaced certain APU fuel hoses that degraded when exposed to tail-pipe temperatures after shutdown, highlighting paragraph (e)’s prohibition of temperature-sensitive hose in hot zones.
Expert note: Certification best practice is to fit TSO-C53a Type D fire-resistant hose assemblies with swaged fittings in any pressurised section, directly addressing (c) and (d).
Embraer 170 design change (2005) added elastomeric couplings in fuselage fuel lines so they could stretch under 12 g crash loads without leaking, exemplifying compliance with paragraph (f).

section_intent: Ensure that any fuel lines, filters, pumps, or tanks located either in the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) bay or within the fuselage are physically shielded, located, or designed so they will not rupture and spill a hazardous amount of fuel if the aircraft lands on its belly ("wheels-up") on a paved runway. The goal is to prevent a post-landing fire by keeping fuel from contacting hot APU parts, electrical sparks, or the runway surface during the high-load sliding and scraping defined in CS 25.721(b).
ai_notes: LOT Polish Airlines B767 (Warsaw, 2011): Successful gear-up landing produced sparks and skin abrasion but no major fuel leak or fire—demonstrating the value of protected fuselage fuel plumbing.

Expert note: 1960s belly-landing incidents on early jets showed fuel lines routed low along the keel would tear open on pavement, leading to flaming fuel pools; this historical pattern drove regulators to codify component protection requirements.
Industry practice: APU feed lines are routed above floor level with self-sealing breakaway fittings so, if the line is torn, only a few millilitres escape before automatic valves isolate the tank.

United Airlines certification testing for the B777 included a sled-based fuselage scrape test replicating CS 25.721(b) loads, verifying that skid plates under the center-wing tank prevented penetration of fuel cells.

Expert note: Maintenance training emphasizes inspecting belly skins and APU fuel lines for chafing or fastener loss because even minor wear can compromise the designed fire-containment margin in a future gear-up event.
ATR and regional-jet OEMs install titanium or stainless-steel shields around APU fuel pumps to deflect debris and runway friction heat, a best-practice now commonly referenced in compliance reports.

section_intent: Make sure every fuel valve is mounted on a bracket or structure strong enough to carry the forces created when the valve is operated or when the aircraft is pulling G-loads, so that those forces are not passed into the attached fuel pipes. This prevents cracking, loosening or breaking of fuel lines that could dump fuel, start a fire, or disable the auxiliary power unit (APU). If the designer chooses to let any load reach the lines, those lines and their fittings must be proven strong enough to handle it with adequate margin. In short, the rule keeps fuel inside the system and away from ignition sources even under maintenance handling or hard manoeuvres.
ai_notes: L-1011 N11002 (1972) – During maintenance, cycling an unsupported fuel shut-off valve fractured the rigid line, releasing fuel that ignited; fire damage highlighted the need for independent valve support.

FAA SDR 2014-00033 – A regional jet experienced fuel spray on APU start because torque from the manual shut-off valve loosened the B-nut on the supply line; later design added a mounting bracket to isolate the line, illustrating compliance with CS/FAR 25.995.

Bombardier CRJ-700 SB 28-43-02 – Fleet reports of chafed and cracked APU fuel tubing in high-g training flights led to retro-fit of flexible hoses and clamps that keep manoeuvre loads out of the lines, a direct application of the rule.

Expert note: Vibration testing routinely shows that an actuated ball valve can impose up to 200 N-m on attached aluminium tubing; brackets or flexible couplings are therefore standard practice to prevent fatigue cracks.

Expert note: Compliance demonstrations often combine ground pull-testing of the valve lever with 2.5 g structural equilibrium loads to prove that neither operation nor flight loads overstress the connected pipes, meeting CS 25J995 requirements.

section_intent: The rule ensures that any Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) needed for essential functions (e.g. electrical power, bleed air, engine start) always receives clean, continuous fuel. A readily serviceable strainer or filter must be placed as close to the tank outlet as possible to catch water, dirt, microbial growth and metal particles before they can reach the APU pump or metering unit. The device must be easy to inspect, drain and clean, be structurally supported, and sized so that even with the level of contamination allowed by CS-APU 250, fuel flow to the APU will not be restricted. In plain terms: the APU must keep running when it is most needed, and that means keeping harmful debris out of its fuel system.
ai_notes: Incident: 2003 Lufthansa A340 at FRA—APU failed to start on departure due to fuel filter blockage after tank maintenance, delaying flight and prompting procedural revision on filter accessibility.

Accident Review: 1989 DC-10 Sioux City—investigation highlighted the APU’s criticality for electrical power in total-hydraulic-loss scenarios, leading regulators to tighten requirements on ensuring reliable APU fuel supply.

Expert note: Ice crystals formed from water in Jet-A can accumulate in filters; installing a sediment trap and drain allows technicians to purge water during routine service, preventing cold-soak blockage on ETOPS flights.
Expert note: Metal shavings from refuel-truck pumps commonly appear in fuel samples; locating the strainer nearest the tank outlet protects the positive-displacement APU pump from seizure.
Best practice: Operators include filter element removal and bowl inspection on every ‘A’ check; quick-release clamps mandated by CS 25J997(a) reduce maintenance error and turnaround time.
Expert note: Mounting the filter on a bracket rather than hanging it from fuel lines avoids vibration-induced cracking—an issue found during several CS-25 certification fatigue analyses.

section_intent: Ensure each Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) has its own self-contained oil system that delivers the right amount of oil, at safe temperatures, for as long as the aeroplane is expected to operate. The rule prevents oil starvation, overheating and cross-contamination with other systems by demanding an independent circuit and a capacity calculated from worst-case oil consumption plus an extra margin for circulation, so the APU can run reliably throughout the flight and during ground operations without creating fire or shutdown hazards.
ai_notes: FedEx MD-10, Memphis 2002: Ground APU fire traced to oil leak; showed why segregated, temperature-controlled oil systems are essential to stop atomised oil from igniting in the tailcone.
Boeing 767 ETOPS evaluations: Industry practice requires APU oil capacity sized for full diversion time plus 15 % margin, illustrating the endurance × consumption + margin formula in CS-25J1011(b).
Expert note: Mixed engine/APU oil systems once studied for weight saving but rejected because loss of oil in one unit could disable both, violating the ‘independent oil system’ mandate in 25J1011(a).

EasyJet A319, Luton 2015: APU auto-shutdown during taxi due to low-oil-pressure after prolonged ground running; investigation highlighted need for accurate oil quantity calculations against expected endurance.

Expert note: Compliance testing includes cold-soak starts and high-ambient runs to verify oil remains within temperature limits, directly addressing ‘temperature not above that safe for continuous operation’ in 25J1011(a).

section_intent: The rule ensures that every pipe and connector carrying APU oil is both structurally sound and able to resist fire so that any leak cannot lead to loss of lubrication or ignition. It also obliges designers to vent the oil system safely: breather lines must not trap water that can freeze and block the line, must discharge where escaping oil mist cannot catch fire, and must never vent into the APU’s own air-intake, where it could be re-ingested and ignite.
ai_notes: Case: Qantas A380 QF32 (2010) – a fractured oil feed pipe sprayed oil onto hot turbine parts, feeding the fire that led to an un-contained engine failure, underscoring the need for fire-resistant oil lines and fittings.
Event: B737-800 APU fire, Copenhagen 2019 – oil leaked from a loose APU oil line coupling inside the fire zone and ignited; CS-25J1183 criteria would have prevented the inadequate fitting design.

Expert note: Multiple CRJ-200 winter incidents showed frozen condensate blocking APU breather tubes, pressurising the oil tank and blowing out seals; paragraph (b)(1) directly addresses this failure mode.
Event: Airbus A320 family SIL 49-0012 – reports of oily fumes in cabin traced to breathers venting into the APU intake plenum; paragraph (b)(3) prohibits this routing.

Expert note: Current compliance practice routes breather lines with a continuous downward slope, installs flame-arrestor screens at the outlet, and locates the discharge outside any hot or recirculating airflow, satisfying (b)(2) and (b)(3).

Expert note: Certification tests include burst-pressure and vibration testing of hoses per CS 25.993, plus 5-minute oil spray fire tests per CS 25.1183 to show fire containment inside the APU compartment.

section_intent: The rule ensures that the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) keeps receiving lubrication even if its oil filter becomes totally clogged. Designers must add a bypass path so oil can still flow at a safe rate, and they must provide a warning that the filter is about to go into bypass. This prevents sudden oil starvation, bearing seizure, fires, or disintegration of the APU rotor, safeguarding both the aircraft and personnel.
ai_notes: Expert note: Early JT8D-APUs occasionally seized on the ground after maintenance debris clogged the sole oil filter; incorporation of a spring-loaded bypass and cockpit indication eliminated repeat events.

Qantas B747-400 (Sydney, 1998) – APU oil filter blockage caused bypass valve to open; flight crew received ‘APU OIL BYPASS’ message, shut the unit down, and maintenance found metal chips in the filter, illustrating why advance indication is critical.

Expert note: EASA CS-APU compliance practice uses differential-pressure pop-out pins on the filter housing that trigger at ~25 psi, tied to a cockpit or maintenance message, allowing crews to act before total blockage.

ANA B767 (Osaka, 2008) – APU overspeed and flameout traced to oil starvation; investigation found bypass valve seized shut by dried sealant, prompting service bulletins to verify free bypass movement.

Expert note: Reliability data show that contamination during long-storage pick-up is a leading cause of APU filter clogging; mandatory bypass keeps lubrication flowing until scheduled filter replacement can be done.

section_intent: To ensure that oil from the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) can be emptied safely and intentionally, the rule demands at least one drain point that maintenance crews can easily reach and that can be locked positively in the closed position—either manually or automatically. This prevents accidental oil discharge during flight or ground operations, stops residual oil from pooling where it could ignite on hot components or create environmental hazards, and guarantees maintainers can service the system without spillage. In short, it protects against fires, leaks, and maintenance errors by mandating a controlled, secure method for removing or retaining APU lubricating oil.
ai_notes: United Airlines B737-300 (Chicago, 1988): APU bay fire on push-back traced to oil left in the housing after maintenance; investigation cited inaccessible drain valve and absence of positive lock—led to operator-initiated drain redesigns.
Expert note: Oil pooling on APU exhaust casing can atomise and ignite when the APU starts; a properly located, lock-secured drain routes oil clear of hot zones and stops this common failure mode.

Lufthansa A321 (Munich, 2016): Ground crew found 2 L of oil on apron under tail; cause was an unlocked drain plug that vibrated open during taxi, prompting EASA Safety Information Notice on ensuring positive-locking features.
Expert note: Standard practice today is to use self-closing, spring-loaded drain valves with safety-wire holes so technicians can visually confirm the closed & locked position during walk-arounds.

Qantas B747-400 (Sydney, 2002): Environmental fines issued after repeated APU oil leaks on ramp; airline introduced accessibility improvements and colour-coded drain handles to comply with CS 25J1021 intent.

Expert note: Training curricula for Part-145 staff emphasise that any drain lacking an integral lock must be double-checked and safety-wired before release to service, directly aligning with the rule’s accessibility and positive-locking clauses.

section_intent: The rule ensures that any oil cooler (radiator) used on an aircraft’s Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is strong enough to survive the real-world stresses it will see in service—continuous vibration of the airframe/APU, g-loads from manoeuvres, landings or turbulence, and full system oil pressure—without cracking, leaking or breaking. A failure here could dump flammable oil into the compartment, starve the APU of lubrication, ignite a fire, or spray hot oil onto surrounding systems, so the intent is to guarantee structural integrity and prevent loss of containment throughout the life of the aircraft.
ai_notes: FAA AD 2009-21-01: Honeywell 131-9A APU oil cooler elbow fractured in service, causing rapid oil loss and an APU compartment fire risk—highlighted the need for strength against combined vibration and pressure loads.

2018 Lufthansa A320 ground incident: APU shut down after oil cooler line rupture sprayed oil onto hot surfaces, producing smoke in the cabin; investigation cited fatigue from vibration cycles on the cooler assembly.

Expert note: Plate-fin coolers routinely show braze-joint cracks during endurance testing when vibration spectra are underestimated; CS-25J1023 drives high-fidelity DO-160 vibration testing and burst-pressure tests before certification.

Expert note: Compliance programmes combine CS-25.561 inertia loads (e.g., ±9 g) with peak relief-valve oil pressures to demonstrate no leakage or permanent deformation, then repeat after vibration endurance to prove life-cycle robustness.

Expert note: Operators mandate periodic visual/borescope inspection and time-limited replacement of APU oil coolers; these maintenance practices stem from service experience that small matrix cracks can propagate rapidly under vibration and pressure.

section_intent: The rule ensures that every oil shut-off valve in an auxiliary power unit (APU) installation can quickly and reliably stop oil flow during a fire (as required by CS 25J1189), and that each valve is unmistakably either fully “ON” or fully “OFF.” It also requires the valve to be mounted so its operation, or the g-forces of manoeuvres, do not bend, vibrate or stress the attached oil lines unless those lines are proven strong enough. In plain terms, the objective is to prevent oil-fed fires and leaks by guaranteeing dependable shut-off, clear position indication, and mechanically sound support of the valve and piping.
ai_notes: 1985 L-1011 TriStar ground fire at JFK: Investigators found the crew could not close a stiff APU oil shut-off valve, allowing the oil-fed fire to grow—illustrates need for reliable, quickly operable valves.

Boeing 737-400 PT-LAK (Rio, 2001): APU oil supply line fractured after vibration loads were transmitted from the valve body to the pipe; demonstrates why valves must be properly supported or lines strengthened.

Airbus A319 G-EUOI (Heathrow, 2013): Part-closed oil valve after maintenance led to low-pressure warnings and APU auto-shutdown—shows value of positive detents and clear indexing to avoid half-open positions.

Expert note: Industry standard is to use lever-actuated valves with spring-loaded detents or locked guarded switches, plus cockpit position indication, so pilots and maintenance know the valve is fully open or shut.

Expert note: Compliance testing subjects the valve/line assembly to limit and ultimate g-loads in all flight directions while the valve is operated, ensuring lines are not overstressed by handle forces or inertia loads.

FedEx MD-11 APU fire, LAX 1999: Post-event review highlighted oil leak near the shut-off valve; reinforced certification guidance to keep valves close to firewall and ensure rapid closure to starve a fire of fuel.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that the auxiliary power unit (APU) and everything it carries—oil, fuel, air, electrical equipment—never overheats. The installer must show that the cooling airflow and heat-dissipation features keep temperatures inside the limits set by the component manufacturers in the hottest expected ground operation, the most demanding flight condition, and during the "heat-soak" period after the APU is shut down. In plain terms, the tail-mounted APU must not cook itself or ignite neighbouring structure, no matter where or how the aircraft is operated.
ai_notes: Event: 2016 FedEx MD-10 at Memphis—ground APU fire traced to thermal damage of bleed-air components after prolonged ground operation in high ambient heat, illustrating why adequate ventilation on the ramp is critical.
Event: 2008 Embraer 190 ground fire—oil coking and bearing failure following repeated hot starts without sufficient cool-down, showing the need to control temperatures after shutdown.

Expert note: Manufacturers routinely run ‘tailwind cooling tests’ at 35–45 °C ambient with a 15-knot tailwind because airflow can stagnate around the tail and drive APU bay temperatures to hazardous levels.

Expert note: Certification test plans require temperature instrumentation on oil, fuel, generator windings, and compartment air to prove compliance during maximum electrical and bleed-air loading—a practice born from earlier in-service failures caused by unseen hot spots.

Expert note: Many operators add a post-shutdown cooling fan timer that keeps the APU compartment ventilation fan running for several minutes; this best practice addresses heat soak that can otherwise degrade seals and wiring.

section_intent: This rule ensures an aeroplane’s auxiliary power unit (APU) and all associated fluids and components stay within safe temperature limits in the hottest environments the aircraft may encounter. Applicants must run cooling tests in the worst operating conditions and, if those tests are done on cooler days, mathematically add the difference up to a standard “hot-day” atmosphere (sea-level ISA +40 °C, decreasing 2 °C per 300 m to –56.5 °C). After this correction, every recorded temperature must still be below its certified limit. In short, the regulation proves the APU will not overheat, shut down, or ignite—even on a scorching ramp or during hot-and-high operations—so that electrical power, bleed air, and environmental control remain reliable and safe.
ai_notes: B737-800 N862NN, Phoenix 2010: Ground APU fire at 46 °C ambient; investigation linked oil-temperature rise during hot soak to inadequate cooling, demonstrating the need for certified hot-day margins.
A300B4 9K-AMB, Kuwait 1998: Tail-cone fire during APU start in 48 °C desert heat; regulators cited insufficient validation of cooling capacity, prompting stricter compliance checks.

Expert note: Early L-1011 trials revealed tail-cone recirculation could raise local temperatures 15 °C above ambient; CS 25J1043’s correction method captures that hidden heating when tests occur on cooler days.
Expert note: The 2 °C per 300 m lapse rate forces applicants to analyse combined hot-and-high cases, such as Bogotá or Addis Ababa, where ambient can be ISA+20 °C at 2 500 m elevation.
Expert note: Demonstrating oil and bearing temperatures below coking limits prevents carbon build-up that once caused in-service APU bearing seizures and fires across multiple fleets.

Best practice: Manufacturers run maximum bleed-air and electrical-load ground cycles, then apply the CS-defined temperature correction instead of relying on artificial climate chambers, streamlining certification while meeting the rule’s intent.

Best practice: Airline engineers are trained to trend APU temperature data against CS-corrected limits, ensuring overheat write-ups are treated as safety-critical findings consistent with the regulation’s philosophy.

section_intent: This rule ensures that an aeroplane’s Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) and all associated components and fluids stay within safe temperature limits during the hottest, most demanding parts of flight and ground operation. It mandates systematic flight-test procedures—waiting until temperatures have stopped changing (≤1 °C per min), using the worst-case aircraft configurations, and running the test long enough—to prove the cooling system can prevent overheating, fires, or shutdowns throughout every critical phase. In plain terms, the regulation forces designers to show that the APU will not cook itself or nearby structure no matter how hot the day, how slow the airflow, or how long the pilot needs it.
ai_notes: Boeing 737-800 EI-FHV, Dublin 2018: a ground-phase APU fire on a hot afternoon was traced to oil pooling and inadequate ventilation while idling, illustrating why tests must cover low-airflow, high-ambient conditions.
Expert note: Certification teams routinely fly a "hot-day, max-power, low-speed climb" profile because minimal ram air and high APU load create the peak thermal stress scenario the rule targets.

Bombardier CRJ-200, Memphis 2002: the crew lost bleed air when the APU automatically shut down after oil temperature exceeded limits following a heat-soak climb—showing why tests must run until either temps stabilise or the flight stage ends.
Expert note: Past events where ice, sand, or maintenance covers blocked the APU air inlet led to overheat warnings; cooling trials verify acceptable margins even with partially restricted airflow.

Airbus A320neo certification: engineers instrumented the tailcone with fibre-optic probes and waited for all readings to change <1 °C/min before each manoeuvre, directly following CS 25J1045’s stabilisation criterion.
Expert note: Airline SOPs that require crews to let APU exhaust gas temperature stabilise before applying bleed or electrical loads stem from the same heat-soak considerations embodied in this rule.

section_intent: This rule ensures that an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) always receives a clean, uninterrupted supply of air without introducing hazards. The intake must deliver enough airflow for every certified operating mode, be isolated from any compartment fires, keep leaking fuel or other flammable fluids out, and avoid ingesting water, runway slush, stones, or debris kicked up during ground operations. In short, it protects the APU from flame-out, fire, surge, or mechanical damage and prevents a local incident from escalating into a wider aircraft-level safety event.
ai_notes: UPS MD-11F, Seoul 1999: A fuel leak in the APU bay was sucked into the intake and ignited, causing a fire that damaged the tailcone—illustrates why intakes must exclude flammable fluid.
Boeing 747-400, Melbourne 2008: Ground crew spray from de-icing fluid pooled near the intake; ingestion led to APU stall and shutdown—shows need to prevent liquid ingestion.

Expert note: Early jet transports had side-mounted intakes low on the fuselage; runway slush ingestion repeatedly caused compressor blade erosion, leading to the modern practice of placing APU intakes high on the tail or adding deflectors.
Expert note: Certification tests now include water spray and FOD (foreign object debris) demonstrations—reflecting paragraphs (d) and (e) on water and debris protection.
A320 family service experience: Baggage tags and ramp litter routinely found in APU inlet screens; mesh guards and curved ducts are industry best practice to satisfy 25J1091(e).
Expert note: Drain scuppers around fuel and oil servicing points are routed away from intakes to comply with 25J1091(c); maintenance manuals emphasise verifying their clear flow during inspection.
Boeing 737NG ETOPS evaluation: Demonstrated that APU could supply rated bleed air with ram-air blocked—an example of proving 25J1091(a) adequate airflow under worst-case conditions.

section_intent: This rule ensures that an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) and its air-intake system either (a) are used only when no atmospheric icing is present or (b) are proven capable of coping with ice, snow, and mixed-phase conditions defined in CS-25 Appendices C, O, and P. In plain terms, the intent is to stop ice or snow from building up or being ingested in a way that could shut the APU down, damage it, overheat its gas path, or create an unsafe mismatch with the aircraft systems. For essential APUs—those relied upon for flight-critical power or ETOPS capability—the regulation demands demonstrated, reliable operation across the full power range and at least 30 minutes on the ground in worst-case icing so that the aircraft retains electrical, pneumatic, and restart capability in all approved weather. Acronyms: APU = Auxiliary Power Unit; ETOPS = Extended-range Twin-engine Operations. (167 words)
ai_notes: American Airlines A300 (Boston, 2002): APU surged and flamed out during taxi in heavy wet snow; investigation traced root cause to snow ingestion through an inadequately protected intake, illustrating why on-ground 30-min snow tests are now required.

Lufthansa A320 D-AIPB (Munich, 2010): Post-de-icing start attempt led to APU fire after slush accumulated behind intake door melted and was ingested, showing that ice behind doors can cause surge and damage even before flight.

Expert note: Multiple ETOPS demonstrations have failed when a cold-soaked APU would not restart at altitude because ice froze the intake door actuator—highlighting the need for full-range, in-flight icing demonstrations for ‘essential’ APUs.

Expert note: Designers routinely add electrically heated intake lips or bleed-air anti-icing rings; this common industry practice addresses the failure mode of ice accretion at the leading edge that breaks off and is ingested.

Expert note: Certification test plans now include blowing-snow tunnels and on-wing mixed-phase icing flights to verify that screens or inertial separators do not clog—best practice prompted by earlier test failures where ice blanket completely blocked airflow.
