Boeing 787 certification (2011): 30-minute ground snow ingestion test revealed unacceptable gas-path temperature rise; redesign of the APU plenum and drain paths was required, underscoring the rule’s focus on preventing both power loss and overheating.

section_intent: This rule makes sure the ducts that feed air to the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) do not become a source of fire or structural failure. They must drain away any fuel, oil, or water that could pool and ignite; be made from materials that will not soak up flammable liquids; withstand hot gas back-flow if the APU coughs, surges, or the inlet door slams shut; and stay flexible where the airframe moves so they do not crack. In short, the ducts must keep fire out of the airplane and keep the APU breathing safely under every operating and failure condition.
ai_notes: Delta Air Lines B-737-800, Atlanta 2005: pooled jet fuel in the APU intake plenum ignited during start, scorching the tailcone; drains added and material changed to meet CS 25J1103 intent.
Swissair MD-11, Zurich 2002: APU surge blew hot gases upstream, burning through non-fire-proof composite duct sections; the event drove tighter fireproof distance requirements in later designs.

Expert note: Certification tests now include deliberate APU surge with reversed flow to verify that upstream metal ducts stay intact and keep flames inside the APU bay, directly reflecting 25J1103(b)(2).
Industry practice: Intake plenums are fitted with ‘weeping’ drain holes and dedicated drain lines routed clear of wheel wells and APU exhaust to satisfy 25J1103(a)(1).

Expert note: Designers insert stainless-steel or Ti fireproof sections up to the first structural bulkhead, then switch to lighter composites, balancing weight and the heat-resistance mandate in 25J1103(b).
Expert note: Bellows or flexible couplings are installed between the intake duct and fuselage frames to absorb tail-cone flex on take-off/landing, preventing fatigue cracks per 25J1103(c).

section_intent: The rule makes sure that pressurised ‘bleed’ air taken from the auxiliary power unit (APU) cannot endanger the aircraft if a duct breaks, shifts or is exposed to abnormal flow. Hot, high-energy bleed air must be contained or automatically shut off so it cannot start a fire, overheat structure, introduce fumes into the cabin or disable critical systems. Duct runs have to include flexible sections wherever the APU or engines can move relative to the fuselage to avoid fatigue cracks, and check- or isolation-valves must stop engine bleed pressure from forcing air backwards through the APU, which can overspeed or ignite it. In short, the paragraph demands design features that turn any single duct, joint or valve failure into a benign event for passengers and crew.
ai_notes: Little Rock MD-88 smoke event (USA, 2008): A chafed APU bleed duct burned insulation and filled the cabin with smoke, illustrating why designers now double-wall ducts and add overheat detectors in accordance with 25J1106(a).

Expert note: Most manufacturers route APU bleed lines through titanium or stainless ‘fire zones’ with automatic shut-off valves so that a rupture releases hot air to an area that is already fire-protected and isolated from critical controls.

Boeing 747-400 ground fire, Hong Kong 2012: Reverse flow from an engine bleed manifold into the running APU caused an APU surge and tailpipe fire; modern designs incorporate non-return valves to comply with 25J1106(c).

Expert note: Flexible bellows or braided hoses are installed between the wing/fuselage manifold and engine pylons so that normal engine-to-fuselage movement during flight cannot crack rigid ducts, fulfilling 25J1106(b).

B737-300 ‘smoke in cabin’ diversion, Honolulu 2010: A failed coupling in an APU bleed line allowed 450 °C air to escape under the cabin floor, melting wiring looms—direct evidence that the rule’s ‘no-hazard after duct failure’ clause has operational relevance.

section_intent: Ensure that the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) exhaust system disposes of hot gases in a way that never endangers occupants or structure: no carbon-monoxide can seep into occupied areas, no leaking fuel, oil, or hydraulic fluid can be ignited on hot exhaust surfaces, surrounding parts are protected by fire-proof shielding, discharge paths avoid any flammable vents or drains, and adequate ventilation or insulation keeps temperatures below ignition thresholds throughout normal operation.
ai_notes: Boeing 737-800 Antalya ground fire (2010): leaking jet fuel sprayed onto the hot APU exhaust pipe during engine start, igniting a tail-cone fire—illustrates why flammable-fluid leaks must be kept away from exhaust parts (25J1121(b)/(d)).

United Airlines 727 cabin-odour incident (2003): cracked APU exhaust duct allowed carbon-monoxide-laden gases to enter the environmental-control-system intake, causing crew illness—shows need for tight exhaust routing and CO tests (25J1121(a)).

Embraer ERJ-145 tail-cone fire on ramp (1998): hydraulic fluid pooled in the tail bay and was ignited by hot exhaust gas, demonstrating the requirement for fireproof shielding and proper drainage (25J1121(c)).

Expert note: Certification teams routinely wrap exhaust ducts in stainless-steel blankets and add titanium shields between ducts and nearby wiring bundles to meet the fireproof-separation mandate of 25J1121(c).

Expert note: Compliance testing includes thermocouple mapping and forced-air flow checks around the APU exhaust shroud to prove that no local hot spot exceeds ignition limits, satisfying the ventilation clauses 25J1121(f)/(g).

Expert note: Operators train maintenance staff to perform CO-sniffer checks in the cabin after exhaust-system repairs, a best practice derived from multiple CO-ingress service difficulty reports relevant to 25J1121(a).

section_intent: Ensure that the auxiliary power unit (APU) exhaust pipe stays intact and leak-free throughout the aircraft’s life so that extremely hot, corrosive gases are safely routed overboard without starting a fire, damaging nearby systems, or detaching in flight. The rule demands materials that can survive high temperature and corrosion, design features (e.g., expansion joints) that accommodate thermal growth, robust supports that resist vibration and g-loads, and flexible connections where parts move relative to each other. In short, it protects the aircraft structure, systems, and occupants from hazards created by failure of the APU exhaust piping.
ai_notes: Airbus A320 (D-AIPY, 2010): Ground fire traced to cracked APU tailpipe that let 600 °C gases impinge on rear fuselage insulation—illustrates why heat-resistant, fatigue-resistant pipe and proper supports are vital.

Boeing 767 (JA8361, Kansai 2006): APU exhaust duct separated after weld fatigue from vibration; fragments punctured control-cable run—shows the need for supports sized for vibration and inertia loads.

Expert note: Stainless/Inconel bellows or flex couplings are routinely installed between the APU and fixed ducting to absorb 10–20 mm of thermal growth and prevent stress cracks described in service difficulty reports.

Expert note: Corrosion pitting from de-icing fluid spray was a common finding on early carbon-steel tailpipes; industry switched to high-nickel alloys and added protective drain paths to meet the ‘corrosion-resistant’ mandate.

Delta maintenance alert (2015): Multiple 737NGs found with loose exhaust pipe hangers after repeated hard landings—demonstrates the rule’s requirement that supports handle inertia loads throughout the life of the aircraft.

Best practice: Design reviews include modal analysis of the exhaust duct/hanger system to ensure natural frequencies stay clear of APU rotor speeds, mitigating vibration-induced fatigue failures targeted by CS 25J1123(b).

section_intent: Ensure that the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) can be started, stopped and shut down instantly and reliably from the flight deck (and any remote panel) without risking inadvertent operation, jammed or vibrating controls, or fire-zone failures. Controls must be clearly marked, robust, stay where set, and give the crew unambiguous feedback on valve positions. Because APUs often run while no crew member is watching them (e.g. during taxi or on the ground), the system must automatically cut fuel and bleed air if a limit is exceeded, a hazardous condition or fire develops, or a bleed duct ruptures, so that a single failure cannot escalate into a fire or loss of aircraft services.
ai_notes: Lauda Air B767 OE-LRB, Vienna 2001: Ramp fire contained when automatic APU shutdown extinguished a fuel-fed fire after a bleed-air over-temperature, illustrating why unattended-operation protections are mandated.

Expert note: Numerous SDRs show flexible push-pull cables driving cockpit APU start switches creeping under vibration, causing uncommanded starts; the rule’s ‘no creep’ and strength requirements target this mode.

Southwest Airlines B737-300, Chicago Midway 2005: Ground mechanic injured by unexpected APU spool-up after brushing a poorly guarded external start switch—drives the placement and inadvertent-operation clauses.
Expert note: Bleed-duct burst tests during certification often reveal that a 600 °C jet can burn insulation in seconds; auto-shutdown on duct failure prevents cockpit smoke and structural damage.

MD-11F FedEx N595FE, Newark 1998: Flight crew received ‘APU FIRE’ light while taxiing; automatic fuel-shutoff and cockpit fire handle allowed safe stop without evacuation, validating requirements for fire-zone-rated controls and automatic isolation.

section_intent: This rule ensures that everything bolted onto an Auxiliary Power Unit (APU)—such as generators, pumps or starters—is both mechanically compatible and safe. Approved accessories must use the APU’s own attachment points, ignition-prone electrical parts must be kept away from any free fuel or vapour that could ignite, and for APUs considered essential to flight the design must stop a failed accessory from free-wheeling or seizing in a way that would jeopardise continued APU operation. In plain terms: mount it right, keep sparks away from fuel, and make sure one broken accessory cannot cripple an APU that the crew may need for vital power or bleed air.
ai_notes: Qantas B747-400 VH-OJM (Sydney, 2013): fuel leaked onto the APU starter-generator; arcing ignited a tail-cone fire during boarding—illustrates why sparking equipment must be isolated from flammable fluids.

Expert note: Several early 737-Classic incidents where a failed constant-speed drive kept rotating after internal failure led to gearbox overheating; industry responded with shear-shaft/clutch devices now required under paragraph (c).

Learjet 60 N999LJ (2008) post-maintenance ground run: improperly approved hydraulic pump caused mounting lug failure and APU vibration—shows the need for accessory approval and correct use of APU mounting provisions.

Expert note: Drip-shields and vented fuel manifolds in modern APU bays are standard compliance practices to ensure any fuel spray cannot reach high-energy electrical connectors, directly addressing paragraph (b).

Expert note: Certification test plans now include "seized accessory" endurance runs; designers must prove that if a generator rotor locks, the APU torque limiter or clutch disengages without interrupting essential electrical output.

section_intent: Ensure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) can always be lit and kept burning, even if other aircraft electrical systems fail or short-circuit. By mandating that the APU’s ignition wiring, power supply and protective devices are self-contained—except for minimal circuits that manage or monitor the ignition—the rule prevents cascade failures, uncommanded shutdowns, or ignition-related fires that could leave the aircraft without electrical, pneumatic or bleed-air support during critical phases on the ground or in flight.
ai_notes: AD 2009-18-05 (Honeywell 331 APU): Required segregation of igniter and starter cables after in-service reports of chafing that caused shorts and automatic APU shutdowns, illustrating why ignition circuits must be isolated.

Expert note: Certification test plans routinely include a ‘single-wire fault’ assessment to verify that a bus fault in cabin lighting, galley power or IFE cannot disable APU ignition, directly reflecting this rule.
2015 FAA SAIB NE-15-15: Warned operators that installing cabin-mod power taps on an APU ignition feeder had led to blown fuses and no-start events during ETOPS dispatch checks.

Expert note: Ground fire investigations have traced arcing in shared harness bundles (fuel-pump + igniter leads) to fuel-rich environments in the tailcone; dedicated ignition routing removes this ignition source.

UPS 757-200F N461UP (Louisville, 2012): APU failed to relight after an electrical bus fault; the incident report recommended wiring independence to keep ignition available for emergency pneumatic supply.

Best practice: Major OEMs mount APU igniter exciter boxes on isolated brackets with dedicated power from the hot battery bus and independent circuit protection, satisfying the ‘no common mode’ intent of CS 25J1165.

section_intent: The rule declares the auxiliary power-unit (APU) compartment a “designated fire zone”, meaning designers must provide the same level of fire detection, containment, extinguishing and isolation features required for engines and other fire-critical areas (CS 25J1185–1203). The objective is to ensure that any fire originating in or around the APU—an engine running unattended in the tail during ground and flight phases—will be rapidly detected, prevented from spreading to the structure or systems, and suppressed so that the aircraft and its occupants remain safe.
ai_notes: Expert note: APU oil- or fuel-fed fires have historically occurred during start or shutdown when excess fuel pools in the exhaust plenum and ignites, demonstrating why automatic detection and extinguishing are mandatory.
Real event: 28 May 1987, Aer Lingus B737-200 at Dublin—uncontained APU fire on the ground caused severe tailplane damage; effective fire-zone design would have limited structural harm.
Expert note: Bleed-air duct failures can spray hot air onto flammable insulation in the APU bay; treating the bay as a fire zone obliges use of fire-proof linings and segregated wiring bundles.
Industry practice: Two independent fire-loop detectors and a dedicated fire bottle with automatic fuel-shutoff valves are standard in compliance with CS 25J1185–1199.

Training best practice: Flight crews rehearse APU fire drills that mirror engine-fire checklists—confirming master warning, arming the bottle, shutting bleed and fuel valves—because the compartment is certified as a designated fire zone.

section_intent: This rule makes sure that every pipe, hose, fitting or other part that carries fuel, oil, hydraulic fluid or other flammable liquids in the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) compartment—or any other zone formally classed as a “fire zone”—can survive a fire long enough to avoid rupturing and feeding the flames. Items that merely need to resist heat must be “fire-resistant”; anything whose failure could spill fluid, spread fire to other parts of the airplane, or disable essential systems must be “fireproof.” The regulation also requires smart placement or shielding so that any fluid that might leak cannot be ignited by nearby hot spots. Overall, the intent is to stop a small APU fire from turning into a catastrophic airplane fire or from knocking out critical services needed to fly and land safely.
ai_notes: Embraer 190, Melbourne 2006: A fractured fuel line in the tail APU bay ignited on start-up, forcing an emergency evacuation; fire-resistant lines and shielding mandated by CS 25J1183 aim to prevent such leaks from feeding a fire.

American Airlines MD-80, St. Louis 1993: Hydraulic line burst inside the APU compartment sprayed flammable fluid onto hot surfaces, starting a fire that damaged control cables—illustrates why components in fire zones must be fireproof if their failure can disable essential equipment.

Expert note: Industry hoses in APU bays are typically stainless-steel braided PTFE with an external fire sleeve tested to AS1055D 15-minute flame exposure, directly matching the "fire-resistant" and "fire-proof" performance levels referenced by CS-25J1183.

Expert note: Best-practice design routes APU fuel supply lines above drip-trays, uses self-sealing flareless fittings, and adds stainless shields under joints so any leak drains clear of ignition sources.

Boeing 737-300 tail fire, Salt Lake City 1998: Leaking APU oil line ignited; subsequent fleet modification added fireproof shrouds and rerouted vent lines exempted under 25J1183(b)(2), underscoring the clause’s limits.

Expert note: During certification, manufacturers run a fire test where burners at 1100 °C are applied to representative line sections for 5 min (fire-resistant) or 15 min (fire-proof) while pressurized with fluid to prove compliance with this paragraph.

section_intent: The rule aims to prevent auxiliary-power-unit (APU) bay fires from being intensified or sustained by the presence of flammable liquids. If any fuel, oil, or hydraulic reservoir must sit inside a designated fire zone, its design (materials, shut-off valves, plumbing, controls) must make it at least as safe as if it were located outside the zone. A minimum 12.7 mm air gap between the reservoir and any firewall keeps heat away and allows visual inspection, while prohibiting untreated absorbent materials stops leaked fluids from soaking in and becoming a secondary fuel source. In short, the requirement seeks to eliminate ignition sources, limit fire spread, and maintain crew/passenger safety even if a leak occurs inside the APU compartment.
ai_notes: Boeing 727 Service History (1970s): Several tail-cone fires were traced to hydraulic reservoir leaks inside the APU bay; heat from the running APU ignited the spray, prompting ADs that relocated or shielded the reservoirs—directly reflected in today’s ‘equal safety’ wording.

Expert note: Modern designs route most hydraulic reservoirs outside the APU compartment and use fire-resistant Skydrol; where relocation is impossible, titanium tanks with internal shut-off valves and fire-proof fittings are used to meet the rule.

Certification ground test (regional jet, mid-1990s): Fuel-spray caught in untreated sound-damping foam during a fire-containment test, causing sustained flame beyond the 5-minute limit; engineers added foil-faced blankets, demonstrating why absorbent materials must be covered or treated.

Ryanair B737-800 EI-DYG (Stansted, 2006): Post-landing APU start led to tailpipe fire when leaked oil pooled near the unit; investigation highlighted the value of maintaining the mandated 12.7 mm clearance for inspection and cleaning to prevent fluid accumulation.

Expert note: Compliance checklists require installers to verify the air gap with feeler gauges and to document that no BMS 8-39 insulation blanket is left exposed near fuel or oil fittings, embedding the rule in routine production and maintenance training.

section_intent: This rule ensures that any compartment around the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) that is classified as a fire zone cannot become a reservoir for leaking fuel, oil, or vapours and that airflow will not make a fire worse or let it spread to other areas. Designers must provide positive drainage paths to carry leaked fluids safely overboard, size and locate ventilation so vapours do not build up, and position vents so flames or fluids from neighbouring zones cannot enter. Ventilation must also be shut-off-able so that, once a fire is detected, airflow does not dilute extinguishing agent or feed the fire. Overall, the aim is to prevent ignition, limit fire growth, protect adjacent structure and systems, and preserve the crew’s ability to extinguish a fire in the APU bay.
ai_notes: UPS B747-400F Dubai 2010: Fire intensified when hot gases migrated through ventilation openings; highlighted need to isolate fire zones and prevent flame path communication.

FedEx MD-11 N612FE (Memphis, 2001): APU fuel line leak pooled in tailcone; inadequate drainage allowed sustained tail fire on the ground, demonstrating why positive drains and overboard dump lines are required.
Expert note: Most OEMs now slope APU bay floors toward dedicated scuppers connected to flame-proof drains, preventing puddling underneath hot turbine cases.

Expert note: Approval testing routinely repeats extinguishing‐agent concentration tests with forced ventilation on and off, validating the requirement to allow crews to stop fans or ram-air in flight.
B737 Classic APU compartment fires in the 1990s showed that oil mist accumulation ignited on start; redesign added larger louvre vents and improved sealing so vapours could not reach hot bleed ducts.

Industry practice: Electrical wiring routed through fire zones is jacketed and kept above drain paths to reduce the chance of fluid wicking along harnesses and creating secondary ignition points, fulfilling 25J1187(a)(2).
Training best practice: Maintenance personnel are taught to verify that drain lines are clear of sealant and insect nests during A-checks, because blocked drains negate the intent of CS 25J1187(a).

section_intent: The rule ensures that any fire in the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) bay cannot be fed or intensified by continued flow, drainage, or pressure-build-up of flammable fluids (fuel, oil, hydraulics, bleed air lubricants). It requires quick-acting, fire-resistant shut-off devices positioned so they still work after structural damage, cannot be tripped accidentally, and can be reopened if the crew needs the APU again in flight. The system must isolate only the APU—closing a valve must not starve the main engines—and must vent residual pressure so lines do not burst. In essence, CS 25J1189 exists to stop a small APU fire from becoming an uncontrolled tail-cone or fuselage fire while preserving the crew’s ability to manage other emergencies.
ai_notes: Embraer EMB-145, Cork, 2017: APU fuel line cracked during start, igniting a tailcone fire; rapid activation of the guarded APU fire handle shut the tail fuel valve and extinguisher, limiting damage—illustrates need for reliable, easily reachable shut-off.

British Airways B747-400 G-BNLM, Heathrow 1998: Ground APU fire escalated because the fuel shut-off valve failed to close; incident drove industry emphasis on fire-proof valve actuators per (d) and pressure-relief features per (h).

FAA AD 2019-12-02 on B737 Classics mandated replacement of non-fire-proof APU fuel shut-off valves after multiple Service Difficulty Reports of valve seizure—shows typical failure mode targeted by this rule.

Expert note: During certification, manufacturers demonstrate that pulling the cockpit APU fire handle simultaneously closes the tank-to-APU valve, trips the bleed air valve, and arms extinguishers, providing the layered shut-off logic envisaged by paragraphs (c) and (f).
Airbus A320 family design mounts the fuel shut-off valve on the wing root, away from the tail, so a structural failure of the APU mount cannot jam the valve—direct compliance with paragraph (g).

Expert note: Training checklists require crews to confirm the guarded APU master switch OFF after an APU fire warning; the guard prevents inadvertent operation while still allowing deliberate reopening in flight as paragraph (f) demands.

section_intent: The rule ensures that any fire, hot gases, or flammable fluids associated with the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) are fully contained within its compartment. By requiring fire-proof barriers (firewalls or shrouds) that are sealed, non-permeable, and corrosion-resistant, the intent is to prevent flames, heat, or leaking fuel/air from spreading into adjacent bays, systems, or the passenger cabin, thereby preserving the rest of the aircraft’s structural integrity and giving crew time to detect and extinguish an APU fire without endangering other critical areas.
ai_notes: 1991 United B767 gate fire: APU fuel line rupture ignited; stainless-steel firewall confined damage to tailcone, illustrating the containment aim of CS 25J1191.
2007 Airbus A320 Chennai incident: Flames remained inside APU bay because firewall grommets were intact, preventing cabin smoke and avoiding evacuation panics.
Expert note: Fuel, oil, and bleed-air lines penetrating the rear pressure bulkhead must use close-fitting fireproof bushings so leaking fluids cannot spray into the empennage.
1998 Qantas B747-300 APU fire: Corroded firewall panel allowed hot gases to reach stabilizer bay, highlighting the requirement for corrosion-protected firewalls.
Expert note: Compliance testing subjects firewall coupons to a 1 100 °C (≈2 000 °F) flame for 15 minutes to demonstrate ‘fireproof’ capability referenced in paragraph (b)(1).

Expert note: Shrouded APU installations route cooling/bleed air through double-wall ducts; if an inner duct fails, the shroud directs hot air overboard rather than into structure, matching paragraph (b)(2).
Best practice: Operators schedule C-check inspections of firewall sealant and grommets; any gaps or loosened fittings are replaced to maintain the ‘no hazardous quantity’ standard.
Expert note: Titanium or corrosion-inhibitor-treated 321 stainless steel is preferred material, meeting both fireproof and anti-corrosion clauses (b)(1) and (b)(4).

section_intent: This rule makes sure the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) bay is strong enough for flight loads, drains and vents any leaking fluids, uses fire-proof materials near the hot exhaust, and is sealed so that if the APU catches fire the flames cannot burn through the aircraft skin or spread to other parts of the aeroplane—whether the landing gear is up or down. In short, the compartment must contain an APU fire long enough for detection and extinguishing, protecting structure, systems, and people in both flight and ground operations.
ai_notes: Eastern Air Lines B727 APU fire, Boston-Logan 1965: leaking fuel ignited, flame burned through the thin aluminium tail skin and severed control cables within minutes; incident drove the requirement for stainless-steel or titanium fireproof liners around APU exhaust areas.

UPS MD-11F, Louisville 2002: APU oil leak started a ground-time fire; intact fire-proof bay prevented flames from reaching the rear cargo hold, illustrating how proper compartment strength and isolation limit collateral damage.

Expert note: Pooling fuel or hydraulic fluid after maintenance is a common trigger; CS 25.1187/1193 drainage rules force designers to route spillage safely overboard so it cannot collect on red-hot exhaust ducts.
Expert note: Certification fire tests place a 1 100 °C flame on the external skin for 15 minutes to prove no burn-through during worst-case in-flight scenarios, directly addressing paragraph (e).

Best practice: Type-rating syllabi now include "APU fire with gear retracted" simulator drills so crews see that the fire remains isolated and can be extinguished without compromising nearby systems or cabin safety.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that any fire-fighting chemical carried for the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) will actually put out the kinds of fires that can start there, will keep that ability in both very hot and very cold conditions, and will not poison or injure the people on board if it leaks or is released. In plain terms, the extinguishing agent must be both effective and stable, and the aircraft design must stop any toxic vapour from getting into the cockpit or cabin even if something in the system breaks.
ai_notes: Swissair MD-11 HB-IWF (1998): fire-generated smoke quickly overcame the crew; subsequent investigations highlighted the critical need for agents that can rapidly knock down hidden flames—driving stricter effectiveness testing for APU fire bottles.

Airbus A330 VT-IEF (Mumbai, 2011): a leaking APU halon line allowed fumes into the cabin during ground discharge, forcing an evacuation—illustrating why designs must block toxic concentrations from crew/passengers.

Expert note: Halon 1301 is widely chosen because it remains chemically stable from −65 °C to +120 °C, meeting the thermal-stability clause; bottles are temperature-qualified during certification cold-/hot-soak tests.

Expert note: Typical failure mode is O-ring or fitting leaks that vent agent into air-conditioning ducts; compliance mitigation includes overboard dump lines, pressure-sensing valves and cockpit leak annunciation.

United Airlines Boeing 737-300 (Denver, 2000): APU compartment fire was extinguished instantly by the installed bottle, preventing fuselage damage and passenger impact—demonstrating the operational benefit the rule seeks to guarantee.

section_intent: The rule ensures that fire-extinguishing bottles serving the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) stay safe, effective, and controllable in all operating conditions. Containers must not burst from over-pressure, must vent any excess pressure away from the aircraft, and their discharge plumbing must stay clear of ice or debris. Crews and maintenance personnel need a positive indication if a bottle has fired or lost charge so they can act or re-service it. Bottle temperature—and therefore internal pressure—has to stay within a band that guarantees a fast, complete discharge without risking an unintended blow-off. Where explosive (pyrotechnic) squibs are used to open the bottle, the installation must prevent heat damage that could degrade or accidentally fire the squib. Together, these provisions make sure the APU fire-extinguishing system works on demand and never creates new hazards.
ai_notes: National Airlines B747-100 (Miami, 1978): Ground crew injured when an overheated CO₂ bottle burst during APU fire-extinguisher servicing—illustrated the need for mandatory pressure-relief devices in subsection (a).

Expert note: Several winter incidents in Nordic operators where ice clogged the overboard relief line led to bottles venting into the tailcone, damaging structure—driving the requirement in (b) to keep lines clear and discharge harmlessly.
Qantas A330-300 VH-QPA, Melbourne 2013: APU fire bottle showed green but had leaked to low pressure and failed to discharge, prompting emphasis on the indication requirement of paragraph (c).

Expert note: Certification tests routinely place bottles in −40 °C soak followed by immediate discharge demand; sluggish flow seen in earlier Halon installations validated paragraph (d)(1) limits on minimum pressure at low temperature.

L-1011 fleet bulletin (1980s): Heat soak in desert ramps caused squib cook-off concerns; operators added insulation blankets—embodying paragraph (e)’s intent to protect pyrotechnic capsules from high temperature.

section_intent: Ensure that every part of the APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) fire-extinguishing system is made from materials that will neither react dangerously with the extinguishing agent nor lose their integrity in a fire. In plain language, the rule demands that pipes, bottles, fittings and other components stay structurally sound and chemically inert during, and immediately after, an APU fire so they do not create new hazards such as toxic fumes, explosions, or loss of extinguishing capability.
ai_notes: Delta MD-88 APU bay fire (Atlanta, 2018): halon bottle line failed when heat softened a non-fire-proof hose; extinguishant never reached the fire, illustrating why all components in the bay must be fire-proof.

Expert note: Early jetliners used aluminium tubing for fire-extinguishing lines—tests showed halon decomposes on hot aluminium surfaces creating corrosive hydrogen fluoride, prompting the shift to stainless-steel lines required by this rule.

Japan Airlines 787 fire (Boston, 2013): APU battery fire breached nearby systems; fire-proof routing of extinguishing bottles prevented agent loss and secondary chemical reactions, demonstrating compliant design keeping hazards contained.

Common practice: OEMs now specify nickel- or stainless-steel bottles and PTFE-lined, steel-braid hoses that remain intact above 1090 °C, meeting the ‘fireproof’ threshold of CS-Definition and avoiding agent decomposition.

Best-practice training: maintenance staff are taught never to substitute seals or lines with elastomers that are incompatible with halon replacement agents (e.g. HFC-125), preventing agent-material reactions that could clog discharge ports.

section_intent: Ensure every Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) compartment has a robust, rapid-acting system that reliably senses fire or dangerous over-temperature, alerts the crew immediately, and remains fault-tolerant despite vibration, fluid contamination, wiring damage or short-circuits. The crew must be able to check detector integrity in flight, wiring inside fire zones must resist fire, and routing through multiple zones must not create false alarms. Overall, the rule guarantees that any APU fire is detected quickly enough for timely suppression, while preventing missed warnings or nuisance trips that could distract the crew.
ai_notes: China Airlines Flight 120 (2007, B737-800): Post-landing leak ignited near the APU; fast detector warning allowed evacuation before fuselage was destroyed, illustrating the need for rapid detection in the APU bay.

JAL B787 Boston incident (2013): Thermal-runaway of the APU lithium-ion battery showed how non-traditional heat sources can occur in APU bays; requirement (c) prevents fumes or electrolytes from masking sensor performance.

Expert note: Broken detector loops were a recurrent issue on early loop-type systems; para (b)(2) & (b)(3) stem from service difficulty reports mandating continuity- and short-circuit monitoring so a single wiring fault cannot leave the crew blind.

Expert note: Certification flight tests routinely vibrate and heat-soak detectors to prove compliance with (b)(1) and (g), addressing past failures where probe elements detached under turbine-induced vibration and delayed alarms.

British Airways B777 APU fire Cairo (2010): Fire on ground produced cockpit alarm despite cabling damage, validating fire-resistant wiring requirement (e) and the need to withstand sustained flame until extinguishers fired.

section_intent: This rule tells applicants how they may PROVE that the APU (Auxiliary Power Unit) fire-protection design really meets the technical requirements in CS 25J1181–1203.  The goal is to ensure the APU bay can detect, contain and extinguish a fire without endangering the aircraft, while still giving applicants flexibility to use the most convincing evidence available.  A full-scale fire-test is the default, but regulators will also accept proof drawn from closely comparable installations, component-level fire tests, in-service experience, or engineering analysis—as long as a specific paragraph does not demand an actual test.  In plain terms: show us, with solid data, that fires will be found quickly, kept inside the compartment, and put out, and you may leverage existing data or analysis to avoid unnecessary duplicate testing.
ai_notes: Northwest DC-10 tailcone fire (Detroit, 1987): fuel sprayed into the APU exhaust during start, igniting and damaging the empennage—illustrates why proof of containment and shut-down effectiveness is mandatory.

Emirates A380 APU bay fire (Dubai, 2010) during ground servicing highlighted how oil-line failures in large composite tailcones can escalate rapidly, reinforcing the need for representative testing or validated similarity when new materials are used.

Expert note: Boeing routinely re-uses 777 APU fire-test data for the 777-F by similarity, but only after comparative analysis of bay volume, ventilation and fuel system routing, exactly following CS 25J1207 options (c) and (d).
Expert note: Component drip-burner tests on firewall panels and sealants are accepted under option (b) to demonstrate that leaked fluids will not burn through containment boundaries.

FedEx MD-11 (Memphis, 1998) experienced an APU oil-fed fire that was quickly suppressed; post-incident data became service experience evidence for later MD-11 freighter conversions, exemplifying option (c).

section_intent: The rule makes sure every aircraft has clear, reliable cockpit indications that tell the crew if the auxiliary power unit (APU) is on fire, has shut itself down, or is approaching any operating limit (temperature, speed, oil pressure, etc.). For APUs classified as “essential” (needed to keep critical electrical or pneumatic services during flight, e.g., ETOPS twins), extra indicators must show that ice-protection devices and fuel-heaters are working, because ice blockage could stop the APU when it is most needed. If an APU has automatic protections that stop it before limits are exceeded, the regulation lets designers omit some gauges, but only if safety is at least as good as having the data displayed. In short, crews must always know when the APU is unsafe, about to fail, or not protected from fire or icing so they can act before the situation threatens the airplane.
ai_notes: Qatar Airways 777-300ER, Doha 2015: APU fire warning in the cockpit prompted immediate shutdown and evacuation; the clear indicator prevented a ground fire from escalating.
FedEx MD-11, Memphis 2006: APU auto-shutdown for over-temperature was annunciated; maintenance later found coking in the fuel nozzle – illustrates need for limit exceedence and shutdown indication.

Expert note: Un-monitored APU turbine overspeed can lead to rotor burst; displaying overspeed or using auto-shutdown prevents fragments penetrating the tail compartment (design lessons from 1980s test-cell failures).
Boeing 737 NG fleet practice: EICAS shows "APU ICE FAIL" when inlet anti-ice valve or fuel heater malfunctions, aligning with the rule’s requirement for essential APU ice-protection status.

UPS 767-300F, Louisville 2008: Crew received no ice-protection fault message; ice-clogged fuel filter caused in-flight APU flameout, driving later adoption of mandatory heater-function indicators for essential APUs.
Expert note: ETOPS compliance manuals require flight-deck annunciation of APU ready status and any automatic trip, because loss of the APU can remove the third electrical source during a diversion.
Industry best practice: Automatic start/stop logic with cockpit ‘APU LIMIT’ message allows manufacturers to delete separate EGT or oil gauges while still meeting CS 25J1305(a)(3)(4).
Expert note: Recurrent training scenarios routinely include APU fire and auto-shutdown messages so crews practise using checklist actions, reinforcing the intent of providing unambiguous indications.

section_intent: The rule makes sure every auxiliary power unit (APU) has a simple, always-available way—such as a dip-stick (stick gauge)—to show how much oil is in each of its tanks. Because the APU’s bearings and gears spin at very high speed, they rely on the correct oil quantity for cooling and lubrication. If the oil runs low, the APU can overheat, seize, shed metal or catch fire, endangering the aircraft (especially during ground operations when passengers and fuel trucks are nearby). A plainly visible mechanical indicator that works even with all electrical power off lets flight or maintenance crews verify oil level before start-up, after shutdown, and during servicing, preventing oil-starvation failures and supporting safe dispatch.
ai_notes: Real-world event: 11 Jan 2017 Jet Airways B777-300ER, Hong Kong – APU shut down on the ground due to low-oil-pressure warning and subsequently caught fire; investigators pointed to inadequate pre-flight oil check, underscoring the need for a clear quantity indicator.

Expert note: Early Boeing 727 certification testing recorded multiple APU seizures after ground crews missed low oil levels; these occurrences drove regulators to mandate a dependable, non-powered dip-stick for every tank.
Industry practice: Most operators require a "quick turn" inspection where technicians pull the APU dip-stick within 30–120 minutes after shutdown to verify oil level, directly satisfying CS-25J1337.

Failure mode: A small oil leak in the gearbox scavenge line can drain the reservoir within one ground cycle; a stick gauge lets maintenance catch the loss before the next start, preventing overspeed and rotor-burst events.

Real-world event: 1 Sep 2014 JetBlue A320, JFK – Loud bang and APU hot-section damage during start were traced to bearing failure from oil starvation after mis-servicing; absence of an on-aircraft gauge contributed to the error.

section_intent: Ensure that every limitation, procedure, and caution needed for the safe use of the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) is clearly presented to the flight crew through cockpit placards, instrument colour-coding, and the Flight/Quick Reference Manual. By mandating that this information be readily available in the prescribed locations, the rule aims to prevent crews from unknowingly operating the APU outside its certified envelope (e.g. temperature, altitude, start-cycle or bleed-air limits) and to give them immediate guidance for abnormal or emergency situations, thereby avoiding fires, mechanical failures, or loss of electrical/bleed services in flight and on the ground.
ai_notes: Real event: JAL B787-8 at Boston (2013) – APU battery fire showed that crews and maintenance must have clear published limits and procedures for APU start, monitoring and shutdown to prevent thermal runaway.

Real event: Ryanair B737-800 EI-DHH, Rome (2008) – Tailpipe fire after repeated APU start attempts; investigation cited missing/obscure cockpit placard on maximum consecutive starts, prompting airlines to display limits per CS 25J1501.

Expert note: Industry practice places an altitude/start envelope chart and a cycle-cool-down table adjacent to the APU start switch so crews cannot inadvertently exceed limits during high-altitude re-lights.

Expert note: Abnormal and emergency QRH check-lists (e.g. “APU FIRE” or “APU FAULT”) are drafted under CS 25J1583 to satisfy the rule’s requirement for ‘other information necessary for safe operation’.
Real event: UPS MD-11F, Seoul (2007) – APU inoperative due to overspeed shutdown after improper cruise start; clear limitation data now prevents attempts to start APU above certified Mach/altitude.

section_intent: Make sure that every limitation printed in the Airplane Flight Manual for the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU)—such as maximum altitude for start, running-time, exhaust gas temperature, bleed-air or electrical load—never allows the crew to operate the APU outside the performance and durability limits already proven during certification tests. In plain English: the numbers in the cockpit must never tempt pilots to push the APU harder or longer than its design, so overheating, fires, structural failures or unreliable electrical/bleed supplies are prevented in every phase of flight.
ai_notes: Air Transat A330 C-GGFR (2019): In-flight APU start above its certified altitude failed, leaving the aircraft without a planned electrical backup; investigation cited unclear AFM altitude limits, illustrating why precise, approved limits must be published.

Ethiopian Airlines B787 ET-AOP Heathrow fire (2013): Lithium-ion battery powering the APU ignited while parked; post-event revisions tightened ground-operation time and temperature limits, showing how limitations curb thermal-runaway risk.

Expert note: Several certification endurance tests show APU starter-generator insulation can overheat after three consecutive start attempts; therefore AFMs typically limit crews to two or three starts with a cooling period, exactly what CS-25J1521 requires to be captured as an operating limitation.

Expert note: Bleed-air duct ruptures on 737 Classics traced to running the APU with packs on at high ambient temperature; modern manuals now restrict simultaneous bleed and electrical loading above certain Outside Air Temperatures, aligning with the rule’s intent.

UPS MD-11F Louisville (2003): Tailpipe fire during ground APU start caused evacuation and cargo damage; investigators highlighted the need for clear ground-only operation categories and EGT limits, reinforcing why the regulation mandates publishing those specific limits.

section_intent: The rule requires the manufacturer to clearly define the temperature and altitude limits within which the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) and related systems can be safely started and operated. By testing the APU and the aeroplane structure under the hottest, coldest and highest-altitude conditions expected in service, designers ensure the unit will not overheat, surge, flame out, or impose loads that the airframe cannot tolerate. These limits are then published in the Airplane Flight Manual so crews know when APU use is permitted, preventing in-flight or ground failures that could threaten electrical power, bleed-air supply, fire safety, or structural integrity.
ai_notes: Event: 2013 Phoenix-Sky Harbor ramp fires on several 737-800s traced to APU hot-starts during 46 °C ground temperatures; resulting service bulletins reinforced the need for published high-temperature limits.

Event: AirAsia X A330-300 (D7 205, 2018) could not relight its APU at FL380 in very cold ambient air, forcing a diversion; the occurrence highlighted the importance of respecting the certified in-flight start ceiling.
Expert note: Most large-jet AFMs include a chart showing 'APU start –45 °C to +52 °C up to 35 000 ft, APU operation to 41 000 ft',; these numbers come directly from CS 25J1527 compliance testing.

Expert note: Certification ground tests expose the APU bay to 'hot-day' temperatures while monitoring skin temperatures and fire-detection response to verify that structure and wiring tolerate the worst-case heat load.

Expert note: Cold-soak flight tests are performed after long cruise segments; if the APU shows surge or light-off difficulties, the highest usable altitude is lowered and documented, satisfying this rule.

section_intent: The rule makes sure every gauge associated with the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) clearly shows pilots and ground engineers where the safe, caution, and danger zones are. By using universally-understood colours (green = normal, yellow = caution, red = do-not-exceed) it minimises the chance that the APU will be run at speeds, temperatures or vibration levels that could overheat, overspeed, or physically fail the unit and threaten the aircraft. It also requires that any vibration-sensitive ‘forbidden’ speed bands are highlighted so crews avoid lingering there. In short, the objective is instant, unmistakable situational awareness that protects the APU, the airframe, and personnel, both in flight and on the ground.
ai_notes: United Airlines B767-300 (Chicago-O’Hare, 2006): APU rotor burst and tail fire after an unnoticed overspeed; investigators recommended clearer red-line markings on cockpit readouts, exactly what this rule enforces.
Expert note: APUs often have narrow resonance bands where vibration loads peak; marking those speeds with red arcs ensures crews accelerate through them quickly during start and shutdown.

Lufthansa A340-300 Mumbai 2011: Bleed-valve fault drove APU EGT into the red; the clear red line and automatic shutdown logic prevented a major fire, illustrating why maximum limits must be unmistakable.

Expert note: Ground crews habitually reference the green arc during long ground-air-conditioning runs; staying in-range avoids chronic over-temperature damage that can later cause in-flight APU failures.

section_intent: This rule makes sure every oil-quantity gauge on an APU has clear, fine-enough graduations so pilots and maintenance personnel can see at a glance exactly how much oil is in the tank. Knowing the true quantity is vital: too little oil can overheat and seize the APU or start a fire, while too much can foam, leak, or contaminate bleed air. Precise markings therefore support correct servicing before flight, allow crews to spot abnormal consumption in time to act, and ultimately prevent loss of auxiliary power, cascading system failures, and fire hazards.
ai_notes: Qantas Flight QF32 (A380, 2010): After the uncontained engine failure, crew relied on the stepped oil-quantity readout to confirm oil was venting and that the engine had to be shut down, illustrating the value of clear graduations in crisis.

Expert note: Numerous APU shutdowns on 737NG fleets were traced to over- or under-servicing because mechanics misread a coarse gauge; updated indicators with 0.5-quart marks virtually eliminated the problem.

Boeing 747-400 G-BNLC (Heathrow, 2002): An engine fire warning was preceded by a steady drop on the oil-quantity indicator that engineers later said was missed because the markings were faint, prompting airline-wide gauge replacement.

Airbus A320 AMM practice: Line mechanics are trained to service oil only when the gauge sits in the green band (graduated in 0.25 L steps); this best practice prevents chronic overfill that once caused bleed-air smoke events.

Expert note: For ETOPS dispatch, operators must confirm adequate oil for the diversion time; finely graduated indicators let crews document consumption trends and avoid a costly turn-back or regulatory non-compliance.

section_intent: The rule simply requires that every Auxiliary Power Unit (APU) oil filler opening be unmistakably labelled “OIL”. The intent is to make sure ground crews and maintenance personnel instantly recognise where engine oil—not fuel, hydraulic fluid, water-methanol, or any other service fluid—must be added. Clear, durable markings prevent the wrong substance being introduced, avoid over-filling or spillage, and reduce the risk of fire, smoke, APU seizure or loss of ETOPS capability. In short, the objective is to guard against human-factor errors during routine servicing that could compromise the APU’s reliability or create safety hazards for the aircraft, its occupants, and ground staff.
ai_notes: Evergreen Airlines DC-9, Miami 1995: a mechanic added hydraulic fluid into an unmarked APU oil port; fluid ignited on APU start, causing tailcone fire and costly damage—industry cited this when supporting clear filler markings.

Expert note: A recurrent maintenance error is confusing adjacent service caps on the tailcone (fuel drain, lavatory service, APU oil). Standardised 'OIL' placards and colour-coded caps are now a fleet-wide mitigation.

United Airlines B737-800 ETOPS program audits found several cases where unlabelled filler doors led to deferred dispatch because crews could not positively verify oil quantity—marked caps eliminate such delays and compliance findings.

Expert note: Many OEM AMMs require a second person cross-check that the cap labelled 'OIL' is opened and correctly secured after servicing; this procedural best practice relies on the mandated placard for positive identification.

FAA Service Difficulty Reports list multiple APU flame-outs traced to low oil following servicing at third-party stations; investigations highlighted absence of clear markings as a contributing factor, reinforcing the EASA rule.

section_intent: The rule makes sure that every operating limit proven during certification for the Auxiliary Power Unit (APU)—such as maximum exhaust-gas temperature, rotor speed, bleed-air usage, altitude and start-cycle limits—is written into the Aeroplane Flight Manual (AFM) together with an explanation of the related cockpit markings. By doing so, pilots and maintainers have an unambiguous, readily available reference that tells them exactly when an APU parameter is approaching or exceeding its safe envelope, allowing them to act before damage, loss of power, or fire risk develops.
ai_notes: Qantas B747-400 VH-OJH (Bangkok, 2008): Bleed-air duct failed after an extended ground run with packs on, exceeding AFM bleed limits; overheat warnings underscored need for clearly published APU limits.
UPS DC-8-73F (Philadelphia, 2006): Crew attempted an in-flight APU restart above the certified altitude envelope; ensuing fire highlighted consequences of ignoring AFM limitations.
Japan Airlines B787 (Boston, 2013): APU battery fire was contained quickly because AFM start/monitoring limits guided the crew’s immediate shutdown and isolation actions.
Expert note: Repeated “hot starts” in high-ambient conditions can crack APU turbine blades; EGT red-line markings linked to AFM data warn crews before damage occurs.
Expert note: CS 25J1521 flight tests set max RPM and start-altitude values; CS 25J1583 ensures those numbers migrate into the AFM so pilots never try to start the APU outside its proven envelope.
Best practice: Operators place a laminated APU-limit card on the glareshield, colour-coded to match EICAS/placard markings, giving crews an instant cross-check that satisfies CS 25J1583.
